abstract: Wal-Mart Stores says net income in its fourth quarter rose 4.5 percent, to $2 billion, compared with $1.92 billion year ago; sales in period ended Jan 31 rose 10 percent, to $56.6 billion, from $51.4 billion; Home Depot says net income dropped 20 percent, to $465 million, compared with $578 million in year-earlier period; sales in period ended Jan 28 rose 14 percent, to $10.46 billion (M)

headline: Brazil Postpones Its Beef Dreams

headline: Cowles Publishing Names 2 New Officers
abstract: Cowles Publishing Company names Elizabeth A Cowles as chairwoman and W Stacey Cowles as president; they succeed their uncle, James P Cowles (S)

headline: TWA's Farewell Will Radically Alter U.S. Airline Market
abstract: WASHINGTON—  The plan of American Airlines' parent group to acquire the critically ailing Trans World Airlines Inc. and certain US Airways assets, confirmed Wednesday, would give American control of one-fourth of the U.S. air travel market and expand its reach abroad.

headline: U.S. Preparing to End Ban and Approve Sale of F-16's to Chile
abstract: Outgoing Clinton administration prepares to approve sale of F-16 fighter jets to Chile, ending ban of more than two decades on sale of sophisticated American weapons in Latin America (S)

headline: Turkey's Turmoil Exacts a Price in the Billions
abstract: ISTANBUL, Feb. 24 — As political tantrums go, the one thrown by the Turkish prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, will go down as one of history's most expensive.

headline: Israel's Ties With Germany Elude U.S. Jews
abstract: Postwar Germany's close ties with Israel, expressed in military, intelligence, political and economic support and personal contacts, are not reflected in opinions of Jewish Americans, whose view of Germany centers on Nazi past alone; Avi Primor, former Israeli envoy to Germany, says his regular talks about good relations are met with shock and indignation among Americans; David A Harris of American Jewish Committee observes that Americans have had 'luxury', which Israel could not afford, of avoiding Germany; result is odd disparity as Germany intensifies ties with Israel even as problems mount with Americans over restitution and with some Germans who resent what they see as 'Holocaust industry'; hostility to Germans does exist also in Israel, where Holocaust commemoration remains important; long, painful efforts by which Israelis and Germans have come together, from payment of reparations to decades of work by young German volunteers, discussed; photo; individuals on both sides comment (M)

headline: Kim Dae Jung Wants Bush Team's Support : Seoul to Make Its Case For 'Sunshine' Policy
abstract: SEOUL—  President Kim Dae Jung said Friday that he expected to go to Washington soon after President-elect George W. Bush is inaugurated for a summit meeting in which he will try to win the new administration's support for his "sunshine" policy of reconciliation with North Korea.

headline: Looking at Aibo, the Robot Dog
abstract: SCIENCE fiction writers of the 1950's might have been astounded to find that the world's first mass- produced, widely adopted robot, Sony's second-generation Aibo ERS-210, did not do housework, fetch slippers or aspire to dominate mankind.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Large Companies Prevail In U.S. Auction of Airwaves  Taking advantage of rules intended to help the smallest telecommunications companies and bolster competition, the nation's largest wireless phone services and their partners are on the verge of winning scores of new licenses in a $17 billion auction of airwaves.    The small companies that were supposed to have received special treatment to promote competition are complaining that they lost at the expense of giants like AT&T Wireless, Sprint PCS, VoiceStream and Cingular. Verizon Wireless, which refused to form a partnership with a small company, appears likely to pay the highest price. [Page A1.]

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNET ORIGINAL `INCUBATOR' PULLING PLUG Idealab , once a prominent builder of Internet businesses, is closing its Silicon Valley "incubator," company officials said yesterday. The company, based in Pasadena, Calif., will continue to support the three companies that operate out of its Palo Alto, Calif., offices. Idealab executives said the 33 employees of the incubator would be offered jobs at one of the three Palo Alto companies but no new companies would be started. The move is a sign of how times have changed in the Internet industry. Idealab, which offered promising start-up companies money, advice and services in return for an ownership stake, helped get concerns like CarsDirect.com, HomesDirect and eToys off the ground. Jayson Blair (NYT)

headline: Mad Cow Disease (and Anxiety)
abstract: People in France and elsewhere in Europe who gave up beef at height of mad cow anxiety are beginning to eat it again, but slowly and selectively, definitely not in quantities that will lift the depressed fortunes of cattle farmers, slaughterhouses and butchers; meat sales to restaurants, though not fast food chains, are holding up, but demand from supermarket chains, butchers and public institutions remains way down; exports outside European Union have dropped; farmers are increasing their pressure on politicians to do something; photo (M)

headline: Viewing the First Bubble And How It Blew Up
abstract: Norton Simon Museum, Pasadena, Calif, exhibits 65 watercolors depicting tulips available in 1630's, when their prices soared and crashed, providing classic example of investment bubble (S)

headline: MY FIRST JOB; Hauling Trash, Confidentially
abstract: Mark A Ernst, president and chief executive of H & R Block, writes My First Job column on his first job, trash collector; photos (M)

headline: Quebec French Speakers Want More Bilingualism : An English Comeback
abstract: MONTREAL—  The convoy of minivans began filing into the schoolyard of Ecole Somerled hours before dawn.

headline: An Account Review For Mail Boxes Etc.
abstract: Mail Boxes Etc, part of US Office Products, begins review for its creative and media account, with billings estimated at $20 million; creative duties have been handled by Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and media buying has been haandled by Ogilvy sibling, MindShare (S)

headline: MEDIA: New Risks and Venues Emerge in a Multifaceted Business; Girls and Lipstick And More Magazines
abstract: More magazines aimed at teenage girls are being rolled out because market seems inexhaustible and irresistible to advertisers (S)

headline: Current and Former Xerox Employees File Bias Charges
abstract: Eighteen former and current sales representatives for Xerox Corp file charges with Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, contending that they were discriminated against on the basis of race; also plan to bring private lawsuits agaisnt company, possibly seeking class-action status; photo (M)

headline: Teen Hacker Pleads Guilty to Attacking Company Web Sites
abstract: MONTREAL, Jan. 19 — A 16-year-old computer hacker who goes by the name Mafiaboy pleaded guilty here today to 56 charges related to attacks last year on some of the busiest commercial Web sites in the United States.

headline: Article 2001031691561860021 -- No Title
abstract: March 16, 2001

headline: Mexico Agrees To Extradite Drug Suspect To California
abstract: Mexico's Supreme Court rules that Mexican citizen charged as cocaine kingpin in United States court could be extradited to California, precedent-setting decision long sought by American authorities; case of trafficker, Arturo Paez Martinez, is seen on both sides of border as test of Mexico's willingness to extradite people accused of drug trafficking to face American justice; court, in companion ruling, says reputed lieutenant in another drug cartel, Oscar Malherbe de Leon, could also be extradited to United States (M)

headline: Tribute to a Hairdo: Immortalizing the Mullet
abstract: Web site Mullet Madness is dedicated to the mullet hairdo; its archive section renders portraits of celebrities with this haircut; photos (M)

headline: ENERGY EAST BUYING ROCHESTER UTILITY
abstract: Energy East Corp acquires RGS Energy Group Inc for $1.4 billion in cash and stock to add power and natural-gas customers in New York State (S)

headline: Now That We're Still Here, Where Do We Go? 7 Answers
abstract: Seven people who are on panel and have been taking chances through ups and downs of Internet exchange e-mail messages on future of Web for business community; they are Patrick Byrne of Overstock.com, Bill Gross of Idealab, Vincent Caminiti of Delta Air Lines, Mark T Hogan of General Motors, Ted Leonsis of America Online; Roger McNamee of Integral Capital Partners, and Stephen Riggio of Barnes & Noble; partial text of their discussion; photos (L)

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC BUYS CATHETER INNOVATIONS
abstract: Boston Scientific Corp acquires Catheter Innovations (S)

headline: Business Is Business: $3 Billion Israeli-Egyptian Gas Deal
abstract: Egypt agrees to start supplying Israel with natural gas next year, in deal totaling $3 billion that will continue until at least 2012; Yaakov Razon, director general of state-owned Israel Electric Corp, says decision between often bitterly estranged neighbors is based in 'purely commercial considerations'; long-term sales contract will forge first strong economic bond between two countries; diplomats hope it will undergird regional peace efforts with new financial and security links (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: State Workers Ruled Unable To Sue Under Disability Act  The Supreme Court ruled that state employees cannot sue for damages for violations of the Americans With Disabilities Act, carving out a new area of immunity for the states from the reach of federal civil rights law.    Beyond its immediate effect on state workers who are entitled under the law to reasonable accommodations for their disabilities, the decision was important for what it portends, both for other types of cases under the act and for other civil rights statutes. [Page A1.]

headline: Fort McMurray Journal; For a Big Job, Big Trucks and Women to Use Them
abstract: Syncrude Canada Ltd of Fort McMurray, Alberta, largest producer of oil from oil sands, employs women to drive so-called 'Frankentrucks,' $3 million dump trucks that can carry 380 tons, or six times loads of mining trucks of 1970's; Jim E Carter, company president, says that with mining becoming increasingly high tech, brains are taking precedence over brawn; northern Alberta's oil sands typically contain 12 percent oil; sands are mined and oil is separated with hot water; new oil boom is convulsing city, and women now make up quarter of Syncrude's heavy equipment operators; photo; map (M)

headline: BASF'S PROFIT IS MIXED
abstract: BASF says its operating income was up 15 percent, to 3.4 billion euros ($3.1 billion), in 2000; sales climbed 22 percent, to 1.24 billion euros (S)

headline: Former Bosnian Serb Leader to Cooperate With Tribunal
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 9 — The former president of the Bosnian Serb republic was reported today to have flown to the Hague to cooperate with the United Nations war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, but her exact whereabouts were shrouded in mystery.

headline: TRANS WORLD ENTERTAINMENT TO RENAME 730 MALL STORES
abstract: Trans World Entertainment Corp will rename its 730 mall-based stores, which operate under several names; company says its Record Town, Camelot, The Wall, Disc Jockey and other stores will be given name 'fye,' shorthand for 'for your entertainment'; free-standing Coconuts, Strawberries and Specs stores will not be affected (S)

headline: A Cartoon Giant's Rich Reward
abstract: Article profiles Haim Saban, children's television mogul, who is negotiating to sell his half of Fox Family Worldwide to Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, which owns other half; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Investors May Get Access to Wider Market
abstract: China is planning to allow local investors to trade openly in Class B shares of Chinese companies, category of stock that has been reserved for foreigners; new rules is expected to bring surge of liquidity to Chinese market in Class B shares created 9 years ago; change is part of broader restructuring of China's financial markets that is intended to give healthy companies greater access to captial, so that they compete with well-financed multinationals once China is member of World Trade Organization; graph (M)

headline: WAL-MART CONSIDERING ONLINE EXPANSION
abstract: Wal-Mart retail chain weighs expansion of online services via Wal-Mart.com unit; photo (S)

headline: Putin Dismisses U.S. Reports That Russia Shipped Nuclear Weapons for Baltic Fleet
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir Putin dismisses American intelligence reports that Russian military moved tactical nuclear weapons into storage depot that serves Baltic Fleet (M)

headline: Web Site Peeks at Pompeii Under the Volcano
abstract: Web site on Pompeii is maintained by University of Virginia; photo (M)

headline: Same Yardstick, Different Races
abstract: Mark Hulbert column on shortcomings of making mutual fund investment decisions based on changes in fund's Morningstar ranking; notes Morninstar system's weakness in comparing newer and older funds; graph (M)

headline: Foot-and-Mouth Damages English Tourism, Too
abstract: Outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease is taking its toll on entire regions of England where hoteliers, shopkeepers and suppliers depend on visitors for their livelihoods; much of Britain has been placed off limits to walkers and outsiders for fear they may carry disease to infect new animals; many hotels are all but empty, roads are free of tourists' cars and delivery vans, and employees in tourism business are being laid off; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001011491256949181 -- No Title
abstract: Taking the Offensive Against Cell Phones

headline: Unexpectedly Strong Month for Auto Sales
abstract: DETROIT, March 1 — American consumers continued to flock to car dealerships in February despite the economic slowdown, producing another unexpectedly strong month for auto sales.

headline: Key Figures in the Lockerbie Trial
abstract: CAMP ZEIST, Netherlands, Jan. 31 -- Abdel Basset al-Megrahi, one of the two Libyans put on trial for the 1988 Lockerbie airliner bombing, was convicted on Wednesday of the murder of 270 people, but his co-accused was cleared.

headline: DoubleClick Privacy Lawsuit Dismissed
abstract: Judge Naomi Buchwald dismisses class-action lawsuit accusing DoubleClick Inc of violations of Electronic Privacy Act, Wiretap Act and Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (M)

headline: Strike the Band: Pop Music Without Musicians
abstract: IN the 1950's and 60's, the recording studio became an instrument. From its humble origins documenting live performances, the studio turned into a music-maker itself, retooling raw material — the work of musicians — into a finished product. Once mere "records" of musical events, recordings were now something much more exotic and autonomous, painstakingly layered confections. But even after multitrack recording had severed music making from real time, somebody still had to play that guitar.

headline: Budapest Journal; A Real Voice, at Last, for Hungary's Pariah People
abstract: Article on Radio C, Hungary's first gypsy radio station which began broadcasting from Budapest on February 11; station can reach most of city's 150,000 Gypsies, who make up between 6 percent and 10 percent of Hungary's population of approximately 10 million; photo (M)

headline: Long-Distance Competition Drags WorldCom Profit Down
abstract: WorldCom Inc reports net income in fourth quarter totaled $726 million compared with $1.3 billion year earlier; revenue grew 3 percent, to $9.6 billion from $9.3 billion year ago (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    CHINA: FALUN GONG FATALITIES -- December was a deadly month for Falun Gong followers in China, where four more adherents of the spiritual discipline have died in confrontations with the police, a Hong Kong rights group said. Falun Gong followers say more than 90 members have died at the hands of the police since China banned the group and began a campaign of suppression in July 1999.    Craig S. Smith (NYT)

headline: One Hurt as Car Bomb Goes Off In Orthodox District of Jerusalem
abstract: Car bomb explodes in strictly Orthodox Jewish neighborhood of Jerusalem, shaking buildings and sending chunks of metal hurtling through air, but injuring only one person; bombing comes two days after election in Israel of rightist leader Ariel Sharon; statement faxed to new agency, signed by previously unknown Palestinian Popular Resistance Forces, takes responsibility for blast, calling it message directed to 'criminal and fascist Sharon'; Mayor Ehud Olmert of Jerusalem, political ally of Sharon, calls for 'systematic response' to such acts of terror; photo (M)

headline: $150 Million Loan For Sirius Is Delayed
abstract: Sirius Satellite Radio Inc says flaws in its software that prevent clear audio signals have delayed its receipt of $150 million loan from Lehman Brothers Inc; is planning to sell radios that receive commercial-free programming for $9.95 a month (S)

headline: Price of Airline Consolidation
abstract: Price of Airline Consolidation** Airline industry experts say better frequent-flier programs, more convenient schedules and higher fares are most likely outcome for many consumers if American Airlines succeeds in its plan to purchase Trans World Airlines and part of US Airways; American would immediately become stronger presence along lucrative and crowded East Coast, allowing it to compete more effectively with Delta Airlines and United Airlines, which is seeking government approval for its pruchase of bulk of US Airways; eliminating weak TWA from market would shelve carrier that often sells discounted tickets from major cities not served by low-fare carriers; Donald J Carty, chief executive of American's parent, AMR, is likely to face close scrutiny from consumer groups over takeover proposal; map; charts; photos (M)

headline: PHARMACIA TO CREATE SEPARATE BIOTECHNOLOGY COMPANY
abstract: Pharmacia Cr

headline: Macedonia Uses Helicopters Against Rebels for First Time
abstract: Macedonia uses attack helicopters against ethnic Albanian rebels for first time, firing rockets at their positions above Tetovo (S)

headline: BRIDGESTONE RECALLS SMALL BATCH OF SPORT UTILITY TIRES
abstract: Bridgestone Corp voluntarily recalls about 8,000 P265/70R16 Wilderness LE tires made at its Cuernavaca, Mex, plant during week of April 23, because about 150 of them might have wrong kind of rubber in and around one of their steel belts, making it possible that tire would come apart at that point; tires were installed on GMC Yukon XL 1500 and Chevrolet Suburban 1500 vehicles built in Mexico (S)

headline: Don't Know What It Is, or What It's About, but Harvard Thinks It's Worth $250,000
abstract: Harvard Business School Press reportedly pays $250,000 for book proposal by Dean Kamen about his newest invention without knowing exactly what it is; invention, called It, will reportedly have profound effect on environment and way people live worldwide (S)

headline: Dot-Com, Esq.: Legal Guidance, Lawyer Optional
abstract: Legal information available on Web allows can reduce need for traditional law firms; clients save substantial sums by downloading generic contracts and paying lawyers to customize them, as opposed to lawyers drafting entire contracts; these developments may result in attorneys charging by the service instead of by the hour; growth of online resources could force lawyers to reduce fees; photos (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.  MONDAY  TCF Finl Corp    TUESDAY  Becton, Dickinson & Co  Ikon Office Solutions Inc  Republic Group Inc  Rollins Inc  RPC Inc  Standard Pac Corp (New)

headline: Credit Card Issuers Toughening Terms
abstract: Advocacy group Consumer Action study reveals that credit card issuers are imposing higher interest rates and stiffer penalties than last year (M)

headline: Rebels Abandon Positions as Macedonian Troops Advance
abstract: TETOVO, Macedonia, March 26 — Macedonian government forces continued to move carefully through the hills above Tetovo today, consolidating their control of villages held by Albanian rebels for nearly two weeks.

headline: But Senate Democrats Assail His Views on Gun Control and Abortion : Ashcroft Vows to Back All Laws
abstract: WASHINGTON—  Democratic senators on Wednesday continued a sometimes fierce questioning of John Ashcroft, the attorney general-designate, eliciting repeated assurances that he would vigorously enforce all U.S. laws, including some he strongly opposes, such as the constitutional right to abortion.

headline: Singapore Shows Strong Growth
abstract: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry issues preliminary figures estimating that Singapore's economy expanded 10.1 percent in 2000, with growth in last three months of year beating government's own expectations; forecasts that growth will slow in 2001 to 5 percent to 7 percent; says export growth in November was 8.1 percent, half of what it was year earlier; holds goods-producing industries grew 12.4 percent in fourth quarter from year ago, compared with 11.4 percent in third period (S)

headline: South Africa May Cite Crisis To Lower Cost Of AIDS Drugs
abstract: South African government weighs declaring AIDS epidemic national emergency in effort to eliminate legal obstacles to importing and producing cheap, generic versions of patented AIDS drugs; move would allow copies of life-saving medicines to be imported and produced without consent of multinational drug makers who hold patents; marks change in government strategy; follows announcement by officials that they wanted to avoid seizing patents, fearing it could unsettle potential investors (M)

headline: Tyson Foods to Buy Leading Beef Packer
abstract: Tyson Foods Inc. reached an agreement yesterday to buy IBP Inc., the nation's biggest packer of fresh beef and a top pork processor, in a $3.2 billion stock and cash deal that would create the world's largest meat producer and processor. The agreement ends a running battle between Tyson and Smithfield Foods, the No. 1 pork processor in the country, for IBP. Tyson would also assume $1.5 billion of IBP's debt as part of the purchase.    Article, Page A13.

headline: A Felon Seeks Vindication: Will Milken Be Pardoned?
abstract: Floyd Norris column opposes pardon for Michael R Milken unless he owns up to his abuse of power in securities markets; photo (M)

headline: VOLVO UNHAPPY WITH ALLIANCE
abstract: Volvo AB says it is dissatisfied with its alliance with Mitsubishi Motors Corp and is in talks to modify deal; cites concern with role of its chief competitor, DaimlerChrysler, which owns 34 percent of Mitsubishi and has option to buy majority control in 2003 (S)/

headline: The Humble Résumé Enters Cyberspace
abstract: Internet has made job-hunting process easier to find information; basic content of job resume has not changed, but medium has changed radically; most job-seekers go directly to employer's Web site and fill out online questionnaires that are stored in employer's database; employers then search database using relevant keywords (M)

headline: MERCATA IS LATEST ONLINE CASUALTY
abstract: Mercata Inc, online merchandise auctioneer that is majority owned by Microsoft Corp co-founder Paul Allen's Vulcan Ventures, is closing after failing to raise more money; Mercata.com will accept orders until Jan 31 and returns if they are postmarked by Jan 20 (S)

headline: THE WEB IN TOUGHER TIMES; Life After Dot-Death For a Pair Of Content Providers
abstract: Dot-com boom offered writers unprecedented job opportunities, but now New York is teeming with unemployed 'content providers'--new media writers and editors who worked for now-defunct or pared-down Web sites; two of them tell their stories; they are Aaron Stoker-Ring and Hoag Levins; they are casualties of dot-com blowout, but they are surprisingly more enriched than bitter; photos (M)

headline: Feeling the Pinch On Luxury Leather; Prices Climb as European Supplies Dwindle Because of Cow Diseases
abstract: Animal diseases threatening meat supply in Europe are driving up price of hides because fewer animals are being slaughtered for meat; trend will likely have impact on price of luxury leather products in United States because Europe, particularly Britain, is major supplier of most prized hides; trend is already placing cost pressures on tanneries around world; graph of hide prices; photos (M)

headline: Head of G.M.'s Saturn Quits to Build Boats
abstract: Cynthia M Trudell, president and chairman of Saturn division of General Motors, will become president of Sea Ray boat-building group of Brunswick Corp; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Officer Is Killed by Israelis
abstract: Two Israeli helicopter gunships swooped over northern Gaza yesterday and fired four missiles at the car of a senior Palestinian security officer, instantly killing him. Israel holds him responsible for a failed mortar attack on a Jewish settlement in Gaza and for unrealized plans to kidnap senior Israeli military officials.    Palestinian officials quickly condemned Israel for the death of the man, Massoud Ayyad, saying Israel was acting like ''a state above the law'' in its continued use of assassinations to eliminate Palestinian militants.

headline: AOL Time Warner Quarterly Loss Is Related to Merger
abstract: AOL Time Warner, in first report as combined company, posts fourth-quarter loss of $1.09 billion, up from year-earlier loss of $201 million (M)û

headline: A Mad Scramble by Donors for Plum Ambassadorships
abstract: WASHINGTON, March 17 — Charles Gargano, New York State's economic development czar, has arranged for an array of backers, including Gov. George E. Pataki, to plug his name with the White House as the perfect United States ambassador to Rome.

headline: Independent Plants a Factor In the Latest Energy Crisis
abstract: Independent energy companies are reshaping power-generation industry across much of US; now account for more than 20 percent of domestic electricity generation, and number is expected to increase as demand for power continues to grow; nearly every new power plant in US is being built not by old-fashioned state-regulated utilities but by largely unregulated operations; industry's growing market power is starkly evident in California's energy shortage; state's four-year-old deregulation law has allowed independent producers to grab larger share of generation capacity than in most states; trend is same nationwide, where electricity supplies are increasingly controlled by companies that do not operate under oversight of state regulators; charts (M)

headline: U.S. and Russians Meet on Defenses Against Missiles
abstract: CAIRO, Feb. 24 — Secretary of State Colin L. Powell arrived here today on the first leg of his first overseas trip as the United States' chief diplomat and immediately plunged into talks with the Russian foreign minister, Igor S. Ivanov, on the two sides' widely differing plans for missile defenses.

headline: AT&T to Increase Cable Rates; It Raises Billions in New Credit
abstract: AT&T will modestly increase its cable television rates even as it secures big credit line arranged by some of nation's largest banks (M)

headline: A new campaign will try to identify a company's cellular phones with the idea of self-expression.
abstract: Cingular Wireless begins $200 million advertising campaign to introduce its national brand of wireless service; campaign is being created by BBDO New York and BBD South; Cingular is joint venture formed in October between BellSouth Corp and SBC Communications (M)
