abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Web Comes Up Fast on the Outside
abstract: Online gambling poses threat to Hong Kong's Happy Valley Racecourse, where more than million people bet regularly on horse racing and pour nearly $11 billion annually into coffers of Hong Kong Jockey Club, which donates most of its profits to charity; explosive growth of online gambling on horses and other sporting events has caused 10 percent erosion in Club's revenues since 1997 peak; and number of Hong Kong people who visit online gambling sites has doubled during past six months, further threatening racetrack's once-impregnable gambling franchise; photos; list of international philanthropic giants (L)

headline: South Korean President Sides With Russia on Missile Defense
abstract: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 27 — Less than a week before he meets President Bush in Washington, the president of South Korea today publicly took Russia's side in the debate over Washington's plan for a national missile defense.

headline: Business Travel; Midsize and smaller airlines tend to get the best ratings in the latest customer survey by Zagat.
abstract: Zagats release their 2001 Airline Survey; midsize and smaller carriers are highest rated; top-rated domestic airline for economy-class travel is Midwest Express Airlines; for premium-service seats, top five domestic carriers are Hawaiian Airlines, Alaska Airlines, Continental Airlines, American Airlines and United Airlines (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Times to Increase Delivery Price
abstract: New York Times will raise its price for home delivery (S)

headline: Pakistani Tale of a Drug Addict's Blasphemy
abstract: Frontier Post letters editor Munawwar Mohsin and six colleagues have been charged under Pakistan's blasphemy law, which can carry death sentence, for publishing letter that attacked Prophet Muhammad; Mohsin, drug addict who was newly out of detox, says he published letter largely unread; letter spurred furious mob to attack newspaper's Peshawar offices and authorities to shut down paper, which bought ad space in rival papers to apologize; Gen Pervez Musharraf has scored abuse of press freedom, not mob, in stand critics say shows his unwillingness or inability to take on Islamic fundamentalists; map; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001021393837133283 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: WIRELESS AD PLAN OUTLINED
abstract: NetZero, which offers free and paid-for Internet services to more than 8.4 million registered users, says it will design technology using standard developed by Qualcomm to deliver advertising on wireless devices (S)

headline: 11% Quarterly Gain at Merrill Lynch Beats Forecasts
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co says earnings in fourth quarter rose 11 percent, surpassing Wall Street expectations; brokerage firm earned $877 million compared with $793 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 4 percent, to $6.3 billion (M)

headline: Michael Oksenberg, 62, China Expert in Washington
abstract: Michel Oksenberg, who helped establish full diplomatic relations between Washington and Beijing as member of Pres Jimmy Carter's National Security Council, dies at age of 62; photo (M)

headline: G.E. Reports Rise in Profits
abstract: Balancing a softening in sales with a ratcheting up of productivity, the General Electric Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 16 percent even though revenue gained only 6 percent. But the company also said layoffs were likely.

headline: Flames Consume Dead but Not the Anguish
abstract: Mass anguish follows Jan 26 earthquake in Bhuj, India, that took nearly 700 lives; there is no time for customary funerals; unwashed dead are wrapped in blankets and sheets of plastic, then brought to one of city's four cremation posts; bodies are immediately laid on log mounds and pyres are lit as distraught relatives look on; photo (M)

headline: Job Forecast: Internet's Still Hot
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics predicts that one of five fastest-growing jobs will be computer-related for years 1998-2008; listings of fastest-growing and fastest-declining occupations; drawings (M)

headline: Janiya Journal; An Arab Village Strangled in the Name of Security
abstract: Three-week Israeli blockade has prevented people of West Bank village of Janiya from leaving town by car except for medical emergencies; there has been no delivery of gas in almost month, so many villagers are cooking over open fires; grocery shelves are sparsely filled; Janiya is relatively isolated village bordered by Jewish settlements on three sides; strict blockade has seemed baffling punishment to villagers, who are relatively low-key politically and claim no 'martyrs' to recent uprising; photos; map (M)

headline: Putin to Sell Arms and Nuclear Help to Iran
abstract: Russia's Pres Vladimir V Putin breaks openly with US and predecessor Boris N Yeltsin, formally agreeing to resume sales of conventional arms to Iran after hiatus of more than five years; reiterates at Kremlin meeting with Pres Mohammad Khatami Russia's intention to help Iran complete long-stalled nuclear power plant some American experts contend could advance Iran's nuclear weapons program; announcements, neither unexpected, come during first meeting in four decades between Iranian and Russian heads of state in warm session billed as diplomatic turning point; meeting is seen as pointed signal to Bush administration that Iranians and Russians intend to limit American influence in Middle East by both diplomatic and military means; Russia sold approximately $5 billion in weapons to Iran from 1989 and 1995, when sales stopped under terms of accord signed secretly with US by former Pres Boris Yeltsin; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Admiral Delivers Apology to the Japanese in Sub Sinking
abstract: Adm William J Fallon, Navy's second-ranking officer, delivers letter of apology from Pres George W Bush to Prime Min Yoshiro Mori and visits families of nine people lost in accidental sinking of Japanese fishery school ship by United States submarine; visit is latest in extraordinary series of apologies by United States, which has included telephone calls from Bush and Secretary of State Colin L Powell to Japanese leaders; despite these efforts, some Japanese continue to voice dissatisfaction with American response and are demanding that sunken ship, Ehime Maru, be raised to recover the bodies; photo (M)

headline: A Grisly Mystery in Ukraine Leads to a Government Crisis
abstract: Political stability in Ukraine is threatened by growing crisis involving Pres Leonid D Kuchma and adbuction and possible murder of journalist Georgy Gongadze; scandal sets off anti-Kuchma demonstrations in dozens of cities, as well as counter demonstrations by state workers ordered into streets or bused to pro-Kuchma rallies; is touched off by discovery of headless body, believed to be Gongadze's, and release of secret recordings made under Kuchma's couch by security agent in which Kuchma appears to order Gongadze's abduction or worse; has touched off fractious brawl in Parliament, where Kuchma's political majority has been upended by defections and formation of new centrist opposition; photo (M)

headline: CHIP SALES GROW, BUT SO DO INVENTORIES
abstract: Semiconductor Industry Association says worldwide chip sales in 2000 grew 37 percent over 1999, reaching record high of $204 billion; warns that high supply of chips waiting to be sold might drive growth down to as low as 10 percent in 2001; sales declined 2.1 percent between November and December, to $17.9 billion (S)

headline: Virginia Court's Decision in Online 'John Doe' Case Hailed by Free-Speech Advocates
abstract: In what was apparently the first Internet defamation case to involve both an anonymous plaintiff and anonymous defendants, the Supreme Court of Virginia refused to grant an unidentified company access to America Online's confidential subscriber information unless the firm agreed to reveal its identity.

headline: The long-suffering and lonely Maytag repairman will get a new look and a new mission in 2001.
abstract: Maytag repairman, who has become one of best-known characters in advertising since his introduction in 1967, is being recast and rethought for new generation of consumers; makeover is brainchild of longtime Maytag agency, Leo Burnett USA, with assistance from Will Vinton Studios; photo (M)

headline: New Talks on China's Entry To World Trade Group Fail
abstract: China's effort to join World Trade Organization is held up by major disagreement over its subsidies to its 900 million farmers; when China joins organization it wants same flexibility developing countries have with agricultural subsidies (M)

headline: George Carman, a Whiz at Libel Lawsuits in Britain, Dies at 71
abstract: LONDON, Jan. 6 — George Carman, a libel lawyer who became a courtroom legend for his ability to woo juries with wit and warmth while doing in opponents with one- liners and devastating 11th-hour disclosures, died of prostate cancer Tuesday at his home in Wimbledon. He was 71 and had retired on his doctor's advice in August after 47 years at the British bar.

headline: Coca-Cola Earnings Gain But Sales Are Lackluster
abstract: Coca-Cola Co reports fourth-quarter operating earnings rose sharply to $839 million, while net incomer rose to $242 million, compared with $45 million loss in 1999 period; photo (M)

headline: Searching for the Right Words For Saying 'Gotcha' in Turkey
abstract: Comment on problem of keeping track of numerous corruption investigations unfolding in Turkey these days; law enforcement authorities coin names for each new inquiry to help keep track; some of names such as Hurricane, Matador, Parachute and Storm noted (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Unemployment Rate Jumped to 4.2% in January  Responding to a slowing of the economy, the unemployment rate jumped in January to 4.2 percent -- the highest level in 15 months -- as the number of jobs in manufacturing continued to shrink, the Labor Department reported.    But the vast service sector, bucking the ebbing tide in American industry, produced enough new jobs to clearly suggest that the overall economy has not tipped into recession. And consumer confidence, which fell sharply in December and early January, appeared to stabilize by the end of the month, according to the latest survey by the University of Michigan's Consumer Research Center. [Page A1.]

headline: Former NBC Official Takes Job at Turner
abstract: Garth Ancier, former president of NBC Entertainment, is named executive vice president for network programming at Turner Broadcasting System (S)

headline: Mitsubishi Motors Charts an Austerity Plan of Its Own
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors Corp outlines sweeping restructuring plan that in some ways mirrors that of DaimlerChrysler, which owns about one-third of its stock; Mitsubishi, which has been reeling from sagging car sales as well as recalls and scandals, says it will eliminate 9,500 jobs, or 14 percent of its global work force, close one of its four car plants in Japan, and find ways to reduce spending on parts and supplies by 15 percent; company's goal is to achieve gross profit margin of 4.5 percent by 2003; photo (M)

headline: CHRYSLER TO END PRODUCTION OF JEEP CHEROKEE
abstract: Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler AG says production of Jeep Cherokee will end this summer; new vehicle of similar size, the Liberty, will replace Cherokee; Grand Cherokees will reamin in production (S)

headline: DRIVEWAY.COM ENDING WEB-STORAGE SERVICE
abstract: Driveway.com, online file-sharing and storage service, gives customers until March 5 to remove all files before it shuts down its operations; is also cutting its staff as it moves to focus on enterprise-level companies; suggests customers transfer files to former rival, FreeDrive (S)

headline: Shopping by PC For More Than PC's
abstract: Jupiter Media Metrix predicts that grocery items will account for a bigger share of consumers online purchases in 2005 than personal computers, software and peripheral devices, the current leading online product category; drawing (S)

headline: Decisions Made On 2 Accounts
abstract: Sprint Corp expands its relationship with McCann-Erickson Worldwide Agency by naming agency to handle Sprint Ion account; assignment, with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million, had been handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles; Best Western International selects Davis Media Group to handle creative and media-buying duties for its account, with spending at $25 million; account was handled by BBDO West (S)

headline: Moscow Journal; Why the Rabbi Blowtorched the Kremlin Kitchen
abstract: Kremlin creates an entire kosher kitchen and prepares kosher meal for visiting president of Israel, Moshe Katsav, under supervision of Rabbi Michol Gershzon, whose grandfather was killed for baking kosher motzo in Leningrad 51 years ago; this remarkable gesture on part of a nation that branded Israel a pariah state not two decades ago follows other efforts by Pres Vladimir V Putin to publicize Russia's Jewish heritage and to preach acceptance of Judaism and other religions that were persecuted in Soviet times; photo (M)

headline: Edward T. Tait; Federal Official, 80
abstract: Edward T Tait, expert on antitrust and corporate law who was executive director of Securities and Exchange Commission and a member of Federal Trade Commission during Eisenhower administration, dies at age 80 (S)

headline: Machinist Union at T.W.A. Objects to Merger With American
abstract: International Association of Machinists, largest union at Trans World Airlines, formally objects to proposal by American Airlines to buy most of TWA's assets in bankruptcy court, complaining American is not bargaining in good faith; American reiterates its commitment to bringing most of TWA's employees under its union contracts; Galileo International, which operates one of four major international computer reservation systems, offers to buy TWA's 26 percent stake in WorldSpan, rival reservation system, for $220 million; rival bid for most of TWA assets is received from collection of little-known investors calling themselves Jet Acquisitions Group; group has proposed buying TWA's assets for $889 million and investing billions more to turn airline around (M)

headline: Altered U.S. Corn Found In Samples Sent to Japan
abstract: Health Labor and Welfare Ministry of Japan says it has found traces of genetically modified corn in samples shipped from US to Japan, though results were negative when samples were tested in US; different results are likely to renew concerns in Japan, and in other parts of world about effectiveness of testing in US to prevent StarLink, genetically modified corn manufactured by Aventis, from seeping into grain exports (M)

headline: Fed Cuts Key Rate by Half a Point, Citing Slowdown
abstract: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 — The Federal Reserve today cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point for the second time this month, making clear that it intends to wage an aggressive battle against the growing possibility of a recession.

headline: The Wave Of Layoffs: Is It Bound To Get Bigger?
abstract: December unemployment rate was 4 percent, only tenth of percentage point above its lowest level in 30 years, even as announcements of layoffs reached their highest level in seven years; apparent contradiction reflects nothing more than timing; low unemployment rate gives picture of where economy has been, not where it is going; number can distort reality during turning points in economic cycle; as announced layoffs take effect, unemployment rate will start rising, perhaps as soon as Feb 2, when government releases next jobs report (M)

headline: Qaddafi Rants Against the U.S. In a Welcoming After Bomb Trial
abstract: Col Muammar el-Qaddafi turns personal welcome for Libyan released in Lockerbie bombing trial into rambling tirade against guilty verdict against other defendant and entire handling of affair; Qaddafi, standing in front of carefully preserved wreckage of his own house, which was bombed by United States in 1986, says relatives of hundreds killed and wounded then deserve compensation as much as families of Lockerbie victims; Qaddafi promises to release evidence that he says would establish innocence of Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi, Libyan intelligence agent found guilty; photos (M)

headline: How Agencies Read Signs of a Slowdown
abstract: Advertising colummn contends that as Madison Avenue anxiously watches faltering performance of national economy for signs of recession, executives have been keeping their eyes on calendar as well as clock; this year marks 10th anniversary of last recession, which inflicted significant damage on agencies as advertising spending fell for first time in 30 years; industry leaders fear that history could repeat itself if current slowdown in ad spending spirals into an actual decline; photo (M)

headline: Taliban Seem to Be Making Good on Opium Ban, U.N. Says
abstract: Initial results from survey of opium-growing areas of Afghanistan indicate that Taliban may have succeeded in sharply reducing poppy crop; astonished UN narcotics-control officials report no major signs of cultivation this year in northern provinces; farmers tell inspectors they are trying to grow other crops; World Bank warns at same time that country faces major famine; UN appeals for help for 100,000 Afghans caught in bitter cold (S)

headline: Is Japan Digging Out, Or Falling Deeper?
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin interview with Gary Motyl, chief investment officer at Templeton Institutional Group, on prospects for Japanese economy and Japanese stocks; photo (M)

headline: VINTAGE PETROLEUM INCREASES ITS HOLDINGS IN CANADA
abstract: Vintage Petroleum to acquire Genesis Exploration for $572 million (S)

headline: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Council Bid on Palestinian Force
abstract: Bush administration casts its first veto in Security Council, scuttling Palestinian hopes for United Nations observer force in Israeli-occupied territories; resolution would align Security Council with Palestinian criticism of Israel; United States never agreed even to consider mention of force, which Israel has repeatedly rejected and which Secretary General Kofi Annan has described as unworkable without consent of both parties (M)

headline: COMMUNICATIONS PRODUCTS FROM INTEL
abstract: Intel introduces seven new optical networking chips that help extend reach of telecommunications systems in metropolitan areas (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.75        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.56   5.48   5.76        3-month T-bills   4.92   4.92   5.51        6-month T-bills   4.75   4.75   5.70        10-yr. T-infl.   3.44   3.46   4.30        10-yr. T-note   5.06   5.18   6.64        30-yr. T-bond   5.53   5.50   6.31        Telephone bd.   7.71   7.76   8.35        Municipal bds.   5.33   5.33   6.25          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: As the ethnic population swells, agencies make moves to reach the faster-growing groups.
abstract: American division of Publicis Groupe is forming Publicis Sanchez & Levitan to handle advertising aimed at Hispanic consumers by acquiring two of four offices of Siboney and 49 percent stake in Sanchez & Levitan; Aida Levitan will be chairwoman and chief executive of new unit and Fausto Sanchez chairman, president and chief creative officer; Admerasia is reorganizing as agency company named New A that will offer advertising and other services aimed at Asian-American consumers and co-called emerging ethnic audiences; moves reflect increase in minority populations and stress on faster-growing groups (M)

headline: In the War on Gibberish, a New Investor Ally
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column commends Committee for Corporate Governance of New York Society of Security Analysts for demanding accurate financial information from Amazon.com (M)

headline: Stocks Perk Up, With Nasdaq Posting Gain in a Harsh Week
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average ends week at 9,504.78, up 115.30 for day; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises to 1,139.83, up 22.25; Nasdaq composite rises to 1,928.68, gain of 30.98; prices fall in bond market, as money moves into stocks; 10-year Treasury note yield jumps to 4.80 percent, from 4.74 percent day before; its price falls 16/32, to 101 18/32; graph; list of key rates (M)

headline: Raytheon Sued in Sale of Unit
abstract: L-3 Communications Holdings , a maker of military communications systems, has asked a court to overturn its $160 million purchase of a Raytheon unit, saying it was misled about the unit's financial condition.

headline: U.N. Council Agrees to Plan To Get Troops Out of Congo
abstract: United Nations Security Council, moving with remarkable speed and unanimity in response to cooperative new government, agrees on step by step plan to withdraw all foreign troops from Congo; is expected to adopt accord, drafted by France, as resolution after meetings with represenatives of African countries and rebel armies involved in war; plan follows outline of accord reached by all warring sides in Dec, but never acted on; Rwanda and Uganda have already promised to begin withdrawing; Sec Gen Kofi Annan says UN has been slow to begin peacekeeping operation because nations in region have not shown that they really want to end war (M)

headline: Text of Statement by the Federal Reserve
abstract: Text of statement released by Federal Reserve on decision to lower interest rates 50 basis points

headline: Delta Cuts Earnings Outlook
abstract: Hurt by winter storms and a pilot slowdown, Delta Air Lines warned investors today that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall short of Wall Street's expectations.

headline: What's This Pill For? Log On to Find Out
abstract: Internet can help the elderly learn more about drugs prescribed for them and how to lower cost of necessary drugs; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Tom Sullivan, president at Princeton Partners, is named chief executive; succeeds Cathy Mathis, who will become consultant (S)

headline: ANOTHER BEEF IMPORT BAN
abstract: South Korea forbids import of fresh meat from hoofed animals from all 15 European Union nations as precaution against foot-and-mouth disease (S)

headline: In Hollywood, Strike Planning Turns From 'If' to 'When'
abstract: Movie and television industries brace for strikes by writers and actors, which promises to be bruising for studios, strikers and production workers caught in middle; effects of impending strikes have been masked by rush to production, as studios have attempted to get as many films finished as possible before strike deadlines, but that surge is beginning to dry up; strike could allow news and reality programs to make further inroads with television viewers; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: Tokyo Stocks Fall Sharply
abstract: TOKYO, March 1 — Snubbing the Bank of Japan and its interest-rate cut, investors hammered Japanese stocks again today.

headline: Risks in Commercial Paper
abstract: Bruce R Bent letter responds to Feb 11 article concerning risk to money market mutual funds posed by commercial-paper investments

headline: On Eve of a Visit by Powell, Rising Unrest in the Mideast
abstract: Israeli officials rebuff Colin L Powell's pleas for easing of blockade of Palestinian territories and Palestinian militants burn him in effigy on eve of his first visit to region as secretary of state; actions seen to reflect hostility that has gripped area rather than sentiment about Bush administration; during visit Powell is expected to reiterate his recent calls for end to terrorist violence and easing of Israeli security and economic restrictions on Palestinian communities; in West Bank, Palestinians lob gasoline bombs at Israeli soldiers in Hebron and trade fire with Israeli forces outside Ramallah; this backdrop of violence stiffens Israeli resistance to measures that might reduce increasing economic distress in Palestinian areas; photo (M)

headline: Amgen Wins Court Battle Over Drug For Anemia
abstract: Judge William G Young rules that Transkaryotic Therapies infringed three of five Amgen patents covering Epogen, drug for anemia; ruling prevents Transkaryotic and its partner, Aventis SA, from selling their version of drug, biotech industry's top seller (M)

headline: Arafat Accepts Peace Plan, But Violence Erodes Hope
abstract: Clinton administration accepts Palestinian leader Yasir Arafats word that he will abide by Pres Clinton's proposals as basis for further talks with Israel; outlook for accord before Clinton leaves office fades further as much of focus shifts to how to contain violence in region; Clinton briefs Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak by phone on his talks with Arafat; Barak's 'peace cabinet' decides to send Gilad Sher, Barak's staff chief, to Washington to discuss with American negotiators Arafat's reaction to Clinton plan, but not meet with any Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: Irina Bugrimova, 90, an Enchanter of Big Cats
abstract: Irina Bugrimova, Russian circus animal tamer, dies at age 90; photo (M)

headline: M.I.T. Professor Reconsiders Children's Online Lives
abstract: There are few neighborhoods left where children can meet their pals after school for a friendly game of kickball in a vacant lot. Parents should accept this reality of contemporary life and understand that the virtual world can be a boon to today's latchkey child.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises after report on Japan's services industry suggests economy may not be as weak as previously thought; dollar settles at 116.39 yen, down from 117.42 yen in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Chief Resigns At Terra Lycos After Dispute With Owners
abstract: Robert J Davis, who took Lycos from university project to fifth-most-popular Web site in US, resigns as chief executive of Terra Lycos after dispute with Spanish owners, Terra Networks; Davis was to become chief executive when Terra Networks bought Lycos last year and Juan Villalonga, chairman of Telefonica, parent of Terra Networks, would also be chairman of Terra Lycos; after Villalonga resigned in July, Joaquim Agut was named executive chairman of Terra Lycos; but he also wanted to exert more management control over Terra Lycos than Davis thought appropriate; Davis will serve as vice chairman of Terra Lycos board; Terra Lycos says Ted Philip, chief financial officer, will leave that position to become senior vice president of strategic planning; Elias Rodriguez-Vina is named chief financial officer; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001012591684153284 -- No Title
abstract: January 25, 2001

headline: Cartoon of Wartime 'Comfort Women' Irks Taiwan
abstract: Chinese-language edition of Japanese comic book is causing storm in Taiwan over depiction of Taiwanese women who were kept in Japanese military brothels during World War II; mob of Taiwan legislators and other protesters recently stormed into Taipei's biggest bookstore, grabbed armloads of comics and set them on fire on sidewalk outside; critics are outraged by what they say is distorted account of Japan's last years in Taiwan, when army rounded up 'comfort women' for soldiers' use; cartoonist Kobayashi Yoshinori depicts women lining up willingly for duty, and to buttress his claims includes long interview with aging Taiwanese industrialist Hsu Wen-lung, who asserts that no women were forced to serve Japanese military; Hsu's remarks are particularly explosive because he is supporter and adviser to Pres Chen Shui-bian (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: BLOUNT INTERNATIONAL, Montgomery, Ala., named Harold Layman, president, to the additional post of chief executive, succeeding John Panettiere, who is retiring but will continue as chairman.    BORGWARNER, Chicago, named George Strickler executive vice president and chief financial officer, succeeding Larry Skatoff, who retired. Mr. Strickler had been executive vice president and chief financial officer at Lake West.

headline: People
abstract: Rob Slosberg is named to new post of executive vice president and group creative director at Bates USA; Andy Bateman and Jennifer Garr are named executive principals at Publicis in New York (S)

headline: BANK LOANS TO FINANCE AT&T STAKE
abstract: NTT DoCoMo Inc, Japan's dominant cellular phone company, is borrowing 1.2 trillion yen ($10.3 billion) from five Japanese banks to pay for 16 percent stake it is acquiring in AT&T Wireless Group (S)

headline: When the Golf Is Good, Zambia Is Doing Better
abstract: Copper and golf industries are making comeback in Chingola, Zambia; no one in Chingola is under illusion that Nchanga Golf Club will soon rejoin ranks of world's finest golf courses or that country's mining industry will return to its heyday, when it was world's third-biggest miner of copper, but they are optimistic; photo (M)

headline: A Funny Thing Happened On the Way to the Rollout
abstract: Linus Torvalds' statement announcing latest upgrade of his Linux computer operating system parodies typical corporate news release; photo (M)

headline: Despite Objections from Orthodox Church, the Pope Will Visit Ukraine
abstract: ROME, Jan. 25 — John Paul II confirmed today his plans to visit Ukraine in June despite objections by the main Orthodox Church there, and also said he would visit Syria.

headline: GLOBAL JOBLESS REPORT
abstract: United Nations' International Labor Organization employment survey finds that 160 million people are jobless, 20 million more than before Asia's 1997 financial crisis; says growth in labor supply and loss of jobs from restructuring are causes (S)

headline: Four-Footed Robot
abstract: Daniel Handwerke letter on Jan 25 article on Sony's robotic dog

headline: OPEL CHAIRMAN IS NAMED
abstract: Carl-Peter Forster is named chairman of Adam Opel AG; photo (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Summit Pptys Inc

headline: In Bush's Words: 'Both Sides Must Take Important Steps' in the Mideast
abstract: Excerpts from Pres Bush's news conference, answering questions about Israel, campaign finance reform, drilling for oil and other topics; photo (L)

headline: Opposition to Coalition Simmers in Israel's Labor Party
abstract: JERUSALEM, Feb. 21 — Ehud Barak's sudden resignation from political life appears to have cleared the way for a unity government under Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon, but there are still bitter opponents to the coalition within the now leaderless Labor Party.

headline: Omnicom seeks ways to work more closely with troubled online agencies in which it has stakes.
abstract: Organic, troubled online ad agency, is talking with BBDO Worldwide about alliance that could lead to merger of Organic with attmosphere, digital marketing division of BBDO; Organic says about 300 employees will be dismissed; Grey Global Group is forming single worldwide interactive media services unit by merging two digital operations of MediaCom, its media services agency, with Beyond Interactive, unit of Grey (M)

headline: Bankruptcy Judge May Be Solution to California Energy Crisis
abstract: Bankruptcy court judge may be only person with authority to ask electric rate increases and cost cuts in California that growing number of analysts say are necessary, but nobody in state has been able to agree upon; bankruptcy filings by state's largest utilities, Southern California Edison and Pacific Gas and Electric, would only make it harder for them to borrow money, further shaking confidence of power-generating companies that are already threatening not to sell them electricity; bankruptcy court filing would not satisfy consumers because they are almost certain to be forced to pay large chunk of $12 billion two utilities owe power generators now; Pacific Gas and Electric and its parent, PG&E Corp, say they defaulted on $76 million of commercial paper; Southern California Edison says it will not pay $596 million it owes bondholders and power generators; photo (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: ALKERMES, Cambridge, Mass., named David Broecker chief operating officer, succeeding Robert Breyer, who remains president until he retires at the end of the year. Mr. Broecker was most recently marketing director for business development at Eli Lilly & Company.    CHICAGO STOCK EXCHANGE named A. D. Frazier Jr. president and chief executive, succeeding Bob Forney, who is retiring. Mr. Frazier had been head of the United States institutional investment management unit of Amvescap.

headline: Oxfam Joins Campaign to Cut Drug Prices for Poor Nations
abstract: Oxfam, influential British charity, begins campaign to force multinational drug companies to cut prices of their live-saving drugs to poor nations; accuses companies and rich nations of keeping drug prices high by using trade sanctions to protect patent treaties that give companies 20-year monopolies on their drugs; Oxfam is joining Doctors Without Borders, Act-Up, and others who have been conducting similar campaign for last year (M)

headline: KAO AND ARCHER-DANIELS TO COLLABORATE ON COOKING OIL
abstract: Japan's Kao Corp will form joint venture with Archer Daniels Midland Co to make and sell ingredients for Kao's popular cooking oil in Decatur, Ill (S)

headline: Patents; In health emergencies, Brazil allows the copying of drugs, to the dismay of American companies.
abstract: Sabra Chartrand Patents column on Brazilian patent laws, how they differ from American laws and US drug manufacturers' dismay over 1999 presidential decree that allows government to license drug patents in cases of national emergency (M)

headline: AT&T Raises $3.6 Billion To Cut Its Debt
abstract: AT&T Corp, in effort to reduce debt, will sell some cable television stations in US and its stake in Japan Telecom for total of $3.6 billion; Mediacom Communications Corp will pay $2.2 billion in cash for cable operations serving 840,000 customers in Georgia, Iowa, Illinois and Missouri; Vodafone Group agrees to buy AT&T's 10 percent stake in Japan Telecom for $1.35 billion (M)

headline: Damascus Journal; How to Pick a Ram to Make the Supreme Sacrifice
abstract: Damascus Journal describes process of selecting rams for ritual slaughter to celebrate annual Feast of the Sacrifice in Damascus, Syria, and rest of Muslim world that pays homage to Abraham, founding patriarch of Islam; photo (M)

headline: Google Search Engine Reaches Into Usenet
abstract: Search engine company Google will acquire Deja.com, which archives and allows searching of messages on Internet newsgroups; Deja currently contains 500 million messages dating back to 1995 (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Judges Use Laptops In Microsoft Appeal
abstract: Judges hearing appeal of Microsoft antitrust case use laptop computers to communicate with their clerks and to study legal documents during proceedings; computers are equipped with Microsoft Windows operating system and Internet Explorer as well as Netscape navigator Web browser--software programs at center of case; drawing (M)

headline: A Trek to See if Only Memories Survived Quake
abstract: Earthquake destruction in Indian village of Adhoi, where no structure is unscathed, described; about 2,000 villagers, fifth of population, died; map (S)

headline: Business on Internet Time; The Ups Are Fast. The Downs Could Be Even Faster.
abstract: Questions about role of Internet in current economic slowdown are brought to fore by unexpected plunge in orders and revenue at Cisco Systems Corp and the surprise of other manufacturing companies at abrupt drop in orders and runup in inventories; Internet allows managers to monitor every link of supply chain that feeds their manufacturing processes and to change direction with unprecedented nimbleness, but this may have encouraged a complacency that prevented faster adjustment to unforeseen forces; another factor is that Cisco and many companies farm out actual production to contract manufacturers and may have lost touch with overall market environment; photos; graph (M)

headline: Dual Focus: The Ball, the Nest Egg
abstract: Interview with tennis player Monica Seles on her finances, which she only started to consider seriously after being stabbed in 1993 and losing lawsuit against German Tennis Federation for damages related to the assault; she is worth, perhaps, $40 million, but has no housekeeper and no Ferrari; she is very aware that a star's winnings can stop quickly; photos (M)

headline: YEN PLUNGES AGAINST DOLLAR
abstract: Value of Japanese yen falls 1.9 percent, to 125.52 to US dollar (S)

headline: Huge Soccer Scandal Taints National Obsession of Brazil
abstract: Multimillion-dollar scandal spreading throughout Brazilian soccer causes shock, disgust, outrage and sorrow among ordinary Brazilians, who hold sacred the sports integrity; has touched team administrators, managers, players agents and even some top players, although latter have apparently been more naive victims of manipulative team officials than wrongdoers; irregularities uncovered thus far include income tax evasion, nonpayment of social security taxes, money laundering, evasion of foreign exchange controls, skimming of gate revenues and perhaps even bribing of referees to help throw games; photo (M)

headline: JOHNSON & JOHNSON NAMES 2 TO NEW VICE CHAIRMAN POSTS
abstract: Johnson & Johnson names James Lenehan and William Weldon vice chairmen (S)

headline: 2 Acquisitions Are Announced
abstract: Ad agency Market Facts acquires Copernicus: The Marketing Investment Strategy Group in deal valued at about $16.5 million; Panoramic Communications acquires Odyssey Systems (S)

headline: SPANISH WIRELESS PROFIT IS UP
abstract: Telefonica Moviles reports 52 percent increase in subscribers and 36.5 percent rise in operating profit, to 2.45 billion euros ($2.25 billion), despite significant drop of average revenue per user in Spain; consolidated revenue rose 47 percent in Latin America; Spain contributed 68 percent of sales, 28.2 percent increase at 4.80 billion euros ($4.41 billion) (S)

headline: Lockerbie Prosecutor Delivers Closing Statement
abstract: CAMP ZEIST, the Netherlands, Jan. 9 — The chief prosecutor in the Lockerbie trial dropped two lesser counts against the defendants today, and tried to convince the three-judge jury that he had proved them guilty of murder.

headline: NUCOR BUYS STEEL-BAR MILL ASSETS FOR $115 MILLION
abstract: Nucor Corp will buy almost all of Auburn Steel Co's steel-bar mill assets in Auburn, NY, for $115 million, to expand its steel-bar production into Northeast (S)

headline: YEARS AND YEARS WORTH OF TABLOIDS
abstract: New York Post, owned by News Corp, will soon make almost 200 years' worth of newspapers available on Internet; Cold North Wind Corp will create digital images of paper and make them part of global online newspaper archive (S)

headline: Studios and Writers Guild Break Off Contract Talks
abstract: LOS ANGELES, March 1 - Negotiations broke down today between the Writers Guild of America and representatives of the leading Hollywood studios and television networks, making the prospect of a long-dreaded strike this summer much likely.

headline: Judges Voice Doubt On Order Last Year To Split Microsoft
abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 — The government suffered a second difficult day of questioning in its Microsoft antitrust case today when a Federal appeals court cast doubt about a judge's order last year to break the company in two.

headline: Roll 'Em, Digitally, On a Disc
abstract: State of the Art column on Hitachi's new DZ-M100A digital camcorder, first consumer product that does not record on tape; removable disc stores still and motion pictures, overcoming two shortcomings of tape: clumsy editing and location of material and, importantly, degraded signal quality that occurs with passage of time; photo (M)

headline: A new campaign asks consumers to remember an earlier time, and a familiar sneaker.
abstract: Keds unit of Stride Rite Corp introduces revamped Keds Original sneaker and launches $7 million advertising campaign that invokes its heyday; agency is Toth Brand Imaging; photo (M)

headline: HUB, A TORONTO INSURANCE COMPANY, BUYS KAYE GROUP
abstract: Hub International Ltd, insurance company based in Toronto, acquires Kaye Group for $120.5 million in cash and convertible debentures (S)

headline: First Meeting: China Testing Firmer Way Of Bush Team
abstract: Pres Bush meets with Qian Qichen, Chinese deputy prime minister, in Oval Office session that highlights sharp discord between United States and China on security issues and human rights, but appears to do little to resolve it; Bush publicly says he intends to foster good relations with China but also to speak out bluntly on disagreements; privately, Bush urges Chinese to respect human rights and religious freedom, and encourages Beijing to release Gao Zhan, Chinese scholar based in United States who has been held in China for last five weeks (M)

headline: Share Prices Gain Despite New Round of Profit Warnings
abstract: Nadaq composite index gains 25.29 points, or 1.2 percent, to 2,142.92; Dow Jones industrial average rises 85.99 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,562.30, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 7.23 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,241.41; graph; chart (M)

headline: A Home Fixture as a Market Shelter
abstract: Article points to relative stability of cable television businesses regardless of economic climate; minimal dependence on advertising, ease of capital spending in times of low interest rates and favorable regulatory climate make cable company stocks useful market shelters; drawing; graph (M)

headline: Before Vote, Israel Sees 'Day After'
abstract: Israelis presume that Ariel Sharon will be elected prime minister and are already looking beyond Election Day to diplomatic and political repercussions of what news programs call 'The Day After'; are tired after months of disorienting commotion, deterioration of Israeli-Palestinian relationship into ongoing violence and divisive election campaign; photos of Sharon and of Prime Min Ehud Barak (M)

headline: And Now, Bonds for the Masses
abstract: Intercapital LLC begins selling corporate bonds with minimum, commission-free purchase of $1,000, further democratizing a market where institutions have traditionally dominated and individuals have ventured at their peril (S)

headline: President of CNNfn Quits As a Revamping Begins
abstract: C Shelby Coffey 3d is resigning as president of CNN's financial news network, CNNfn; earlier it was announced that Bob Furnad is leaving as president of CNN's Headline News; AOL Time Warner has begun companywide reorganization that it to involve elimination of hundreds of positions (M)

headline: GOLDMAN SACHS AGREES TO BUY MARKET MAKER
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group agrees to buy Benjamin Jacobson & Sons LLC for about $250 million in cash and stock to expand its floor-trading operation on New York Stock Exchange (S)

headline: 2 Drug Companies Post Solid Quarterly Results
abstract: Merck and Johnson & Johnson post robust fourth-quarter results; Merck reports 12 percent increase in profits; net income was $1.76 billion compared with $1.57 billion year earlier; Johnson & Johnson's profit rose 16 percent, to $924 million compared with $796 million a year ago; net income was $891 million compared with $754 million in year-earlier quarter (M)

headline: Schwab Tells Some Workers To Stay Home
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp tells about half of its employees not to show up for work on three Fridays in next five weeks; stretching out weekends will bolster Schwab's reported earnings for quarter, even though firm expects most of eligible employees to use vacation time; Schwab expects that group to comprise between 8,000 and 13,000 of its 26,000 employees (M)

headline: MOTOROLA CUTTING 300 JOBS
abstract: Motorola Inc will eliminate another 300 jobs from division that makes cell phones and other communications devices; graph (S)

headline: Article 2001012190122191289 -- No Title
abstract: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

headline: As a Russian Hurries Home, Washington Is Suspicious
abstract: Federal Bureau of Investigation identifies Vladimir Frolov, Russian press attache in Washington who abruptly cut short second tour of duty in US, as spy who may have handled Richard P Hanssen, agency operative who has been charged with spying for Russia; officials say Frolov was not forced to leave by US; speculate departure may have been part of pre-emptive move by Russian government in anticipation of Bush administration demands that some of its intelligence officers leave (M)

headline: Article 2001012193023679089 -- No Title
abstract: Web Sites Begin to Self Organize

headline: FleetBoston Sells Package Of Bad Loans
abstract: FleetBoston Financial Corp sells $1.35 billion of troubled loans to Patriarch Partners, ridding itself of some customers who have had trouble paying back debt; Patriarch, founded in April by investors Dennis Dolan and Lynn Tilton, pays about $1 billion for loans, about 26 percent less than their face value; sale shrinks FleetBoston's nonperforming loans to about $925 million from $1.03 billion in September (M)

headline: CORNING CUTS JOBS AFTER DEMAND SLUMPS
abstract: Fiber optic cable maker Corning says it has laid off 825 employees from manufacturing centers in New York and Pennsylvania; plants make equipment for optical communications networks (S)

headline: SULZER MEDICA OF EUROPE ADDING INTRATHERAPEUTICS
abstract: Sulzer Medica AG, Europe's biggest maker of orthopedic devices, agrees to pay $145 million in cash for Intratherapeutics of US to move into fast-growing market for peripheral stents (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Heating oil falls after unexpected gain in supplies signals that stock will be adequate for winter; heating oil for February delivery falls 4 cents, or 4.6 percent, to 82.22 cents a gallon in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: KOZMO SEEKS ONLINE GROCER
abstract: Kozmo, online delivery company, is reportedly in talks to buy PDQuick, privately held Internet grocer operating in 30 communities in Los Angeles and Orange County (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   9.00   8.50       Discount rate   5.00   5.50   5.00       Federal funds   5.68   5.90   5.64       3-month T-bills   4.84   4.85   5.46       6-month T-bills   4.62   4.73   5.63       10-yr. T-infl.   3.50   3.55   4.27       10-yr. T-note   5.11   5.22   6.57       30-yr. T-bond   5.50   5.59   6.28       Telephone bd.   7.84   7.71   8.30       Municipal bds.   5.37   5.39   6.30        (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Bush Seeking To Overhaul Policy Making
abstract: Pres-elect Georgw W Bush is seeking ways to overhaul economic policymaking in his administration, with advisers debating whether to strip trade representative's office of cabinet rank and eliminate National Economic Council, powerful White House council that overseas foreign and domestic economic policy; Richard W Fisher, Democrat, is leading candidate to fill top trade post; former State Dept official Robert B Zoellick is also contender, but is also being considered for No.2 job at Treasury Dept; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Stocks Dive and Economy Softens, the Dollar Is Positively Robust
abstract: US dollar has grown stronger as US economy softens, investors flee stocks and interest rates drop, all forces that normally batter dollar; dollar is near two-year high against Japanese yen and is battering euro; many investors still think that US is better able to deal with its economic troubles than Japan or Europe; graph (Market Place column) (M)

headline: G.M. Earnings Dropped 92% In 4th Quarter
abstract: General Motors Corp says profit plunged 92 percent in fourth quarter because of large one-time charges, slight erosion of profits in North America and heavy losses overseas, especially in Europe; company earned $30 million in Europe in fourth quarter of 1999, but that turned into $463 million loss during fourth quarter of 2000; North American operations earned $979 million in fourth quarter; company earned $609 million; sales fell to $45 billion from $46.26 million a year earlier; for all of 2000, profits fell 25.8 percent, to $4.45 billion compared with $6 billion in 1999; sales rose to $184.63 billion from $176.56 billion; Robert Hendry, chief executive of GM's German subsidiary, Adam Opel AG, says he will resign at end of March (M)

headline: After Slaughter of Ireland's Cattle, a Severe Disposal Problem
abstract: European Union regulations, prompted by re-emergence of mad cow disease late last year, force farmers across Continent to test or detroy all cows more than 30 months old; Irish agriculture officials worry about what to do with bodies of slaughtered cattle; about 300,000 are expected to be destroyed by June (M)

headline: Tales From the Nasdaq Casino: The Winners Get Stiffed
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on how many day traders lost money when computer error through electronic trading network Redibook resulted in huge fluctuations in price of Axcelis Technologies Inc's stock and Nasdaq canceled many orders; says Wall Street should find way to compensate traders who were not at fault for fluctuations otherwise, Nasdaq looks like casino that values customer's business only until he starts winning; financial plight of day trader Paul Parsons noted (M)

headline: Apple Putting Hopes on New Macintosh Line
abstract: Apple Computer's chief executive Steven P Jobs introduces revamped Macintosh personal computer line and ultra-thin, titanium-clad portable model at annual MacWorld Exhibition, San Francisco; 5.3-pound G4 model, with Motorola processor, has built-in DVD player and 15.2-inch widescreen display; new machine, which will begin shipping in January, will sell for $2,599 to $3,997; photo (M)

headline: BETTER MARGIN AT CLOTHIER
abstract: Marks & Spencer PLC, leading clothing retailer in Britain, says profit as percentage of sales widened eight-tenths of percentage point in 16 weeks to Jan 20 even as sales fell 5.1 percent at stores open year or more; graph (S)

headline: Foot-and-Mouth Disease Intrudes, Putting British Farmers in Dread
abstract: British farmers fear for their futures as foot-and-mouth disease, highly contagious virus that attacks cloven-hoofed animals like cows, pigs and sheep, spreads; are barring visitors and leaving farms only when necessary; hunting, fishing and sports events have been cancelled to deter spread of virus, which rarely affects humans but can be carried by people, cars, clothes and even wind; photos (M)

headline: INSURER'S REVENUE GROWS
abstract: AXA SA, France's biggest insurer, says revenue increased to 80.1 billion euros ($74.4 billion) in 2000 from 66.5 billion euros in 1999 (S)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Real-Time Challenges, in Cyberspace and on the Ground; Looser Policy Likely On Antitrust Scrutiny
abstract: Bush administration is expected to easier than Clinton administration in applying antitrust rules to mergers, but some experts predict that change in administration may not fundamentally alter policy, since large majority of mergers and acquisitions are approved anyway and since some industries like telecommunications have become so consolidated that there is little room left for many blockbuster mergers (M)

headline: A change at TWBA illustrates concerns over a slow economy.
abstract: Omnicom is naming Jean-Marie Dru to replace Michael Greenlees as president and chief executive at TBWA Worldwide; change in leadership at TBWA is sign of increasing scrutiny of agency performance as economy sputters and uncertainty grows over whether clients will proceed with spending plans for 2001 that they made as recently as December; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Financier Tried to Escape German Jail
abstract: Martin R Frankel, former financier who is awaiting extradition to US on charges that he embezzled more than $200 million, tries but fails to escape from prison in Hamburg, Germany (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Losing money, Culturefinder hopes to find success in a switch from dot-com to dot-org.
abstract: Culturefinder.com, which helps consumers find tickets and data about performing arts organizations and events, to transform itself from money-losing commercial concern to nonprofit group; chief executive Eugene Carr devised plan after laying off company's entire staff of 40; photo (M)

headline: Cash Flow Increases 17% At Viacom as Net Falls
abstract: Viacom reports cash flow rose 17 percent in fourth quarter, to $1.45 billion; revenue increased 5 percent, to $6.35 billion; net income fell to $30.4 million from $133 million year earlier (M)

headline: Body Shop Will Report Profit Slide of at Least 10%
abstract: body shop will report profit slide of at least 10

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Feb 4 artiel on Super Bowl as stock market indicator

headline: Chime Communications Agrees to Purchase LNS
abstract: chime comm

headline: Judge Rebuffs Bear Stearns Effort to Reduce $171 Million Award
abstract: Judge Victor Marrero rejects Bear Stearns Cos request to reverse $171 million court award to Henryk de Kwiatkowski, Canadian currency speculator; jury concluded in May that Bear Stearns failed to warn de Kwiatkowski adequately of risks of foreign currency speculation (M)

headline: Katni Journal; A Pox on Politicians. A Eunuch You Can Trust.
abstract: Profile of Kamla Jaan, 46-year-old eunuch who has won election as mayor of Katni, India; Jaan, an illiterate, foul-mouthed eunuch, who has a masculine bulk and voice, but prefers feminine attire and pronouns, is among five other eunuchs who were swept into office in cities and towns this year; role of eunuchs in Indian culture discussed; photo (L)

headline: NO BIDS FOR CHEMICAL CONCERN
abstract: Auction of Cia Petroquimica do Nordeste, Brazilian petrochemical maker, fails for second time (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AFRICA    UGANDA: EX-CANDIDATE QUESTIONED -- The police questioned the loser in last week's presidential race over a spate of attacks that have killed more than a dozen people around the country since the election. The former candidate, Dr. Kizza Besigye, left, who was President Yoweri Museveni's physician, denied any involvement in the attacks, saying the government is harassing him because of his accusations that Mr. Museveni won only by wholesale vote rigging. Last weekend, army officials prevented Dr. Besigye from traveling to South Africa because of what they said were suspicions that he may have been linked to the attacks.    Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline: Quake Disrupts Salvador Coffee Deliveries
abstract: El Salvador's coffee crop faces serious delivery problems after the Saturday earthquake, which damaged mills and blocked roads, the director of the Salvadoran Coffee Council said in a phone interview from San Salvador.

headline: Microsoft Gives Boost To Outlook for Macintosh
abstract: Microsoft is updating its popular Office 2001 software suite to run on Apple's Mac OS X and announces a Macintosh version of Outlook, the e-mail, address book, calendar and collaboration program (S)

headline: INTEL TO USE I.B.M. SOFTWARE IN SOME CHIPS
abstract: Intel agrees to embed IBM software in chip kits it plans to market to developers of new wireless electronic devices and software applications for them; IBM software, known as middleware, is intended to allow developers to create wide range of Intel-based products for mobile appliances that can easily interact with each other directly or over Internet (S)

headline: Leslie C. Quick Jr., a Pioneer in Discount Stock Brokerage, Dies at 75
abstract: Leslie C Quick Jr, pioneer in discount stock brokerage, dies at age 75; photo (M)

headline: American Airlines Reported Near a Deal to Buy T.W.A
abstract: American Airlines is reportedly negotiating complex transaction to acquire Trans World Airlines and buy separate stake in US Airways in deal that could fundamentally reshape airline industry; will reportedly acquire carrier after it files for bankruptcy for third time in less than decade; would take on company's debt as part of reorganization under chapter 11; terms of merger, said to be valued at about $2 billion, discussed; acquisition would put American and United at top of shrinking list of national carriers and end one of most enduring franchises in commercial aviation dating back to Charles Lindbergh; decline of TWA for years following selloff or cutback of most overseas routes discussed (M)

headline: PrivateSector; New-Job Pioneer Sued for Taking One
abstract: William O Warren, pioneer in online job search industry, is sued by his former employer, TMP Worldwide, which contends that Warren used its proprietary information to establish his current venture, WOWemployers Network; photo (S)

headline: New F.C.C. Chief Would Curb Agency Reach
abstract: New Federal Communications Commission chief, Michael K Powell, signaling marked departure from his Clinton administration predecessors, voices skepticism about wide array of regulations affecting broadcasters, telephone companies, cable operators and Internet service providers, news conference; places greater faith in marketplace to correct possible problems and sees sharply reduced role for agency; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001012891144896440 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Fighting Spills Into Kosovo, Killing 3 and Wounding 16
abstract: SKOPJE, Macedonia, March 29 — Fighting between Macedonian security forces and ethnic Albanian rebels in the north spilled over the border into Kosovo today, killing three people and wounding 16.

headline: Outlook for Andrew Corp.
abstract: Andrew Corp, maker of equipment for wireless communications systems, says second-quarter sales and profit will fall short of its forecast because customers are spending less (S)

headline: Facing Slump and Big Debts, Xerox Hires Consulting Firm
abstract: Xerox Corp hires Blackstone Group to advise it on how best to shore up its balance sheet in face of economic downturn (M)

headline: Bush Promises Colombia Help on Trade but Refuses Peace Role
abstract: Pres George W Bush, in his first meeting with Pres Andres Pastrana, agrees to press for expanding trade preferences to Colombia, but refuses request to take part in peace talks between government and Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia rebels (M)

headline: Article 2001021191250682240 -- No Title
abstract: In Tapping the Net, the F.B.I. Insists Privacy Is Not a Victim

headline: DIAL AND HENKEL END THEIR JOINT VENTURE IN MEXICO
abstract: Dial Corp, maker of Dial soap and other products, ends joint venture in Mexico with Henkel of Germany; sells its interest in Mexico partnership to Henkel for $18.9 million (S)

headline: Warming Data:The Threat Can Now Be Tackled
abstract: GENEVA—  Tackling the threat of global warming can be effectively started with existing technologies if governments decide to take action, a group of top climate-change experts says in a final report wrapping up the first comprehensive study of climate change data in five years.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: EBay to Give Users Access To 300 Auction Houses  Ebay, the largest online auction company, will announce an agreement today that will allow users to participate in live auctions at 300 auction houses worldwide.     EBay announced a live auction service last year for buying fine art, wine and other luxury goods through a small number of auction houses. Today's agreement, with icollector, will greatly expand the reach of the live auction initiative and will expose eBay's 22.5 million registered users to those sites. [Page C2.]

headline: Palm Offers 2 Models That Are Built to Grow
abstract: Palm offers two new hand-held computer models, one with full-color screen, that have expansion slot for MultiMedia Cards; MMC's are postage-stamp-size storage devices that contain various programs; photo (M)

headline: Financing an Endurance Film Does Not a Survivor Make
abstract: John J Mack, until recently president of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, had firm put up $3 million for two George Butler films about Sir Ernest Shakleton; photo (S)

headline: Not Museum Pieces, Yemeni Jews Do Their Best to Survive
abstract: Article on plight of Yemen's small community of Jews which totals approximately 300 after waves of immigration; community is doing best to survive in hard place at time when tensions between Jews and Arabs are once again boiling into violence in Gaza Strip and West Bank; maps; photo (M)

headline: Step 1: Grit Teeth. Step 2: Buy Junk Bonds.
abstract: Outlook for investing in junk bonds funds discussed; high-yield bond prices are sinking and default rate is rising, making it hard to value bonds; graphs (M)

headline: CORNING PLANS OPTICAL FIBER PLANT IN OKLAHOMA
abstract: Corning plans to invest about $400 million to build optical fiber plant in Oklahoma City; plans to increase its fiber manufacturing capacity by about 25 percent a year from 2002 to 2004 (S)

headline: Charles Helou, 88, President Of Lebanon in Tumult of 60's
abstract: Charles Helou, who was Lebanon's president and head of state from 1964 to 1970, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline: Felipe Pazos, 88, Economist; Cuban Split Early With Castro
abstract: Felipe Pazos, Cuban economist, dies at age 88 (M)

headline: Japanese Theme Parks Facing Rough Times
abstract: Japanese theme parks are facing rough economic times as government and private industry grapple with immense debt; bankruptcy filing by Phoenix Resort, theme park operator, has cast harsh spotlight on problems in what Japan calls its third sector, enterprises partly owned by local governments; potential fallout could badly set back efforts to clean up Japan's anemic public finances and its floundering banking industry; Seagaia, which runs park in Miyazaki that includes indoor beach, is only one of hundreds of third-sector enterprises reeling from financial difficulties; there are 6,794 corporations in Japan in which municipal body holds stake of 25 percent or greater; pressure to step up leisure spending, coupled with success of Tokyo Disneyland, touched off boom in park building; new theme parks will be opening despite financial problems at others; Universal Studio park will open in Osaka on March 31; photo (M)

headline: In a wee bit of a stretch, not-so-Irish marketers jump on the St. Patrick's Day bandwagon.
abstract: Bernard Stamler column on ad campaigns for Irish and faux Irish products that appear around St Patrick's Day; says even cities that are decidely un-Irish--like Rome and Tokyo, where recent ads for Jameson Irish whiskey are set--can sometimes be focus of St Patrick's Day advertising; photo (M)

headline: Auditing Panel Approves New Rules on Circulation
abstract: Audit Bureau of Circulations makes final new system governing how newspapers measure and report their circulations to advertisers, overwhelmingly ratifying procedures that will give advertisers more information about who is buying newspaper and giving publishers more latitude in counting discounted copies as paid circulation (M)

headline: Bomb Explodes in Van, Killing Man in Israel
abstract: Taxi van explodes in northern Israel after police stop it at roadblock during search for terror suspect; one passenger is killed and nine others wounded; police suspect Palestinian passenger, who lost both legs in explosion, of planting bomb; photo (M)

headline: DopeWars Game Offers Furtive Thrills as It Raises Hackles
abstract: THE person sitting next to you on the subway or train — the one who seems to be busily rearranging a business calendar on a hand-held computer — could very well be selling crack, buying Ecstasy and getting tips on heroin prices.

headline: China's Prime Minister Pledges to Promote Private Enterprise
abstract: Beijing, March 5 - Prime Minister Zhu Rongji unveiled China's 10th Five-Year Plan today, promising that the country would forge ahead with the introduction of market forces and private enterprise. He said the Government would continue its program of large-scale investment's in the country's infrastructure and other forms of economic stimulus. He also predicted an annual growth rate of 7 percent in the years ahead, somewhat lower than in the previous five years.

headline: EXECUTIVE IS PROMOTED TO CHAIRMAN AND CHIEF AT CNBC
abstract: General Electric Co promotes Bill Bolster, president of its CNBC financial news channel, to newly created position of chairman and chief executive of unit; also announces promotion of Pamela Thomas-Graham to president and chief operating officer of CNBC (S)

headline: TLC Laser Expects A Better 3rd Quarter
abstract: TLC Laser Eye Centers Inc forecasts better-than-expected results for its fiscal third quarter, saying fewer customers are using discount competitors to correct their vision (S)

headline: What Will Deal Mean? Depends on Destination
abstract: American Airlines is set to announce that it will take over Trans World Airlines and also buy about one-fifth of US Airways; United Airlines is seeking government approval to buy remainder of US Airways' assets; if deals come to pass, TWA and US Airways will disappear, and American and United will become major presence in Northeast; Caribbean could find itself with less competition and country's most conveniently situated hub--St Louis--will pass from hands of limping airline to sprawling global one; photo (M)

headline: Despite Strong Sales, Dell Warns of Lower-Than-Expected Earnings
abstract: Dell Computer warns that earnings will miss its estimates for current quarter despite sales growth that quadrupled average for personal computer industry; Dell blames economic slowdown and dwindling demand for personal computers; Dataquest says Compaq Computer continues to hold top spot in worldwide personal computer sales, with 12.4 percent of market; Compaq's lead over Dell dwindled because its sales increased by only 1.5 percent from previous year; Dell, with 11.3 percent of market, grew 41 percent; Hewlett-Packard, which grew 18 percent, remains in third place with 7.7 percent; IBM is in fourth place; sales slowed 5 percent for NEC and 9 percent for Gateway, which hold fourth and fifth places; photo (M)

headline: Helping New Workers Look the Part
abstract: Dress for Success, four-year-old nonprofit organization in New York City, provides free clothing to low-income women entering or re-entering work force; to qualify for free clothing, woman needs referral from any of array of nonprofit organizations, including homeless shelters and job-readiness programs; all clients receive clothes before interview; after landing job, they receive work-appropriate outfits, so their first-year salary is not drained by building wardrobe; clothing is acquired in annual clothing drive, and in donations from apparel companies; photo (M)

headline: LOUDCLOUD, INTERNET CONSULTANT, GAINS ON DEBUT DAY
abstract: Shares of Loudcloud Inc rise on their first trading day; asking price was reduced twice prior to initial offering (S)

headline: EUROPE APPROVES STRICT FOOD RULES
abstract: European Union Parliament passes measure establishing strict rules on genetically modified organisms, preparing to end Europe's unofficial moratorium on bioengineered seeds and food; strictness of new controls is intended to respond to intense suspicions about genetically modified foods; rules govern testing, planting and sale of crops and food for humans and animals and testing and sale of pharmaceuticals; all genetically altered products will be tracked in database that will also mark locations of all crops; separate bill to set tough food labeling and tracing requirements is to be ready by April, and is widely expected to pass in some form; under European Union law, all 15 member countries are required to make their laws conform to new rules in 18 months; governments of France and Denmark say they would resist approvals; defying laws would open countries to suit in European Court of Justice to force compliance (M)

headline: Article 2001013094090021560 -- No Title
abstract: Mining the 'Deep Web' With Specialized Drills

headline: DUTCH COMPANY BUYS AMEX SPECIALIST AND MARKET MAKER
abstract: Van der Moolen Holding to buy 51 percent of Cohen, Duffy, McGowan & Co, market specialist and market maker on American Stock Exchange (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy Will Try to Forge a Common Position, Israeli Says
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak says American envoy Dennis Ross will seek common ground for statement on peace negotiations that could be issued by Pres Clinton before he leaves office; Palestinians issue position paper rejecting option of signing broad declaration of principles; also disagree with Israeli report that two sides have accepted security plan drawn up by CIA Dir George J Tenet (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Slumping Sales in Europe To Hurt McDonald's Profit  McDonald's said that its first-quarter earnings would fall more than expected because of slumping sales in Europe, where consumers scared of mad cow disease are buying fewer hamburgers.    For the quarter, McDonald's expects to earn 29 to 30 cents a share, down from 33 cents in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected McDonald's to earn 32 cents. In addition to its problems in Europe, McDonald's said its first-quarter results would be hurt by the rise in the value of the dollar. [Page C4.]

headline: The DopeWars Fantasy
abstract: Gary L Adler letter on Mar 15 article cites reasons for popularity of DopeWars computer game

headline: E-Commerce Report; A report indicates that companies see little reason to move quickly into buying over the Internet.
abstract: Jupiter Research study finds that procurement managers see so little advantage in doing business online that nearly half of those surveyed expected to do less than 20 percent of their procurement online for at least the next two years; main reason is that most companies' existing suppliers are not yet on Web; purchasing managers are also reluctant to learn how to use various intranet and Internet sites that sell to corporations and do not necessarily trust those sites to deliver critically important goods on time (M)

headline: Bus Driver Who Killed 8 Israelis Says in Court That He Isn't Sorry
abstract: Khalid Abu Elba, Palestinian bus driver who ran over and killed eight Israelis last month, says at court hearing that he is not sorry, and that he acted intentionally to avenge deaths of Palestinians at hands of Israeli troops; he had full security clearance to work inside Israel for bus company, driving Palestinian laborers from checkpoint in Gaza to their jobs inside Israel; he is charged with murdering eight people, seven of them soldiers (M)

headline: MEDIA: New Risks and Venues Emerge in a Multifaceted Business; Can a Name Give McCall's A New Image?
abstract: Magazine industry has doubts about whether Rosie O'Donnell will be able to revive McCall's magazine; Gruner & Jahr publication is being renamed Rosie's McCall's; photo (S)

headline: People
abstract: Mark Gault, executive vice president and director for worldwide accounts at McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, is named regional director at McCann-Erickson North America, succeeding Tony Miller, who is named to new post of vice chairman at sibling, World Group Marketing Communications; Stephen Carlis, president of Shooting Gallery, is resigning; no successor is named; Chip Sleeper is named to new post of executive director at Blue Dingo/GB; Marcy Q Samet, managing director at Gillespie, is named executive vice president and managing director; Mike Edelstein and Tom McManimon are named managing partners (S)

headline: Tissue Tied to Mad Cow Is Found in Some Beef From the Continent : Risky Meat In Imports Angers U.K. Farmers
abstract: PARIS—  British farmers, long used to seeing their beef banned in Europe, reacted angrily Friday to findings that meat imports from Germany and the Netherlands contained material most at risk from mad cow disease, and a leading agriculture spokesman in Brussels termed the fact "criminal."

headline: Death Toll in the Kosovo Bomb Attack on Serbs Rises to 11
abstract: British peacekeepers and United Nations police say 11 people including baby died in bomb blast, Podujevo, that destroyed bus full of Serbs escorted into Kosovo by Swedish peacekeepers; say two others are missing and dozens hurt; attack raises tensions across Kosovo and sets back return of any Serbian refugees; most Albanians express weariness at violence and shame at terrorism; map; photo (M)

headline: German Foreign Minister Gives Testimony in Murder Trial
abstract: FRANKFURT, Jan. 16 - In a courthouse here, Germany confronted a critical chapter of its postwar history today as Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer testified at the trial of an accused terrorist who was once Mr. Fischer's comrade in revolutionary struggle.

headline: FINNISH PHONE COMPANY SLIPS
abstract: Shares of Sonera Oyj, Finland's biggest telephone operator, fall 11 percent one day after government used its position as majority shareholder to dismiss most of its board (S)

headline: Bush Calls for End to Mideast Bloodshed
abstract: WASHINGTON, March 29 — President Bush called on both sides today to end the bloodshed in the Middle East and said the United States stands ready to help achieve a peace. But he reiterated his stance that America cannot impose peace conditions on the region.

headline: Article 2001011192427999990 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Sri Lanka Restarts Drive on Rebels at Crucial Pass
abstract: Hopes that cease-fire by rebels in Sri Lanka would quickly revive a moribund peace effort seem to fade this week as government mounts major offensive to recapture a strategic spit of land (M)

headline: AIRLINE IN BANKRUPTCY SAYS NEW MONEY HAS NOT ARRIVED
abstract: Legend Airlines Inc, start-up carrier that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in December 2000, says Legend Funding Group has not fulfilled promise to provide $20 million to help it restart operations; Legend Funding Group says it is still working to provide funds for carrier (S)

headline: No More Store Mirrors
abstract: Carrie Gray letter responds to March 1 Online Shopper column on buying bathing suits online

headline: Taiwan's Top Court Decides Halting A-Plant Was Improper
abstract: Taiwan's high court rules government of Pres Chen Shui-bian acted improperly in halting building of nuclear power plant begun by his Nationalist predecessors; says government should have sought approval of Nationalist-controlled legislature; $5.5 billion project has come to symbolize rift between long-dominant Nationalists and Chen's party, which ousted them from presidency in 2000 (M)

headline: A Joke About Sprouts Leaves a Bitter Taste
abstract: Thomas Cook advertisement featuring plateful of brussels sprouts as reason to flee Britain angers sprout growers (S)

headline: Mr. Goodwrench Meets His Match
abstract: Jiffy Lube International hires Faith Popcorn to make its services more friendly toward females (S)

headline: Missing the Mark in 2000, Stocks Look for a Steadying Hand Ahead
abstract: Investors are focused on Federal Reserve to lift stock markets by reviving economy; investors are happy to be rid of stock market 2000; all broad market indexes ended year in negative territory, but indexes most heavily weighted toward technology fared worst; Dow Jones industrial average lost 6.2 percent compared with 10.1 percent decline in Standard & Poor's 500 index and 39.3 percent drop in Nasdaq composite; graphs; charts; drawing (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Lawrence R. Creatura; Clover Small Cap Value Fund
abstract: Carole Gould column profiles Clover Small Cap Value fund, stock mutual fund offered by Clover Capital Management, and its manager, Lawrence R Creatura; funds will be renamed to reflect Clover's alliance with Turner Investment Partners; photo; chart (M)

headline: Mexican Jail Easy to Flee: Just Pay Up
abstract: Cocaine trafficker Joaquin Guzman apparently bribes way out of maximum security Puente Grande prison in Mexico City while serving 20-year sentence, angering new Pres Vicente Fox and security chief Alejandro Gertz Manero and underscoring how nation's laws can be bent with fistful of money (M)

headline: Ellen Hammer, 79; Historian Wrote on French in Indochina
abstract: Ellen J Hammer, historian who wrote about Indochina and Vietnam before Vietnam War, dies at age 79 (M)

headline: 3 Oil Companies Say Earnings Soared in 4th Quarter
abstract: Exxon Mobil, Chevron Corp and Texaco Inc say earnings soared in fourth quarter; Exxon Mobil says net income more than doubled, to $5.2 billion from $2.3 billion in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose more than 17 percent, to $64.1 billion; company earned $17.7 billion for all of 2000, more than double $7.9 billion it made for all of 1999; Chevron reports net income of $1.49 billion compared with $809 million year earlier; earnings reached $1.54 billion, excluding charges; revenue rose 23 percent, to $13.52 billion, from $10.98 billion; Texaco reports net income of $545 million, up from $318 million; company earned $840 million compared with $370 million year ago; revenue increased 36 percent, to $14.4 billion, from $10.6 billion in 1999 period (M)

headline: Article 2001021793217805290 -- No Title
abstract: Teenagers Try Online Learning
