headline: Lernout Is Restarting Talks With Daimler on Sale of Unit
abstract: Belgian software maker Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products is about to reopen discussions with DaimlerChrysler about sale of its automotive software unit (M)

headline: Consolidation Set For Guinness Stout
abstract: Guinness unit of Diageo will consolidate worldwide creative duties for its Guinness stout brand at two of its roster ad agencies, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO in London and Saatchi & Saatchi in London; worldwide spending is estimated at more than $300 million (S)

headline: SWEDISH BANKING MERGER
abstract: SEB AB merges with Swedbank in stock swap valued at roughly $7.4 billion; SEB shareholders will own 51.5 percent of new entity, to be called SEB Swedbank (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GARDEN BOTANIKA INC., Redmond, Wash., a personal-care products company, said it would close all of its 109 stores, lay off 65 workers and seek to sell its trademarks, Web site and other assets to an undisclosed party. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April 1999.

headline: Bankruptcy Bill Tightens Rules For Businesses
abstract: Bankruptcy bill passed by US Senate sets new rules for corporations that would give faltering businesses less time to settle their debts and reorganize and could force more small companies out of business; critics say result may be loss of jobs at time when employment outlook is already weakening; bill would define small businesses as companies with debts of $3 million or less; such companies account for more than 80 percent of 9,000 companies that filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of bankruptcy code last year (M)

headline: P.& G. Suit Against Amway Is Revived
abstract: Federal appeals court panel resurrects suit Procter & Gamble filed against Amway for allegedly spreading rumor that Procter & Gamble has ties to Satanism and that a lot of company's profits go to Church of Satan; Amway says case is about freedom of speech and effort by Procter & Gamble to make company and its distributors scapegoats for rumor that has persisted both within and outside Amway network (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: NEWELL RUBBERMAID, Freeport, Ill., appointed Brian Schnabel to be the group president for its children's products division, succeeding Richard Dell, who resigned the position last month. Mr. Schnabel had been the chief operating officer at TrueValue.    VIGNETTE CORP., Austin, Tex., appointed Thomas Hogan to be president and chief operating officer. As president, he will succeed Greg Peters, who continues to be chairman and chief executive. Mr. Hogan had been the senior vice president for worldwide sales and operations at Siebel Systems.

headline: Article 2001021990918698780 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Bridgestone President Announces Resignation
abstract: TOKYO, Jan. 11 - The president and chief executive of the Bridgestone Corporation, parent of the tire maker that was linked to scores of fatal car accidents in the United States, said today that he would resign in March after eight years in the top post at the Japanese company.

headline: FLEXTRONICS BUYS COMPONENTS MAKERS
abstract: Flextronics plans to announce acquisition of Wave Optics and Fico Fiber Optics (S)

headline: LOW-INCOME WEB SURFERS PROLIFERATE
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings reports that number of home Web users with annual incomes of less than $25,000 a year rose 46 percent, to 6.3 million in February 2001, compared with 4.3 million year earlier; those earning $50,000 to $74,999 had second-highest rate of increase during year, up 42 percent to 30.4 million in February 2001 (S)

headline: High on Attitude, Boots Kick Up a Storm
abstract: MILAN—  From ruched boots to flat, razor-sharp ankle boots to sassy thigh-length ones, there's no getting away from this season's hottest accessory, for just about every international ready-to-wear designer from New York to Milan is putting the boot into fashion.

headline: Article 2001032290426953390 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Queen Elizabeth National Park Journal; Grumpy and Big Eaters, Refugees Are Welcomed
abstract: Uganda's Queen Elizabeth National Park has become haven for approximately 100 elephants fleeing civil war in neighboring Congo; animals have been welcomed in country where wildlife is only hope for reviving seriously slumping tourist trade; map; photos (M)

headline: Bad Times for I.P.O. Funds
abstract: Mutual funds that invest in initial public offerings suffer major losses in value (M)

headline: In Move Toward Peace, Singing Ugandan Soldiers Leave Congo
abstract: Hundreds of Ugandan soldiers prepare to leave Congo after two years, part of larger effort to ease tensions in country by moving soldiers away from each other; nearly all combatants in war in Congo say they are observing deadline to begin moving troops back almost 10 miles from front line; Congolese government and its chief military supporter, Zimbabwe, say they began pullback, paving way for 3,000-strong United Nations peacekeeping force (M)

headline: REPORT DETAILS ONLINE FRAUD
abstract: Internet Fraud Complaint Center report says online auction fraud leads list of complaints center referred to law enforcement agencies during its first six months of operation; of 20,014 complaints center received between May 8 and Nov 8, 2000, 6,087 were referred to enforcement agencies across country for further investigation; of those referrals, 64.1 percent involved auction fraud, 22 percent involved problems with nondelivery of merchandise or payment, and nearly 5 percent involved credit and debit fraud; center is operated by FBI and National White Collar Crime Center (S)

headline: Article 2001012994031464190 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: TRADE PANEL TO EXAMINE BRAZILIAN LAW
abstract: World Trade Organization agrees to examine US complaint that Brazil's 1997 patent law discriminates against imported products (S)

headline: Stocks End Higher on Hopes of Economic Turnaround
abstract: Technology stocks rose today as investors were unfazed for now by new corporate profit warnings and a dour economic outlook.

headline: Blair Confidant's Slip Gives an Old Party Rival Running Room
abstract: Resignation of Peter Mandelson, closest confidant of Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain, places extraordinary powers with Chancellor of Exchequer Gordon Brown; Mandelson has been only man who challenged Brown for Blair's allegiance, but relationship between Blair and Brown has been marked by irritations (M)

headline: Beijing Is Given an Olympian Burnish
abstract: Chinese authorities in Beijing sweep streets, give taxi drivers crash course in English phrases and generally burnish city in preparation for inspection by technical delegation from International Olympic Committee; photo (M)

headline: RAILWAY TO SELL HEALTH UNIT
abstract: Deutsche Bahn, Germany's state-owned railway, is seeking buyer for its health careunit, DB GesundheitsService, whose doctors, nurses and technicians treat 240,000 railroad workers at 68 locations; sale is part of railway's plan to slim down to its core business, go public and break even by 2005 (S)

headline: FEDERAL-MOGUL IS EXPECTING A WIDER LOSS
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp, leading maker of automotive engine bearings and seals, says first quarter loss will be wider than forecast because of lower production of cars and trucks reduced demand (S)

headline: Checking the Doctor List
abstract: Letter from Larry Gelb, president of CareCounsel, comments on March 4 article on difficulty of ascertaining whether hospital physicians are affiliated with one's health insurance plan

headline: Treasury to Sell Bills and Note
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a two-year note being auctioned on Wednesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.81 percent, and the six-month issue was 4.73 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 4.67 percent.

headline: Warrior Who Confounds -- Ariel Sharon
abstract: Man in the News profile of Ariel Sharon, 72-year-old veteran soldier and controversial political figure now elected to lead Israel; photos (M)

headline: Member Agencies Acquire Consortium
abstract: Worldwide Partners, consortium of 81 independent advertising agencies, is acquired by its member agencies (S)

headline: Icon MediaLab Will Sell a Unit
abstract: Icon MediaLab International in Stockholm, Internet consulting company that has Interpublic Group of Companies as substantial minority shareholder, will sell its BrandLab consulting unit to FutureBrand, division of Interpublic (S)

headline: On Way to Inauguration, A Putin Ally Lands in Jail
abstract: Pavel P Borodin, prominent Russian government official accused of taking millions of dollars in kickbacks from Swiss companies, appears in federal court in Brooklyn on Swiss arrest warrant; he had been picked up at Kennedy International Airport on his way to inauguration of George W Bush; Borodin is close associate of both Pres Vladimir V Putin and former Pres Boris Yeltsin; photo; case reviewed (M)

headline: INTEL AGREES TO ACQUIRE XIRCOM
abstract: Intel Corp will buy Xircom Inc, maker of networking devices for laptop computers and mobile devices, for about $748 million in cash; Xircom will become subsidiary of Intel; Xircom also announces quarterly earnings of one cent per share for quarter ended Dec 31, compared with 55 cents during period year earlier; revenue was $120.1 million, compared with $124.1 million year earlier (S)

headline: Armstrong Sales Fall
abstract: Armstrong Holdings says sales fell 8.8 percent in fourth quarter, to $659.1 million; operating loss of $86.7 million compares with loss of $185.9 million a year earlier; E Follin Smith resigns as chief financial officer and is replaced by Leonard Campanaro (S)

headline: More to Messages
abstract: Donna C Moss letter responds to Feb 22 article concerning finding help online for message boards

headline: Missing Fugitive Delays French Corruption Trial
abstract: Multimillion-dollar corruption trial of former French foreign minister, Roland Dumas, is again postponed to await extradition from Germany of Alfred Sivren, fugitive oil executive involved in case who once bragged he knew enough secrets to bring down republic 20 times (S)

headline: Gene Research Finds New Use In Agriculture
abstract: Scientists, amid intensifying controversy surrounding genetically modified foods, are trying to use rapidly growing knowledge about genes to enhance conventional breeding of crops and livestock rather than implant genes from one species into another; many say such an approach is less likely to arouse the public objections that have been raised by development of genetically altered plants and animals; enchanced breeding approach involves testing which genes are in plant or animal, allowing researchers to select more easily which ones to cross and shaving years of breeding of new variety; photo (M)

headline: Turning to eBay as a Cure for Auction Fever
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on eBay's new online service that allows bidders to participate, in real time, in auctions held in 300 auction houses worldwide, which offer authenticity and assurances not provided by eBay's regular online auctions; service, called eBay Great Collections Live Auctions, charges successful bidders a 15 percent premium beyond their bids; drawing (M)

headline: S.E.C. Approves Nasdaq Quote Display Plan
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission approves Nasdaq stock market's plan to centralize display of its best stock quotes, overriding opposition from automated trading networks that compete with it; SuperMontage plan will make three best customer orders for each stock more visible to investors on Nasdaq; vote is limited victory for SEC chairman, Arthur Levitt, who has fought long battle to get securities industry to increase price competition by centralizing US stock trading (M)

headline: One Club to Induct 2 Into Hall of Fame
abstract: One Club for Art and Copy will induct David Abbott, former chairman and creative director at Abbott Mead Vicker BBDO and Harry Jacobs, chairman emeritus at Martin Agency, into its Creative Hall of Fame (S)

headline: Broad Cuts at Lucent Include 10,000 Jobs
abstract: Lucent Technologies, one of the world's biggest makers of communications equipment, announced a broad reorganization that includes eliminating 10,000 jobs, about 9.4 percent of its workers. Fifteen hundred of those are to be in New Jersey, where the company employs 17,000 people. Throughout Lucent, many cuts will come in overlapping sales and marketing groups.    The plan, which includes a charge of at least $1.2 billion, is meant to help the company climb back to the top of the digital economy after a series of damaging missteps.

headline: Labor Market Remains Tight, Despite Slowing Economy
abstract: Labor Department reports unemployment rate held steady at 4 percent in December 2000, suggesting slowing economy has done little to weaken tightest labor market in 30 years; even as manufacturing companies cut both jobs and workers' hours during month, companies in much larger service sector continued to add to record-high payrolls; graphs (M)

headline: Excerpts From Bush News Conference
abstract: Excerpts from news conference by Pres-elect George W Bush after meeting with business executives in Austin, Tex

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Fort Dearborn Income Secs Inc  Genuine Parts Co

headline: Losing Bidder Asks Japan For Details on Sale of Bank
abstract: Pasona Softbank, temporary employment service that was one of bidders for failed Tokyo Sowa Bank, is asking Japanese government to clarify its decision to sell bank to Lone Star Group; Pasona Softbank says its bid would have cost taxpayers less than 702 billion yen ($5.94 billion) government plans to inject into bank to clean up its balance sheet as part of its deal with Lone Star; Hakuo Yanagisawa, head of Financial Services Ministry, has stressed that bids for failed banks will be judged mainly by how much public money they require (M)

headline: Provider and Delivery Service Skip Step in Online Promotions
abstract: People who get their high-speed Internet service through Speakeasy Networks receive movie-rental discounts and free deliveries from Kozmo.com under a promotion that dispenses with coupons and does not even require them to type in a promotional code when they order a delivery online; Kozmo.com recognizes them as Speakeasy subscribers by their Internet protocol, or IP, numbers and makes discounts available (M)

headline: Media Talk; A Special Section for the Zoo Trade
abstract: Washington Post plans special section on arrival of two new pandas at National Zoo; photo (M)

headline: Bush Aides Debate Ways To Press China Over Rights
abstract: Bush administration is debating how hard to press China on human rights; it may drop condemnation of China at annual human rights meeting next month in preference for what some see as more pragmatic approach to extracting reforms from Chinese; Chinese government has offered number of inducements to persuade Washington to drop traditional resolution, including ratification of United Nations rights convenant (M)

headline: Soul-Searching As a Power Pursuit
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney hires Ari Kiev, psychiatrist and author of Trading to Win: The Psychology of Mastering the Market, to advise its traders (M)

headline: New Economy; Yahoo charts the spread of the news by e-mail, and what it finds out is itself becoming news.
abstract: Yahoo News feature that tracks items most frequently forwarded by readers of its Internet news site to others via e-mail has become something of cult favorite among heavy consumers of news; most e-mailed stories tend toward quirky and bizarre; items favored in most-viewed list, another feature, tend to be breaking news; photos (M)

headline: At Iraq's Backdoor, Turkey Flouts Sanctions
abstract: Turkey openly flouts United Nations economic embargo against Iraq; sanctions-busting smuggling is regulated and taxed by Turkish government and tolerated by UN and United States; estimates on volume of Iraqi oil and diesel fuel passing through Habur, Turkey, only legal crossing betwen Iraq and Turkey, range from $300 million to $600 million a year; western diplomats calculate that illicit business puts $120 million a year in pocket of Pres Saddam Hussein; western diplomats justify turning blind eye because money helps battered economy in battered region of Turkey, an American ally; trade also is chief source of income for northern Iraq's Kurdistan Democratic Party, which opposes Hussein; but there is no way to monitor how Hussein spends money he makes from trade, and whether he uses it to buy arms; situation underscores quandary confronting Bush administration as it shapes its sanctions policy; photos (M)

headline: Punta del Este Journal; As Elite Resort Slumps, Argentina Doesn't Cry
abstract: Punta del Este, resort area in Uruguay known throughout Latin America as playground of Argentine rich and of European royalty, is in slump because of two-year-old recession gripping Argentina; crisis is product of long-term social trends as well as five years of generally mediocre economic performance in Argentina; wealthy and upper-middle-class Argentine families once took month of two off in Punta as matter of recreation and prestige, but currently take shorter vacations; with overvalued peso pegged to strong dollar, they increasingly go to Europe, US and Brazil; map; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Memo on Clinton's Role: Some Angry Words
abstract: Excerpts from memorandum issued by Palestinian Media Center criticizing role of Clinton administration in Middle East peace talks (M)

headline: TRUCKING COMPANY LAYS OFF ANOTHER 160 EMPLOYEES
abstract: Yellow Corp, trucking company, lays off 160 managers, or about 4 percent of its executive work force, because demand has slowed (S)

headline: Jobs Report and Intel Woes Send Stocks Down Sharply
abstract: Stocks fell sharply today, erasing their gains from earlier in the week, as investors' hopes for another aggressive interest-rate cut were shaken by the surprisingly mild weakness in February's employment report.

headline: CONTAINER MAKER TO CLOSE PLANTS AND ELIMINATE JOBS
abstract: Sonoco Products Co, which makes containers for food and consumer products, plans to cut 487 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force, and close some plants to reduce costs (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar surges against euro after surprise interest rate cut eases concern economy is headed for recession; euro settles at 92.85 cents, down from 95.03 cents in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: KAZAKH TEST WELL
abstract: International consortium developing Kashagan oil field in Caspian Sea off Kazakhstan finds hydrocarbons in exploratory well, which analysts say tends to support estimates that field might be among biggest found in decades, with reserves up to 50 billion barrels (S)

headline: Satellite Collaboration May Lead to Merger
abstract: Craig O McCaw has recruited Ellipso, satellite communications start-up company, into his plan to use satellites to provide voice and data services to customers beyond reach of land-based communications networks; ICO-Teledesic Global, McCaw's holding company, says it will help Ellipso find solutions to technical, regulatory, financial and commercial problems; collaboration could lead to merger (S)

headline: Toll of Ethnic Violence in Indonesia Reaches 200
abstract: Ethnic violence continues in Indonesian section of Borneo, with death toll rising to at least 200 in six days of fighting between indigenous Dayak tribesman and Madurese migrants; thousands of Madurese have been relocated to Borneo under government program, now abandoned, to reduce overcrowding in heavily populated areas; resettling proved recipe for disaster; photo (M)

headline: PLANE MAKER'S PROFIT GROWS
abstract: Brazilian jet-maker Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica reports 2000 net profit of $300 million, 57 percent above 1999 results (S)

headline: SIEMENS BUYING MODEM MAKER
abstract: Siemens AG strengthens its position in high-speed Internet business in US with agreement to acquire Efficient Networks, large maker of modems for fast Internet connections, for $1.5 billion in cash; photo (S)

headline: Beijing, Turning Tables, Defends Its Repression of Sect
abstract: Chinese government lashes out at critics of its harsh crackdown on Falun Gong spiritual movement, making strenuous new efforts to paint group as evil and murderous, and accusing the United States and other critics of harboring 'ulterior motives'; government also responds angrily to State Department report that condemned China's human rights record in 2000; Mary Robinson, United Nations commissioner for human rights who is visiting China, says officials have indicated that government may ratify UN Covenant of Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (M)

headline: A Foiled Plot by Terrorists Was Aimed at Hundreds of Victims
abstract: After weeks of advanced training in explosives at one of Osama bin Laden's Afghan camps, Raed Hijazi, a onetime Boston cab driver, was ready for his mission. The chemicals for the explosives were stockpiled. The targets were selected, the homemade detonators wired.

headline: Merger Over, The New AOL Will Lay Off 2,000 Workers
abstract: Newly combined AOL Time Warner begins series of steps meant to streamline company's far-flung operations, including elimination of at least 2,000 jobs; job cuts, representing slightly more than 2 percent of company's 85,000 workers, comes less than two weeks after America Online's acquisition of Time Warner; cuts come atop 400 jobs company said last week that it would eliminate at its cable news network, CNN; AOL Time Warner also intends to shut down or sell its 130 Warner Brothers retail stores; if stores are sold, roughly 3,800 employees who work in them will become employees of another company; if stores are simply shut, those jobs will be eliminated; Richard D Parsons and Robert W Pittman, company's co-chief operating officers, say 2,025 jobs cuts will come from units that include America Online Internet operation, New Line Cinema film studio, Time Inc magazine company and Warner Music Group, as well as company's headquarters; Shelby Coffey 3d, president of CNNfn financial news network, and Bob Furnad, president of CNN's Headline news network, announce their resignations; Teya Ryan, deputy to Coffey, is taking over Headline News, and Ken Jautz, who has been running n-tv news network in Germany, is taking over CNNfn; New Line Cinema's president Michael De Luca has resigned and been succeeded by Toby Emmerich, head of New Line's music division; Parsons and Pittman say almost all of AOL Time Warner's remaining employees will be given stock options in one-time move meant to give workers feeling of responsibility for new company; company has essentially shut down Entertaindom.com show business Web site, merging it into Warner Brothers' other on-line operations and eliminating about 100 jobs out of 11,000 total at Warner Brothers; about 100 employees at Manhattan headquarters have been let go; photos (M)

headline: The Issues; For Internet Wagers, Shifting Legal and Financial Ground
abstract: Legal, political and financial issues involved in Internet gambling are in state of flux; established casino operators are embracing it after initially arguing it should be illegal; some banks will not allow their credit cards to be used for online gambling because collection of gambling debts cannot be enforced in most states (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DB EVENTURES INC., London, a venture-capital unit of Deutsche Bank, said it had led a $14 million investment in Gilian Technologies Inc., Redwood Shores, Calif., a producer of software to make Web sites more secure. The Deutsche unit teamed with Polaris Venture Capital, Ascend Technologies, Evergreen Venture Capital and Chase Capital Corp. to make the investment for an undisclosed minority stake.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices drop on expectations that inventories have rebounded from their lowest level in 27 years; in New York, crude oil for April delivery falls 29 cents, or 1 percent, to $28.13 per barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Gyula Obersovszky, Samizdat Star, Dies at 74
abstract: Gyula Obersovszky, a Hungarian writer and journalist who was prominent in the 1956 revolt against Soviet forces and became an early practitioner of the underground writings known as samizdat, died on Thursday in a Budapest hospital. He was 74, and was being treated for a heart ailment.

headline: Troubles Are Piling Up at Pacific Century

headline: In Unruly Colombia, a Mother's Hope
abstract: Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia arrives in heart of guerrilla-held territory to hold first day of meetings with leader of Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, Manuel Marulanda; Pastrana assures mothers and relatives of 470 soldiers and policemen held by FARC that one of first points he will raise with Marulanda is need for exchange of sick rebels held by government for other ailing soldiers held by guerrillas; FARC has said that it would release 50 or more soldiers and policemen once sick prisoners are exchanged; mothers' movement in Colombia has coalesced to put pressure on government; they believe government places priority on securing release of hostages who are wealthy; photos (M)

headline: New Worries Of Planting Altered Corn

headline: Do-It-Yourself Stock Trades Drop as Fast as the Markets
abstract: Heyday of do-it-yourself investor is over, as customers pained and confused by stunning reversal of paper fortunes return to traditonal brokerage firms that Internet was supposed to make obsolete; firms that specialize in offering fast and cheap stock trades scramble to recast themselves as trustworthy advisers before their customers seek refuge in arms of conventional stockbrokers; advent of electronic trading was supposed to spell doom for old-fashioned brokers; instead, it gradually forced them to change their ways by lowering prices, reducing their emphasis on generating trading commissions and even offering their own online-trading services; photo; chart (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Outlines Huge Spending for the Military

headline: Yoga on the Internet: Finding Inner Peace With Your Keyboard

headline: Equity Shrivels as Homeowners Borrow and Buy
abstract: Millions of American homeowners have borrowed heavily against their homes, often to help support greater spending; Federal Reserve reports that borrowing has been so extensive, in fact, that homeowners, after building up equity through much of 1960's and 1970's, have let their ownership shares deteriorate over last two decades to lowest level on record; borrowing even accelerated in 1990's, helping to explain how Americans easily manged to outspend their incomes thorugh two long economic expansions; graph (L)

headline: Dissecting a Terror Plot From Boston to Amman
abstract: Second of three articles in series Holy Warriors, on global Islamic terrorism, focuses on foiled plot in Jordan, backed by Osama bin Laden, to kill hundreds of Americans, Israelis and other visitors marking dawn of year 2000; officials call plot case study of how bin Laden and his deputies, isolated in Afghanistan, have greatly extended their reach by aiding locally initiated terrorism; say Raed Hijazi, onetime Boston cabdriver of Palestinian origin being retried in case in Jordan, has given them new data on plot and its ties to Osama's Al Qaeda; maps; photos (L)

headline: Digging for Oil; Canada Is Unlocking Petroleum From Sand
abstract: Billions of dollars of oil investments are quietly transforming wilderness of Fort McMurray, Alberta, into what may soon be continent's leading oil producing area north of Gulf of Mexico; within five years, oil flowing south from Alberta's oil sands is expected to surpass current output of one million barrels a day from Alaska's North Slope; by end of decade, two million barrels per day is to be pumped from Alberta into North American pipeline network that stretches from Portland, Ore, to Portland, Me, helping feed market in US that now consumes about 20 million barrels of oil per day; oil companies involved in project include Suncor Energy, Syncrude Canada, Gulf Oil, Exxon Mobil, Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Chevron; map; photos (M)

headline: Bill Gates's Brain Cells, Dressed Down for Action; Pressed to Innovate, Microsoft Relies Again on an Inner Circle

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    AFGHANISTAN: OPPOSITION TAKES CITY -- Bamiyan, a strategic city west of Kabul, has been captured by opposition forces, according to spokesmen for both sides in the conflict. If itcan hold the city, the opposition will deal a major setback to the Taliban militia, which has suffered few battlefield reversals in the past year. Bamiyan was once a bastion for Afghan Shiite Muslims. The Taliban are primarily Sunni.    Barry Bearak (NYT)

headline: German Leader to Brief Bush on New Realities of Europe
abstract: BERLIN, March 28 — A little more than a decade ago, George W. Bush's father played a decisive role in uniting Germany. On Thursday the President will come face to face with the consequences of that act as he meets a buoyant German Chancellor carrying firm, sometimes confrontational, messages from Europe.

headline: BUSINESSMAN IS ATTACKED
abstract: Three masked assailants attack Brian Cass, managing director of Huntingdon Life Sciences, British drug testing firm that has been target of animal rights protesters (S)

headline: China Backs Away From Initial Denial In School Explosion
abstract: Prime Min Zhu Rongji makes highly unusual nationally televised apology to people of China for deadly schoolhouse explosion in rural Jiangxi Province, and softens earlier denials that children at school were making fireworks; says he has ordered high-level investigation; government's attempts to contain conflicting accounts of blast were undermined by citizens' rapidly spreading access to Internet and other information channels and by increasingly self-assertive press; explosion killed 42 people, 38 of them children aged 9 to 11 years old; local government had announced that deranged suicide bomber was responsible for blast; bereaved parents and surviving students unanimously rejected this, saying children were forced to make fireworks at school; attempted media blackout only fueled speculation that there was coverup reaching into central government; photo (M)

headline: Solid Year for Spain's Top Phone Company

headline: Rules Proposed to Eliminate Some Tax Shelter Incentives
abstract: Treasury Department proposes rules to take some of financial incentives away from lawyers, accountants and investment bankers who promote abusive corporate tax shelters and from big companies that use them; proposals would increase likelihood that companies would have to pay penalties when found to have violated tax laws and would prohibit tax shelter advisers from collecting fees contingent on how much they save a company; tax lawyers would also be subject to disciplinary action if they are found to have written opinions approving dubious deals; Treasury officials say corporate tax evasion will continue to flourish without tough new laws, even if proposals are adopted; Treasury Sec Lawrence H Summers says 'abusive tax shelters are the most serious problems in the US tax system' (M)

headline: Berkshire Buys 3 Stakes

Buffett, reported stakes in Mueller Industries, H&R Block Inc. and the Sealed Air Corporation in filings today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.     Shares in Mueller, a maker of copper, brass and aluminum plumbing fixtures based in Memphis, jumped more than 12 percent to $29.75 after Berkshire reported holding 3.2 million shares, or 9.6 percent, of Mueller's common stock.

abstract: Federal Reserve reports consumer borrowing rose $16 billion in January, bringing total to $1.5 trillion, followed by December gain of $7.2 billion; Federal Reserve's beige book report shows record economic expansion finished its 10th year with 'sluggish to modest' growth and declining demand for workers; map (M)

headline: Final Count Has Uganda President Winning 69% of Vote
abstract: Pres Yoweri Museveni sweeps hard-fought elections in Uganda, winning 69.3 percent of vote; his main challenger, Kizza Besigye, takes 27.8 percent and four other candidates split rest; Museveni calls his victory acclamation of 15 years of peaceful rule; Besigye accuses him of extensive cheating and vote rigging; weeks leading up to election were fraught with incidents of violence, disturbing to nation so eager to transcend its turbulent past; photo (M)

headline: GOOGLE GETS DEJA.COM's USENET
abstract: Internet search engine Google acquires Deja.com's Usenet discussion service, as well as related software, domain names, trademarks and other intellectual property (S)

headline: Hague Tribunal Convicts Bosnian Croat for War on Muslims
abstract: UN war crimes tribunal at The Hague convicts former Bosnian Croat leader, Dario Kordic, of playing important role in campaign against Muslim civilians; sentences longtime ally of late Pres Franjo Tudjman to 25 years in prison; also sentences Mario Cerkez, former brigade commander in Bosnia, to 15 years; charges stem from Bosnian Croat offensive against towns in Lasva Valley, where hundreds of people were killed or imprisoned and thousands were expelled (M)

headline: Sharon Orders His First Raid After Bombing
abstract: Israeli helicopter gunships bombard bases and training camps of Yasir Arafat's personal security forces after Palestinian suicide bombing kills two Israeli teenagers in central Israel; this is Prime Min Ariel Sharon's first military response to spate of Palestinian attacks; Sharon, who took office three weeks ago, was elected largely because of his iron-fisted image; pressure on him to retaliate has mounted as Palestinian attacks have escalated; Israeli helicopters bombard security camp of Force 17 presidential guard in Ramallah, and four different Force 17 sites in Gaza Strip; Palestinians report two deaths and 65 injuries; Israeli officials say they believe Force 17 is behind most recent attacks on Israelis; Hamas has claimed responsibility for latest suicide bombing; photo; map (M)

headline: A Turf Fight for the Airwaves; The Military Holds. Wireless Is Hungry. Small Users Worry.

headline: Yugoslavia's Troops Return To Zone Bordering Kosovo

abstract: German manufacturing orders fell 0.9 in November from October, second decline in three months and latest sign that euro zone's economic expansion is slowing; chart (S)

headline: Head of Palestinian TV Slain by Masked Gunmen
abstract: Three masked gunmen shoot and kill Hisham Mikki, director of Palestinian television, at beachfront restaurant in Gaza; Palestinian Authority blames 'collaborators' with Israel, but Israel denies any involvement; hour after killing, Yasir Arafat meets in Cairo with Israeli Foreign Min Shlomo Ben-Ami in attempt to move peace efforts forward; Mikki was associate of Arafat and had office in his headquarters(M)

headline: 'I' Before 'E,' Forever
abstract: Michael L Ronall letter on Mar 15 article deplores Richard L Wade's effort to homogenize English spelling

headline: Article 2001010991241576920 -- No Title
abstract: January 9, 2001

headline: Mbeki Strongly Urges Racial Reconciliation in South Africa
abstract: mbeki strong urges racial reconciliati

headline: REUTERS WILL SELL SHARES IN ITS INSTINET GROUP
abstract: Reuters Group plans to raise as much as $450 million by selling shares in Instinet Group, its electronic securities trading unit that allows investors to trade stocks directly with one another (S)

headline: WESTPOINT STEVENS TO CLOSE PLANT AND CUT 468 JOBS
abstract: WestPoint Stevens Inc, leading maker of bedding and towels, will close plant in Seneca, SC, and cut 468 jobs as it consolidates manufacturing to reduce costs (S)

headline: A Glum Season for Retailers
abstract: Goldman Sachs Index of Retail Sales shows sales at stores open at least one year rose one-tenth of 1 percent in five weeks ended last week of December, compared with same period in 1999; results were most anemic since March 1995, when sales declined 0.1 percent compared with month a year earlier; it was worst December growth since Goldman began keeping track in 1987; investors, counting on lower interest rates to revive consumer spending, are already looking forward to better times; sales figures for specific stores and chains noted; graphs; photos (M)

headline: The Right Thing: An Offer You Can't Refuse. Well, Maybe.
abstract: AGOOD employee is not only hard to find but also hard to keep. With the nation's unemployment rate holding steady at 4 percent — the lowest in more than 30 years — it is no wonder that many employers are having a difficult time tracking down and retaining top talent. But as the offers and counteroffers fly, an ethical question arises: Once you accept a job offer, is it ethical to go back on your word because someone else makes you a better deal?

headline: G.E. Near Deal to Sell Unit To European Satellite Group
abstract: General Electric Co is close to selling its satellite services unit to Societe Europenne des Satellites of Luxembourg for about $5 billion in cash and stock; satellite unit has 15 satellites in orbit that provide television and radio service nationwide (M)

headline: Article 2001030191957150761 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Learning to Manage Managed Care
abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer column on resolving disputes over whether patient's disease is rare enough to require insurance network to pay for outside specialist; details case in which Oxford Health Plans refused to pay for outside specialist for member Joseph Burke; drawing (M)

headline: Article 2001012592941638761 -- No Title
abstract: Mining the 'Deep Web' With Specialized Drills

headline: The Casino on the Desktop; Bettors, Veteran or Novice, Find the Lure of Online Gambling Hard to Resist
abstract: Millions of Americans are gambling online, some to point of addiction; 1,300 or so sites, often based in Caribbean, project look and sounds of actual casinos or betting parlors and offer slot machine, blackjack table or sports book; gamblers take on not only the odds they would face in a real casino, but also risk that online casino may not pay or may fiddle with the odds; photos (M)

headline: Vatican Rebukes a Theologian, but He Says He Can Work On
abstract: Vatican formally rebukes Belgian Jesuit theologian, Rev Jacques Dupuis, over his writings, two years after it began investigation into accusations against him; Dupuis says he can continue his work 'in good conscience'; long and secretive Vatican investigation of Dupuis is latest example of how Pope John Paul II is determined to rein in Catholic theologians who stray from strict doctrinal orthodoxy (M)

headline: Wearing Your Vital Signs on Your Wrist
abstract: Digital Angel monitors wearer's vital signs, reports that information to others and notifies friends or family members of wearer's emergency plight and location; it raises some concerns about privacy and security of medical information (M)

headline: CANADIAN AIRLINE ACQUISITION
abstract: Canada 3000 Inc is offering one share for 2.5 shares of Royal Aviation Inc on Montreal; transaction is valed at 84 million Canadian dollars (S)

headline: UNION ASKS BOEING TO HALT TALKS WITH JAPANESE COMPANY
abstract: Union leaders urge Boeing Co to stop talks with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries over possibility of hiring Mitsubishi to build wings for jumbo jets in Japan (S)

headline: Prudential of Britain to Buy American General
abstract: LONDON, March 12 — In the biggest transatlantic insurance deal ever, Britain's Prudential P.L.C. said today that it had agreed to buy the United States' second largest life insurer, the American General Corporation, in an all-stock deal that it valued at $26.5 billion .

headline: SUEZ GIVES UP ON LIQUIDE
abstract: Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux abandons attempts to combine with Air Liquide Group after second rejection of merger proposal (S)

headline: WESTFIELD AMERICA TRUST TO BUY REST OF U.S. AFFILIATE
abstract: Westfield America Trust Ltd of Australia agrees to buy part of its US shopping mall affiliate, Westfield America Inc, it does not already own for $268 million in cash; will also assume about $452 million of debt (S)

headline: A MAKER OF RAIL CARS REDUCES OUTPUT AND WILL POST LOSS
abstract: Trinity Industries, maker of rail cars, trims its production plan for second time this month and says it will cut jobs and record fiscal fourth-quarter loss because railroads were reducing orders (S)

headline: After Israelis, South Lebanon Remains a Ragged War Zone
abstract: Even though Israeli occupation of southern Lebanon is over, area remains tense and barren battleground for forces outside control of people who live there; rocky landscape, much as it was during 22 years of Israeli control, is littered with unexploded mines and abandoned farms; current military flashpoint is Shabaa Farms, remote and rugged plot of land which stretches along Israeli-Lebanese border and has been under Israeli control since 1967; Lebanese officials have laid claim to land since withdrawal, on grounds that it does not belong to Syria's as Israel claims; UN says issue must be decided between Lebanon and Syria; Lebanon's claim has been used as justification by militia of Hezbollah to maintain its own grip on south; map; photo (M)

headline: Democrats Turn Up Heat on Bush's Conservative Appointments : Senate Confirmation Fight Looms
abstract: WASHINGTON—  President-elect George W. Bush and his congressional allies continued to work through the weekend to put in place an administration and a legislative leadership with strong focus on achieving the goals on which he campaigned, headed by a sweeping tax cut.

headline: BARAK MAY JOIN SHARON'S CABINET AS DEFENSE CHIEF
abstract: Ehud Barak has reportedly agreed to serve as defense minister under Israel's Prime Min-elect Ariel Sharon, right-wing leader who crushed him at polls last week; Barak also tentatively agrees to bring his Labor Party into national unity government with Sharon's Likud Party; this would be victory for Sharon's determined bid to forge stable government; agreement between two men is conditioned on final coalition agreement and endorsement of both parties; if agreement stands, Sharon will be flanked by two Laborites, Barak as defense minister and Shimon Peres as foreign minister; Likud-Labor government creates united Israeli front to take on Israeli-Palestinian crisis; Labor would be backing away from or deferring its peace platform, which Sharon opposes; at same time, Labor politicians would be expected to moderate Sharon's hawkish tendencies; photo (M)

headline: Bearing Gift of Skill, Doctor Takes a Team to India
abstract: Dr Butchi Babu Paidipaty, who was born in India far from where earthquake hit, and has practiced medicine in Livonia, Mich, for many years, has assembled team to fly to India and provide emergency care; those on team will forgo most personal items and fill their bags with medical supplies; photo (M)

headline: Tianjin Journal; For a Fee, This Chinese Firm Will Beg Pardon for Anyone
abstract: Tianjin Apology and Gift Center in Tianjin, China, is offering, for fee, apologies on behalf of people too embarrassed to do so themselves; company is novelty in Chinese culture in which apology is complicated matter; forbidding act, rarely offered or accepted, must be delivered with proper gravity and requires great loss of face; photo; map (M)

headline: APPLE ADDING FEATURES
abstract: Apple Computer chief executive Steven P Jobs announces several new consumer-oriented products, including multihued iMacs, which will have faster processors and ability to both read and write CD's, and faster version of its G4 Cube computer, which will also come with ability to write directly to blank CD's (S)

headline: Former Cendant Executives Charged With Fraud
abstract: Walter A. Forbes, who built a small company into the giant Cendant Corporation, was an active participant in a fraud that resulted in the company reporting more than $500 million in phony profits, the government charged today. The case is the largest accounting fraud ever, with investors having lost $19 billion.

headline: Serbia Arrests Fired Chief Of Feared Secret Police Unit
abstract: Serbia's new government announces arrest of Rade Markovic, former Pres Slobodan Milosevic's feared secret police chief, on suspicion of murder; Serbia's justice minister, Vladan Batic, says government is determined to arrest all criminals, remark seen as signal that Milosevic and other members of his circle may be detained soon; Markovic is suspected of involvement in assassination attempt on opposition leader Vuk Draskovic and in apparently orchestrated car crash in which Draskovic's brother-in-law and three bodyguards were killed in Oct 1999; phto (M)

headline: Napster Planning Fees Starting in Summer
abstract: Napster says it intends to start charging users this summer to exchange music files online; proposes giving $1 billion over five years to record companies, including major record labels that sued it after accusing it of abetting copyright infringement; Napster is contemplating charging users fee between $5.95 and $9.95 to download unlimited number of music files, and may charge additional fee for users who want to transfer files to their own compact disks (M)

headline: INTEREST RATE UNCHANGED IN EUROPE
abstract: European Central Bank keeps interest rates unchanged, leaving key minimum bid rate at 4.75 percent; decision is mainly based on current inflation rates still above 2 percent in euro zone (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CALPINE CORP., San Jose, Calif., an owner and developer of power plants, has signed two contracts valued at up to $8.3 billion to sell electricity to the Department of Water Resources in California for 10 to 20 years.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Hormel Foods Corp

headline: Business Diary: A Name, a Name, Destined for Fame
abstract: In recognition that a spring, a spring is a marvelous thing, next month the Toy Manufacturers of America will induct Betty James, 82, the retired toy maker who gave the Slinky its name, into the Toy Industry Hall of Fame.

headline: Experts Try to Make Missile Shield Plan Palatable to China
abstract: American and Chinese military experts begin exploring ways to make American plans for national missile defense palatable to China and say a compromise may be possible, although it would require near-heretical political steps by leaders in both countries; Pres Bush would have to place clear limits on size of shield and acknowledge China's stature as nuclear power, agreeing, implicitly at least, that China could preserve a capacity to hit back at US with at least a few nuclear bombs, even after suffering a surprise American attack; China would have to move beyond reflexive condemnation and relax hypersecrecy that has surrounded its weapons program, allowing US a clear idea of size and capability of its arsenal, and would have to convince American planners that any nuclear buildup would go only so far and would be keyed to size of American shield (M)

headline: World's Imperiled Shores and Coral Reefs to Get Millions in Aid
abstract: United Nations Foundation, created in 1997 by Ted Turner, is proposing to make its largest grant to date, $10 million, to international campaign to save and restore world's dwindling coral reefs; money would go to alliance of private, academic and intergovernmental groups, International Coral Reef Action Network, led by UN Environment Program; members of network are expected to raise additional $4 million (M)

headline: Repercussions of Risky Debt
abstract: Corporate bond defaults rise in 2000 to their highest level since recession years of 1990 and 1991; Moody's Investors Service analyst David Hamilton estimates that 6 percent of high-yield bonds defaulted in 2000 and predicts rate of 9.1 percent in 2001--or as high as 13 percent if there is recession; graph (S)

headline: Nigeria's Press Bounces Back From Military Rule
abstract: Nigeria's newspapers have re-emerged with return to power of civilian government; at least five new papers have joined about 15 major dailies in last year, sealing victory of vibrant culture over military repression and security Nigeria's standing as West Africa's news media capital; photo (S)

headline: Article 2001022493671225512 -- No Title
abstract: February 24, 2001

headline: I Scream, You Scream: Consumers Vent Over the Net
abstract: Disgruntled consumers turn to Internet to voice their complaints about products and services; sites include Baddealings.com, uGetHeard.com, EComplaints.com, TheComplaintStation.com, and PlanetFeedback.com; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Accuses Former Cendant Chiefs of Fraud
abstract: Walter A Forbes, former chairman of Cendant Corp, and its former vice chairman, E Kirk Shelton, are indicted on charges of being active participants in fraud that resulted in company's reporting more than $500 million in phony profits; Securities and Exchange Commission files civil fraud case against two men; charges, which both deny, contend that fraud went on for more than decade, with company officials systematically altering financial statements to increase profits to impress investors; chronology of events in case, 1976 to present; photo (M)

headline: An Office Field Guide, From A to Zombie
abstract: Workplace has been reshaped, but every office still has familiar collection of people types, and it makes no difference whether business is dot-com or not; types run gamut from office gossip to social zombie; drawings (M)

headline: British Regulators Overturn Interbrew Acquisition of Bass
abstract: LONDON, Jan. 3 - In a decision that will probably curtail the expansion plans of Interbrew S.A. and cost it hundreds of millions of dollars, British regulators overturned the company's $3.5 billion acquisition of Bass Brewers today.

headline: Article 2001031993536722472 -- No Title
abstract: March 16, 2001

headline: BMW picks a shop to introduce its Mini car to the United States.
abstract: BMW of North America names Crispin Porter & Bogusky to handle advertising for reintroduction in US of Mini Cooper, small, sporty automobile; photo (M)

headline: New Cell Phone Batteries Harness the Power of the Sun
abstract: Sunpower Systems combines cell phone lithium-ion battery with solar cell array, permitting full recharging of battery in five hours on a bright day; photo (S)

headline: Hunting bin Laden's Allies, U.S. Extends Net to Europe
abstract: Spurred by growing international alarm about Osama bin Laden's militant networks, the police in Britain and Germany have recently arrested more than a dozen Islamic radicals. American officials say some of those arrested were plotting terrorist attacks in Europe and elsewhere.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Yahoo Warns Of Sharp Drop In Earnings
abstract: Yahoo Inc, facing slowdown in overall economy and devastation among Internet companies, says its profits will fall 10 percent to 30 percent in 2001, sharp reversal from 34 percent growth analysts had expected; says that with $1.7 billion in cash and marketable securities, it has financial strength to make it through slowdown; posts loss of $97.8 million in fourth quarter, in contrast to profit of $37.7 million a year earlier; company earned $80.2 million in quarter, in line with analysts' estimates; Yahoo expects revenue of $220 million to $240 million for current quarter, roughly same as $230 million posted last year; says sales will be $1.2 billion to $1.3 billion for all of 2001 (Market Place column) (M)

headline: DAEWOO TO REOPEN PLANT
abstract: Bankrupt Daewoo Motor says its plant in Pupyong district of Inchon, South Korea, will resume production despite union threats to stop it (S)

headline: 10 Years Later, Hussein Is Firmly in Control
abstract: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Feb. 25 — Ten years ago, Saddam Hussein looked — at least in the view of the American- led military alliance that defeated his forces in Kuwait — every inch a finished man, another discredited dictator heading for the ignominy of history's rubbish heap.

headline: Passing Time on Internet Watching Clocks Go By
abstract: Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago offers selection of 30 clocks on view at its Web site; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Companies Start to Warm Up to Restricted Stock
abstract: Restricted stock is enjoying comeback as form of executive compensation because companies and investors have grown disillusioned with unbridled use of stock options; restricted stock differs from options in that it represents actual ownership in company; executives may contribute to purchase of shares or company may reduce their cash compensation by amount of stock; execuives cannot sell shares for several years, and company must book cost of shares, unlike options, as expense; companies find that executives expect fewer shares than they would stock options, so investors worry less about their stake being diluted (M)

headline: AT&T SELLING WIRELESS STOCK TO REDUCE DEBT
abstract: AT&T Corp will sell about $3 billion of AT&T Wireless stock, instead of distributing it to investors, and will use proceeds to repay its debt; also will delay by one month exchange of its shares for wireless stock that is part of plan to split into three companies and create tracking shares for its consumer long-distance unit (S)

headline: Of Offers and Counteroffers
abstract: Letter from Reg Brown comments on Jan 21 article regarding workers' first accepting and then declining offers of employment

headline: PANAMSAT FORMS INTERNET JOINT VENTURE FOR MEXICO
abstract: PanAmSat Corp forms joint venture with affiliate of Mexican cellular telephone company Grupo Pegaso SA to provide Internet and satellite services in Mexico (S)

headline: It's Not Too Late To Reduce 2000 Taxes
abstract: Article suggests last-minute strategies to cut personal income tax liabilities (M)

headline: After So Many Fantasies, Back to Reality
abstract: Peter Olafson Game Theory column reviews two new computer games, Sudden Strike and America; photos (M)

headline: Ailing Lucent to Eliminate 10,000 Jobs in Restructuring
abstract: Struggling to regain its former glory, Lucent Technologies Inc. announced a broad restructuring plan today that includes eliminating 10,000 jobs, or about 9.4 percent of its workers.

headline: A Popular Port for Computer Users
abstract: Connecting printers, scanners and external storage devices to a computer with a USB (Universal Serial Bus) is much easier than with serial and parallel ports, but USB has compatibility problems with older hardware, and plugging in too many USB devices at the same time can cause a noticeable slowdown; USB Implementer's Forum, a trade organized that promotes USB, has created a testing program to make sure that new products meet certain specifications; computers and peripherals with the faster USB 2.0 will be on the market later this year; photos (M)

headline: KOREAN AIRPORT OPENS
abstract: Airlines take off for first time at Inchon International Airport in South Korea; Pres Kim Dae Jung hails airport as crucial to country's drive to reach out toward world (S)

headline: Schwab Plans Up to 3,400 Job Cuts
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp, forecasting no rebound in investor sentiment for remainder of 2001, will lay off between 11 and 13 percent of work force; warns first-quarter earnings will fall short of already lowered expectations; cuts will reduce work force of 25,500 by 2,705 to 3,400 (M)

headline: S.E.C. Tells Concerns to Disclose Cancellations of Stock Purchases
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chief accountant Lynn Turner tells Financial Accounting Standards Board panel that companies that let their executives who had exercised stock options early in 2000 rescind that exercise late in year, after stock prices fell, must disclose fact in annual reports and record move as expense that will cut profits; disclosure is likely to surprise outside shareholders and other employees who were not given same chance (M)

headline: Companies Unravel Rice Genome, Providing Model for Grains
abstract: Syngenta and Myriad Genetics unravel genetic code of rice, first commercially important crop to have its genome sequenced; accomplishment is expected to pave way for efforts to improve rice, which serves as staple food for large part of world's population (M)

headline: Recording Group Asks U.S. Court for Tighter Controls on Napster
abstract: Recording Industry Association of America asks federal court to force Napster to tighten filter designed to prevent users from exchanging copyrighted files online; Napster says it is aggressively complying with court order and has significantly cut into exchange of copyrighted files (M)

headline: SHARES PLUNGE AFTER DOT-COM SEEKS PROTECTION
abstract: LetsBuyIt.com NV, Internet company that was granted temporary bankruptcy court protection from creditors in Netherlands just before new year, sees its stock plunge by more than half when trading resumes, closing at 0.54 euro (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY -- None  TUESDAY -- None  WEDNESDAY -- Construction Spending/Nov.    THURSDAY -- Factory Orders/Nov.  Weekly Jobless Claims    FRIDAY -- Unemployment/Dec.  New-Home Sales/Nov.

headline: Belgian Software Maker Said to Have Pact for Rescue Loan
abstract: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products NV, struggling maker of voice-recognition software, reaches preliminary agreement on $60 million in rescue financing from Ableco Finance LLC, affiliate of Cerberus Capital Management (M)

headline: Resignation In Quebec Reflects Split In Nationalism
abstract: Unexpected resignation of Lucien Bouchard as Quebec's premier reflects rift between younger generation of Quebecers, like Bouchard, who are open to French-speaking poeple of immigrant backgrounds and an older generation with strain of xenophobia; Yves Michaud, 70-year-old Parti Quebecois candidate in by-election, recently criticized Jews as being anti-Quebec and 'immigrants,' prompting condemnation from Bouchard (M)

headline: An Escape Hatch in the Dot-Com Dive
abstract: Shares in many dot-com companies may soon trade like Confederate bonds, valued more for their historical significance than their financial worth.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 10 through 12 with 1,124 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 823 are not yet retired.

headline: Radiation From Balkan Bombing Alarms Europe
abstract: Discovery of low-level radiation at 8 of 11 sites visited by United Nations panel sends sense of panic and fury throughout Europe about well-being of soldiers sent to serve in Balkans, more than 12 of whom have died of leukemia; residents of contaminated areas resent that they did not know until now of need to clean up low-level uranium dispersed by American weapons dropped over Bosnia and Yugoslavia; UN panel recommends contaminated areas be quarantined until cleanup is complete; photo; map (M)

headline: Metricom, in Financial Trouble, Warns of Shutdown
abstract: Metricom's market capitalization drops 44 percent after company, provider of high-speed wireless networks, announces disappointing subscription rates and says it will shut down in second half of year if it fails to secure more financing; announces plans to cut costs, including unspecified number of layoffs and halt to its expansion in smaller markets; says it lost $114.4 million in fourth quarter, compared with loss of $56.3 million year before; revenue was $2.4 million, down from $4.9 million (M)

headline: DANA IS BUILDING A TEXAS PLANT TO SUPPLY G.M. PARTS
abstract: Dana Corp will build factory in Longview, Tex, to make frames and other structural parts for a General Motors vehicle; about 450 workers will be hired for plant (S)

headline: Patents; A coming court test on whether corn seed and mathematical instructions have similar status.
abstract: Pioneer Hi-Bred International lawsuit charging that JEM AG Supply infringed its corn seed patents gives Supreme Court opportunity to decide whether genetically engineered plants should be awarded kinds of patents that usually cover mechanical, electrical or chemical inventions; two lower courts have held that plants created from seeds are eligible for utility patents (M)

headline: Layoffs at Jupiter Media Metrix
abstract: Jupiter Media Metrix, the international Internet research company based in New York's Silicon Alley, is laying off about 80 employees, a move prompted by a slackening of revenue in the last quarter, company officials said today.

headline: Schlumberger Is Reported in Negotiations to Buy Sema
abstract: Schlumberger Ltd, American energy services company, is negotiating to buy Sema, European information technology company, in deal valued around $5 billion; Sema recently hired Rothschild and Credit Suisse First Boston to explore its options after profit warning related to its $4.7 billion acquisition of LHS, United States telecommunications software company; Sema has been under pressure since November, when its shares dropped 44 percent in one day, after it warned that its earnings would not meet analysts' estimates; Sema shares have risen 37 percent since then, on speculation that company would be taken over; purchase would give Schlumberger beachhead in Britain, where information technology business has been dominated by Electronic Data Systems (M)

headline: S.& P. Lowers Its Rating on Japanese Debt
abstract: Standard & Poor's lowers its rating on Japanese debt to AA+ from AAA, its first downgrade of Japan ever (M)

headline: Article 2001020790796742972 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: DEALS

headline: As Hopes Wither, Africans Turn on Leaders
abstract: VICTORIA FALLS, Zimbabwe, Feb. 24 — The rain burst from the heavens and drenched the faces of the jubilant supporters who serenaded the old man at his birthday bash here today. All across town, young women celebrated the leadership of their longtime president, singing, "South Africa will follow you, Mugabe, Namibia will follow you."

headline: Times Promotes Executive
abstract: Nancy A Lee, director of business development at News Services division of New York Times, is promoted to vice president for business development (S)

headline: Credit Offerings During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.17 percent and on a six-month bill, 5.02 percent.

headline: Barak's Party Reels After His Swift Exit
abstract: Ehud Barak's sudden resignation from political life seems to have cleared way for unity government under Israeli Prime Min-elect Ariel Sharon, despite continued opposition from some in Barak's now leaderless Labor Party; has stilled some of Labor infighting (M)

headline: Bush Takes First Step to Shrink Arsenal of Nuclear Warheads
abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 — President Bush will order a comprehensive review of the nation's nuclear arsenal, a first step toward the unilateral cuts in warheads and missiles that he promised during last year's campaign, senior military and administration officials said today.

headline: Revlon Debt Relief
abstract: Revlon Inc's main unit agrees to pay $1.6 million fee and higher interest rates on its loans to be released from requirements that will free up some cash and make it less likely company will default on debt; lenders are led by J P Morgan & Co (S)

headline: Article 2001022792203818103 -- No Title
abstract: February 26, 2001

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of crude oil falls after OPEC's president says he does not see need for output cut when group meets in March; in New York, crude oil for March delivery falls 91 cents, or 3.1 percent, to $28.80 per barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Procter & Gamble Reports 4% Sales Drop
abstract: Procter & Gamble says sales fell 4 percent in last quarter and that, to counter declines in market share, it is partially abandoning its attempts to raise prices; global sales for quarter ended Dec 31, company's fiscal second quarter, were $10.2 billion, compared with $10.6 billion in last year's second quarter; earnings rose 6 percent in quarter, compared with year earlier (M)
