headline: PSINET SELLS UNIT FOR $300 MILLION
abstract: PSINet Inc sells its PSINet Transaction Solutions unit to investment group led by GTCR Golder Rauner for $300 million (S)

headline: T.W.A. Deal Will Not Face U.S. Challenge
abstract: Justice Department will not challenge bid by American Airlines to take over troubled Trans World Airlines; American will become world's largest carrier as result of acquiring TWA (M)

headline: Flare-Up on Kosovo Border Leaves Serb Dead and 4 Hurt
abstract: Fighting between Yugoslav military and ethnic Albanian guerrillas in tense buffer zone east of Kosovo in southern Serbia rises sharply, with four Serbian soldiers reported wounded and one killed on January 26 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: NEW ZEALAND

headline: A New Entree to Bonds
abstract: Barclays Global Investors and Nuveen Investments plan to create first bond index exchange-traded fund; EFT's are similar to mutual funds but trade throughout day (S)

headline: Bush Is Due to Meet Chinese on Crucial Issues
abstract: As President Bush prepares for his first meeting with a senior Chinese official, his administration faces two military decisions that could put the United States on a collision course with China while the Bush administration is barely under way.

headline: MEDICAL EQUIPMENT RENTAL COMPANY SEEKS CHAPTER 11
abstract: Mediq, which rents medical equipment to nursing homes and more than 5,000 hospitals, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after it misses interest payments; lists $3.07 million in assets and $120.4 million in debts (S)

headline: Blasts Kill 18 In Textile City South of Beijing
abstract: Apparently coordinated explosions kill at least 18 people in Shijiazhuang, industrial city 120 miles south of Beijing, send riot police into streets and spark rumors of laid-off textile workers and others seeking revenge; map (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    NORTHERN IRELAND: TRIMBLE FAULTED -- A Belfast High Court judge ruled that the Northern Ireland government's leader, David Trimble, was wrong to bar ministers from Sinn Fein, the political party representing the Irish Republican Army, from attending meetings with their counterparts in the Irish government that were set up by the 1998 peace settlement. Mr. Trimble, who took the action in an effort to produce disarmament moves from the I.R.A., said he would appeal the decision.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Argentina Picks New Official to Try to Rescue Economy
abstract: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar gains after report shows that inflation is in check, bolstering expectations for interest rate cut; euro settles at 93.42 cents, down from 94.10 cents in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Selling Advice in a Down Market
abstract: TheStreet.com editor in chief Dave Kansas defends decision to publish investment guide for Internet era in face of Internet stock slide (S)

headline: A Voice That Says a Rate Cut Is Not the Cure for All Ills
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on investment strategist Byron R Wien's view that Federal Reserve interest rate cuts will not automatically boost stock prices; he sees stock prices unlikely to rise now, predicting shallow, relatively short recession in 2001 first half; graph of interest rates and stock prices in 1989 and 1990, when rate cuts failed to boost stocks (M)

headline: Over World Protests, Taliban Are Destroying Ancient Buddhas
abstract: Afghanistan's Taliban officially announces ongoing systematic destruction of Great Buddhas of Bamiyan, priceless artifacts that survived wrathful cannon of Genghis Khan 800 years ago; supreme leader Mullah Muhammad Omar has ordered destruction of 'idols' that date to centuries befor Islam supplanted Buddhism, more than 1,000 years ago; international outcry results (M)

headline: Storage That Is Dollar Size And Almost as Cheap
abstract: New DataPlay disc, which will cost no more than $10, can store up to 500 megabytes of music, photographs and other digital content for portable devices; photo (S)

headline: China Says U.S.-Based Scholar Is Spy for 'Overseas Agencies'
abstract: BEIJING, March 27 — The Chinese government today accused a United States-based sociologist who has been held in isolation for more than six weeks of being a paid spy for "overseas intelligence agencies."

headline: PrivateSector; Ali and Frazier They Aren't
abstract: Warren E Buffett, whose Berkshire Hathaway owns Geico auto insurance company, and Edward Rust, chief executive of State Farm, joust about whose auto insurance business is superior (S)

headline: CHIEF OF TRADER.COM WILL DECLINE PAY FOR 2 YEARS
abstract: Trader.com, classified advertising publisher, says president and chief executive, John MacBain, will forgo all compensation, including stock options, in 2001 and 2002 as part of company's plan to reduce costs and preserve cash (S)

headline: Sotheby's Posts 4th-Quarter Loss and a Drop of 14% in 2000 Sales
abstract: Sotheby's Holdings, auction house staggered by price-fixing scandal, reports losing $6.5 million in fourth quarter, compared with profit of $34.4 million a year earlier; revenue for quarter falls 24 percent, to $143.1 million; auction sales for all of 2000 decline 14 percent, to $1.9 billion; Christie's auction sales for 2000 rise $2.3 billion from $2.2 billion in 1999 (M)

headline: Parting With France, It Plays Down State Sovereignty and Urges U.S. Role : Germany Boldly Sets Own Chart for Europe
abstract: BERLIN—  Germany is staking out a new leadership stance for itself in Europe with a specific call for a future that bolsters the European Union's institutions at the expense of national sovereignty and welcomes a strong accompanying role for the United States.

headline: Business; Advanced Online Banking, Born of Necessity
abstract: Brazil is leader in Internet banking even though majority of population has no Internet access; its banks devised speedy electronic payment systems and rapid clearance of checks in early 1990's when inflation was so great that customers could love money during processing; this paved way for advanced Internet banking; most Brazilians seldom, if ever, go inside banks; photo (M)

headline: FREEMARKETS BUYING ADEXA
abstract: FreeMarkets will buy Adexa, manufacturer of e-commerce software, in deal valued at $340 million (S)

headline: Robert L. Clare Jr., 86; Ran Wall St. Law Firm
abstract: Robert L Clare Jr, corporate lawyer who played critical role in growth and international expansion of Wall Street law firm of Shearman & Sterling, dies at age 86; photo (M)

headline: BELLSOUTH AND DELL IN PC DEAL
abstract: BellSouth Corp and Dell Computer Corp say they will cooperate to deliver personal computers equipped for high-speed Internet access (S)

headline: Long Before Verdict, Lockerbie Changed Airport Security
abstract: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 — The destruction of Pan Am 103, along with subsequent bombings and other suspected terrorist acts, produced a profound change in airline security long before today's verdict.

headline: Uranium-Tipped Arms Ban Rejected by NATO Majority
abstract: Majority of NATO countries turns down requests from several allies for temporary ban on inclusion of depleted-uranium munitions in NATO arsenals; weapons have caused political storm in Europe because of suspicions that they harmed health of Western peacekeepers in Balkans as well as environment; some ambassadors of alliance are critical of United States, which has been main proponent of munitions; but most reject demands from Italy, Germany, Norway and Greece to remove munitions from arsenals until it is made clear whether they are linked to cancers and other ailments that have developed in peacekeepers sent to Balkans; photo (M)

headline: British Retailer Says It Still Plans Spinoff
abstract: Kingfisher PLC, third-largest British retailer, says that it will consider offers for divisions not involved in its primary home improvement and electronics businesses (M)

headline: Lumber Dispute Threatens U.S.-Canada Trade Ties
abstract: Agreement limiting Canadian lumber exports to US is set to expire, and American lumber producers are preparing countervailing-duty complaints charging that Canada's wood exports to US are unfairly subsidized by provincial governments, which own more than 90 percent of forests from which lumber is cut; 51 senators have urged Pres Bush not to permit Canadian producers open access to US lumber market, where prices have already fallen because of Canadian competition; cite closing of more than 100 lumber mills in last six months; photo (M)

headline: PARTHUS POSTS 68% GAIN IN REVENUE
abstract: Irish microchip designer Parthus Technologies announces 68 percent increase in annual revenue, to $31.9 million, but net loss of $16.1 million for year ended Dec 31; revenue from license sales rose threefold; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Acquisition of VoiceStream Delayed by Changing Terms  Deutsche Telekom's planned $50.7 billion acquisition of VoiceStream Wireless has been delayed by an amendment that was quietly added to the terms of the deal earlier this week, executives close to the companies said.

headline: INTEL OFFERS AUDIO PLAYER
abstract: Intel introduces digital-audio player and says it will show off two wireless computing systems at trade show this week; pocket-size player, which begins selling next month for $299, runs on two AA batteries and holds four hours of music; graph (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises on speculation that Paul O'Neill, nominee for US Treasury Secretary, favors weaker dollar to bolster US economy; dollar settles at 117.51 yen, down from 118.31, in New York trading; graph; chart (S)

headline: Court Orders Inquiry Into '99 Gucci Stock Deal
abstract: Dutch court orders investigation of deal Gucci Group struck with Francois Pinault to thwart acquisition advances of Bernard Arnault, who controls LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton; Arnault has been struggling to undo 1999 deal in which Gucci sold controlling 42 percent stake in itself to Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, retail group run by Pinault; deal gave Gucci $3 billion to spend on acquisitions and effectively halved LVMH's stake in Gucci to 20 percent (M)

headline: Odd-Lot Short Sales Dim as Sign of Upturn
abstract: Odd-lot short sales on New York Stock Exchange surged for the week, giving sign of possible market upturn ahead (M)

headline: South Korea's New Best Friend?
abstract: Analysis of South Korea's act of independence from Washington, tilting toward Russia on issue of American missile-defense program; South Korean officials say they fear another crisis over North Korea's ballistic missile program, and value Russia's increasingly important role in trying to persuade North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, to give it up; photo of Pres Vladimir V Putin during visit to Seoul (M)

headline: Article 2001010293831034291 -- No Title
abstract: E-COMMERCE REPORT

headline: Bush Meets With British Prime Minister
abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 — President Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain discussed a wide range of world issues today and vowed that their countries would continue to have, as Mr. Bush put it, "an alliance that has made a huge difference in the world."

headline: Consumer Prices Rose Sharply in January
abstract: Americans paid sharply higher prices for energy in January, causing inflation at the consumer level to rise at its quickest pace in 10 months, the government reported today.

headline: SPIRIT SALES HELP DIAGEO
abstract: Diageo PLC says operating profit for six months ended Dec 31 was 1.23 million pounds ($1.78 million) compared with 1.15 million pounds year earlier; operating profit at Burger King unit fell 6 million pounds, to 99 million pounds (S)

headline: Mideast Talks Resume With Little Hope for a Full Accord
abstract: Israelis and Palestinians resume their peace talks, Taba, Egypt, after 48-hour hiatus (S)

headline: Chtaura Journal; In a Foreign Town, Syrians (Shhh!) Bank and Buy
abstract: Chtaura, Lebanon, just 10 miles from Syrian border, has prospered even during years of civil war that made Beirut unlivable; Syrian citizens visit Chtaura in droves to stash their illegal dollars away from prying eyes in Lebanese banks, to get credit cards that Syria's state-controlled banks do not issue, and to shop for delicacies, like real Coca-Cola, not available or forbidden in their own country; bankers and merchants of Chtaura worry that boom may end now that Hafez al-Assad has died and been succeeded by his son, Bashar al-Assad, who has started relaxing all kinds of rules in Syria; photo; map (M)

headline: 2 Plead Guilty in Multimillion-Dollar Investment Scheme
abstract: Frank A Persico, stockbroker from Staten Island, and Robert P Gallo, employee at Manhattan investment firm, plead guilty to participating in scheme to fleece millions of dollars from investors through stock manipulation, violence and fraud; are among 120 people indicted last June; were charged with participating in one part of ring--racketeering operation in which 21 people, including members and associates of five New York organized crime families, were said to have worked in league with DMN Capital Investments to manipulate stocks; prosecutors say schemes netted more than $50 million (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    IRELAND: EX-PREMIER AILING -- Former Prime Minister Charles Haughey, 75, who already suffers from prostate cancer, had a heart attack. Mr. Haughey was a major figure in Irish political life in the 1980's and continues to exert influence over the dominant party, Fianna Fail. His financial affairs are under scrutiny in a government investigation of payments by business interests to politicians.    Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline: INKTOMI'S RESULTS MISS FORECASTS
abstract: Inktomi Corp says fiscal first-quarter sales and earnings missed forecasts; revenue for period ended Dec 31 was $80 million to $81 million (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: ADOPTIVE PARENTS SUED  The British couple who adopted American-born twin girls have been ordered to appear in American courts by lawyers for a California couple who had been caring for the girls. Vickie and Richard Allen of San Bernardino, Calif., are contesting the legality of the adoption by Judith and Alan Kilshaw. The Britons were served in Chicago after they appeared with the Allens on Wednesday at a taping of the Oprah Winfrey show. The twins are staying with a British social service agency while the legal struggle goes on.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Colombian Governors Protest U.S.-Backed Spraying of Coca
abstract: Four Colombian governors charge American-supported aerial spraying of illicit coca crops is jeopardizing health and food supply of small-scale farmers; are urging Pres Andres Pastrana and Bush administration to rethink what they maintain is militaristic approach toward peasant farmers, in exchange for plan involving social pacts and alternative crops in southern drug-growing states that they represent (M)

headline: Indonesia and Aceh Rebels Agree to Extend Cease-Fire
abstract: GENEVA—  The Indonesian government and rebel Aceh negotiators agreed to extend a cease-fire by one month, replacing an existing cessation of violence that is due to expire Monday.

headline: DISAPPOINTING WIRELESS AUCTION
abstract: Australia's auction of high-speed wireless spectrum yields just $585 million, far below government estimates (S)

headline: Article 2001020992456278951 -- No Title
abstract: February 9, 2001

headline: Mexican Rebels Set Off on Protest Caravan to the Capital
abstract: Zapatista rebels set off from San Cristobal de las Casas for two-week, 32-city tour of southern Mexico that is intended to summon attention and momentum to their cause; Subcommander Marcos, masked as ever, addresses crowd of some 10,000 supporters; rebels' caravan of vans, trucks and buses is accompandied by human rights monitors and foreign sympathizers; has divided Pres Vicente Fox from leaders of his conservative National Action Party, which has urged him to ban demonstration, and political leaders across the country describe caravan as affront to law-abiding citizens; photo (M)

headline: Imperfect Pitch
abstract: Jay M Pasachoff letter comments on Jan 4 article on Doppler radar

headline: Article 2001030990268199041 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Workers Seize Big Daewoo Car Plant in South Korean Port
abstract: Hundreds of Daewoo Motor Company workers seize huge manufacturing facility in Inchon, South Korea, pledging to hold it until company gives up plans to lay off more than a third of its workforce; more than thousand police encircle plant; Daewoo continues takeover talks with General Motors, only potential suitor since Ford Motor Co withdrew from negotiations (M)

headline: INDUSTRIAL GAS DEAL IN GERMANY
abstract: Allianz, Germany's biggest insurer, and Goldman Sachs Group will buy Aventis's 67 percent stake in German industrial gas company, Messer Griesheim GmbH, for 1.6 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in cash and assumed debt; photo (S)

headline: LINUX DISTRIBUTOR BUYS A CONSULTANT
abstract: Red Hat Inc, largest US distributor of software based on Linux operating system, acquires network consultant, Planning Technologies Inc, for $47 million in stock (S)

headline: Buoyed by Service Industry, Jobless Rate Holds Steady
abstract: Buoyed as usual by the service industry, the economy created more jobs than expected last month, which helped keep the nation's unemployment rate unchanged at 4.2 percent for February, according to Labor Department figures released today. But the hemorrhage of factory jobs continued.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: Court Says Employers Can Require Arbitration of Disputes
abstract: US Supreme Court, in 5-4 decision, rules that companies can insist that workplace disputes go to arbitration rather than to court; decision resolves disagreement among lower federal courts about scope of Federal Arbitration Act, 76-year-old law that makes arbitration agreements enforceable in federal court; court leaves unresolved important questions about what rights workers might retain under other federal laws, like major antidiscrimination laws that guarantee rights to punitive damages and legal fees; among questions left open by decision, Circuit City Stores v Adams, is what role remains for federal administrative agencies in pursuing enforcement actions on behalf of employees who are covered by arbitration agreements; court rules 7 to 2 that federal law, Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, pre-empts state law on designation of beneficiaries of Erisa-covered pension plans; in case, Egelhoff v Egelhoff, man who was recently divorced died without will and without removing his wife's name as beneficiary of his pensions; under Washington State law, benefits should have gone to his children by earlier marriage, but court rules that Erisa designation should prevail (M)

headline: Cap Gemini Has Contract For Services to 4 Hospitals
abstract: Cap Gemini Ernst & Young reaches seven-year $350 million contract to provide technology services to Beth Israel Medical Center, St Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary and Long Island College Hospital; will provide computer support and data management services, including accounting, patient billing and communications, to hospitals (M)

headline: Europe Sets Examination Of G.E. Deal
abstract: European Commission confirsm it will open extended investigation into General Electric Co's planned $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell International Inc, despite 11th-hour effort by GE chief executive John F Welch Jr to secure quick clearance by European regulators (M)

headline: Strength of January Vehicle Sales Surprises Automakers
abstract: Automakers sold vehicles at seasonally adjusted annual rate of 17.2 million vehicles in January, far better than pace of 15.4 million vehicles sold in December; industry considers anything above 16 million to be strong month; sales were down 6 percent from those in month year earlier; graph; chart (M)

headline: Taking Video Games Seriously, as Art and Product
abstract: TRIGGER HAPPY: VIDEO GAMES AND THE ENTERTAINMENT REVOLUTION

headline: LIBBEY WILL TRIM PRODUCTION AS EARNINGS MISS TARGETS
abstract: Libbey Inc, leading maker of glassware, will reduce production at its plants in US and joint venture in Mexico; says its first-quarter earnings will be below analysts' estimates (S)

headline: State Dept.'s Work Rules: Powell's Free and Easy Guide
abstract: Sec Colin L Powell, four days on job, addresses State Dept employees, telling them everyone at dept will be connected to Internet, that he is not impressed with people who put in long hours just for show, and that he intends to step up recruitment of minorities; photo with Canada's Foreign Min, John Manley (M)

headline: ITALIAN FASHION : Luggage Takes Off On Flight of Fancy
abstract: MILAN—  According to Italian ready-to-wear designers, and their high-flying European competitors, it will take more than a bout of cabin pressure to cramp the new club-class style. And they're not talking about new luxury beds or improved leg room.

headline: Economic Scene; Americans' waistlines have become the victims of economic progress.
abstract: Virginia Postrel's 'Economic Scene' column on link between bigger American waistlines and economic progress; Prof Tomas J Philipson says average weight rises as men give up manual labor for better-paying desk jobs; sharp increase in paid labor among women last three decades may account for rapid rise in their weights; housework, while only moderately strenuous, is more physically demanding that sitting at desk; photo (M)

headline: If Protesters Can't Take to the Streets, They Can Go to the Mountain
abstract: Internet art project devised by Johannes Gees allows people anywhere in the world to submit their messages over the Internet and have them projected by laser beam onto the mountainside overlooking Davos, Switzerland, site of World Economic Forum; Gees says idea is to open a less antagonistic channel of communication between protesters and world leaders; photo (M)

headline: LUFTHANSA TO ACQUIRE A STAKE IN SKY CHEFS CATERING
abstract: Deutsche Lufthansa AG acquires Onex Corp's 47 perent stake in their LSG Sky Chefs venture for 1.3 billion Canadian dollars ($827 million) to take control of Sky Chefs, world's leading airline-catering company (S)

headline: A Tempest Over Photo of Shackled Boy
abstract: Ingeborg Coffman of Plant City, Fla, has filed wrongful-dismissal suit against Wal-Mart Stores, which contends that it only reprimanded her for failing to follow company policy; Coffman was dismissed for giving police copy of photo she discovered at store's photo lab showing young boy shackled to toilet, which Coffman saw as act of child abuse, although photo turned out to be prank; Coffman gave copy of photo to police; photo (M) requested photo (M)

headline: THE BOSS; Many Think of Me as Lucky
abstract: The Boss column by Donald J Trump on how he built Trump Organization; photo (M)

headline: Euro RSCG Buys Black Rocket Stake
abstract: Euro RSCG Worldwide will acquire majority stake in ad agency Black Rocket (S)

headline: HOLY WARRIORS -- First of three articles: A Network of Terror; One Man and a Global Web of Violence
abstract: First of three articles on Osama bin Laden and the creation of Al Qaeda, Muslim terrorist group he founded 13 years ago; group's initial target was Soviet forces occupying Afghanistan, but today its enemy is United States, which it regards as an imperial power propping up corrupt and godless governments; chronology; photos (L)

headline: Happy Skies of Continental; Satisfaction Is Up. Morale Is Up. So Is Profit.
abstract: Continental Airlines, once a prime symbol of labor strife, lifts revenues and wins praise from passengers with help of program to improve employee morale; executive at competing carrier attribute tranquillity at Continental to fact that its labor contracts come up for renewal after other carriers; country's largest carriers--United Airlines, American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines--are facing possible strikes in coming months by pilots, flight attendants or mechanics; graph; photos (M)

headline: Using Shock To Peddle The Goods
abstract: Article on growing number of companies that are using death and dying as theme in television commercials; companies with such theme include Toshiba Corp, Discover, FedEx and Toyota; photos (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Real-Time Challenges, in Cyberspace and on the Ground; When the Vote Reformers Call, Many Will Answer
abstract: Technology companies are jockeying for access to government funds that are expected to flow in 2001 into better voting systems, a result of legal wrangling following presidential election; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001012693413555341 -- No Title
abstract: January 26, 2001

headline: NORTHWEST TO BUY NEW PLANES FROM AIRBUS AND BOEING
abstract: Northwest Airlines Corp decides to divide $5 billion order for new aircraft between Airbus Industrie and Boeing Co; to replace 44 aging DC-10's, Northwest will buy 24 wide-bodied A330-300 jets and 6 smaller A319's from Airbus, while Boeing will supply 20 single-aisle 757-300s and 2 of its 747-400 jumbo jet (S)

headline: How Did They Value Stocks? Count the Absurd Ways; Those Lofty 'New Economy' Measures Fizzle
abstract: Investors devastated by precipitous decline in shares of 'new economy' companies are learning folly of believing that 'old economy' investment standards can be ignored with impunity forever; survivors of previous market fads that fizzled say best thing investors can do to keep their portfolios safe from future busts is to learn from their mistakes; photos; graphs (L)

headline: Economic Scene: Comparing Nasdaq and Tulips Unfair to Flowers
abstract: WAS the Nasdaq bubble yet another example of tulipmania?

headline: South Africa's President Vows to Renew War Against Poverty
abstract: South African Pres Pres Thabo Mbeki uses 89th anniversary of African National Congress to promise that it will work even harder in government in 2001 in war against poverty and to root out corruption (S)

headline: Russian Defector Was Spy, Not Diplomat, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Sergei Tretyakov, Russian intelligence officer working under cover as diplomat at United Nations, reportedly defected to United States in Oct with wife and other family members and has been extensively debriefed by Federal Bureau of Investigation and Central Intelligence Agency; several current and former US officials say his acceptance as defector when US and Russia are not direct adversaries indicates he offered significant information; say ranks of Russian intelligence officers in US have risen to nearly cold war levels, while US has not fully rebuilt its intelligence presence in Moscow (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/William B. Frels; Mairs and Power Balanced Fund
abstract: Carole Gould column profiles William B Frels and Mairs and Power Balanced fund he manages; photo; fund data list (M)

headline: Colombia, in Risky Move, Plans to Cede Zone to 2nd Rebel Group
abstract: SAN PABLO, Colombia, Jan. 22 — Two years ago, hoping to end more than 30 years of grinding civil war, President Andrés Pastrana took the unusual step of ceding a Switzerland- size region of land to the largest guerrilla group in the country to lure it into peace talks.

headline: BRAZIL CELL PHONE DEAL
abstract: Brazilian wireless phone company Telesp Celular Participacoes agrees to pay $556 million for Global Telecom, cellular phone company in wealthy southern states of Parana and Santa Catarina; will assume $654 million in debt; sellers are DDI and ITX of Japan and Inepar SA Industria e Construcoes of Brazil (S)

headline: Rebels in Sri Lanka Renew Cease-Fire
abstract: Ethnic Tamil rebels in Sri Lanka extend their cease-fire for an additional month and call on other nations to persuade Sri Lanka to halt its military offensive and restart peace talks that broke off more than five years ago (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., said its GE Aircraft Engines, the largest jet engine producer in the world, won a deal worth more than $500 million from CargoLifter Development G.m.b.H., a German airship maker, to supply and maintain engines for a new fleet in development.

headline: Disc Machines Gaining on VCR's
abstract: DVD players, which reached market four years ago, are fast gaining on VCR; sales of DVD's more than doubled last year, with 6.4 million sold in United States; by contrast, sales of VCR's grew only 6.2 percent; photo; graphs (S)

headline: Polishing the Sound
abstract: Brewer Shettles letter comments on Dec 21 on recording music at home

headline: EMC's Big Bet On Explosion In Data Storage
abstract: Competition is strong among manufacturers of data storage hardware; some analysts project that spending on data storage products will surpass expenditures for computers and account for 70 percent of information technology budgets by 2005; EMC Corp is working hard to maintain its competitive edge in field; Photo (M)

headline: The Boss: Persuasion and Persistence
abstract: When I was at Westminster College in New Wilmington, Pa., I noticed a theater there that played terrible movies, things like Abbott and Costello meet the monster. In my sophomore year, the theater closed. Who was going to see Abbott and Costello on a Saturday night?

headline: A Horror Movie Adds Shudders to a Shooter
abstract: Herold Charles reviews Clive Barker's Undying, new video game published by Electronic Arts; drawings (M)

headline: Colombian Paramilitaries Adjust Attack Strategies
abstract: BARRANCABERMEJA, Colombia, Jan. 21 — Block by block and house by house, gunmen from Colombia's surging right-wing paramilitary army are waging a fierce urban battle against leftist rebels in this grimy northern industrial center in a conflict that is usually fought in the countryside.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    UKRAINE: BACKING FOR EX-OFFICIAL -- Hundreds of protesters chanting ''Yulia!'' marched through Kiev demanding the release of Yulia V. Timoshenko, the former deputy prime minister arrested on corruption charges that she claims are politically motivated. Ms. Timoshenko, left, waged a battle last year to bring transparency to the corrupt energy sector. The Interfax news agency said up to 1,000 marchers from Ms. Timoshenko's Fatherland Party picketed the prosecutor general's office in central Kiev, the scene of large protests against President Leonid D. Kuchma this winter.    Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)    RUSSIA: MISSILE TESTS -- Russia test-fired two intercontinental ballistic missiles with dummy warheads, one from a submarine in the Barents Sea and the other from the Plesetsk testing grounds. Both landed on the Kamchatka Peninsula, a military spokesman said. The spokesmen said the tests were intended to prove the continuing reliability and accuracy of Russia's nuclear deterrent forces, but some political analysts suggested that the tests also sent a political message that Moscow intends to oppose any deployment of an American missile shield.    Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

headline: Visiting Chinese to Urge Bush Not to Sell Arms to Taiwan
abstract: Deputy Premier Qian Qichen, highest-ranking Chinese official to visit Washington in two years, is expected to urge Pres Bush during upcoming White House meeting not to sell more advanced weapons to Taiwan; will visit two weeks before Bush must decide which weapons US will sell Taiwan in current year under terms of 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, which mandates that US provide equipment with which island can defend itself (M)

headline: Severe Earthquake Strikes India, Killing Thousands
abstract: NEW DELHI, Jan. 26 — A devastating earthquake struck India's western state of Gujarat today, then shook the rest of the subcontinent from top to bottom. About 2,000 people died, and hundreds more were missing or injured, officials said.

headline: 2 Airlines Offer Alternatives To T.W.A. Sale
abstract: Continental Airlines tells Delaware bankruptcy court that it is interested in buying some of assets of Trans World Airlines for as much as $400 million as part of plan to keep ailing airline operating as independent carrier; Continental raises several objections to plan by AMR Corp to buy most of TWA's assets for $500 million in cash and assumption of $3 billion in leases; Northwest Airlines, in separate filing, objects to American's plan and says it is willing to offer cash for TWA's 26 percent stake in Worldspan, computer reservation system, that it owns along with Delta Air Lines (M)

headline: 5 Drug Makers Use Material With Possible Mad Cow Link
abstract: Food and Drug Administration has repeatedly asked pharmaceutical companies for last eight years not to use materials from cattle raised in countries where there is risk of mad cow disease, but five companies, including GlaxoSmithKline, Aventis and American Home Products, were still using ingredients from those countries in 2000 to make nine widely used vaccines; some of companies say that they found FDA's request unclear and do not believe they did anything wrong; others say the could not keep up with government's expanding list of countries where cattle could be infected; nine vaccines include some regularly given to millions of American children, including vaccines to prevent polio, diphtheria, anthrax and tetanus; Federal health officials calculate that odds of these vaccines passing on disease are between one in 40 million and one in 40 billion doses; all five vaccine makers have agreed to stop using suspected materials, which include blood, fetal calf serum and meat broth; map (M)

headline: NOVELL NAMES NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Novell Inc says its chairman and chief executive, Eric Schmidt, will give up latter position; will be replaced by Jack Messman, his counterpart at Cambridge Technology Partners; photo (S)

headline: Long Up for Sale, Insurer May Have a New Owner Soon
abstract: Bidding for Liberty Financial Companies closes, but bankers and analysts say it could be several weeks before details are worked out and buyer is announced (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: JEWS TO SUE OVER INTERNET -- The Central Council for Jews said it intended to sue Internet service providers exhibiting extreme right-wing or racist Web pages. The group expressed frustration at what it called the ''snail's pace'' of government action in applying anti-Nazi laws to fight racist and anti-Semitic Internet content.    Desmond Butler (NYT)

headline: COMPASS BUYS COMPANY TO BUILD HOSPITAL FOOD BUSINESS
abstract: Compass Group acquires Morrison Management Specialists for $563 million to strengthen its worldwide business of supplying food to hospitals and nursing homes; will assume $63 million in debt (S)

headline: Dismissing a Dozen, Hiring One
abstract: Law firm Dewey Ballentine lays off 12 midlevel and senior lawyers and hires bankruptcy specialist Michael J Sage (S)

headline: HMS Buys Fahlgren In a Stock Purchase
abstract: HMS Partners is acquiring Fahlgren; financial terms of stock transaction are not disclosed (S)

headline: Kevin Garnett of the Minnesota Timberwolves is the focus of a campaign for And 1 sneakers.
abstract: Kevin Garnett of Minnesota Timberwolves is focus of advertising campaign for And 1 sneakers; campaign was developed by Fallon New York; photo (M)

headline: Russia Is Set to Expel Four U.S. Diplomats
abstract: Russia said that it was expelling four United States diplomats, and promised other measures, but did not identify the diplomats or reiterate that Russia would fully retaliate for the Bush administration's decision to expel 50 Russian diplomats between now and July.     But State Department officials expect a fully proportional response.

headline: The Greener Grass Is, Well, Greener
abstract: Monster.com runs promotional sweepstakes, Dream Job for a Day, and one prize is job of Barry Schuler, America Online chief executive (S)

headline: Keithley Sees Lower Sales and Earnings
abstract: Keithley Instruments Inc, maker of machines that test semiconductors, says quarterly sales and earnings will be lower than company forecast because customers are spending less on new equipment (S)

headline: With Income Up 16%, G.E. Warns of Layoffs
abstract: General Electric says fourth-quarter earnings rose 16 percent even though revenue gained only 6 percent; company earned $3.59 billion compared with $3.09 billion year earlier; revenue rose to $35 billion from $32.90 billion; for 2000, GE earned $12.7 billion, 19 percent increase over 1999, on revenue that increased 16 percent, to $129.9 billion (M)

headline: F.C.C. Auction Hit With Claim Of Unfair Bids
abstract: George D. Crowley Jr., a longtime telecommunications entrepreneur, recalls the day last fall when an old friend contacted him about an intriguing opportunity. The friend represented SBC Communications. As Mr. Crowley knew, the Federal Communications Commission was preparing to begin an auction in December of wireless airwave frequencies that the largest telephone companies desperately needed.    But many of the licenses were being set aside for small companies like his, while others available to any buyer could be bought by such companies at a deep discount. What if, the friend proposed, SBC's wireless phone venture, Cingular Wireless, helped to bankroll him in the auction?

abstract: Immunex Corp reports clinical trials of drug Enebril for chronic heart failure and Nuvance for asthma have failed, dealing double blow to efforts to expand product line beyond treatment for rheumatoid arthritis (M)

abstract: Edward Fitzgerald, author and former executive of Book-of-the-Month Club, dies at age 81; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: EURO STRENGTHENS. The euro neared a six-month high against the dollar on concerns about the health of the U.S. economy. In New York, the euro settled at 95.82 cents, up from 94.92 cents on Thursday.

abstract: Creating a Generation of Slouchers

headline: Flat-Panel Monitor Takes Up Less Desk and Wallet Space

headline: Compressed Data; Biometric Security Plan Under Review by NASA
abstract: NASA tests eTrue technology that uses facial scanning and fingerprint readers to verify identity of computer users; technology may eventually allow its engineers to sign onto its computer systems remotely to operate spacecraft; photo (M)

headline: Earnings Decline 3.1% at Federated Stores
abstract: Federated Department Stores Inc says fourth-quarter earnings fell 3.1 percent; profit from operations fell to $434 million compared with net income of $448 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: Dell Computer to Cut Work Force by 4%
abstract: Dell Computer will eliminate 1,700 jobs, or about 4 percent of its employees, in first large-scale layoff in its 16-year history; attributes cutbacks to general deterioration of economic conditions and faltering demand for its desktop personal computer; Dell reports income was $508 million in its fiscal fourth quarter ended Feb 2; revenue reached $8.7 billion, up 28 percent, year on year; Hewlett-Packard Corp says revenue increased 2 percent, to $11.9 billion, in its fiscal first quarter ended Jan 31; earnings were $727 million, down 12 percent from year-earlier quarter; revenue grew to $11.9 billion from $11.6 billion; photo (M)

headline: Rwanda and Uganda Cut Back Troops in Congo
abstract: KIGALI, Rwanda, Feb. 28 — Two armies in the sprawling conflict in Congo took what appeared to be a major step toward peace today, pulling back soldiers from front-line positions with the expectation that other combatants would do the same soon.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; What Were Once Ladders Are Now Chutes
abstract: Market Place column on losses incurred by some initial public offerings made in 2000; says shares valued at $11.3 billion at offering prices were sold to investors in 77 initial public offerings from Jan 31 through March 10, 2000; holds on March 10, when Nasdaq composite peaked, those shares were valued at $25.9 billion, but they have now fallen 80 percent to $5.3 billion; companies discussed include Turnstone Systems, Hotel Reservation Network and Palm Inc; graphs; drawing (M)

headline: New Files Tie U.S. to Deaths Of Latin Leftists in 1970's
abstract: Recently declassified State Department documents show Latin American officers involved in Operation Condor, joint effort in 1970's by right-wing governments to crush left-wing opposition, used American communications installation to share intelligence; appear to open new avenues of inquiry about American role in Condor, shadowy operation to stamp out Latin American left that, among other things, dispatched death squads to kill critics at home and abroad; contents of cable of Robert E White, former US ambassador to Paraguay who opposed American support in suppressing leftists, discussed; photo (M)

headline: As Fed Convenes, Gloom Deepens : Consumers in U.S. Lose Confidence
abstract: NEW YORK—  Confronted by withering consumer confidence in the U.S. economy, the Federal Reserve Board is widely expected to reduce interest rates by half a percentage point when its two-day meeting ends Wednesday, a cure likely to revive American growth but possibly at the price of encouraging a spendthrift society.

headline: The Bids Too Low, Cablevision Is Said to End Rainbow Auction
abstract: Cablevision Systems Corp takes its programming unit, Rainbow Media, off auction block after it fails to receive bids beyond $4 billion; is reconsidering creating separate tracking stock for Rainbow Media (M)

headline: RAIL PROBLEMS HIT RETAILER
abstract: Selfridges says holiday sales at its flagship department store on Oxford Street in London grew only marginally because disruptions of British railway service deterred shoppers from traveling; sales rose 1 percent from 1999 levels in six weeks ended Jan 6, while sales at second store, in Manchester, rose 22 percent (S)

headline: A Consolidation Plan From the Continent
abstract: Financial Times Group, part of Pearson, is beginning review to consolidate advertising and public relations accounts of its North American newspaper and Web site operations; total billings estimated at $10 million to $20 million; ad account for Financial Times newspaper is at Avrett Free & Ginsberg, while ad account for FT.com is at BBDO Worldwide (S)

headline: Powell, Meeting Both Sides in Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Makes Little Headway
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell meets with Israel's prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, in Jerusalem and with Yasir Arafat in Ramallah, West Bank, but does not make much headway in breaking logjam on negotiations for peace (M)

headline: Compressed Data; After Napster, Falling Back on Pig Latin

headline: In Test of Troubled Waters, Powell Rebuffs Montenegrin
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell refuses to see Milo Djukanovic, president of Montenegro, sending firm signal that Bush administration opposes independence for Serbia's last partner in Yugoslav federation; Djukanovic is in Washington to explain why he thinks Montenegro should be independent; Powell's predecessor, Madeleine K Albright, met with Djukanovic several times, although she never explicitly came out in favor of independence for Montenegro; Montenegrins themselves are equally divided over matter of independence (M)

headline: Motorola to Lay Off 2,500 At Illinois Cell Phone Plant
abstract: Motorola Inc will shut down production at company's last domestic cellular phone plant, in Harvard, Ill, laying off all 2,500 manufacturing workers; 2,500 employees there will continue to handle distribution, engineering and marketing (M)

headline: Bartle Bogle Wins Gold Ad Campaign
abstract: World Gold Council in London names Bartle Bogle Hegarty to handle global advertising campaign to be introduced this year in major markets around world; spending is estimated at more than $50 million (S)

headline: Mexicans Seen Waiting Some More for a Phone
abstract: Telefonos de Mexico has made only modest gains in wiring nation after promising to promote efficiency and competitive spirit in industry; Mexico's ratio of phone lines to people is among lowest in Latin America; many Mexicans' hopes for more affordable residential service were raised by Avantel's announcement that it is ready to challenge Telmex by offering local service in Mexico City, but analysts are warning that it will be large businesses, not ordinary residents, who benefit from new competition; photo (M)

headline: PSINET HIRES ADVISER AS SHARES DROP
abstract: Shares of PSINet, long-struggling Internet service provider, plunge 74 percent after company announces hiring of Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein to advise it on restructuring corporate debt; company names Harry G Hobbs president and chief operating officer (S)

headline: Oscar Ratings Fall to All-Time Low
abstract: The American television audience seems to be losing its fascination with the Oscars.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    NETHERLANDS: LOCKERBIE TRIAL NEARS END  In a surprise move, the defense in the Lockerbie trial rested its case, indicating that the hearings will end soon. Closing arguments were scheduled to begin today. After a month's delay to seek documents from Syria, the prosecution said Syria had refused to turn over a document requested by the defense. The lawyer for Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi said he would not call his client to testify. Mr. Megrahi is one of two Libyans accused of blowing up Pan Am 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, killing 270 people.    Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)    FRANCE: MAD COW PROTESTS  Demanding more help from the government to offset losses caused by the panic over mad cow disease, French cattle dealers and slaughterhouse workers set up blockades on several of the main roads leading to Paris. Similar protests were held near Rennes, Lyon and Bordeaux. The protests, which in some areas caused 30-mile-long backups, were finished by the afternoon. But the strikers said they would renew their roadblocks if the government failed to respond to their concerns.    Suzanne Daley (NYT)

headline: Over World Protests, Taliban Are Destroying Ancient Buddhas
abstract: NEW DELHI, March 3The Great Buddhas of Bamiyan priceless artifacts that 800 years ago survived the wrath of Genghis Khan -- are being steadfastly destroyed bit by bit with hammers, spades and explosives, Afghanistan's Taliban militia stated officially today for the first time.

headline: Layoffs and Cutbacks Expected at News Corp.´s Internet Unit
abstract: News Digital Media, the leading Internet unit of the News Corporation, has decided to abandon its ambitious efforts to provide original content on its Web sites and will instead lay off several hundred workers within the next few weeks, according to three executives close to the decision.

headline: Rohm & Haas Expects a Drop in Profit
abstract: Rohm & Haas Co, one of world's largest makers of specialty chemicals, says its first-quarter profit will be lower than expected because of rising energy costs and slower demand from industrial customers (S)

headline: Napster to Start Blocking Access to Protected Music Files
abstract: Napster will begin blocking users from exchanging some copyrighted songs online, first concrete sign that Napster is at last succumbing in the face of huge legal obstacles; move is probably only precursor to more severe limits soon to be imposed by court; photo (M)

headline: Transcript of Ambassador Alon Pinkas's Visit to the Middle East Forum
abstract: Ambassador Alon Pinkas, the consulate general of Israel in New York, answered questions about the Mideast peace process on Wednesday in a forum on The New York Times on the Web.

headline: Stocks End Volatile Week on a High Note
abstract: Battered prices and fresh memories of a remarkable rally attracted bargain hunters today to pick up a wide array of the stock market's offerings.

headline: Schröder Joins a Hot Debate, Saying He's Proud to Be German
abstract: BERLIN, March 19 — Chancellor Gerhard Schröder joined a heated debate today over whether Germans have the right to feel national pride, declaring himself "a German patriot, who is proud of his country."

abstract: February 15, 2001

headline: As the Disease Marches On, Britain Dooms More Animals
abstract: LONDON, March 14 — The confirmation of 27 new cases of foot-and- mouth disease today brought the total in Britain to 232 and prompted Prime Minister Tony Blair to order an intensified slaughter of animals in areas directly affected. He also said the government should consider easing restrictions caused by the disease in economically hard hit regions that are free of the virus.

headline: Subsidiary Fails, Dealing a Blow to Korea's Hyundai
abstract: Korea Industrial Development Co, unit of Hyundai conglomerate, is unable to meet debt payments and is expected to apply for bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: On Africa's Caravan Trail
abstract: In a corner of Niger that was once a vast sea, dozens of families mine salt, and are the inheritors of a caravan trade that brought life to the Sahara for centuries. Page A12.

headline: North Koreans Join Relatives In the South As Putin Visits
abstract: Group of 100 North Koreans arrives in Seoul on third round of long-awaited family reunions; Pres Kim Dae Jung highlights his 'sunshine' policy as he prepares to receive Russian Pres Vladimir Putin (S)

headline: Bush Holds His First White House News Conference
abstract: Pres Bush holds his first White House news conference; seeks public attention and support for his proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut (M)

headline: GENERAL MOTORS AGAIN CUTS PRODUCTION PLANS
abstract: General Motors Corp will build 100,000 fewer cars and trucks in first quarter North American than it had planned last month, to try to reduce dealer inventories as sales slow; will produce 1.2 million vehicles, down 21 percent from last year's first-quarter output of 1.521 million; plans to produce 562,000 cars and 638,000 trucks (S)

headline: Fewer Borders For Global Accounting
abstract: New International Accounting Standards Board is appointed, with mission of producing coordinated acounting standards within few years; board will be led by Sir David Tweedie, who formerly directed Accounting Standards Board in Britain; Sir David expresses hope that several major standards will be agreed upon within three years and will be accepted by accounting regulators in leading countries; to extent that identical accounting standards are accepted in major countries, this would reduce costs for multinational companies in complying with varying rules, and make it easier for investors to compare companies in different countries; Paul A Volcker headed committee that appointed 14 members to new board (M)

headline: EUROPE'S INFLATION RISES
abstract: February consumer prices in 12 countries using euro rises at annual rate of 2.6 percent, lessening likelihood of European Central Bank cutting interest rates soon (S)

headline: No Labor Accord at Northwest
abstract: Northwest Airlines and its mechanics fail to reach agreement on contract by deadline March 11; union supporters march in front of White House to protest Pres George W Bush's order to delay strike for 60 days; photo (M)

headline: De Beers Posts Solid Results But Predicts a Tougher Future
abstract: De Beers posts sales of $5.67 billion for 2000 but says it expects economic slowdown in US to reduce sales 15 percent this year, nearly $900 million; says sales reached record last year, as wholesalers bought rough diamonds to replenish stocks that had been run down in 1999 as premillennium buying spree; net income in 2000 rose 84 percent, to $1.29 billion; sales of uncut stones slumped to $2.15 billion in second half of 2000 from $3.52 billion in first half (M)

headline: KULICKE & SOFFA CUTS 300 JOBS AS FEWER ORDERS COME IN
abstract: Kulicke & Soffa Industries, leading maker of semiconductor-assembly equipment, is cutting about 300 jobs, or 7 percent of its work force, because of fewer orders (S)

headline: HEWLETT OFFERS INTERNET SOFTWARE
abstract: Hewlett-Packard introduces two Internet-based software suites that help business clients streamline their Web operations (S)

headline: OFFICE DEPOT TO CLOSE STORES AND CUT JOBS
abstract: Office Depot Inc, top American retailer of office supplies, plans to close 70 stores in 18 states and Canada, eliminate 1,590 jobs and take fourth-quarter pretax charge of $300 million related to cutbacks; chief executive Bruce Nelson says company expanded too aggressively to compete with rivals like OfficeMax and Staples and that some markets have become saturated; will invest $110 million to spruce up some of its 818 surviving stores in North America and install new inventory-tracking systems at warehouses (S)

headline: PENTAIR CUTS 400 JOBS AT TOOL UNIT AND HEADQUARTERS
abstract: Pentair Inc, maker of power tools, says it has cut 400 jobs since end of third quarter and that its first-quarter earnings will be better than estimates; says 340 of jobs came from closing down production in last two weeks of December and first two weeks of January; also says it has cut half staff at its headquarters, closed executive offices in Minneapolis and moved operations to its offices in St Paul; says actions will save about $20 million annually (S)

headline: Thai Leader Narrowly Escapes Jet Explosion
abstract: KUALA LUMPUR—  Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra of Thailand said Sunday that an explosion on a Thai Airways jet that he was minutes from boarding was probably an assassination attempt.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMER OYJ ,  Helsinki, the Finnish owner of the Wilson sports and Atomic ski brands, said it would close its United States tennis ball factory in Fountain Inn, S.C., and move production to a factory near Bangkok, because of rising labor and raw material costs. The closure would result in the loss of 300 jobs.    HEIDELBERGER ZEMENT A.G.,  Heidelberg, Germany, the No. 3 cement maker in the world, has agreed to take control of PT Indocement Tunggal Prakarsa T.b.k., the No. 2 maker of cement in Indonesia, increasing its cement capacity by 25 percent as it expands in developing regions. Terms of the pact were not disclosed.

headline: A Nominal Role for Lipper
abstract: Lipper Inc, mutual fund research and tracking firm Reuters Group bought from founder A Michael Lipper in 1998, has not renewed Lipper's contract as consultant and nonexecutive chairman (S)

headline: Eroding Paper Gains May Undo a Remarkable Resiliency
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column says that individual stock investors have shown remarkable staying power despite decline of stock prices since March 2000, but that much of their faith may be due to fact that they still retain much of unrealized profits they have earned since beginning of bull market; cites study by Jim Bianco, who says that investors may jump ship en masse once these unrealized profits disappear and that at that point reverse wealth effect would begin to harm economy; graph (M)

headline: Severe Earthquake Strikes India, Killing Thousands
abstract: Devastating earthquake strikes western state of Gujarat in India; more than 2,300 people are confirmed dead, and total could rise by thousands; rescue teams work under floodlights, often with bare hands, to clear rubble as they struggle to save victims buried in collapsed buildings; quake is thought to be about same magnitude as severe quake that struck El Salvador on Jan 13, which measured 7.6; in town of Ahmedabad, apartment buildings collapse in center of town and on quiet residential streets; Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee pledges to give affected states every assistance; many people are missing; photos; map (M)

headline: Financial Role Reversal
abstract: Paul Feiner letter on Jan 14 article concerning teenage investors

abstract: Microsoft begins avertising drive aimed at businesses for its computer software (S)

headline: Israel Hunts Down and Kills a Top Arafat Security Officer
abstract: JERUSALEM, Feb. 13 — Two Israeli helicopter gunships swooped over northern Gaza this morning and dropped four missiles on the car of a senior Palestinian security officer, instantly killing a man whom Israel considered a terrorist in a uniform and a beret.

headline: Chihuahua State Governor Shot; Ex-Officer Is Detained in Attack
abstract: Patricio Martinez Garcia, governor of Chihuahua, Mexico's largest state, is shot and wounded in assassination attempt; he is said to be in stable condition; spokesman for state attorney general's office announces arrest of Victoria Loya, police officer dismissed four years ago after being accused of trying to shoot her husband; Martinez had been regarded as potential presidential candidate in 2006 (M)

headline: Sour Economic Reports Send Nasdaq to 2-Year Low
abstract: Technology stocks fell sharply today, pulling the Nasdaq composite index down more than 4 percent to its lowest close since the end of 1998, after more sour economic reports failed to prompt the immediate cut in interest rates that much of Wall Street had come to expect.

headline: ABBEY REJECTS BID AGAIN
abstract: Abbey National rejects for second time 19.2 million pound ($28 million) takeover offer from Llodys TBS Group; British regulators approve proposed merger between Abbey National and Bank of Scotland (S)

headline: BALTIMORE TECHNOLOGIES REPORTS SALES SURGE
abstract: Baltimore Technologies PLC, Irish developer of security software, reports preliminary annual sales of 74.2 million pounds, or $110.9 million, for year ended Dec 31, increase of 219 percent over 1999; says its loss rose to 25.4 million pounds from 20 million pounds for 2000; reports loss of 8.7 million pounds on sales of 28.4 million pounds in quarter (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: THE AMERICAS    CHILE: PINOCHET CHARGES REDUCED  The Court of Appeals reduced charges against the retired general Augusto Pinochet from planning the kidnapping and deaths of 75 leftists in the early 1970's, but said he could still stand trial on charges that he covered them up. The reduction will probably be appealed to the Supreme Court. In another action, the court rejected a motion by lawyers for the former dictator to nullify an order placing General Pinochet under house arrest.    Clifford Krauss (NYT)

headline: Capitol Hawks Seek Tougher Line on Iraq
abstract: Sec of State Colin Powell is taking lead in shaping new policy toward Iraq that is being criticized by conservative Republicans in Congress as too lenient; some Republicans charge senior Bush officials, including Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld and deputy Paul D Wolfowitz, are failing to live up to pre-election advocacy of stepping up efforts to overthrow Pres Saddam Hussein (M)

headline: NORILSK REORGANIZATION APPROVED

headline: Primedia and Brill Media in Joint Venture
abstract: Primedia, magazine conglomerate, says it will place its properties that report on media industry under editorial guidance of Steven Brill, founder of Brill's Content magazine; move will combine 172 magazines, newsletters, Web sites and other properties; Brill's company, Brill Media Holdings, will relinquish 49 percent of that company in return for undisclosed interest in venture (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Singapore Telecom to Buy Australian Mobile Company  Singapore Telecommunications has won the competition to acquire Cable and Wireless Optus, the second-largest mobile phone company in Australia, with a bid as high as $8.55 billion that was slipped in before the other serious contender, Vodafone Pacific, could clear regulatory hurdles and make a formal bid of its own, people close to the deal said.    Cable and Wireless of Britain, the majority owner of Optus, is expected to announce the deal today. The total value is slightly less than most analysts had forecast. [Page C2.]

headline: A Faint Voice in the Rubble, And a 5-Day Ordeal Is Ended
abstract: Man pulled out of rubble of India's earthquake after 5-day ordeal is Fairleigh Dickinson University student, home in Bhuj for family visit; Viral Dalal, 24, is rescued by members of International Rescue Corps flown to India by British government; he had been trapped in small space with 30 feet of rubble on top of him; Dalal, who emerges unhurt, is probably only member of his immediate family left alive; photo; map (M)

headline: EBay Greatly Expands Live Online Auction Bidding
abstract: Online auction company EBay reaches pact with icollector that will let its users take part in live bidding at 300 auction houses worldwide (M)

headline: Roughnecks Wrangle for More Money
abstract: Workers trying to force a reluctant employer to give them a raise, generally have to threaten to strike or to leave. Now, though, a group of Texas offshore oil workers has come up with a novel strategy for wringing more money out of their bosses: antitrust litigation.    According to a complaint filed in federal court in Galveston, the rig hands contend their employers have been meeting secretly the last 10 years or longer to set ceilings on wages and police the agreement. Such activity constitutes price fixing, the complaint asserts, a felony.

headline: Powell Pledges Strong Support for Wide Spectrum of U.N. Activities
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell holds meeting with United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan, seeking to assure Annan that he can count on Bush administration's strong support across wide spectrum of UN activities; Powell praises Richard C Holbrooke, former American envoy to UN, for his work in solving problem of American debts to organization; Powell goes further than most Republicans in pledging to cooperate with UN in working on social and economic problems (M)

headline: Proposed Law Stirs Concern on Europe E-Commerce
abstract: Advertisers, publishers and online commerce companies warn that barriers to communicating across borders in European Union would be erected by proposed law to govern noncontractural liability in cross-border disputes within union and clarify which nation's laws should apply in dispute involving citizen of one country and company marketing its goods or services, or communicating over Internet, from another; proposed law provides that law in consumer's country should apply in such dispute; such rule would contradict several others, including directive on e-commerce passed in 2000; newspapers that publish online would also be affected, because proposal covers rules on defamation (M)

headline: Changes of agencies and accounts may affect the marketing of meat and motoring.
abstract: Verizon Wireless names New York office of Bozell Group as advertising agency of record on its account, including its national brand advertising; billings estimated at $300 million; Bozell is awaiting word on fate of National Pork Producers Council assignment; billings are estimated at $25 million; Jaguar cars division of Ford Motor Co is expected to name London and New York offices of Young & Rubicam Advertising to create worldwide campaign for X-Type, compact all-wheel-drive Jaguar sedan to be introduced in summer (M)

headline: Australia Set to Auction Mobile Phone Licenses
abstract: Auction for third-generation mobile phone licenses in Australia, scheduled to begin on March 15, is progressing more smoothly than recent sales in some other countries; timetable is on track, and a range of companies, both domestic and multinational, recently paid deposits to participate (M)

headline: A Rocky Meeting in Belgrade For War Crimes Prosecutor
abstract: Carla del Ponte, chief prosecutor of United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague, meets with Pres Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia in Belgrade, and they appear to disagree on many issues; del Ponte leaves in some haste without handing over a sealed indictment for someone living in Yugoslavia whom she hoped the government would help to arrest; has demanded that former Pres Slobodan Milosevic be arrested and transferred to The Hague, but Kostunica has made it clear that he is reluctant to cooperate and has repeatedly described tribunal as a political institution that is biased against Serbs; photo (M)

headline: American Is Guiding A Market For China
abstract: James Liu is an American. That is not surprising until you consider what Mr. Liu does: he helps run the Shanghai Stock Exchange. He is the exchange's executive vice president, working to reshape China's state-dominated equity markets into a capitalist tool.    It has not been easy. Most recently, he backed proposals to open the country's hard-currency share market to local investors, only to have superiors override his advice that it be done gradually. The sudden opening sent prices rocketing more than 50 percent.

headline: The Postal Service is going right along with the trend of putting ads on everything in sight.
abstract: US Postal Service is accelerating plans to offer marketers advertising space to peddle private goods and services in places where paid pitches had never appeared until last year, including sides of mail trucks and collection boxes, in post office lobbies and on service's Web site; photo (M)

headline: China's Long — but Uneven — March to Literacy
abstract: BEIJING—  Hua Lijun owns a most decidedly unfashionable pair of thick black reading glasses, and when she puts them on she has no trouble at all threading a needle. Still, she mutters constantly about her poor eyesight.

headline: Indications Of New Vision At Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft Corp names Richard E Belluzzo, who has been group vice president overseeing deelopment of Windows.NET operating platform and MSN Network of Web sites for 18 months, to be its president and chief operating officer; appointment gives clearest signal yet that future of computing, and Microsoft's future, lies beyond personal computer, foundation of its business and still source of about 70 percent of its revenue; Belluzzo succeeds Robert J Herbold, who is retiring; Microsoft confirms Justice Department has opened new inquiry into company's $135 million investment in Corel Corp, rival software maker; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001010690993841820 -- No Title
abstract: Creating a Generation of Slouchers

headline: British Telecom May Cancel Public Offering for Wireless Unit
abstract: British Telecommunications confirms it may delay initial public offering for its wireless unit (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Inventory Problem Leads To Profit Warning at Nike  Nike said that its third-quarter profit would fall short of forecasts because of problems with an inventory system that led to shortages and late deliveries.    To compensate for the shortages, the company said, it ordered so many shoes that it will be trying to work through excess inventory for months to come. Nike now expects to earn 34 to 38 cents a share for the quarter -- far below its previous estimate of 50 to 55 cents a share. In after-hours trading, shares of Nike fell as low as $40.30 after closing at $49.17. [Page C2.]

headline: A short film during Women's History Month pays tribute to the leaders in the industry.
abstract: Advertising Women of New York honors experiences and contributions of women in advertising and marketing as part of Women's History Month observances; program features film produced and donated by History Channel that focuses on some 20 female top executives, past and present (M)

headline: Priceline Extends Late Booking for Travel
abstract: Priceline.com is extending its last-minute booking feature to all its travel services; company is allowing customers to buy airline tickets as late as 6 pm on day before their departure; they can also book hotel room until 6 pm for stay same evening or rent car and pick it up within four hours (M)

headline: WIRELESS GIANTS PLAN GAMES STANDARD
abstract: Ericsson, Motorola and Siemens will work together to develop games standard for wireless communications devices (S)

headline: Strouds Bankruptcy Sale
abstract: CITY OF INDUSTRY, Calif., Feb. 2 — Strouds Inc., a seller of bed and bath linens, has asked a bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del., to approve its plan to sell 50 stores and most of its remaining assets to iHome Inc. for about $38 million. IHome, which sells linens and furniture over the Internet, agreed to buy all but six of Strouds's stores, all its trademarks and copyrights, two distribution centers and a Web site, Strouds said. Strouds filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in September.

headline: Limits of Recording
abstract: Warren Wetmore letter, commenting on Jan 4 Q&A, says his new Pentium III computer with an internal CD-R burner cannot successfully record a disc if another application is being used

headline: Intel Again Warns of Slumping Revenue This Quarter
abstract: Intel Corp, for second time in six weeks, cautions that its revenue this quarter will fall short of Wall Street expectations; will eliminate 5,000 jobs by year's end, mainly through normal attrition, and trim spending on research and development by 2 percent (M)

headline: Powell Shifts Emphasis of Mideast Policy
abstract: Sec of State Colin Powell articulates for first time major underpinnings of Bush administration's Middle East policy, address, conference of American Israel Public Affairs Committee, Washington; draws sharp distinction from Clinton administration's strategy of engagement in Israeli-Palestinian conflict by stating that US stands ready to 'assist, not insist;' says status quo should not be allowed to stand, but that it is parties themselves who must start dialogue; conference is addressed by new Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon; he says violence between Israelis and Palestinians must stop; focuses on terrorism as scourge of region; accuses Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat of reverting to belief that Palestinians can defeat Israel by means of armed struggle, and of willingness to destabilize entire region to achieve his goals; photo (M)

headline: Broadcast of Rape Angers Women's Groups in Israel
abstract: broado

headline: Golden Boy to Visit Middle Kingdom
abstract: Canadian trade delegation to China will include 12-year-old Keith Peiris, who founded and runs highly successful Web site company; photo (S)

headline: Sentences of Some Dissidents Are Quietly Reduced in China
abstract: sentences of some dissidents a

headline: Postal Office Offers Secure Online Service To Government
abstract: The United States Postal Service offers online service that allows transfer of sensitive documents, like birth certificates and medical records, over Internet in secure way; service is electronic version of certified mail; uses system of passwords and secure identification cards embedded with computer chips to provide sender with proof that document was delivered to intended recipient; Social Security Administration has begun to use service, joining Health Care Finance Administration in testing program (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   8.50   8.50   8.75        Discount rate   5.00   5.00   5.25        Federal funds   5.56   5.50   5.76        3-month T-bills   4.84   4.86   5.62        6-month T-bills   4.66   4.71   5.74        10-yr. T-infl.   3.41   3.40   4.26        10-yr. T-note   5.16   5.13   6.36        30-yr. T-bond   5.53   5.48   6.13        Telephone bd.   7.78   7.85   8.25        Municipal bds.   5.42   5.42   6.17          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Companies Announce Setback In Treatment for Parkinson's
abstract: Genzyme Corp and Diacrin Inc, in new setback for experimental therapy for Parkinson's disease, say implanting fetal pig cells into patients' brains failed to improve their condition compared with control group; says both treated and control group, which had sham surgery, seemed to improve, indicating strong placebo effect; says treated patients did not suffer uncontrolled movements found in new academic study, which used cells from aborted fetuses; Diacrin shares plunge (M)

headline: SAGE BUYS INTERACT COMMERCE
abstract: Sage Group buys Interact Commerce Corp, maker of client-management software, for some $260 million; graph (S)

headline: David McTaggart, a Builder of Greenpeace, Dies at 69
abstract: David McTaggart, credited with building Greenpeace in worldwide environmental movement, dies at age 69; photo (M)

headline: Refugees in Kenya Tell of Shakedown by U.N. Agency
abstract: United Nations quietly probes charges that corrupt workers with UN high commissioner for refugees in Kenya, nation where corruption is norm, extorted fees for agency's essential services, which are supposed to be free; charges focus on bids for asylum in United States by refugees fleeing wars in other African nations; centers on at least four workers responsible for processing and vetting applications; officials of refugee aid groups are unusually afraid to speak out publicly about charges in wake of death threats that forced evacuation of three Western UN employees who reportedly learned about scheme (M)

headline: U.S. and British Jets Strike Air-Defense Centers in Iraq
abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 — The United States and Britain staged air strikes against radar stations and air defense command centers in Iraq today, including targets around Baghdad, in what President Bush called a necessary response to Iraqi provocation.

headline: Procter & Gamble and Coke to Form New Snack Company
abstract: Someday soon, consumers may find cans of Procter & Gamble's Pringles chips next to cans of Coke in vending machines nationwide.

headline: Atlantic Foundation Changing Management
abstract: Prof Harvey P Dale will step down as president of Atlantic Foundation and chairman of its operating arm, Atlantic Philanthropic Services in New York; will remain director endowment; Joel L Fleishman, president of Atlantic Philanthropic Services, is also leaving; new president of Atlantic Philanthropic Services is Alan Ruby (M)

headline: New Directors for Mexico Oil Monopoly
abstract: Mexico's Pres Vicente Fox announces new slate of directors for board of Pemex, state-owned oil company, in effort to transform company from bloated antiquated monopoly into something more like efficient multinational corporation; new board includes 3 of 10 richest people in Mexico: Carlos Slim Helu, chairman of Telefonos de Mexico, Lorenzo Zambrano, president of Cemex, and Alfonso Romo Garza, chairman of Grupo Pulsar; photos (M)

headline: Macedonian Chief Says Albanian Rebels Are in Disarray
abstract: Macedonian Pres Boris Trajkovski appears remarkably calm and reasonable, for leader facing growing insurgency in hills less than 20 miles from his capital, Skopje, a rebellion that threatens not only his security forces but very fabric of ethnically divided country; he says he is optimistic that armed ethnic Albanians who killed four members of his security forces in last week had already been scattered; photo; map (L)

headline: DELL AND UNISYS EXPAND ALLIANCE
abstract: Dell Computer and Unisys complete plans to expand their marketing alliance; new arrangements are expected to generate $1 billion in added sales; Unisys will resell number of Dell midrange servers under its own brand and market Dell personal computers to Unisys customers (S)

headline: Smelling the Coffee
abstract: Howard Zeidman letter comments on Jan 25 Online Shopper column on buying coffee over the Web; photo

headline: This Time, America Kept Its Hands Out of the Crisis in Philippines
abstract: MANILA—  During 400 years of colonial rule and a half century of postwar independence, politics in the Philippines has been consistently influenced by foreign intervention — either overt military action of the Spanish and American armies or behind-the-scenes work by the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: A Decision Is Reached On a Successor At Southwest
abstract: Herbert D Kelleher will step down as chief executive of Southwest Airlines and be succeeded in post by James F Parker, its longtime general counsel, who will also become vice chairman and eventually succeed Kelleher as chairman; Colleen C Barrett will be promoted to new position of president and chief operating officer; Kelleher will remain chairman until at least 2003; photo (M)

headline: Blue Chips Manage Modest Gains After Fed Cuts Rates
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 6.16 points, to 10,887.36; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 7.72 points, to 1,366.01; Nasdaq composite index falls 65.2 points, to 2,772.73; graph; table (M)

headline: Article 2001011792114482918 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Compressed Data; Gorbachev: A Site to Remember
abstract: New Web site is dedicated to Mikhail S Gorbachev, former president of former Soviet Union; Diane Meyer Simon, backer of Green Cross International, environmental group he heads, is helping to pay for site, which marks his 70th birthday; photo (M)

headline: EToys, Unable to Find Buyer, Plans to File for Bankruptcy
abstract: EToys Inc will file for bankruptcy protection because it has been unable to find buyer or more financing (M)

headline: LOSS AT SKY BROADCASTING
abstract: British Sky Broadcasting Group says pretax first-half losses rose more than fourfold to $389 million; company says it will return to profit by 2003 with seven million customers (S)

headline: NEW COMPANY BEING FORMED
abstract: Procter & Gamble and Worldwide Magnifi are forming company that will offer marketing knowledge, applications and technology infrastructure to other companies (S)

headline: San Antonio Palopó Journal; The Sincerest Form of Flattery Takes to the Loom
abstract: Livelihood of members of weavers cooperative in San Antonio Palopo, Guatemala, who successfully shifted from subsistence farming 20 years ago is threatened by almost three-quarters of village's residents, who have also made shift to support families and are churning out knockoffs and paying little attention to quality while taking advantage of worldwide reputation of Guatemalan textiles among thousands of tourists who visit each year; see their designs brazenly stolen and their future looking lot like their past, as they are forced slowly back to land; photo; map (M)

headline: A Playful Flirtation With Belle Epoque Erotica . . . Sensuality Is the Key
abstract: PARIS—  Sex is the subtext of these autumn/winter collections. With near naked bodies familiar on the runways and fashion advertising increasingly explicit, designers seem to be pushing ever harder at the boundaries of eroticism.

headline: Barnesandnoble.com to Cut 350 Jobs as Its Loss Widens
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com Inc., the No. 2 Web-based bookseller after Amazon.com, announced today that it would eliminate about 350 jobs in an effort to cut costs.

headline: Q & A: How Do You Send Something as a Zip File E-Mail Attachment?
abstract: .gif" ALIGN="left" ALT=">"> Q. How do you send something as a ZIP file e-mail attachment?

headline: Offerings Set In Debt Market
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.70 percent and a six-month bill was 4.50 percent.
