headline: Turkey Tries to Step Up Sell-Off of State Companies
abstract: Turkey's privatization officials will seek to interest European companies in state-owned telephone company, Turk Telecom, a deal many analysts see as litmus test for country's economy; government, under pressure from International Monetary Fund, has agreed to sell 33.5 percent of company and provide management rights to buyer after offer last year to sell 20 percent failed to attract any bids; government has agreed to sell Turkish Airlines as part of deal to receive $7.5 billion emergency loan from IMF; airline stake is expected to be easier to sell than stake in phone company; photos (M)

headline: DUPONT TOLD TO PAY $12.3 MILLION FOR CHEMICAL DAMAGE
abstract: Jury in Florida says DuPont Co must pay $12.3 million to Ecuadorean shrimp-farming company, Aquamar, because DuPont's Benlate fungicide damaged harvests; Aquamar said that Benlate was used with other fungicides on banana plantations in Ecuador and that runoff from combination poisoned shrimp; twenty-seven more cases brought by Ecuadorean shrimp farmers against DuPont await trial (S)

headline: Agencies Making Four Acquisitions
abstract: Jack Morton Worldwide acquires Planet Interactive; WPP Group is acquiring Imaginet; Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide is acquiring Deen & Black; Cordiant Communications Group is increasing its equity interest in Newcomm Bates Group to 51 percent from 32 percent; Cordiant will initially pay $10.6 million (S)

headline: Tran Van Lam, 88, Top South Vietnam Aide
abstract: Tran Van Lam, former foreign minister of South Vietnam, dies at age 88; photo (S)

headline: NBC Seeks Innovation In Prime Time
abstract: NBC Television's new president, Jeff Zucker, discusses plans to shake up direction of programming in several areas; cites need to improve poor weekend performance; says he will steer programming strategy away from stress on sweeps months and add at least two hours or reality programming a week; says he will act to fix economic structure of entertainment side of business; photo (M)

headline: Yugoslav Parliament Passes Amnesty for Jailed Kosovars
abstract: Yugoslav parliament passes long-awaited amnesty law that will free several hundred Kosovo Albanians held in Serbian prisons since 1999 war, and will also clear thousands of draft dodgers and deserters; first major piece of legislation passed by new parliament is also first real gesture by new government to reverse injustices suffered by Kosovo Albanians; photo (M)

headline: ELECTRONIC DATA AND ARCHIVE SIGN PACT
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp signs seven-year agreement to provide business-to-business integration services and back-end data center operations for Archive Inc (S)

headline: A Makeover For CNNfn
abstract: AOL Time Warner says it will change name of its struggling financial cable news network, CNNfn, to CNN Money and see to it that network becomes available on more cable systems; CNNfn lags far behind CNBC; photo; graph (M)

headline: BROADCASTER WARNS ON PROFIT
abstract: Europe's biggest broadcaster, the RTL Group, warned that softening market conditions for advertising sales in 2001, combined with the effect of revamping its Pearson Television North America unit, would probably keep profits flat. The tempered outlook was delivered as the company, which agreed last month to be acquired by Bertelsmann of Germany, reported that profit in 2000 fell by 61 percent but met analysts' expectations. RTL is based in Luxembourg.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline: Europe Making Sweden Ease Alcohol Rules
abstract: Sweden has for decades imposed measures to discourage consumption of alchohol in effort to undermine tradition of drinking to excess, but it is being forced to take apart its anti-alcohol policies piece by piece because most violate European Union's rules of fair competition; many Swedes applaud changes, but others are deeply concerned that years of controlling consumption through state-owned monopolies and high taxes have not really cured nation of bad drinking habits; photo (M)

headline: Big Companies Prove Winners In Airwave Bids
abstract: Nation's largest wireless phone services, exploiting rules intended to help smallest telecommunications companies and bolster competition, are on verge of winning scores of new licenses at Federal Communications Commission auction at sharp discount through deals with smaller partners; Verizon Wireless, one national company that refused to form partnership with small company, appears likely to pay highest price for licenses, while other small companies complain of losing out to partners of giant companies; over 95 percent of high bids have come from large companies and their partners; table (M)

headline: An End To Laptop Envy
abstract: David Pogue column says the best new Apple Computer product unveiled at Macworld Expo was a PowerBook G4, a lap-top that is one inch thick when closed but that is loaded with power and accommodates a vast, wide screen (M)

headline: High-Stakes Showdown; Enron's Fight Over Power Plant Reverberates Beyond India
abstract: India's state of Maharashtra has stopped paying its bills for huge $3 billion power plant built by Dabhol Power Co, which is largely owned by Enron Corp; says it does not need and cannot afford most of power; Dabhol Power has invoked central government's guarantee to pay up since state has not, and central government says it will honor commitment; Dabhol project has potential to sour foreign investors on India and to sour Indians on foreign investors; accounts for more than 10 percent of total direct foreign investment in India since 1992; map; graph; photos (M)

headline: Arthur Hummel, Ambassador to China '81-85, Dies at 80
abstract: Arthur W. Hummel Jr., who as ambassador to China from 1981 to 1985 negotiated an agreement on United States arms sales to Taiwan, died on Feb. 6 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 80.

headline: H & R BLOCK ISSUES A WARNING, AND SOME REASSURANCE
abstract: H & R Block Inc says that though change in timing of some marketing expenses will cause it to fall short of analysts' expectations for its third fiscal quarter, fourth quarter will be correspondingly better than expected and outlook for full fiscal year ending in April is unchanged (S)

headline: M.I.T. Professor Reconsiders Children's Online Lives
abstract: There are few neighborhoods left where children can meet their pals after school for a friendly game of kickball in a vacant lot. Parents should accept this reality of contemporary life and understand that the virtual world can be a boon to today's latchkey child.

headline: We're Doing Battle Right and Left, Colombia Insists
abstract: Colombian Pres Andres Pastrana, seeking more aid from US and Europe, vows to fight right-wing parramilitaries as well as leftist rebels, interview; some American officials and rights groups see little effort against paramilitary groups, which killed 577 people last year alone; photo (M)

headline: Business Travel; Rosenbluth is cutting back its late-flight guarantees as more delays and problems loom.
abstract: Rosenbluth International, worldwide travel-management company that has popular online business-travel portal, Biztravel.com, is cutting back its promise of substantial refunds to people using Biztravel.com to book tickets on certain airlines if they encounter flight delays or cancellations; cost of guarantee grew from anticipated $600,000 to $1.6 million owing to rise in delays and cancellations (M)

headline: Officials Call Economy Down, But Not Out, in the Philippines
abstract: Tens of thousands of anti-government protesters choke streets of Manila's business district; top advisers to Pres Joseph Estrada acknowledge that political turmoil is damaging economy of Philippines; contend that collapse of Estrada's impeachment trial will not propel country into recession (M)

headline: Palestinians Outline Objections to Clinton Peace Plan
abstract: Palestinians issue first detailed public reaction to Pres Clinton's peace proposals; conclude that plan neglects Palestinian need for viable state and rights of refugees and fails to satisfy conditions required for permanent peace and workable security arrangements (M)

headline: Block Is Ordered to Stop Advertising 'Rapid Refunds' of Taxes
abstract: Judge Raymond A Jackson orders H&R Block to stop using 'rapid refund' and other terms that he says are deliberately intended to disguise expensive loans that Block arranges for people anticipating refunds on their income taxes; finds that Block engaged in false advertising and went to great lengths to conceal reality that rather than receiving refunds, clients were taking out high-interest loan to obtain their money few days sooner than Treasury would have sent it to them at no charge; on some loans, annual percentage rate charged was more than 500 percent; Jackson says Block acted 'maliciously, willfully and in bad faith'; lawsuit was brought by John Hewitt, former Block executive, who founded Jackson Tax Service, and later sold it; Hewitt opened Liberty Tax Service in 1996, which now has franchises in 37 states (M)

headline: New Economy; The updated context notwithstanding, the issues behind unionization drives at dot-coms have a familiar ring.
abstract: Traditional labor issues such as wages, schedules and promotions are arising at Internet startups as initial enthusiasm and gauzy hopes of stock-offering wealth fade; many of these issues came together at Etown.com, where what would have been first unionization vote at dot-com company has been postponed for at least six months, pending outcome of National Labor Relations Board ruling on complaint filed by Communications Workers of America (M)

headline: Article 2001030890438292109 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Russian Wants Dialogue With U.S. on Limited Missile Defenses
abstract: Russian Foreign Min Igor S Ivanov says his country and United States should discuss development of defenses against ballistic missiles in troubled parts of world, but he reiterates Moscow's opposition to any plan to erect national missile defense over United States in violation of 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty; Bush administration, like Clinton administration, advocates going forward with national antimissile system, as well as theater antimissile systems intended to protect American troops and bases in conflicts abroad (M)

headline: CNBC Suffers Slings and Arrows of Market's Slide
abstract: CNBC is accused of covering stock market fall so heavily that it is adding to inordinate sense of doom and market volatility; criticism is coming from several economists, print journalists and even some of its own viewers and has prompted defensive stance from CNBC's executives and correspondents; CNBC, once place where people went to hear stock tips from hottest analysts and fund managers, is now bellwether for market's descent, where people often go to hear latest bad news; photo (M)

headline: They Agree on One Thing: Barak Was All Wrong
abstract: News analysis: Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon, veteran hawk, and Foreign Min Shimon Peres, inveterate peacemaker, share some common ground, which suggests that they could forge unusual working partnership if they can keep their egos and ideologies from colliding; both believe in gradual approach to forging resolution of Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and share disdain for methods of former Prime Min Ehud Barak; photo (M)

headline: Mexico to Extradite an Argentine Accused of Genocide to Spain
abstract: Mexico will extradite Ricardo Cavallo, former Argentine Navy officer accused of abuses committed under Argentina's dictatorship 20 years ago, to Madrid; in Spain he faces charges of genocide, torture and terrorism against Spaniards; human righs experts say never before has person accused of crimes against humanity been sought for trial in second nation and extradited by third; government of Argentina, which imposed sweeping amnesty protecting junta's soldiers from prosecution, argued against extradition (M)

headline: Value Investing Is Back in Style, and So Is a Fund Warhorse
abstract: Rebound in value stocks in 2000 enabled six portfolio managers who run Franklin Mutual Series family of mutual funds to all beat Standard & Poor's 500-stock index for first time since 1994; rebound followed heavy net redemptions, totaling $14 billion since 1998; graph of fund performance; photo (M)

headline: Technology: Real-Time Challenges, in Cyberspace and on the Ground
abstract: Looser Policy Likely on Antitrust Scrutiny

headline: U.S. Finds Firing by Morgan Stanley a Reprisal for Sex-Bias Charge
abstract: Equal Employment Opportunity Commission determines that Morgan Stanley Dean Witter fired Allison Schieffelin, who worked in covertible bond department, as retaliatory move after she accused company of sexual discrimination; finding means that commission may file suit against Morgan Stanley if firm does not settle matter; Schieffelin can take part in that suit or pursue litigation separately; Schieffelin was dismissed in October, soon after Morgan Stanley's formal talks to settle matter with EEOC ended, and four months after commission found that Morgan Stanley discriminated against women and that Schieffelin had been denied promotion to managing director because of her sex; Morgan Stanley says Schieffelin was fired 'as the result of disruptive and insubordinate behavior toward her direct supervisor'; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: David Murphy, president at Irvine, Calif, office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, is promoted to new post of chief executive; Sue Furlong, president for communication practice at DVC Worldwide is promoted to president, succeeding George Valava, now chief executive at DVC and DVC Worldwide; Graham Turner is named to vacant post of executive creative director at Siegelgale (S)

headline: Nestlé Reported to Be Close to Buying Ralston Purina
abstract: Nestlé S.A. is close to reaching a deal to acquire the pet food maker Ralston Purina Company for about $10 billion in cash, according to executives close to the talks. The companies' boards are planning to vote on the transaction today and announce the deal Tuesday morning, the executives said.

headline: Reebok's Quarterly Profit Surges
abstract: Reebok International says net income rose to $6.2 million in fourth quarter compared with loss of $14.7 million year earlier; sales fell to $622.5 million from $622.8 million (M)

headline: Luring the Best in an Unsettled Time
abstract: Companies are searching urgently for new ways to foster old-fashioned loyalty and commitment among employees, most of whom have little institutional loyalty left after years of downsizings, outsourcings and restructurings; several influential corporations are experimenting with concept called 'employer of choice,' in which they seek to identify traits of model employees, figure out what these people want in job and see to it that these people think they will find it more reliably at their company than anywhere else; trick is to win employees' sense of old-fashioned commitment without locking company into old-fashioned employment arrangement; compensation experts say last generation's weapons for fighting war for talent--excellent health insurance and pension plans, and seniority-based compensation schemes--are nonstarters today, because companies must maintain flexibility; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Owing More Than Loyalty to a Company You Run
abstract: Many publicly held companies make loans to chief executives and higher managers that carry far more lenient terms than marketplace offers, and companies often forgive the debts; companies carry loans on their books as assets, but they can quickly turn into liabilities; photos (M)

headline: Marketing Group Forms New Council
abstract: Direct Marketing Association acquires Association of Direct Marketing Agencies, which will be merged with its Agency Leaders Group to form new Direct Marketing Agency Council (S)

headline: Article 2001031292867157738 -- No Title
abstract: A Robot That Works in the City Sewer

headline: Study tries to help retailers understand what drives the shopping habits of women.
abstract: Study from Saatchi & Saatchi Collaborative Marketing tries to help advertisers and agencies increase business by understanding demographic and psychological changes that are altering ways women shop; underpinning of study is belief that the store is becoming medium as important as television, newspapers or Intenet (M)

headline: INDIAN SOFTWARE PROFIT UP
abstract: India's Infosys Technologies says profits in third fiscal quarter increased to 1.66 billion rupees ($36 million) from 737.9 million rupees a year ago; sales more than doubled to 5.5 billion rupees ($118 million) in quarter ended Dec 31 (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: New Economy; Corporate credit managers have long warned about Internet companies' shaky math. Now, people are listening.
abstract: New Economy column contends that stock analysts like Henry Blodget of Merrill Lynch still express enthusiasm about prospects for many of troubled Web companies they follow; holds, however, that with capital markets closed to cash-short Internet companies, bullish analysts no longer hold key to company's ability to raise money; control of cash drawer has shifted to corporate credit managers, decidely less prominent people at companies that sell products to retailers and other concerns (M)

headline: Nextel Says Spending May Hurt Results
abstract: Nextel Communications says that higher spending to attract and keep customers and upgrade networks and capabilities may hurt first-quarter results; stock slides 14 percent and is down 58 percent in past year (M)

headline: ITALIAN FASHION: Many Yarns Spin a Revival in Calabria
abstract: CAULONIA, Italy—  Dipped into the Ionian Sea on one side, and the Tyrrhenian on the other, the wild mountainous region of Calabria has long been sidestepped by development. Communication — and cooperative activities — are often difficult.

headline: Founding of Fatah Is Celebrated in a Militant Mood
abstract: Palestinians in Gaza City and Ramallah celebrate 36th anniversary of founding of Al Fatah, guerrilla organization, by Yasir Arafat; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper prices rise as steadily declining stockpiles signal that mine output is not keeping up with demand; in New York, copper for May delivery rises 0.8 percent, or 1 percent, to 82.4 cents per pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Grim Task Now In India Quake: Excavate Dead
abstract: Search for survivors of devastating earthquake in Gujarat State, India, on January 26 gives way largely to grim task of excavating dead from rubble; approximately 6,400 bodies are recovered out of estimated 20,000 believed to have died; situation in Anjar, city close to earthquake's epicenter, described; maps; photos (M)

headline: 2 Top Executives Quit at Stratos Global
abstract: Stratos Global Corp's chief executive Derek Woods and chief financial officer Robert Benson resign; Carmen Lloyd will replace Woods and David Oake will serve temporarily in Benson's place (S)

headline: Putin Writes to Bush, Urging Warmer Russia-U.S. Relations
abstract: MOSCOW, Jan. 24 — President Valdimir V. Putin sent a letter to President Bush this week proposing broader Russian-American cooperation and setting out the major issues on which he believes the two countries can cooperate, the Kremlin's press service said today.

headline: March Survey Of Consumers Is Brighter
abstract: Stock rise sharply after Conference Board reports that its consumer confidence index rose to 117.0 in March from 109.2 in February, first increase since September; economists are reluctant to read much into one monthly figure, but say recent decline in consumer confidence may be bottoming out; graphs; photo (M)

headline: EIRCOM IN TALKS TO SELL ASSETS
abstract: Eircom, former Irish state telecommunications company, is discussing sale of its fixed-line and Internet assets to Denis O'Brien; photo (S)

headline: Xerox Facing New Pressures Over Auditing
abstract: Xerox Corp is coming under sharp criticism from analysts and management experts for not doing more to address accusations of faulty accounting practices; acknowledged in June that it had uncovered serious accounting improprieties in its Mexican busineses, and now a former financial employee, James F Bingham, is accusing company of 'significant accounting and financial reporting irregularities' in other countries as well; Xerox insists that it has thoroughly investigated its operations outside of Mexico and found nothing wrong (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Tyco's Deal To Buy CIT Turns Heads
abstract: Tyco International will acquire CIT Group for cash and stock worth $9.2 billion; deal would end independence of one of last free-standing commercial finance companies; Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan, which owns about 71 million CIT shares, agrees to accept its portion for $2.49 billion in cash (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Ninian Smart, 73, Author and Scholar of Comparative Religion
abstract: Roderick Ninian Smart, scholar of comparative religion, dies at age 73 (M)

headline: U.N. Agency Sets Its Sights On Curbing Child Marriage
abstract: Unicef opens campaign against forced childhood marriages, saying practice violates human rights; says early marriage has profound physical, intellectual, psychological and emotional impacts on both boys and girls, cutting off educational opportunities and chances of personal growth; says that for girls, it almost certainly means premature pregnancy and childbearing and likely means lifetime of domestic and sexual subservience over which they have no control (M)

headline: Article 2001022693534572948 -- No Title
abstract: TECHNOLOGY

headline: Japan Airlines Plans to Cut 4,200 Workers
abstract: Japan Airlines, Asia's biggest carrier, plans to cut ground staff by almost half as part of its latest effort to reduce costs; airline will also not start flying Airbus Industrie planes for at least three years (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Leaves D.S.L. Customers Without Net Access
abstract: The first bankruptcy of a major provider of fast Internet access sent more than 100,000 computer users scrambling to find new service today as the nationwide network of Northpoint Communications was shut down.

headline: Bomb in Northern Israel Kills 1, Wounds 9
abstract: JERUSALEM, March 1 — A taxi van exploded in northern Israel today after police stopped it at a roadblock during a search for a terror suspect. As officers were checking passengers' identification cards, a bomb aboard was detonated, killing one person and wounding nine others.

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: SOFTWARE

headline: Compaq to Cut 5,000 Jobs; Profit Forecast Is Lowered
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp will cut 5,000 jobs and predicts that first-quarter earnings per share will be about one-third lower than expectations; will merge its commercial and consumer personal computer divisions and trim its marketing force; moves, combined with previously announced cost-cutting, should save company $500 million to $600 million annually; company names Jeff Clarke chief financial officer, replacing Jesse J Greene Jr, who becomes senior vice president for strategic planning; chief executive Michael Capellas blames weak US economy, sliding consumer confidence and cutbacks in industry capital spending (M)

headline: PEDIATRIX MEDICAL IS BUYING MAGELLA FOR $141 MILLION
abstract: Pediatrix Medical Group agrees to buy Magella Healthcare Corp for $141 milllion in stock; acquisition will add doctors to Pediatrix management practices in hospital neonatal intensive care units; Pediatrix will also assume about $48.5 million in Magella debt and subordinated notes (S)

headline: Jewish Leaders Trade Barbs Over Austria's Nazi Legacy
abstract: Ariel Muzicant, Israeli-born real estate baron in Vienna, and Peter Sichrovsky, who comes from one of Vienna's oldest Jewish families and lost relatives in Holocaust, exchange insult and legal threats over proposed restitution package for Nazi victims, which latter supports and Austrian parliament has approved; photos; Sichrovsky insists past should not be endlessly invoked as subject of financial wrangling and, as new general secretary of Freedom Party, says its leader, Jorg Haider, is not anti-Semite or Nazi, but has been goaded by Jewish organizations; Muzicant retorts that Sichrovsky, European Parliament member and longtime resident of Los Angeles, Haider's 'court Jew' (M)

headline: Article 2001021890692785338 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Article 2001021093110544548 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Germany Examines Perjury Allegations Against Foreign Minister
abstract: German prosecutors begin investigation into whether Foreign Min Joschka Fischer committed perjury in testimony in January at trial of Hans-Joachim Klein, a former revolutinary comrade from 1970, who has been sentenced to nine years in prison for murders of three people in 1975 in an attack on OPEC headquarters in Vienna; investigation centers on Fischer's testimony that no member of Red Army Faction had ever lived in building where he and other leftists squatted in Frankfurt in 70's (M)

headline: OPEC Moves to Cut Oil Output by 5%
abstract: VIENNA, Jan. 16 - The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to announce a decision Wednesday to slash production by more than 5 percent in hopes of propping up world oil prices, according to key officials of the group.

headline: Seeking a Common Rule Book for International Mergers
abstract: J William Rowley, chairman of American Bar Association's Global Forum for Competition Policy, seeks to simplify competition laws internationally and to create consensus among regulators to make antitrust scrutiny of international mergers more coherent and predictable; photos (M)

headline: By the Book: Individuality Vs. Franchising; Trading Spark of Creativity For the Safety of Numbers
abstract: Franchising continues to grow in US, and while fast food is still single largest category, hundreds of lesser-known franchises that sell everything from printing services to baby clothes have emerged as well; there are even business-to-business franchises; International Franchise Assn estimates that number of US franchise locations grew by 25 percent in past decade, to about 320,000, representing 1,200 to 1,500 companies; franchising is attractive because it provides streamlined business plan, but the price of that is loss of individuality, regionalism and business creativity; photo; graph (M)

headline: LUCENT REVISES AGERE OFFERING AGAIN
abstract: Lucent Technologies lowers value of shares its plans to sell in microelectronics operation for second time in week, underscoring cool reception expected for offerings of shares in communications companies; Lucent plans to sell operation, recently named Agere Systems, for $12 to $14 per share, compared with earlier range of $16 to $19 (S)

headline: Putting a Price on the Free Lunch
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column describes new Amazon.com 'Honor System,' which allows Internet users to make voluntary payments for intangible things--humor, advice, recipes, etc--they receive from free Web sites; Amazon will funnel these funds from appreciative parties to their favorite sites; photo (M)

headline: Dragons and Flying Brooms
abstract: Mattel gathers world's largest toy retailers in Tucson, Ariz, for private toy fair to show off its product line, particularly secret stable of toys based on J K Rowling's best seller Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone and coming movie version of book; film, distributed by Warner Brothers, is scheduled to open on Nov 16, and with nearly 49 million copies of four Harry Potter books in print, potential audience for tie-in toys is huge; toy makers are being cautious about creating too many tie-in toys and games, worried that most readers are already past their prime toy-buying age; charts; photos (M)

headline: $17.6 Billion Deal to Make De Beers Private Company
abstract: Oppenheimer family, which has controlled much of world diamond trade for more than 70 years, tightens its already powerful grip with $17.6 billion agreement to turn De Beers into private company in partnership with its sister corporation, Anglo American, and other close allies; new De Beers would still be run by Nicky Oppenheimer; De Beers stockholders would be bought out by consortium to be called DB Investments, in which Anglo American and Oppenheimer family would each have 45 percent stake; remaining 10 percent would belong to Debswana, mining venture co-owned by De Beers and government of Botswana, major source of diamonds; photo of Gary Ralfe and Nicky Oppenheimer of De Beers and Louis Nchindo of Debswana (M)

headline: Uranium Furor Puts Kosovars in the Dark Again
abstract: NATO is only now beginning to disclose sites in Kosovo that it bombed with weapons reinforced by depleted uranium and to consider cleaning up whatever debris might be left; people of Kosovo are barely consulted or counted; United Nations administration in Kosovo says that, in cooperation with NATO, it will fence off sites where depleted uranium is known to have been dropped and would put up multilingual caution signs; what most Kosovars will understand of such signs can only be imagined; people of Llozice, Kosovar village, say they trust NATO, which went to war on their behalf against Serbs, to do right thing; World Health Orgn says it has found no increase in leukemia among population of Kosovo; photo; map (M)

headline: Tokyo's Coveted Cafés For Young Wannabes
abstract: TOKYO—  It's not just about what you wear anymore. These days, Tokyo's hip and cultured are less concerned about the latest Prada fashion than the big question of where to take their friends for coffee.

headline: Economic Scene; Seven lessons about Super Bowl ticket prices.
abstract: economi

headline: Signs of Uneasiness in Seoul Over Change at White House
abstract: South Koreans are growing increasingly uneasy about whether they can sustain momentum toward detente with North Korea in face of change of administrations in United States; have been pleased with some of early statements from Bush administration, but note many of Pres Bush's senior advisers have held in recent past that Clinton administration was too eager to normalize ties with North; photo (M)

headline: Upbeat Mood in Manila, and Vows for Future
abstract: Upbeat mood sweeps across Manila, Philippines, with talk centering on pivotal role played by huge public demonstrations in forcing scandal-plagued Pres Joseph Estrada from office; his successor, Vice Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, praises young Filipinos who made up vast majority of demonstrators and brought about resurgence of 'people power' that forced former Pres Ferdinand Marcos from office in 1986; pledges to work to give them bright future; Roman Catholic Cardinal Jaime Sin admonishes Filipinos to remain vigilant (M)

headline: Mexico's New Leader Vows to End Longstanding Impunity for Torture in Justice System
abstract: Mexico's new president, Vicente Fox, says that torture, tool used in his country for centuries, must end; Fox for first time acknowledges that police officers and soldiers use torture to extract confessions from subjects, that judges accept confessions wrung through torture, and that such admissions are often only evidence brought against suspects by police officers who lack investigative skills but possess power to beat people into signing statements; Fox appoints special ambassador on human rights, Mariclaire Acosta, whose portfolio includes stamping out practice; Acosta says ending practice of torture will require enormous political will (M)

headline: Blasts in China Leave at Least 18 Dead
abstract: SHANGHAI, March 16 — A series of apparently coordinated blasts killed at least 18 people in an industrial city 120 miles south of Beijing early Friday, sending riot police into the streets and sparking rumors that laid-off factory workers were wreaking revenge.

headline: Clinton, at Odds With Pentagon, Says Gulf War Pilot May Be Alive
abstract: Pres Clinton says in interview that Lt Cmdr Michael Scott Speicher, American fighter pilot shot down over Iraq during 1991 Persian Gulf war, may still be alive and that United States government will work aggressively to seek his release if he did indeed survive; but defense officials, who changed Speicher's status from 'killed in action' to 'missing in action,' say they have no information that Speicher is still alive; say they are using new MIA declaration to press Iraq for full accounting of his whereabouts (M)

headline: CISCO CHIEF SAYS OUTLOOK IS GRIM
abstract: Cisco Systems sales continue to slow, registering no increase in February; graph (S)

headline: Tighter Rules on Fund Names
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission approves tightening of rules requiring mutual funds to be true to their names; specialized funds with names suggesting that they focus on particular types of investments, like 'high growth' or 'Pacific Rim' stocks, will be required to invest at least 80 percent of their assets in such securities, up from 65 percent under old rule (M)

headline: ISRAEL PICKS HAWK AS DEFENSE CHIEF
abstract: Israel's Labor Party names Benjamin Ben-Eliezer to be defense minister in Prime Min-designate Ariel Sharon's coalition government; Ben-Eliezer is considered ideologically closer to Sharon, Likud Party leader, than to Shimon Peres, Labor Party colleague who will be foreign minister; he advocates holding Palestinian Authority accountable for all violence against Israelis and responding forcefully to every Palestinian attack; Sharon reaches accord in principle to include two rightist parties in coalition; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ROLLS-ROYCE P.L.C., -- London, the maker of aircraft engines, said it was talking to Mitsubishi Heavy Industries of Japan about working jointly on aircraft engine programs, sharing costs and introducing Mitsubishi Heavy to an industry it has sought to enter.

headline: SECURITY ALLIANCE TAKES SHAPE
abstract: Federal government and top technology companies join forces in effort to ease exchange of information and strategies on effective security practices for electronic incidents, threats, attacks and vulnerabilities (S)

headline: German Officials Quit Over Mad Cow Issue
abstract: BERLIN, Jan 9 — The German health and agriculture ministers quit today over their bungled handling of an outbreak of mad cow disease that has shattered consumer confidence in beef and even the country's beloved sausages.

headline: T-ONLINE POSTS LOSS
abstract: T-Online, Internet subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom, reports loss of 125 million euros, or about $116 million (S)

headline: A Cut in Estate Taxes May Not Hurt Insurers
abstract: Life insurance stocks have suffered on expectation of repeal of estate tax because the rich often purchase policies to shield their estates from taxes, but many analysts say market has overreacted and life insurance stocks are now at bargain prices (M)

headline: DESPERATE MIGRATION -- A special report.; Fleeing Famine and War, Afghans Again Meet Death
abstract: Special report on Afghanistan, where thousands of villagers are fleeing famine, many of them dying on journey to bigger towns and cities or borders of neighboring Iran and Pakistan; United Nations officials plea for emergency aid, saying more than million of people are at risk of starvation in country afflicted with unending war, no effectual government and three years of drought; photos of refugee camps; map (M)

headline: Market Reacts Cautiously to Testimony by Greenspan
abstract: Burdened by a dour outlook for corporate profits, the stock market reacted cautiously today to comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman.

headline: Stocks Fall Broadly, With Major Indexes Around Year Lows
abstract: Nasdaq composite index falls 2.13 percent, or 49.41 points, to 2,268.94, its lowest close since March 1999; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 1.85 percent, or 23.67 points, to 1,255.57, and Dow Jones industrial average is off 1.9 percent, ending 204.30 points lower, at 10,526.88; graph; chart (M)

headline: Rwandan Leader, in U.S., Urges Push for Peace in Congo
abstract: Pres Paul Kagame of Rwanda, who is visiting US, warns American and United Nations officials that they must seize opportunity to search for peace settlement in Congo with country's new president, Joseph Kabila, while political situation there remains fluid; describes Kabila as someone who can live in present and look toward future; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of coffee rises nearly 3 percent on buying by processors taking advantage of prices close to eight-year low; in New York, coffee for May delivery rises 1.75 cents, or 2.9 percent, to 61.85 cents per pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: WEBMETHODS ACHIEVES PROFITABILITY
abstract: WebMethods Inc says third-quarter revenues rose 237 percent to $59.4 million (S)

headline: 2 Dead and 13 Wounded in California School Shooting
abstract: In the first serious school shooting in the United States in many months, two students were killed and 13 others were wounded Monday at a high school in a San Diego suburb by a young man witnesses said was a student at the school.

headline: A lighthearted campaign for an Internet service gives data a wry, sometimes cheeky personality.
abstract: Lighthearted ad campaign is created for InterNAP Network Services Corp's by Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide; is emblematic of efforts to makes advertising for high-technology marketrs more palatable by eschewing formulaic approaches and adding emotional elements like humor (M)

headline: Company Faces I.R.S. Suit For Not Withholding Taxes
abstract: Justice Department sues Bosset Marketing Partners, Clearwater, Fla, to recover 'erroneous refund' of employees' taxes withheld in 1996; owner, David Bosset, believes that Internal Revenue Code exempts American-owner companies from income taxes (M)

headline: Home-Style Approach In Hardee's Campaign
abstract: Hardee's Food Systems, part of CKE Restaurants, is promoting itself in humorous but homey way in campaign that is first from its new ad agency, Cliff Freeman & Partners; billings estimated at $80 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of wheat rises after Egypt buys two cargoes of US grain, raising expectations of increased foreign demand; in Chicago, wheat for May delivery rises 7.5 cents, or 2.8 percent, to $2.7675 per bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Bush Appoints Powell's Son To Lead F.C.C.
abstract: President George W Bush appoints Michael K Powell, oldest son of Secretary of State Colin L Powell, to be next chairman of Federal Communications Commission; Powell has served since autumn 1997 as one of two Republican commissioners at five-member agency, and since that term runs until July 2003, his selection as chairman does not require Senate confirmation; photo (M)

headline: Only Joking. But Healing South Africa, Too.
abstract: CAPE TOWN — Behind the screen, the comedian is colorless. He is a silhouette, dancing, crouching, stretching in a sea of red light. Then he emerges: a lanky, brown man with an unruly Afro in front of a mostly white audience.

headline: Arms Control Nominee Defends Shifting View
abstract: John R Bolton, nominee for under secretary of state for arms control and international security at State Dept, tries to explain at his confirmation hearing his seeming about-face on test-ban treaty; he previously characterized supporters of treaty as 'misguided'; now he says he would examine elements of treaty as part of overall strategic review (S)

headline: Socialist Wins Final Round In Race for Mayor of Paris
abstract: Voters in Paris, France, elect Bertrand Delanoe, Socialist, as new mayor; victory is considered particular blow to conservative Pres Jacques Chirac, mayor for 20 years before becoming president; analysts suggest Delanoe's victory was less result of his charisma, than inability of conservatives to get house in order; photo (S)

headline: Funds Watch: Magellan's Retreat From Technology
abstract: How far has the technology sector fallen? The Fidelity Magellan fund is down to a single technology stock among its top 10 holdings, according to its latest report, published last week by Fidelity Investments. At $93.1 billion in assets, Magellan is the nation's largest actively managed mutual fund and a bellwether in the money management industry.

headline: Private Sector; Building a Bridge on the Fairway
abstract: At first glance it might seem curious that former President George Bush would attend an event honoring Jackson T. Stephens, the biggest Democratic power broker in Bill Clinton's home state. But Mr. Stephens, a self-made billionaire investment banker and philanthropist, is financing a cause that transcends politics: golf.

headline: Article 2001011092487257278 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: More Than Just a Wrongful Termination
abstract: Analysis of California appellate court's decision that Playhut Inc's dismissal of Richard D'Sa for refusing to sign noncompete agreement if he left company for any reason was a wrongful termination; while his case does not have direct bearing on noncompete agreements--in his case, he never signed one--employment lawyers say judge's reasoning could have national reverberations; noncompete agreements in effect at some companies discussed (M)

headline: Late Rally Keeps S.& P. From Slumping Into Bear Market
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 31.54 points, or 1.5 percent, to 2,183.37; Dow Jones industrial average falls 45.15 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,450.14; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes up 1.29 points, or 0.1 percent, at 1,241.23; graph; chart (M)

headline: THE BOSS; I Hope What I Do Matters
abstract: Dennis Eck's The Boss column on being chief executive of Coles Myer, largest retail company in Australia; photo (M)

headline: INTEL'S LOW-VOLTAGE CHIPS READY
abstract: Intel Corp unveils two new microprocessors for subnotebook category of laptop computers and says IBM computer will be first to use chips (S)

headline: STRONG SALES AT GUCCI
abstract: Gucci Group says sales of its flagship brand of luxury goods rose more than 30 percent in December from 1999 month, with especially strong showing by its Gucci retail stores; Burberry unit of Great Univeral Store PLC reports 35 percent increase in sales in its third fiscal quarter, including Christmas (S)

headline: Warming's Likely Victims
abstract: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change working group says global warming will likely increase crop yields in temperate northern regions while harming agriculture in tropics, further widening gap between industrialized and poor nations; finds rise in global temperatures in recent decades has already had impact on wildlife, glaciers, sea ice and other earth features; warns of damage and disruption from further temperature rise (M)

headline: Pilot Given Wrong Site For Bombs In Kuwait
abstract: WASHINGTON—  A U.S. serviceman on the ground at a firing range in Kuwait mistakenly directed a pilot to drop his bombs over the site where he and other observers were watching a routine exercise, then sought frantically, but in vain, to call off the bombing, American officials said Tuesday.

headline: Microsoft Introduces New Windows System
abstract: William H Gates introduces new version of Microsoft's Windows software called Windows XP; says Windows XP version will be most important Windows release since Windows 95, blockbuster that generated worldwide attention and made Windows nearly synonymous with personal computing; analysts are less buoyant, with some questioning whether XP will provide 'upgrade pop'--users either buying new machines or installing XP over existing versions--that made Windows 95 so successful but has been absent from last two revisions, Windows 2000 and Windows Me; photo (M)

headline: Colonel's Trial Puts Russian Justice to Test
abstract: Colonel's trial in killing of young Chechen woman puts Russian justice to test; Col Yuri D Budanov, highest-ranking officer to be accused of crime against Chechen civilian, admits that he abducted, beat and killed 18-year-old Elza Kungayeva in Grozny, Chechnya's capital, year ago; claims he believed she was rebel sniper who had killed soldiers in his regiment, and that he killed her in uncontrollable fit of revenge; woman's father disputes this, saying Budanov had 'noticed' his daughter in days before abduction; initial accusation of rape, documented by autopsy, has vanished; Human Rights Watch has documented thousands of cases in which Russian military killed, tortured and raped Chechen civilians with no punishment; despite fact that Kremlin itself expressed outrage at Kungayeva's killing, half of Russians polled feel Budanov should be set free; photos; map (M)

headline: In Strike Against Recession, Fed Cuts Rates Half a Point
abstract: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 — The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point for the second time in four weeks today, making clear that it intends to wage an aggressive battle against the growing possibility of a recession.

headline: PEAPOD, ONLINE GROCER, QUITS SAN FRANCISCO
abstract: Peapod, online grocer that is majority owned by Royal Ahold, has stopped serving San Francisco and is referring customers to rival Webvan Group; will focus on Eastern US, where Ahold operates Stop & Shop supermarket chain (S)

headline: Morgan Stanley Chief to Step Down; Scott to Succeed
abstract: NEW YORK - Morgan Stanley Dean Witter , one of Wall Street's premier investment banks, said Wednesday its president and chief operating officer, John Mack, is resigning effective March 21.

headline: Civil Suit Over Azerbaijan Oil Deal Gains Plaintiffs in London
abstract: Columbia University and Pharos Finance Ltd join civil suit in London against Viktor Kozeny, Czech promoter accused of fraud in $450 million deal to acquire control of Socar, Azerbaijan's state-owned oil company; Kozeny holds he did nothing wrong and lost miillions of dollars of his own because Azerbaijan has not sold Socar (M)

headline: A Downturn?In Asia, Few Are Very Worried
abstract: SINGAPORE—  After two consecutive years of stronger-than-expected expansion, Asia's developing and newly industrialized economies are set to slow significantly in 2001, while Japan, the region's dominant economy, is likely to limp along at a sluggish rate, as it has for nearly a decade.

headline: Russia Entrepreneurs Try The Business of Governing
abstract: As Russia's most powerful businessmen gradually lose their influence over government in Moscow, some have moved into local politics; group of Moscow entrepreneurs has just staged takeover of regional government of Dudinka, far above Arctic Circle in Russia's northernmost region; group is led by Aleksandr Khloponin, 35-year-old former banker; Khloponin's victory follows win by Russia's aluminum tycoon, Roman Abramovich, in region of Chukotka, in Russia's far northeast corner (M)

headline: A Stirring, at Least, in the Long-Suffering Gold Market
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer Portfolios, Etc column speculates on longevity of current slight upsurge in prices of gold bullion and mining stocks; explores connection between 'lease rate', interest charged for borrowing gold, and metal's and mining stocks' market prices; graph (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Judge's Ruling Is Victory For Law Firm's Reputation
abstract: Federal District Court Judge Charles L Brieant rejects charges that Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach, nation's most prominent law firm representing plaintiffs in securities class-action cases, made misrepresentations to lay claim to control of litigation against Oxford Health Plans Inc; case has highlighted friction among plaintiff firms over role of lead counsel in securities cases; ruling is important victory for Milberg Weiss, which has been subject of unflattering reports in legal and business press about its tactics; Oxford's lawyers Sullivan & Cromwell argued that two individual plaintiffs selected by Milberg Weiss were unfit to represent class of shareholders claiming to have been defrauded by company; photo of William Lerach, who pioneered Milberg Weiss's securities class-action practice (M)

headline: The Boss: One Bull Run I Skipped
abstract: My father and my younger brother suffered from asthma. In 1956, after I graduated, we left the Bronx and moved to Miami. Whatever they were allergic to didn't exist there. I was hanging out with the guys. I could have gone left; I could have gone right. The move saved me a lot of aggravation.

headline: RETRENCHMENT AT CMGI
abstract: CMGI says it will not be able to meet its revenue and cash-use targets for balance of its fiscal year ending July 31, as many of its units continue to restructure and lay off workers; CMGI's Alta Vista search engine for World Wide Web eliminates 200 jobs, 25 percent of its staff (S)

headline: Article 2001010892141791497 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: I.R.S. Reports Tax Compliance Rates
abstract: Internal Revenue Service report shows senators, representatives and their employees are much more likely than federal employees as whole not to file tax returns or to have unresolved debts for back taxes; Sen Charles E Grassley says noncompliance rate for Senate is unacceptable; graph (M)

headline: Article 2001012890821380318 -- No Title
abstract: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

headline: Writers Strike May Not Be Inevitable
abstract: Four weeks of talks between Writers Guild of America and major film studios and television networks foster hope that agreement may be reached to forestall strikes this summer by both writers and actors represented by Screen (M)

headline: Electronic Data Systems to Buy Sabre Airline Computer Unit
abstract: Sabre Holdings Corp agrees to sell its business that operates computers for airlines and other assets to Electronic Data Systems Corp for $670 million; American Airlines and US Airways are Sabre's largest computer operations clients; Continental Airlines is largest airline client of EDS (M)

headline: INSURERS PLAN ONLINE MARKET
abstract: American International Group, Kemper Insurance Companies and Prudential Insurance Co of America are joining forces to form Internet marketplace site (S)

headline: Ousted Manila Leader Says He Yielded Just Temporarily
abstract: Former Philippines Pres Joseph Estrada, forced from office amid scandal, indicates he yielded power only as temporary measure and may be creating basis for legal challenge to his ouster; Congressional leaders express concern; Estrada, who never officially quit, fled Presidential palace on January 20 after most of cabinet, military leaders and Supreme Court denounced him and after tens of thousands of protestors threatened to seize him; Gloria Macapagal Arroyo has been sworn in as replacement (M)

headline: Nortel Reports Solid Quarterly Earnings
abstract: Nortel Networks reports strong growth in earnings and revenue for fourth quarter, but warns that tight financing for communications companies might cause sales to reach only low end of estimates in months ahead; says net earnings were $825 million in quarter on revenue of $8.82 billion, 34 percent increase from year earlier (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARE SUN TOPS SERVER MARKET Sun Microsystems displaced I.B.M. as the top seller of powerful server computers in the United States, though I.B.M. remains the main server seller worldwide, according to a widely watched International Data Corporation report on fourth-quarter sales released yesterday. The revenue-based rankings confirm those by a rival, Gartner Dataquest, and settle, for the moment, a bitter and public dispute between two companies eager for bragging rights in the high-profile market for the computers that link networks. I.B.M. took the lead during the quarter in the global market for midrange computers running the dominant operating system, UNIX, International Data said. (Reuters)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FAS MART CONVENIENCE STORES INC., Richmond, Va., said it had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to restructure its debt, citing slumping margins in the gasoline business. All of Fas Mart's 170-plus stores will remain open, the company said, and none of its 1,600 employees will be laid off.

headline: EBAY KNOCKED OUT FOR 11 HOURS
abstract: EBay, Internet's most popular auction service, suffers severe technical problem that brings down its service for nearly 11 hours; crash stems not from single problem but from series of hardware failures compounded by database malfunction; graph (S)

headline: PROFITS UP AT PORSCHE
abstract: Porsche Ag announces 12 percent rise in first-half profits, to $65 million (S)

headline: S.E.C. Faults KPMG's Conduct in an Audit
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission issues cease-and-desist order against KPMG after concluding that the firm violated security laws that require it to be independent from companies it audits; case concerns 1996 KPMG audit of Porta Systems (M)

headline: Wrapping British Farmers in Growing Isolation
abstract: Article describes scene in Hewish, farming village in southern England that lies eight miles from nearest suspected case of foot-and-mouth disease; specter of disease has not only led to quarantine of livestock, but also to virtual quarantine of farmers themselves, who have stopped gathering in groups and visiting other farms for fear of inadvertently spreading the virus; as ripple effect spreads to those who rely on farmers' business, community is barely able to stay economically afloat; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: BARCLAYS PROFIT INCREASES
abstract: Barclays PLC says second-half profit increased 8.5 percent; net income rose to 1.15 billion pounds ($1.68 billion) from 1.06 billion pounds in second half of 1999 (S)

headline: AUTOMAKER DESIGNATES CORPORATE MARKETING CHIEF
abstract: General Motrors Corp names Christopher J Fraleigh head of corporate marketing and advertising (S)

headline: Britain Moves to Curtail Spread of Foot-and-Mouth Disease
abstract: Britain imposes seven-day ban on transporting livestock in attempt to stem outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease that has led to suspension of meat exports and appeal to Britons to steer clear of countryside; Agriculture Min Nick Brown also bans livestock markets and hunting foxes, hare and deer, all of which would carry virus farther afield; outbreak is first in 20 years; it was first identified at slaughterhouse in Essex; since then, five more outbreaks have occurred, one in Northumberland, 200 miles north (M)

headline: No Honeymoon Likely for New President's Foreign Policy Team
abstract: Every president takes office believing he can set the foreign policy agenda for his administration, only to discover that a major portion of that agenda has already been set by the world.

headline: Colombia Adds Troops at Rebel Zone as Deadline Nears
abstract: Colombia has rushed hundreds of troops to area just outside huge rebel-held territory, as prospects of resuming peace talks by Jan 31 deadline with Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia near collapse; Pres Andres Pastrana is cutting short European trip to deal with crisis, which is hurting peso; will weigh effort to take back 16,000 square miles of jungles and ranches he ceded to rebels in Nov 1998; photo (M)

headline: Greenspan Hints Tax Cuts Might Help Weak Economy
abstract: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said today what many Americans have been feeling the last few months: that the economy has slowed sharply. Using the extra-cautious language that is his trademark, Mr. Greenspan indicated that some tax cuts might be a good idea.

headline: NCR TO TAKE A CHARGE FOR DEAL WITH DISTRIBUTOR
abstract: NCR Corp will take first-quarter charge of about $28 million for losses associated with venture with distrubutor of ATM's (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: ABBOTT LABORATORIES, Abbott Park, Ill., named Thomas Freyman, vice president for hospital products, as chief financial officer, effective April 1. He will succeed Gary Coughlan, who is retiring.

headline: Delta Pilots Reject Offer Of Arbitration
abstract: Air Line Pilots Association, which represents pilots at Delta Air Lines, rejects offer of arbitration from federal mediators, setting in motion 30-day cooling-off period required before strike; union and Delta management look to White House to see what action Pres Bush might take; National Mediation Board asks union and Delta to meet on April 16 to resume negotiations (M)

headline: Article 2001013093406097808 -- No Title
abstract: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

headline: Suddenly, at LVMH, Money Is an Object
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, luxury goods company whose business strategy rests on growing wealth of nations, now faces slowing economies worldwide and evaporation of wealth owing to stock market declines; cash flow suddenly becomes important in wake of staggering amounts spent building conglomerate, whose units include Thomas Pink, Chaumet, and TAG Heuer; photos; graph (M)

headline: Private Sector; New-Job Pioneer Sued for Taking One
abstract: William O. Warren, the man who did so much to promote job-hopping in the Internet era, recently job-hopped himself -- and faces a lawsuit over it.    Mr. Warren founded the Online Career Center, a job search site, in 1992, and sold it in 1995 to TMP Worldwide, which operates the employment site Monster.com. He worked for TMP and served as president of Monster.com for a little less than a year before leaving in December 1999.

headline: How Missteps and Overreaching Dimmed Lucent's Promise
abstract: This article was reported by Alex Berenson, Simon Romero and Seth Schiesel, and was written by Mr. Schiesel.

headline: Kabila´s Son Sworn In as Congo President
abstract: KINSHASA, Congo, Jan. 26 — Joseph Kabila, the 29-year-old political heir whom most Congolese had neither seen nor heard until this week, was sworn in today as Congo's new president, inheriting a country occupied by a half-dozen foreign armies.

headline: Macedonian Forces Consolidating Control of Hill Towns
abstract: Macedonian forces move carefully through hills above Tetovo, country's second largest city besieged by ethnic Albanian rebels for 12 days; are consolidating control of villages taken from rebels; photo (M)

headline: Men Are From Quake, Women Are From Ultima
abstract: Women are being drawn in surprising numbers to a new genre of multiplayer Internet games that are set in medieval towns with a knight-in-armor flavor but that, unlike traditional computer games that appeal mainly to men, allow players to do something more than fight and provide a sense of community and social structure; players can chat, buy and sell items like food and weapons, run businesses or make friends and go exploring; three most popular games are Ultima Online from Origin Systems, Asheron's Call and EverQuest from Sony; photos (M)

headline: ARCH COAL RAISES ITS FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT FORECAST
abstract: Arch Coal raises its forecast of first-quarter profit (S)

headline: EMERY WORLDWIDE MAY BE FINED FOR SAFETY VIOLATIONS
abstract: Emery Worldwide air-freight unit of CNF Inc faces possible $698,000 in fines proposed by Federal Aviation Administration for safety violations (S)

headline: Leaders' Cordiality Doesn't Halt Gaza Clashes
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon has told Yasir Arafat that he hopes they can establish 'personal contact' after violence diminishes in region, but prospects for meeting any time soon appear remote as street clashes and gun battles flare anew throughout Gaza and West Bank; photo (M)

headline: White House Reaches Out To Both Sides In Peace Talks
abstract: George W Bush administration, expecting victory of Ariel Sharon in Israel, dispatches messages calling for calm in Middle East and reassuring Israel that relationship with US remains 'rock solid'; Sec Colin Powell issues plea for restraint, call apparently aimed at Palestinian Authority and Arab nations; says he will visit region this month (M)

headline: The Dog Day in June The Lights Went Out
abstract: Companies throughout Silicon Valley dim lights, turn off heating systems and switch to backup generators to keep high-technology industry running as California energy officials struggle to conserve thinning power reserves; risk of blackouts like one last June again threatens Silicon Valley's economy; graph; photo (M)

headline: Cupid Sneaks Aboard Commuter Express
abstract: People often find love while commuting, many by accident but some by design; making a connection seems to be easier on evening ride than on morning one; photos (M)

headline: Japan Banks Are Told Not to Rely on Aid
abstract: Japan's Financial Services Agency head Hakuo Yanagisawa says banks and their corporate customers should reform themselves to improve country's financial system and should not expect additional government aid, interview; his insistence that government does not need to provide more money to financial industry puzzles analysts and economists; photo (M)

headline: PICKUP TRUCKS FOR CHINA
abstract: Shanghai Automotive Industrial Corp will develop pickup truck for sale in rural China with technical help from General Motors Corp (S)

headline: SPRINT AND SUN JOIN TO OFFER INTERNET SERVICES
abstract: Sprint Corp forms alliance with Sun Microsystems to offer advanced Internet services to corporate customers (S)

headline: Article 2001030390383737629 -- No Title
abstract: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

headline: Romania, Under Pressure, Improves Orphanages
abstract: Romania pours money and effort into improving lives of its abandoned children, largely under pressure from European Union, and United Nations now reports dramatic gains since the days when many babies were found lying unloved and uncuddled in rows of urine-soaked cribs in state orphanages; many problems remain, including affordable medical care for 9,000 HIV-infected children and high anemia and malnourishment rates amog pregnant woman and infants; photo (M)

headline: European Copper Industry Investigated
abstract: European Commission conducts surprise investigations in five European countries, seeking evidence of anti-competitive behavior in market for copper tubes and fittings (M)

headline: Patents; Two efforts to prevent disease: one purifies blood; the other reminds people to wash their hands.
abstract: Three researchers at Cerus Corp win patent for technology that it says kills viruses, bacteria and pathogens in blood products; John Lynn wins patent for mechanism that would remind people to wash their hands by leaving nontoxic substance on hand after flushing toilet (M)

headline: Article 2001031691453375039 -- No Title
abstract: EDUCATION

headline: Sotheby's to Cut Staff 8%, With $14 Million Charge
abstract: Sotheby's plans to cut about 8 percent of its worldwide staff, to about 1,900 employees, resulting in fourth-quarter charge of about $14 million, mostly for severance-related expenses; is bracing for mounting fines, legal expenses and possible downturn in art market; says that as of March 5 it will increase amount it charges customers who buy on Sothebys.com to 15 percent of first $15,000 that they spend and 10 percent thereafter; they now pay flat rate of 10 percent (M)

headline: Asking Americans To Build Their Savings
abstract: Consumer Federation of America begins campaign designed to encourage Americans to save and invest more of their money (M)

headline: French Arrest a Basque Hours After Bombing
abstract: French police arrest Francisco Xabier Garcia Gaztelu, reportedly top military leader of Basque separatist group ETA; do not link arrest to car bombing hours earlier in San Sebastian, Spain, attributed to ETA, which killed two workers and wounded four others; he is likely to face trial in France before being extradited to Spain, where he faces murder charges (M)

headline: Quarterly Net Is Down 13% At Goldman
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group says net income fell 13 percent in its first quarter, to $768 million, but decline is less than Wall Street analysts had been expecting; revenue for quarter rose 5.3 percent, to $4.73 billion (M)

headline: Virgin Mobile Names Agency
abstract: Virgin Mobile USA, affiliate of Virgin Group that plans to offer wireless services this year, names San Francisco office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide as first advertising agency of record; billings estimated at $55 million to $60 million (S)

headline: English Village Butchery Blamed for Mad Cow Deaths
abstract: LONDON, March 21 - A report into five deaths from the human form of mad cow disease in the same English village concluded today that the cause was a traditional local method of slaughter that permitted brain matter from diseased animals to contaminate cuts of meat.

headline: 400 Anti-Tax Leaders Meet to Plan Campaign
abstract: Four hundred disparate leaders of movement of citizens who consider tax laws a hoax gather in Arlington, Va, under aegis of We the People Foundation and agree to try to expand their numbers (M)

headline: A Music Reference Goes Electric, Finally
abstract: Latest edition of New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians is released in January in both print and online formats; photos (M)

headline: Compressed Data: Saks.com Mines a List of E-Shoppers
abstract: Apint of Chunky Monkey and a $1,150 Carolina Herrera jacket, delivered by bike messenger in less than an hour? At first glance, that appeared to be the promise of an e-mail message that Saks Fifth Avenue sent earlier this month to former customers of Urbanfetch, the online delivery service in New York and London that shut down in October.

headline: MediaTalk; 'Nightline' to Devote a Full Week to Drugs
abstract: ABC's Nightline program plans five nights of shows on drug trafficking inspired by film Traffic; host Ted Koppel comments (S)

headline: BlackBerry Pagers Get An Update on Updates
abstract: Users of Research in Motion's BlackBerry two-way pagers can now get calendar updates instantaneously over the air, without using cradle to synchronize pager's calendar data with desktop computer (S)

headline: Bartle Bogle Chosen By Children's Network
abstract: Noggin, children's educational cable and digital television network, selects New York office of Bartle Bogle Hegarty to handle its consumer advertising, which had been handled previously on project basis; spending estimated at $12 million (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: UNITED NATIONS    MEASLES KILLS 900,000 -- More than 30 million children still get measles every year and 900,000 die, accounting for more than half the 1.6 million childhood deaths that could be prevented with vaccinations, said the World Health Organization and Unicef. The agencies hope to halve the deaths by 2005 by giving all infants at least one dose of vaccine. Immunizing a child costs 26 cents.       Barbara Crossette (NYT)

headline: Deal by Singapore Telecom Appears Set
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications wins competition to acquire Cable and Wireless Optus, second-largest mobile phone company in Australia; bid of 17.2 billion Australian dollars ($8.55 billion) was slipped before Vodafone Pacific could clear regulatory hurdles and make formal bid of its own (M)

headline: BOND BUYER AND AMERICAN BANKER TO BE SOLD
abstract: Thomson Corp, publisher of The Bond Buyer and American Banker, says it is selling those newspapers and other publications to focus on delivery financial information electronically (S)

headline: Private Sector; A Quiet (Again) Island, on the Block
abstract: For sale: Fijian island with 19th-century-style plantation home, visitor bungalows, airstrip. Price slashed to $10 million. Rebels no longer a threat.     The Forbes family has been trying to sell Laucala Island, bought by Malcolm Forbes in 1972 for $1 million and passed to his descendants after his death in 1990. Insurgents who briefly seized the property last summer in their struggle for Fijian land rights had scared away prospective buyers, but that issue has been solved. Last week, after 10 months of martial law, an interim government was created and stability returned.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS, Burnaby, British Columbia, a fuel cell maker, said it had received a $1.3 million order from Honda Motor Co.'s research unit, which is competing to put an environmentally friendly car on the road.

headline: Innovative Designers Are Challenging Traditions : Spain's Stylish New Buzz
abstract: MADRID—  Fashion has never been so hot in the Iberian Peninsula. From the glamour of Penelope Cruz through the noble tailoring of Miguel Adrover, Spanish has become an international fashion language.

headline: Article 2001031293852437819 -- No Title
abstract: March 10, 2001

headline: Group Backed by Icahn Seeks T.W.A.
abstract: Trans World Airlines acknowledges that investor group with backing from its former chairman, Carl C Icahn, has made offer that bypasses bankruptcy auction of airline and will allow it to keep flying as independent carrier; TWA Acquistions Group, which is headed by banker Brian Freeman, submits its $655 million offer to committee of TWA's creditors and puts down $50 million deposit (M)

headline: Barak May Join Sharon's Cabinet as Israeli Defense Chief
abstract: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15 — Ehud Barak, the caretaker prime minister, conditionally agreed tonight to serve as defense minister under Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon, the right-wing leader who crushed him at the polls last week, Israeli news reports said.

headline: Professor Finds Her Legacy in Internet Law
abstract: When the Electronic Privacy Information Center, an advocacy group based in Washington that loudly campaigns for Internet privacy and civil liberties, announced it had received a $1 million gift a few weeks ago, the money didn't come from a large corporation or private foundation. It came from someone who usually receives grants -- a law school professor.

headline: New Focus for Gates Is Consumer Electronics
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman William H Gates, who calls himself chief software architect, seems focused on entirely different business than personal computer business as his company prepares to introduce its X-Box video-game systemm, its first foray into high-stakes, high-risk consumer electronics business; in Gates's mind, winning in consumer electronics simply requires applying same lessons company has mastered in computer arena; photo (M)

headline: Buoyed by Fed Move, Bush Pushes Tax Cut
abstract: President-elect George W. Bush and a group of American business leaders he was meeting with in Texas said the unexpected cut in interest rates by Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve underscored the need for a deep, across-the-board tax cut to sustain economic growth.    ''One of the messages Mr. Greenspan sent was that we need bold action, not only at the Fed, but I would interpret that to mean bold action in the halls of Congress to make sure this economy stays vibrant,'' Mr. Bush said. His aides said that the interest rate cut was likely to set the relationship between the incoming president and the Fed chairman off to a good start.    Business Day, Page C1.

headline: Head of Internet Board Defends Selection of Domain Names
abstract: Vinton G Cerf, chairman of Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, appears before House Energy and Commerce subcommittee and defends process board used to select new suffixes to compete with popular .com, but says system could be better (M)

headline: The Market May Be Bearish, But Not Everyone Is Suffering
abstract: Broad market indexes are sagging in current bear market, but many individual stocks and some entire industries still prosper; among the winners are mutual funds dedicated to short selling, professional money managers with conservative styles, average employees working in old-economy industries, and hedge funds, which are designed to survive volatile markets; photo (M)

headline: BP AMOCO PLANS TO SHED ITS STAKE IN LUKOIL
abstract: BP Amoco will sell its 7 percent stake in Russia's largest oil company, Lukoil Holding and use $650 million in proceeds to invest in projects elsewhere (S)

headline: IRISH INFLATION IS UP
abstract: Inflation in Ireland rises to annual 5.3 percent rate in February (S)

headline: Zambia's History Is Lost In the Poverty of Today
abstract: Museum built in Livingstone, Zambia, 66-years ago to honor legacy of British explorer David Livingstone is crumbling in nation damaged by poverty and AIDS, and is case study of struggles faced by Africa's cultural institutions; houses Livingstone's illuminating letters and sketches. books, journals and maps; photo; maps (M)

headline: El Salvador Says Earthquake Aid From Abroad Is Lagging
abstract: VERAPAZ, El Salvador, Feb. 24 — Six weeks after a disastrous earthquake and two weeks after a second major quake, Salvadoran officials say assistance from abroad, especially the United States, is lagging.

headline: Verizon Is Told To Split Work In Pennsylvania
abstract: Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission orders Verizon Communications Inc to run separate units for wholesale and individual customers, requirement that spares company from costly breakup (S)

headline: After 5 Years, Israelis Retreat to a Parliamentary System
abstract: Israeli Parliament votes overwhelmingly to abandon direct election of prime ministers and to restore a parliamentary system, under which legislators choose prime minister; 72-to-37 vote is acknowledgment by major parties that five-year experiment in direct elections failed to strengthen office of prime minister as its proponents had hoped (M)

headline: Turner Drops Wrestling in First Decision by Its New Chief
abstract: Turner Broadcasting System plans to stop showing World Championship Wrestling league matches on its TNT and TBS cable channels later in March; cancellation is first programming move made by new TBS head Jamie Kellner (M)

headline: Kinmen Journal; Smugglers on Taiwan Isle Are Glum
abstract: Flourishing black market has long bound together Kinmen Island in Taiwan and coastal towns in nearby Fujian Province in China, and has continued even after opening of direct trade links between Taiwan and China; Taiwan, hoping to encourage newly legal trade, has decided to clamp down on illicit traffic, to dismay of smugglers from Kinmen; photos; map (M)

headline: Taiwan Legislature Reverses Leader on Contested Nuclear Plant
abstract: Taiwan's legislature votes to reverse decision by Pres Chen Shui-bian to scrap partly built nuclear plant; plant is proxy for much broader battle between Chen and Nationalist Party, which he swept out of power last March after 55 years of rule; legislature, dominated by Nationalists, says halting project has caused economic slowdown and social instability; Prime Min Chang Chun-hsiung says government is not obliged to follow vote; standoff has scared away foreign investors, hobbled stock market and undermined currency (M)

headline: SHARP TO SELL LINUX-BASED HAND-HELD COMPUTERS
abstract: Sharp Electronics, which leads Japan's market in hand-held electronic organizers, says it will challenge Palm and Microsoft Corp in US later this year with device running on free Linux operating system (S)

headline: Backing U.P.S. Complaint, Europeans Fine German Postal Service
abstract: European Commission rules that German postal service illegally used profits from its monopoly in delivering letters to subsidize its prices for business parcels and packages; Deutsche Post AG agrees to pay fine of 24 million euros, or $21.8 million, and to separate its monopoly business in letters from its competitive businesses in package delivery; United Parcel Service, which brought complaint seven years ago, reiterates demands that US Transportation Department revoke DHL Worldwide Express's license to forward international freight because of Deutsche Post's control (M)

headline: Leader's Change of Heart on Term Limit
abstract: Pres Frederick Chiluba of Zambia came to power almost 10 years ago, unseating Kenneth Kaunda, who led country out of colonial rule and stayed in office almost three decades; at first, Chiluba was all for term limits; indeed his pledge to introduce and adhere to them helped win him presidency; but now Chiluba and party elite are trying to prolong his rule; moves to change Constitution, which limits president to two five-year terms, have led to protests in recent weeks in Lusaka; map; photo (M)

headline: Aeroflot in Talks on Irish Move
abstract: Aeroflot is in talks to buy Irish unit of Virgin Express; Aeroflot wants to acquire jumping-off point into Europe; analysts say is far from clear that buying Virgin unit would advance Aeroflot's strategy (M)
