abstract: March 20, 2001

headline: Don't Go, Said the Gadfly to the Chief
abstract: Shareholder gadfly Evelyn Y Davis urges BankAmerica chairman and chief executive, Hugh L McColl Jr, to rescind his plan to retire early; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)ú

headline: Bankrupt Daewoo Cuts 1,750 as Angry Workers Protest
abstract: SEOUL, Feb. 16 — Beginning a long-threatened corporate bloodletting over the bitter protests of its union, the Daewoo Motor Company sent dismissal notices to 1,750 employees today. Several hundred workers responded by marching outside a big Daewoo plant in Pupyong, 20 miles west of Seoul, shouting "We will fight to the end," as their families cheered them.

headline: Faults Found at a Schering Plant
abstract: Documents by Schering-Plough and Food and Drug Administration show Schering-Plough repeatedly failed to meet government manufacturing standards in making many of its prescription drugs including Claritin, its popular allergy medication, and Proventil, asthma inhaler; detailed report by federal inspectors, dated Jan 19, and audit by AAC Consulting Group, which was completed last April, describe significant problems at company's factory in Kenilworth, NJ, but does not discuss any effect problems might have had on patients; documents were sent anonymously to Public Citizen, which made them public; company recalled about 60 million Proventil inhalers in March 2000 after finding that some of them did not contain albuterol, ingredient that helps patients breathe; Schering-Plough declines comment (M)

headline: Housing Can´t Thrive on Lower Rates Alone
abstract: East, west. Home's best.

headline: Pentagon Will Order New Review on Cole
abstract: Defense Secretary William S. Cohen plans to order a new study to determine whether military commanders in the Persian Gulf should be held accountable for any security lapses that contributed to the bombing of the destroyer Cole in Yemen last October, Pentagon officials said.

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS/for NANCY F. KOEHN; An Information Age Led by Business, So Far
abstract: Nancy F Koehn, Harvard business historian, answers questions on prospects for business-friendly policies of Bush administration; photo (M)

headline: Germany Weighs Overhaul of 'Consensus' Capitalism
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder faces decision on whether he will support or water down expansion of current laws that give workers direct say in management of companies; Labor Min Walter Riester has drawn up proposed expansion of workers' rights on conviction that law needs to catch up with changes in German industry; Economics Min Werner Muller is convinced that plan will damage German growth and has threatened to resign if it becomes law in its current form; underlying battle is core question of flexibility; photo (M)

headline: Trial in AIDS Drug Lawsuit Opens in Pretoria
abstract: Thousands of demonstrators descend on Pretoria, South Africa, massing outside High Court and marching on US Embassy to protest against international pharmaceutical industry as it begins effort to overturn South African law aimed at easing access to AIDS drugs; photo (M)

headline: North Korea Turns Up the Heat; Calls U.S. a Nation of Cannibals
abstract: North Korea calls United States 'a cannibals' nation' and charges Bush administration with escalating provocative and reckless diatribe against North; pledges 'thousandfold revenge' if United States turns to confrontation; North has been ratcheting up its criticism since Pres Bush, in talks with South Korean president, Kim Dae Jung, expressed 'skepticism' about North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il (M)

headline: DEUTSCHE TELEKOM REPORTS QUARTERLY LOSS
abstract: Deutsche Telekom says it lost 1 billion euros, or $942 million, in fourth quarter; says profit for 2000 was 'basically zero,' compared with 1.25 billion euros in 1999; net income for year rose to 7.4 billion euros; sales rose 15 percent, to 40.9 billion euros, or $38.5 billion, last year from 35.5 billion euros in 1999 (S)

headline: SCHOLASTIC WITHDRAWS BID FOR ETOYS ASSETS
abstract: Scholastic, children's educational publisher, withdraws its bid to purchase assets from struggling online retailer eToys.com (S)

headline: Daewoo Motor's Fate Tied to Labor Strife
abstract: Questions remain about whether General Motors Corp will come to rescue of Daewoo Motor a day after riot police dislodge hundreds of striking workers at its plant in Inchon, South Korea; Commerce Min Shin Kook Hwan says government will jump-start talks with GM as soon as possible since obstacles have been removed; believes primary obstacle has been resistance of workers to layoffs that GM negotiators had made clear had to happen before they could consider renewing offer that they first made in 1999 as Daewoo Motor collapsed under more than $10 billion in debts; photo (M)

headline: Time Revamps Business Titles
abstract: Time Inc reorganizes its business magazines into new unit to be led by John Huey, managing editor of Fortune; Huey is named to new position of editor of Fortune and will be succeeded by Richard Kirkland, magazine's deputy magaging editor (S)

headline: INTERNET-NAMES GROUP QUESTIONED
abstract: Sen Conrad Burns, chairman of Senate subcommittee on communications, says operations of organization in charge of creating and distributing Internet domain names are shrouded in mystery even though group, Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers, is supposed to function in open and transparent way; photo (S)

headline: WASTE SYSTEMS FILES FOR PROTECTION UNDER CHAPTER 11
abstract: Waste Systems International, trash disposal and recycling company, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection for itself and 30 units (S)

headline: GUATEMALA EASES CURRENCY RULE
abstract: Guatemala, in effort to attract foreign investment, remove incentives to use offshore accounts and keep inflation in check, says it will lift ban on use of foreign currencies for financial transactions inside country (S)

headline: Venture Capital Investments Plunged in Fourth Quarter
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 29 — Validating anecdotal evidence and increasingly conventional wisdom, an analysis released today shows that investing by venture capital firms plummeted in the fourth quarter of last year, with investors shying away from start-ups and instead shoring up struggling companies they had previously financed.

abstract: Roundup of advertising account changes (S)

headline: ONLINE ADS CLIMB TO RECORD
abstract: AdRelevance says online advertising impressions increased 21 percent in December 2000 over previous month, reaching record high of more than 65 billion, despite increasingly negative perceptions of online advertising industry; says Yahoo led all sites with more than 7.5 billion ad impressions during December; says MSN brought in most ad revenue that month, $180 million, with average of $486,000 in revenue per advertiser; says Amazon.com led all online advertisers in ad spending with more than $61.8 million, 42 percent of which was on MSN (S)

headline: SCRIPPS SAYS FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS WILL DISAPPOINT
abstract: E W Scripps Co says first-quarter earnings will be less than forecast because of reduced advertising sales (S)

headline: Factory Index Fell Sharply Last Month
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management reports its factory index was 43.7 in December, down from 47.7 in November, suggesting that overall economy was growing at rate of less than 1 percent a year; report adds new intensity to debate over whether US economy is headed for recession this year; index is near 1991 level (M)

headline: Written on Wall (And in Windows)
abstract: Profile of Hermann Zapf, noted German designer of typefaces, whose fonts are generously represented in both Microsoft and Apple Macintosh desktop-publishing and word-processing systems; photo (M)

headline: At a French Factory, Culture is a Two-Way Street
abstract: Article describes cultural and culinary adaptations made by French and Japanese at Toyota Motor Company plant near Valenciennes, France, where first Toyota Yaris, bulbous subcompact model, rolled off assembly line in January; photos (M)

headline: SONERA IN DEAL WITH VODAFONE
abstract: Finland's Sonera telecommunications company will add potential 11.6 million customers to its Zed mobile phone business under deal with Vodafone of Britain (S)

headline: Even Hardware Needs Designated Drivers
abstract: Q. My U.S.B. scanner says that it needs a driver and wants to look on the Internet for it. What does this mean and how does it work?    A. Drivers are pieces of software that allow your operating system to communicate with hardware devices and programs.

headline: When the Shark Bites, Hit the Web
abstract: Sharks are subject of several Web sites, two concerned with shark attacks on people and one site for people who are fans of sharks; photo (M)

headline: Israel Hits Palestinian Targets, Retaliating for New Bombing
abstract: JERUSALEM, March 28 -- Israeli helicopter gun ships bombarded bases and training camps of Yasir Arafat's personal security forces tonight after a Palestinian suicide bombing this morning that killed two Israeli teen-agers in central Israel.

headline: RETAILER REPORTS STRONG DEMAND
abstract: Dixons Group says net income in six months ended Nov 11 rose to 70.6 million pounds ($105.2 million) from 70.4 million pounds ($104.9 million) in period a year earlier (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIANO BUYERS FOR HYUNDAI LIFE

headline: Europe and South Korea Fail To End Shipbuilding Dispute
abstract: Trade officials of European Union and South Korea confront one another in Seoul in bitter dispute over whether South Korean shipbuilding companies are unfairly 'dumping' their goods on world markets; union's trade commissioner, Pascal Lamy, ends his session with Shin Kook Hwan, South Korea's minister of commerce, as he started it--with pledge to bring case before World Trade Organization in Geneva in early May if Europe's demands are not met; Lamy says union will introduce new ways to subsidize its shipbuilders if parties do not reach satisfactory agreemnet; Europeans say that Korean shipbuilders sell ships at 20 percent below fair value, and sometimes as much as 40 percent, and that government subsidizes shipbuilders by rolling over loans and using government-backed entities to help them issue bonds cheaply (M)

headline: Nascar Revs Back Up After Earnhardt Death
abstract: THE death of Dale Earnhardt, the fabled stock car driver, last month was a blow not only to his fans but also to companies that are tied to motor sports. Shares in the dominant racetrack companies, the International Speedway Corporation and Speedway Motorsports plummeted in the days just after Mr. Earnhardt's crash at the Daytona International Speedway in Florida.

headline: Airbus Goes Global in Its Battle to Beat Boeing
abstract: TOULOUSE, France—  As industrial production of the Airbus A380 superjumbo jet gets under way, the contest between Airbus Industrie and Boeing Corp. is shaping up as the world's most bitter commercial battle. It involves big egos, tens of billions of dollars and a race to market the latest aeronautic technology.

headline: Tank Warfare on Jerusalem's Outskirts
abstract: Palestinian killed in Israeli shelling of Beit Jala, attack Israel says was aimed at halting week of nightly shootings from Palestian town at Jerusalem's Gilo neighborhood, is given martyr's funeral; mourners call for suicide attacks on Israel; town has become unwilling battleground in Palestinian uprising; map (M)

headline: THE LITTLE HAND'S ON THE NET
abstract: Timex, in concert with Motorola and Skytel, plans to market Internet Messenger watches offering wireless Web options, including e-mail (S)

headline: A whole lot of executive moving and shaking going on in the run-up to the Super Bowl.
abstract: Advertising column on recent executive changes at TBWA/Chiat/Day, Martin Agency, Hill, Holiday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Saatchi & Saatchi, Leo Burnett Worldwide and Publicis SA (M)

headline: Vehicle Sales Held Strong Last Month
abstract: American consumers continued to flock to car dealerships in February despite economic slowdown, producing another unexpectedly strong month for auto sales; sales fell 6 percent from February 2000, but year-earlier month had been one of best in industry's history; seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales was 17.5 million vehicles; brisk sales, combined with slower shipments to factories, helped car dealers clear lots that had become crammed with unsold vehicles earlier this winter; General Motors has 87-day inventory of unsold vehicles, Ford Motor's inventory is down to 80 days and Chrysler has 58-day supply, its lowest since July 1999; sales at GM declined 9.5 percent from year earlier, while Chrysler's dropped 10.5 percent and Ford's were down 11.2 percent; sales figures for Honda, Mitsubishi Motors, Nissan, BMW and Volkswagen noted; graph; charts (M)

headline: AMERITRADE, ONLINE STOCK FIRM, NAMES CHIEF
abstract: Ameritrade Holdings choses Joseph Moglia as its chief executive (S)

headline: Italian by Design; Stylists of Turin Expand Impact of Auto Couturiers
abstract: Italdesign-Giugiaro and other companies in Turin, Italy, that provide design, engineering and manufacturing services for a fee have withstood rush of mergers and acquisitions that pushed specialty carmakers like Bentley, Ferrari and Maserati into hand of big automakers; are poised to rebound strongly because their impressive talents can help remaining automakers design and engineer cars to distinguish themselves and set apart their ever more common platforms from rest of industry; designs of Giorgetto Giugairo and Leonardo Fioravanti discussed; photos (M)

headline: Troops Say Kosovo Duty Sharpens Their Skills
abstract: American soldiers and senior commanders on duty in Kosovo say they believe their mission is important, and many insist that their work in Kosovo is making them better soldiers; say they welcome opportunity to interact with other NATO militaries; Pres-elect Bush, while campaigning, complained that Balkan peacekeeping diverts military from its primary task of preparing to fight nation's wars and degraded necessary skills; Condolezza Rice, Bush's national security adviser, had warned that if Vice Pres Al Gore became president, America's military would be overdeployed and morale would be weakened; commanders interviewed say duty in Kosovo offers something their troops would never receive in training, chance for young officers and soldiers armed with live ammunition to operate in politically complex and potentially risky situation, making decisions that affect people's lives; photo; map (M)

headline: Campaign to Re-elect Annan at U.N.
abstract: Organization of African Unity opens campaign to have United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan re-elected to second five-year term; Annan has made significant management changes within UN and helped to improve relations with Washington (S)

headline: Village That Rebels Held Is Suddenly Almost Empty
abstract: Ethnic Albanian rebels withdraw from Tetovo, Macedonia's second-largest city, after laying siege for 12 days; flee into wooded hills after emptying village of residents amid offensive by Macedonian Army; withdrawal is seen as coordinated effort to allow Albanian political parties time to negotiate conflict with government; maps (M)

headline: COCA-COLA EXPECTED TO REGAIN CONCESSION CONTRACT
abstract: Coca-Cola Co, recapturing contract that it lost 10 years ago, is expected to announce that it has reached agreement with HMSHost to become exclusive soft drink of nation's largest airports; contract is worth estimated $35 million (S)

headline: Questions in Microsoft Appeal Focus on U.S. Judge's Actions
abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 — A government lawyer had to respond to more pointed questioning today during an appeals court hearing on a federal judge's ruling that the Microsoft Corporation should be broken up.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: AFRICA    SOUTH AFRICA: AIDS-DRUGS TRIAL DELAYED  The judge in the long-anticipated trial of the pharmaceutical industry's lawsuit against the South African government postponed the case to mid-April after rejecting an industry plea to block an AIDS treatment advocacy group from filing a brief in support of the government. The ruling came only one day into oral arguments by the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association of South Africa, which is challenging a law aimed at easing access to AIDS drugs still under patent. It said it would need months to prepare a response to the advocacy group's filings.    Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

headline: PRICES RISE FASTER IN BRAZIL
abstract: Brazil's consumer price index rises 0.59 percent in Dec and 5.97 percent for year (S)1

headline: Business Travel; Competition among premium airline services intensifies.
abstract: Cutbacks in travel expenses at many companies force airlines and corporate travel departments to face question of how much of corporate air fare dollar will continue going toward increasingly supply of first-class, business-class and premium economy-class seats that airlines have been rushing to add to attract business travelers (M)

headline: ATI TECHNOLOGIES SAYS DEMAND IS WEAK
abstract: ATI Technologies says fiscal second-quarter sales will be less than forecast in January and its loss wider than expected because of slow computer sales and higher costs for memory chips; graph (S)

headline: British Cement Maker in New Talks on a Takeover by Lafarge
abstract: Lafarge SA reportedly nears deal to acquire Blue Circle Industries PLC, British cement company, for $4.6 billion (M)

headline: The Cole Investigation Proves Frustrating
abstract: American investigators have only circumstantial evidence, but no proof, of who was ultimately responsible for ordering bombing attack on destroyer Cole four months ago, and exactly how it was planned and carried out; dozen suspects are in custody and in jails in Yemen, but Federal Bureau of Investigation remains convinced conspiracy goes beyond Yemen, in all likelihood to Afghanistan, where Osama bin Laden lives in sanctuary under protection of Taliban; bin Laden is prime suspect, but probe has failed so far to establish more than 'inferential evidence' of his involvement (M)

headline: SONY, TOSHIBA AND I.B.M. WORKING ON CHIP
abstract: Sony Corp, Toshiba Corp and IBM announce joint project to research and develop 'supercomputer on a chip' for extremely fast network processors to be used in range of consumer electronic devices; companies will invest more than $400 million in project over next five years (S)

headline: The View From Wilkes-Barre
abstract: Chuck Cohen letter concerns Feb 4 article on US economy

headline: Sharon Offers Barak and Peres Senior Ministry Jobs
abstract: JERUSALEM, Feb. 9 — Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon offered the post of defense minister today to outgoing Prime Minister Ehud Barak, who is weighing the offer three days after announcing his retirement from politics, Israeli radio and television reported.

headline: JAPANESE CONSUMERS INCREASE SPENDING
abstract: Consumer spending in Japan rose 0.8 percent more in December than in November, even as income slipped 4 percent; graph (S)

headline: 1999 U.S. Document Warned of Depleted Uranium in Kosovo
abstract: US urged allied armies after NATO bombing campaign of 1999 to take special precautions on entering Kosovo, Serbia, because American ammunition littering landscape contained depleted uranium that posed possible health risks; document issued by Joint Chiefs of Staff warned soldiers and civilians against touching spent ammunition and other contaminated materials; growing number of former peacekeepers from Europe and Canada have contracted cancer and cancer-like diseases from exposure, and at least 15 have died; Pentagon and NATO, while acknowledging hazards, deny any links exist between exposure to depleted uranium and illness and deaths of veterans; photo (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Napster Is Stirring Debate on Art and Ethics
abstract: Forum at MIT on Napster focuses on issues of art and ethics rather than the law; Erc Scheirer, analyst with Forrester Research, comments (M)

headline: Making New Friends At Procter & Gamble; Company Seeks Partners as Part Of a Makeover
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co begins licensing its reliability engineering methods, latest move by company into licensing deals and joint ventures; has announced joint ventures in last three months worth billions of dollars; one venture, with Coca-Cola Co, will sell Coke's Minute Maid and Hi-C drinks and P&G's Pringles chips and Sunny Delight juice drink; has also started Project EMM, venture with Magnifi, marketing-services company, to create independent company to make software system to better manage Procter's marketing efforts; has also joined Whirlpool to create new home appliance, Personal Valet; Procter's licensing division has entered into deal that let other companies, including Dana Undies and Marine Optical, use its brand names; photos (M)

headline: PROXICOM, AN INTERNET CONSULTANT, TO LAY OFF 227
abstract: Proxicom Inc, Internet consulting company, will lay off 227 employees, 19 percent of its work force; sees first-quarter earnings forecasts as unattainable (S)

headline: Ignore the Label, It's Flextronics Inside; Outsourcing's New Cachet in Silicon Valley
abstract: Article on San Jose-based Flextronics Inc, world's second-largest company in industry known as electronics manufacturing services; industry, which assembles things like personal computers and various consumer gadgets, got little notice until January, when Swedish telecommunications giant Ericsson announced that it would turn over its factories and manufacturing operations entirely to Flextronics in deal that could be worth as much as $5 billion per year; many high-technology companies, including Ericsson and Microsoft Corp, have abandoned manufacturing, and Flextronics has thrived by filling void; graphs; photos (M)

headline: California Agency Challenges Energy Bills
abstract: California Independent System Operator, manager of state's power-grid system, seeks investigation by federal regulators of its contention that power generators overcharged by $555 million for electricity sold in December, 2000, and January, 2001 (M)

headline: Article 2001020592287781526 -- No Title
abstract: February 5, 2001

headline: Here, Boy. Come to The Toy Store. Please!
abstract: Tiger Electronics' robotic dog toy is on tortuous journey from inventor's workshop to store shelves; photos (M)

headline: Sharon Opens His Campaign; U.S. Diplomat Puts Off Trip
abstract: Ariel Sharon, hawkish Likud Party leader and front-runner for premiership of Israel, formally kicks off his campaign, as American envoy Dennis Ross indefinitely postpones trip to region for last-minute peacekmaking efforts; Sharon has made it clear that if he becomes prime minister in Feb 6 elections, he will consider any Israeli-Palestinian understandings reached at or since failed Camp David talks last July to be void; he reminds supporters he served in military for many years, lost many friends and been wounded more than once; says he, too, yearns for peace; Sharon's lead over Prime Min Ehud Barak in polls is so big that Barak faces mounting pressure from within his own Labor Party to step down as candidate and let Shimon Peres run in his place; photo (M)

headline: Czechs Cracking Down on Fraud
abstract: Czech authorities are cracking down on financial fraud, winning some siginficiant convictions and bringing some important changes in mounting cleanup campaign that they hope will restore investor confidence; though Czech economy grew 2.8 percent last year, loosely regulated stock market is all but dead; nearly all $4 billion that came into country last year was direct foreign investment into banks, factories or utilities controlled by foreign companies; state prosecutor Frantisek Fila says criminals have edge over law enforcement officials; former tennis star Milan Srejber has been sentenced to five and half years in prison for stealing 16 million korunas ($424,000) through share manipulations in several privatization investment funds he controlled; photos (M)

headline: China Asserts U.S. Scholar Confesses Security 'Crimes'
abstract: BEIJING, March 22 — A government spokesman said today that Gao Zhan, a United States-based sociologist who has been held incommunicado since Feb. 11 for unspecified "activities damaging state security," had openly confessed her crimes. But the spokesman, Sun Yuxi of the Foreign Ministry, refused to say what she had confessed to, only noting that the investigation was continuing.

headline: Powerful Media Is Said to Be Seeking Buyer
abstract: Powerful Media, whose World Wide Web site, Inside.com, has drawn wide praise for its penetrating coverage of media, reportedly begins shopping itself to big-name media giants; photo (M)

headline: U.S. REVIEWING AID MEANT TO CONTAIN RUSSIA'S ARSENAL
abstract: Bush administration begins comprehensive review of all American aid programs to Russia set up to stop spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons; Washington now spends more than $760 million a year trying to dismantle former Soviet nuclear, biological and chemical complexes and prevent unconventional weapons and hazardous materials from being sold to rogue states and terrorist groups or stolen by them; senior official says several programs seem 'very effective,' but others are not; cites $6 billion longterm effort to help dispose of 34 metric tons of weapons-grade plutonium as money not well spent; review comes at time of growing tension between Russia and United States; Russian officials accuse Washington of being intent on reviving cold war (M)

headline: Aiming to Break the Rules on Spelling
abstract: Richard L Wade creates Web site dedicated to simplification of spelling of English words; photo (M)

headline: Powell Goes on the Road And Scores Some Points
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell's just-completed first trip abroad reveals intensely personal style of diplomacy imbued with authority and confidence; Powell seems reassured that he was able to rally Arab leaders around new policy on Iraq that would tighten sanctions on military equipement and money and relax them on civilian goods; Powell acknowledged during trip that this policy has not been approved by Bush administration, but by traveling early and speaking out, he has put State Department squarely in favor of sanctions reform, not overthrow; several highlights of trip noted (M)

headline: Internet Services Put Credibility to Test
abstract: Angel Technologies Inc plans to provide high-speed Internet access using solar-powered, high-altitude manned aircraft that will beam service to customers in large cities; will test network in 2002 and provide commercial service in 2003; graph of growth in high-speed access; photo (M)

headline: Fly in a Retro World Under Crimson Skies
abstract: Article reviews Crimson Skies, new computer game published by Microsoft; photos (M)

headline: NEW HAMPSHIRE TV STATION IS SOLD TO HEARST-ARGYLE
abstract: Hearst-Argyle Television buys WMUR-TV, ABC affiliate serving Manchester, NH, from Imes Communications for $185 million; sells its three Phoenix radio stations to Emmis Communications Corp for $160 million (S)

headline: ETOYS SHUTTING BRITISH UNIT
abstract: EToys, beleaguered online retailer, will shut its operations in Britain, its only foreign outpost; all 74 employees will be laid off (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    VATICAN: POPE AND PARKINSON'S  The orthopedic surgeon who operated on John Paul II in 1994 said he was concerned about the pope's health and listed Parkinson's disease as one of the pope's ailments. ''I should order him to rest but it would be futile,'' Gianfranco Fineschi said in remarks to the Italian weekly Oggi that were given in advance to the Italian news agency ANSA. The Vatican has never publicly confirmed the pope has Parkinson's.    Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

headline: Coventry Journal; Godiva Outstripped: A Global Call to Peel It Off
abstract: Article on Freedom to Be Yourself Movement, brainchild of Coventry, England, resident Vincent Bethell, who is campaigner for right to go naked in public; movement has involved stripped-down protests in London in front of House of Lords, Royal Courts of Justice and New Scotland Yard, and has tickled fancy of country with strong libertarisn streak and tendency to celebrate eccentric challenges to authority; Bethell is organizing international nude-in on July 1, when he is inviting people worldwide to remove clothes at 2pm London time; map; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001021090979097826 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: FedEx Makes Deal to Haul Some Mail
abstract: FedEx Corp says it will transport mail for US Postal Service; agreement will also allow FedEx to place collection boxes at post offices around country; Postal Service will pay FedEx about $6.3 billion over next seven years for service, which is scheduled to begin in August; Postal Service will gain single air transportation provider for most of its express and priority mail; job has been handled by Emery Worldwide Airlines, but postal service officials say deal with Emery is too costly and inefficient; say new agreement should provide savings of more than $1 billion a year for Postal Service; photo (M)

headline: Quake's Victims: Rich and Homeless, Poor and Homeless
abstract: Earthquake in India knocked down big concrete houses as well as mud dwellings; rich and poor alike are homeless for now and reliant on charity for food and shelter; world attention has so far focused on Ahmedabad and Bhuj, but officials say much of worst destruction is in 450 villages scattered across landscape in Kutch district of Gujarat (M)

headline: U.S. TRIES DEFUSING ALLIES' OPPOSITION TO MISSILE DEFENSE
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld seeks to defuse opposition to Bush administration's antimissile plans by offering to help European nations and other allies to deploy missile defenses; Rumsfield, first senior Bush administration offical to visit Europe, assures European allies that US would consult with them on its antimissile plan; he does not address one of Europeans' principal concerns: how antimissile defense can be reconciled with strategic arms control and productive relationship with Moscow; Rumsfeld underscores that Bush administration is determined to proceed with antimissile defense of US territory even if it could not overcome objections from Russians, Chinese and Europeans; calls missile defense moral imperative; photo (M)

headline: ROLLS SELLS VICKERS UNITS
abstract: Rolls-Royce sells most of its Vickers Turbine Components unit to private equity fund run by Royal Bank of Scotland for 74 million pounds ($111 million) (S)

headline: TRENDS; Getting Fired Isn't What it Used to Be, and That's Good and Bad
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics' preliminary figures show layoffs rose to 15,700 in 2000 from 14,900 in 1999; Manchester Inc survey shows some dismissed workers are small severance package; graphs (M)

headline: COVAD COMMUNICATIONS TO CLOSE 60 MORE OFFICES
abstract: Covad Communications Group, provider of Internet service over telephone lines, will shut 60 more offices; share price falls 31 percent (S)

headline: Article 2001020591632018026 -- No Title
abstract: STATE OF THE ART

headline: Israel in the Homestretch: Still Surreal
abstract: Ariel Sharon, right-wing leader, holds such a seemingly invincible lead over Prime Minister Ehud Barak that many Israelis have already moved on to debating makeup of Sharon's future government; Barak's campaign schedule is so light it suggests that he has given up, but he insists that Israelis will come to their senses once they are no longer distracted by possibility that he might step aside and let former Prime Min Shimon Peres take over as Labor candidate (M)

headline: A Higher Calling
abstract: Maxx International negotiates 15-year contract with Roman Catholic Church to sell prepaid telephone calling cards with photo of Pope John Paul II; communications service provider is Telstar International (S)

headline: 'MALL' OPERATOR SETTLES CHARGES
abstract: Bigsmart.com, which promised substantial income for investors through an Internet shopping network, agrees to settle charges that it operated an illegal pyramid scheme; will pay back $5 million to its customers (S)

headline: ICAHN IS SEEKING AIRLINE FOR LOWESTFARE.COM
abstract: Financier Carl C Icahn pledges $400 million to finance effort to either build or buy airline for Lowestfare.com, which provides discount travel products and services; move follows failed bid to acquire Trans World Airlines (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Putting Readers in the Assignment Desk
abstract: Plastic.com, Web site fueled by readers and run by editors, begins operations; readers will submit links to items that appear elsewhere online, along with commentary about items; editors will post most clever submissions; readers can then post comments in response; photo (M)

headline: MediaTalk; NBC Election Star Accepts Offer From ABC
abstract: Claire Shipman, who emerged as television star with her on-the-ground presence for NBC and MSNBC throughout election and its messy aftermath, is now leaving NBC, accepting offer from ABC News, which will pay her more than $600,000 a year; photo (M)

headline: First Leader To Visit Bush Is Canadian
abstract: Pres George W Bush welcomes Canada's Pres Jean Chretien in first test of face-to-face diplomacy after spending two weeks getting to know world leaders via telephone (S)

headline: Tales About E-Tailers
abstract: Fran Menzel on Dec 21 Online Shopper column on goods ordered from online merchants that are not delivered on time

headline: When School Is Held on Snow Days
abstract: One of every student's most sacred institutions, the snow day, is being threatened by technology in the classroom of one innovative New York City teacher, who says that school need not close for bad weather.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CALPINE CORP.,  San Jose, Calif., an independent power producer, said it would build a power plant near Beloit, Wis., for $350 million. Construction is scheduled to begin in the third quarter of 2001, and Calpine expects the plant to be operating by the third quarter of 2003.    THERMO ELECTRON CORP.,  Waltham, Mass., a manufacturing conglomerate, said it would sell a power-generation unit, Thermo Ecotek, to AES, Arlington, Va., a global power company, for $195 million in cash.

headline: PURE RESOURCES MAKES DEAL TO BUY HALLWOOD ENERGY
abstract: Pure Resources Inc agrees to purchase Hallwood Energy Corp for $268 million in cash and assumed debt; purchase will increase Pure's natural gas output and add to its oil and gas reserves in Southwest (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    KOSOVO: VIOLENCE CONTINUES -- The commander of the peacekeeping forces in Kosovo ordered extra troops and two special police units into the divided town of Mitrovica in northern Kosovo as violence continued for a third day. Eleven French soldiers and several ethnic Albanian demonstrators were wounded by grenades as Albanians protested the death of a 15-year-old on Monday.     Carlotta Gall (NYT)    NORTHERN IRELAND: LONDON TALKS -- Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, met at 10 Downing Street for what the Northern Ireland secretary, John Reid, left, called a ''stock-taking'' on policing, demilitarization and guerrilla disarmament, issues that threaten the home-rule Belfast government. Talks have become intensive in an effort to reach agreement before a meeting next week of the Ulster Unionists, who want an end to the joint Protestant-Catholic administration unless the Irish Republican Army begins disarming.     Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Officer Admits Osprey Falsifying
abstract: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 — A Marine commander has acknowledged that he falsified maintenance records of the V-22 Osprey squadron as new details emerged on the scope of alleged attempts to cover-up problems in the troubled aircraft program, Pentagon officials said today.

headline: A Dot-Com Decides to Go Nonprofit
abstract: For years, Internet companies have incurred jokes about how their Web sites should be classified as dot-org rather than dot- com, given how closely their balance sheets resembled those of nonprofit organizations.

headline: LLOYDS PROFIT GROWS
abstract: Lloyds TSB Group says pretax profit rose 7 percent in 2000, to $5.24 billion (S)

headline: Bcom3 Postpones Initial Public Offering
abstract: Bcom3 Group decides not to make initial public stock offering this year, citing market conditions (M)

headline: Satellite Vs. Cable: A Rivalry Beyond TV
abstract: Cable modems are shaping up as nation's preferred medium for high-speed Internet service even as upgrading of digital cable service is eroding satellite's longstanding dominance in television programming; both satellite and cable companies try to assemble broad packages of video, Internet and even futuristic interactive TV; News Corp will likely soon merge its global satellite operations with DirecTV, dominant US satellite provider; but largest US cable provider, AT&T, considers its bundle of digital service, high-speed Internet and telephone service adequate to garner it the lead in satellite-cable battle; chart (M)

headline: Arthur Hummel Jr. Dies at 80; Negotiated Taiwan Arms Pact
abstract: Arthur W Hummel Jr, former ambassador to China who negotiated arms sales to Taiwan, dies at age 80; photo (M)

headline: JAPANESE CONSUMER SPENDING FALLS
abstract: Japanese consumers spent 1.5 pecent less in November than in October; cautious spending habits are often held responsible for Japan's continuing economic doldrums (S)

headline: Economic Jitters Send Latin American Stocks Reeling; Brazil Frets Over Rate Rise And the Turmoil Next Door
abstract: Brazil's stock markets plummet on heels of surprise half-point increase in interest rates by Brazilian central bank, and they are rattled further by economic problems in neighboring Argentina (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled for Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Japan Is Shackled by Deflation, Blocking Its Hope for Recovery
abstract: Deflation is major cause of many of Japan's economic woes, blocking any hope for recovery as country shows signs of falling back into recession; rare but devastating drop in prices of goods and services is feeding on itself, chipping away at asset values, increasing credit risks, pinching wages and salaries, and preventing economy from generating any sustained growth after decade of stagnation; stocks trade at same prices of 15 years ago, and land values in major cities which back many loans made by Japanese banks have fallen 65 percent from peak in 1991; excluding fresh foods, prices nationwide fell 1.1 percent in 2000 in greatest decline since World War II; though some economists have championed deflation as road to economic modernization, question is whether Japan can tolerate its pain; charts; photo (M)

headline: ELECTRONICS MANUFACTURER IS TRIMMING 8,200 JOBS
abstract: Solectron Corp, electronics manufacturer, is cutting 8,200 jobs, or more than 10 percent reduction, because demand is falling; company says net income for second quarter ended March 2 rose 26 percent, to $121.9 million; sales rose 85 percent, to $5.42 billion (S)

headline: Of Offers and Counteroffers
abstract: Jonathan Sack letter responds to Jan 21 article about accepting, and then declining, a job offer

headline: NBC and Paramount Agree On 3-Year 'Frasier' Extension
abstract: NBC and Paramount Television announce, after difficult negotiations, their agreement that will keep hit TV show 'Frasier' at NBC for three more years (M)

headline: Article 2001012891756373366 -- No Title
abstract: January 28, 2001

headline: Article 2001011592493480266 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: A Legal Tender of One's Own
abstract: Giacinto Auriti has deposed Italian central bank from its money-printing monopoly by printing and distributing local currency in Guardiagrele called the simec beginning in summer of 2000; Auriti believed about 2 billion simecs, worth $1.9 million at Auriti's exchange rate, were in circulation by mid-August; currency's rapid spread unsettled local officials, who ordered financial police to impound simecs in circulation; court in Chieti soon restored them, arguing that Italian law proscribed counterfeiting national currency, but not printing money of one's own; Auriti estimates that about 700 million simecs are in circulation; photos (M)

headline: HARTZ SAYS IT HAS BEEN ACQUIRED BY MANAGEMENT GROUP
abstract: Hartz Mountain Corp, leading maker of pet supplies, is acquired by its management group, J W Childs Associates; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: SONY'S PROFIT SLIPS
abstract: Sony Corp says its third-quarter profit declined 22.8 percent, to 72.2 billion yen ($611 million) (S)

headline: A Secret Life Emerges in Lawsuit Facing Toronto Mayor
abstract: Grace M Louie is suing Melvin Lastman, recently re-elected Toronto mayor, holding they had 14-year affair and secret family; seeks $4 million for herself and two now middle-aged sons; scandal threatens political future of man who may be Canada's most popular politician, although poll shows many voters continue to back Lastman (M)

headline: Thais Vote, but Sorting Out Who's In May Take Weeks
abstract: Thailand holds elections and Thaksin Shinawatra appears headed for victory as prime minister, notwithstanding his indictment for corruption charges; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls against dollar on report that points to further inflation risks in Europe; graphs; table (S)

headline: Now the Weather, Brought to You by Doppler Radar
abstract: Doppler radars and other radar advances greatly enhance meteorologists' ability to pinpoint storms and allow them to see certain storms even before they form; drawings (M)

headline: Murdoch Deal On TV Stations May Help UPN
abstract: Eight television stations Rupert Murdoch's News Corp plans to buy from Chris-Craft Industries are set to extend their accord to be affiliates of Viacom's UPN network through next television season; purchase will thus make Murdoch UPN's most important station owner; UPN competes with News Corp's Fox network for young male audience; News Corp president Peter Chernin says company might eventually seek UPN stake (M)

headline: Article 2001020192911395466 -- No Title
abstract: February 1, 2001

headline: Coffey Is Said to Resign Top Post at CNN Financial News Channel
abstract: C. Shelby Coffey III, the president of CNN's financial news network, CNNfn, has resigned from his position to pursue the creation of a medical foundation, CNN executives said today.

headline: Addenda: Jaguar Announces New Global Agency
abstract: Jaguar Cars, part of the Ford Motor Company , formally announced yesterday the selection of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group , to handle its worldwide creative account. Billings for the account, to be led from the agency's Irvine, Calif., and London offices, were estimated at $125 million.

headline: White House Reveals Plans For New Taiwan Arms Sale
abstract: Bush administration officially tells Congress for first time details of Taiwan's request for advanced weapons; appears to be paving way for package of sales that China vigorously opposes (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNET AD AGENCY CITES DIFFICULT OUTLOOK The online advertising company 24/7 Media , based in New York, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss widened, and it warned that its growth for the rest of the year could be much slower than anticipated as the advertising industry weakens. The company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $677.1 million, or $15.96 a share, partly because of investment write-offs, compared with a loss of nearly $13 million, or 58 cents a share, a year earlier. "It is going to be tough this year in the media business," said David J. Moore, the chief executive of 24/7. Jayson Blair (NYT)

headline: Cindy Crawford, no longer a fixture for Revlon, is hired to give Ellen Tracy apparel youthful appeal.
abstract: Cindy Crawford is hired to endorse Ellen Tracy line of women's fashions; ads are being created by Ziccardi & Partners; campaign is budgeted at $10 million; photo (M)

headline: A Wait Pays Off At Merrill
abstract: Some longtime Merrill Lynch & Co stockbrokers are disappointed to see brokerage firm's shares that are usually deposited in their accounts on first trading day of new year, portion of brokers' earnings, not in their accounts on morning of Jan 3, but are elated to find out Merrill Lynch will deposit shares into their accounts at end of Jan 4; Merrill Lynch shares closed at $73.44, up $7.69 (M)

headline: DDB Worldwide Gets Amex Account
abstract: American Stock Exchange, owned by National Association of Securities Dealers, names New York office of DDB Worldwide to handle its advertising account, which had been handled by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer/Euro RSCG Worldwide; billings estimated at $10 million to $20 million (S)

headline: In Sahara Salt Mine, Life's Not Too Grim
abstract: Salt from mines in Bilma, Niger, is used strictly for livestock, and is so sought after that many herders prefer it to vitamins and other chemical supplements; photos; map (M)

headline: Article 2001012092345211186 -- No Title
abstract: January 20, 2001

headline: FIRST VIRGINIA TO BUY JAMES RIVER BANKSHARES
abstract: First Virginia Banks acquires James River Bankshares Inc for $107.1 million in stock to increase its size in five Virginia counties (S)

headline: Proposal Could Leave Only a Little Bit of the Sky for the Also-Rans
abstract: American Airlines plan to buy some of US Airways' assets and take over faltering Trans World Airlines has convinced many experts that chance of third airline's challeging United and American will be slim if complicated set of deals is consummated; analysts say antitrust authorities that American and United have designed their deals to placate will have difficulty approving agreements among Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and Continental Airlines; American has agreed to pay United $1.5 billion to buy 86 jets and 15 gates at six East Coast airports and to jointly operate lucrative Boston-New York-Washington shuttle; it has also agreed to buy 49 percent stake in DC Air, carrier created to operate many of US Airways' assets at Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington; American will also take over most TWA's assets for $500 million after carrier declares bankruptcy (M)

headline: Global Look at Racism Hits Many Sore Points
abstract: UN conference on racism, planned for this summer in South Africa, may be explosive, given moves afoot to cast globalization as racial issue and to demand reparations for slave trade and colonialism; meeting first proposed by Cuba was always expected to have anti-Western bias, but chance to air grievances has been seized by groups in developing countries from China to Chile (M)

headline: Loews Cineplex May Seek Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: Loews Cineplex Entertainment, one of nation's largest movie exhibitors, may file for bankruptcy protection in wake of the industry's building binge; Loews will close 112 aging theaters with 675 screens, nearly one third of company's total screens (M)

headline: Old Soldier, New Battle
abstract: Ariel Sharon faces new challenges after election as prime minister of Israel, including building working coalition from unruly Parliament and addressing Palestinian conflict; his words indicate that he wants to redefine himself and confound world's expectation, but circumstances, partisan politics and his own adventurer's disposition could quickly undermine him (M)

headline: Timia Journal; A Nomad Deserts the Desert; His Garden Blooms
abstract: Tauregs and other nomads, know for leading wandering and borderless lives in no man's land between black Africa below Sahara and Arab Africa above it, are settling down in desert swath from Mauritania to Chad, forced by environmental and political changes in Africa in last two decades; about 6,000 have settled in villages across northern Niger, such as Timia, where many have taken up gardening; photos; map (M)

headline: AT&T Wireless To Begin a Review
abstract: AT&T Wireless, which is to be spun off by AT&T Corp, says it will begin review for its advertising account, which has been handled by FCB Worldwide; billings estimated at $400 million (S)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for PATRICK McGURN; The Shareholders at the Barricades
abstract: Patrick McGurn, director for corporate programs at Institutional Shareholder Services, unit of Thomson Financial, answers questions about the big issues in this year's proxy season; photo (M)

headline: Weak Outlook at Egghead
abstract: MENLO PARK, Calif., Jan. 26 — Egghead.com Inc. said today that its fourth-quarter sales would miss expectations because of softening demand for personal computers. But, because of cost-cutting measures, Egghead, an Internet retailer, expects to report a smaller loss than the 41 cents expected by Wall Street analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Egghead said it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss of 23 cents to 25 cents a share on revenue of $91 million to $93 million.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: QUEST DIAGNOSTICS INC., -- Teterboro, N.J., a medical laboratory test provider, agreed to pay $13.1 million to settle allegations that Nichols Institute, a unit it bought in 1994, overbilled government health-care programs between 1989 and 1995 for tests that were not medically necessary.

headline: CHARTER ONE BUYS ALLIANCE BANCORP FOR $245 MILLION
abstract: Ohio's Charter One Financial acquires Alliance Bancorp for $245 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: BUY.COM CHIEF RESIGNS
abstract: Gregory Hawkins resigns as chairman and chief executive of Buy.com, and Mitch Hill resigns as chief financial officer; James B Roszak will serve as interim chief executive; Donald Kendall, retired chief executive of Pepsico, is appointed chairman; photo (S)

headline: Bristol-Myers Squibb Names Marketing Official as Chief Executive
abstract: Peter R Dolan, president of Bristol-Myers Squibb, is promoted to chief executive officer; will take over for Charles A Heimbold Jr (M)

headline: In a Future Generation of Tiny Chips, Silicon May Shine
abstract: Team of scientists at University of Surrey in England use standard semiconductor production techniques to make proptotype of an all-silicon LED that converts electricity to light with efficiency that approaches that of some conventional devices made from other semiconductors; development of silicon chip that can transmit and receive light signals directly may one day lead to smaller, faster semiconductors and perhaps even to all-silicon lasers; drawing (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Firm Invests $240 Million For Stake in Nasdaq Market  The Nasdaq stock market, in another step to bring in outside investors, announced a $240 million investment by Hellman & Friedman, a private investment firm in San Francisco.    The investment comes as part of a commitment by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which owns Nasdaq, to sell its interest in the market. Hellman & Friedman's investment is the first by a firm unaffiliated with Nasdaq, which is seeking investors to finance its efforts to become a more technologically sophisticated global exchange. [Page C7.]

headline: I.M.F. Creates Unit to Spot Early Signs of Foreign Crises
abstract: International Monetary Fund is creating unit to anticipate and head off financial crises in countries to which fund makes loans; unit, to be known as International Capital Markets Department, will consolidate gathering and analysis of information that are now spread among other IMF departments; fund's managing director Horst Kohler comments (M)

headline: Plutonium Agreement With Russia Could Backfire, a Critic Says
abstract: Independent researcher Arjun Makhijani warns Russian-American disarmament accord to take 68 tons of plutonium out of nuclear weapons could have unintended effect of increasing chance of nuclear proliferation; Energy Department defends accord and seeks to help Russians sell material in Europe as reactor fuel; Makhijani also finds efforts around world to make plutonium and use it as reactor fuel have cost about $100 billion, and make little economic sense (M)

headline: Cesare Maltoni, 70, Dies; Cut Workplace Cancer Risks
abstract: Dr Cesare Maltoni, oncologist who identified cancer risks in workplace, dies at age 70 (M)

headline: Business Diary: Mr. Goodwrench Meets His Match
abstract: After years of offering customers Guns and Ammo magazines in the waiting rooms while workers in grease-covered overalls changed their oil, Jiffy Lube International wondered how it could do better. To its surprise, it learned from marketing research that at least half of its customers were women. So it hired Faith Popcorn, the marketing consultant, to find ways to reach women more effectively.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC., Sunnyvale, Calif., a maker of computer chips, said it would buy back as much as $300 million of its stock. The move is expected to increase the company's earnings per share by reducing its 313.4 million outstanding shares.    NESTLÉ NEDERLAND B. V., Vevey, Switzerland, a unit of the world's biggest food company, Nestlé S. A., has agreed to supply up to 7,000 tons of French fry potato mix annually to Tasty Fries Inc., Blue Bell, Pa.

headline: Animal Illness Suspected On Continent Prompts Bans
abstract: France and Belgium report suspected outbreaks of foot-and-mouth disease; two arms are quarantined as officials strive to reassure public about outbreak of livestock virus now centered in Britain (S)

headline: UNISYS OFFERS VOTING SYSTEM
abstract: Unisys, Microsoft and Dell Computer will join forces to develop technologies for electronic voting using Internet (S)

headline: The Big Question: How Much Further Is the Fed Willing to Go on Rates?
abstract: Article on how much further Federal Reserve is willing to cut interest rates; says central bank can be expected to do whatever it thinks is necessary to keep economy from heading into what Pres-elect George W Bush calls 'tailspin' (M)

headline: Senate Ends Bitter Dispute With the U.N. On U.S. Dues
abstract: Senate votes to immediately release $582 million the US owes in back dues to United Nations, recognizing that organization has made significant strides toward revamping operations (M)

headline: A Small Swiss Company Takes On Mad Cow Disease
abstract: Prionics of Switzerland develops test that pinpoints whether animals are infected with prion that causes cow disease and does so before damage to cow's brain is visible; is on cusp of profiting from widespread determination to test beef cattle more widely to prevent mad cow disease from entering human food chain; Bruno Oesch, Prionics founder, comments; photo (M)

headline: Romania Seeks to Stay On the Track to Europe
abstract: Adrian Nastase, new Romanian prime minister, knows that his government represents Romania's last, best chance of reversing huge popular frustration that fed a sizable vote for neofascism in last December's elections; Western officials, diplomats and investors know it too, after 10 years of watching Romania slide deeper into poverty and anger; they are skeptical, frustrated by Romania's years of dawdling on economic change, its endemic corruption and narrow-minded political squabbling; photo of Nastase; map (M)

headline: Primer on the Popular Instant Messaging Services
abstract: Tens of millions of people spend hours using instant messaging services, but it remains unclear whether companies that provide them can ever make money from it; their popularity is thought by many to have played critical role in growth of America Online; requiring AOL to open its system to rivals was thus seen by some Federal Communications Commission members as important step toward promoting competitive market for Internet service; Microsoft, MSN and Yahoo also provide such service (M)

headline: Serbian Prosecutors Show Signs of Closing In on Milosevic
abstract: Latest sign that government of Serbia is determined to pursue Slobodan Milosevic is announcement by Belgrade prosecutor of first formal investigation into his activities; Milosevic is widely blamed for wars and atrocities of last decade but also for widespread corruption in Serbia; he is currently living in government villa in Belgrade but under 24-hour surveillance(M)

headline: Builders' Optimism Is Up, Survey Says
abstract: National Association of Home Builders' housing market index increased in February to 58 from 55 in January; reading higher than 50 signals that majority of builders are positive about market conditions (S)

headline: CO-FOUNDER OF VOXEO STEPS DOWN AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Gary L Reback, co-founder of Voxeo Corp, is stepping aside as company's president and chief executive, but will remain as chairman of board; Reback's replacement will be Nancy Faigen (S)

headline: PHELPS DODGE SAYS ENERGY COSTS MAY FORCE LAYOFFS
abstract: Phelps Dodge Corp warns it might reduce copper production and lay off as many as 2,350 employees at mines in New Mexico and Arizona because of high energy costs in California has spilled over into nearby states (S)

headline: Pepsi Has 5th Quarter of Strong Growth
abstract: PepsiCo announces fifth consecutive quarter of double-digit earnings growth and predicts a sixth, despite persistent weakness in soda sales; revenue rose 7.6 percent, to $6.1 billion; operating profit rose 12.4 percent, to $984 million, and net income increased 14.7 percent, to $567 million; photo (M)

headline: Nortel Meets Estimates and Confirms Forecast
abstract: Nortel Networks, the largest maker of fiber optic equipment, reported strong growth in earnings and revenue for the fourth quarter Thursday, but it warned that tight financing for communications companies might lead sales to meet only the low end of estimates in the months ahead.

headline: People
abstract: Michael Garcia is named to new post of president and general manager of Latin American operations of Tribal DDB Worldwide; Larry Bevins is named to vacant post of vice president for creative and creative director at Townsend Agency (S)

headline: U.S. Fighter Jet Attacks Iraqi Defenses
abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 — An American fighter jet attacked a missile defense battery in Northern Iraq today, Pentagon officials said, resuming low-level skirmishes with Iraqi air-defense forces six days after American and British jets launched the first military strike authorized by President Bush.

headline: BRITANNICA CUTS BACK ONLINE
abstract: Britannica.com will dismiss 68 of its 220 United States employees; site, which offers free information from print version of Encyclopaedia Britannica, has not shown profit since it was introduced in October 1999 (S)
