headline: Cleaning Up and Feeling Good
abstract: Thomas Darden and James Anthony form Cherokee Property Foundation, which will accept donations of contaminated properties, clean them up, resell them and give profits of sale to charities after deducting clean-up costs and handling fees (S)

headline: Statement About Rates
abstract: Text of statement released by Federal Reserve after Federal Open Market Committee decides to lower interest rates

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas falls on expectations that milder weather in Midwest and Northeast will reduce demand; in New York, natural gas for March delivery falls 29 cents, or 5.2 percent, to $5.278 per million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: Waiting for the Other Shoe to Drop on a Sagging Economy
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column on view of some economists, still a minority, that economic slump in US will turn into recession and dim prospects for stock market because there may soon be layoffs and declines in worker income, which would slow consumer spending; graph (M)

headline: Insurers Push Rates Higher For Medigap
abstract: Rising costs of prescription drugs are driving up premiums of insurance plans that supplement traditional Medicare and include drug coverage; high costs of these so-called Medigap policies are forcing many elderly and disabled people out of programs even as Medicare managed care plans and employers are retreating from providing drug coverage; officials in New York, Illinois and Wisconsin report big increases; in New York, Empire HealthChoice, largest Medigap drug insurer, says it will raise premiums 31 percent on March 1 on Medigap policies with drug coverage; Empire, in letters to policyholders, says it underestimated rising medical costs even after 10 percent premium increases in each of last two years (M)

headline: Article 2001011893688880067 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Talk Is Still Waiting to Catch Fire
abstract: Tina Brown's Talk magazine is having difficult start; newsstand sales are well below initial projections of Ronald A Galotti, president of parent company Talk Media; percentage of copies shipped to newsstands that actually sell is at bottom of industry; advertising pages and revenue are down from comparable periods of late 1999 to late 2000; Talk suffered from case of high expectations when its first issue arrived in summer of 1999, given visibility of its founders, Brown and Galotti; Brown and Galotti say they are optimistic about Talk's future; photo; chart (M)

headline: NATO Troops Help Macedonians Drive Away Ethnic Albanian Rebels
abstract: SKOPJE, Macedonia, March 8 — United States-led peacekeeping troops in southern Kosovo occupied a village on the border with Macedonia today, as part of a coordinated move with Macedonian military forces through the night and morning to flush out ethnic Albanian rebels from their mountain base.

headline: Russia to Investigate a Mass Grave in Chechnya
abstract: Russian military officials promise to investigate grave containing a number of bodies found near Russian military base outside Chechen capital, Grozny, but make clear that they believe that its inhabitants were killed by Chechen rebels and not by Russian soldiers (M)

headline: CAMPBELL SOUP HIRES 2ND TOP EXECUTIVE FROM NABISCO
abstract: Campbell Soup Co names Robert Schiffner, treasurer at Nabisco Holdings Corp, its new chief financial officer, succeeding Basil Anderson, who is retiring (S)

headline: Nortel Plans to Cut 10,000 Jobs as It Lowers Earnings Outlook
abstract: Nortel Networks, Canadian maker of communications equipment, plans to eliminate 10,000 jobs; says it expects sales to grow only 15 percent this year, down from already lowered estimate of 30 percent; cites slower-than-expected sales in US as main reason for its reduced expectations; chief executive John Roth comments (M)

headline: Exchange Hires Former Banking Official
abstract: Chicago Board of Trade hires David Vitale, former vice chairman of Bank One Corp, to be its chief executive (S)

headline: Unusual Bear Market Begins, Concentrated on Tech Stocks
abstract: The bear market in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, the most widely followed broad measure of large American stocks, became official today as the index ended the day down more than 20 percent from the peak reached last March.

headline: For Tech-Happy Gastronomes, Reviews Are Always Handy
abstract: World of online restaurant guides is changing; hundreds of Web sites have sprung up in last few years offering vast array of restaurant selections--by name, state, city or neighborhood, cuisine or price or service or any combination of attributes diner could think of; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARE CHIP MAKER MISSES FORECASTS Advanced Micro Devices reported fourth-quarter net income yesterday that narrowly trailed forecasts and joined its larger rival Intel in predicting that slack sales of PC's would hurt first-quarter sales. Advanced Micro Devices said its net income for the quarter more than doubled to $177.9 million, or 53 cents a share, from $65.1 million, or 21 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 21 percent, to $1.18 billion. Analysts had expected the Sunnyvale, Calif.- based company to earn 55 cents a share. In light of weak demand for personal computers and slowing worldwide economies, the chip maker said it expected that normal seasonal weakness in first-quarter demand for PC processors coupled with the effects of excess PC inventories in distribution channels would hurt PC processor sales in the first quarter of 2001. (Reuters)

headline: Killing of 2 Israelis Shuts Down the Mideast Talks, but Hope Is Still in the Air
abstract: Killing of two Israeli civilians by Palestinian militants on West Bank interrupts new round of peace negotiations in Taba, Egypt; Prime Min Ehud Barak condemns the slayings and orders three cabinet ministers in the talks to return to Jerusalem (M)

headline: Intipuca Journal; Gaining Dollars, Town Is Losing Its Folkways
abstract: El Salvador has adopted dollar as its official currency, beginning Jan 1; town of Intipuca has been driven by dollars for more than 20 years, the result of especially large migration to United States and many dollars sent back; for every one of town's 7,200 people, nearly two others have been lured to United States to toil in restaurants, factories and construction sites; emigre dollars have helped country amass significant dollar reserves, but some critics say search for dollar is exacting cost from their society; photo; map (M)

headline: G.E. SAYS PROFITS WILL INCREASE AT LEAST 10% THIS YEAR
abstract: General Electric Co says that its profit will rise in 2001 by at least 10 percent and that earnings from its planned purchase of Honeywell International will be greater than previously estimated (S)

headline: M.T.A. Extends Contract With Agency
abstract: Metropolitan Transportation Authority extends its contract with Korey Kay & Partners for additional year beyond three-year term (S)

headline: Article 2001032994178508237 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Long Goodyear Run For Thompson Ends
abstract: Detroit office of J Walter Thompson ends its 16-year relationship with Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co by declining to participate in review of company's North American business; billings estimated at $60 million (S)

headline: Fed Cuts Key Interest Rate by One-Half Point
abstract: Confronted with increased evidence that the economy is stalling, the Federal Reserve slashed its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point today, stunning investors and sending a powerful signal of concern about the prospects for keeping the long expansion alive.

headline: Article 2001010491392772147 -- No Title
abstract: January 3, 2001

headline: Emergency Exits in a Wired World
abstract: Matt Richtel article suggests ways of ridding vacation of cell phones, e-mail and the Web in a world where they have become ubiquitous; cartoon (M)

headline: Timing the Market on Tuition
abstract: James Schembari Midstream column on selling stock holdings in order to put money away for children's college educations; drawing (M)

headline: Fuel Prices Rise and Business Slows in Turkish Crisis
abstract: Drop in value of Turish lira of 25 percent is being felt everywhere in Turkey: shop owners report declining sales; employees complain about not be paid; prices of gasoline and electricity increase 10 percent, first in what economists predict will be wave of increases in coming weeks; Turkish Muslims start nine-day religious holiday this weekend, but economic crisis has soured mood and translated into sharp drop in travel bookings; Turkish officials plan to work through holiday to devise plan to get economy back on track; Prime Min Bulent Ecevit says he is hoping for $25 billion loan from international agencies, but there is no indication that such large sum will be forthcoming; Turkey has received $5 billion of $11 billion aid package approved earlier by International Monetary Fund; lira's rate drops to 915,700 liras to dollar from 685,000 on Feb 21, before crisis; photo (M)

headline: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER SELLING PLANT IN TEXAS
abstract: American Electric Power Co, which owns utilities in 11 states and Europe, agrees to sell 500-megawatt power plant in Texas to Teco Energy Inc for $265 million; Federal Energy Regulatory Commission required American Electric to sell plant as part of its $12.2 billion purchase of Central and South West Corp, Dallas-based utility (S)

headline: Government Files Brief in Response to Microsoft Appeal
abstract: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 — Microsoft's effort to overturn the antitrust ruling against the company rests on a stale recitation of the same arguments that failed the first time they were offered in court, the government argued in a brief filed with the court of appeals today.

headline: NATO Leader Asks for More Kosovo Troops
abstract: NATO Sec Gen Lord Robertson asks NATO members to send about 1,400 more troops to Kosovo to step up border patrols to keep Kosovo Albanians from bolstering Macedonian rebels; stresses NATO does not plan to extend Kosovo peacekeeping operation into Macedonia; Pres Bush says United States will work with NATO to develop strategy to help Macedonia protect itself; US is not expected to send more troops (M)

headline: Construction Spending Is Down
abstract: Commerce Department reports construction spending fell in November, first drop in four months; drop of 0.6 percent in spending, to $815.6 billion at annual rate, comes after 0.8 percent increase in October; spending on residential construction, which accounted for 43 percent of value of all building, fell 1.5 percent during November, to $353.8 billion pace after climbing 2.1 percent a month earlier; spending on single-family home construction rose 0.3 percent after falling 0.1 percent in October (M)

headline: Losses in Online Ventures Cut Pearson's Profit 17%
abstract: Pearson PLC reports earning 333 million pounds ($489.5 million) in pretax profit in 2000, after investing 196 million pounds ($288 million) spent in Internet ventures; this compares with 402 million pounds ($591 million) in pretax profit year earlier; photo (M)

headline: Net Income Doubles At New York Life
abstract: New York Life Insurance Co says net income rose to $1.2 billion in 2000 from $555 million in 1999; results include realized investment gains of $387 million compared with $29 million year earlier; operating revenue rose 13 percent, to $11.7 billion from $10.4 billion (S)

headline: Creating Contracts With Corporate America
abstract: Gingrich Group, corporate strategic consulting firm of New Gingrich, former House speaker, advises eclectic array of companies; photo (S)

headline: As Savings Go Up, Worries Go Down (A Little)
abstract: THE number of Americans saving for retirement has jumped sharply in the last few years, a recent New York Times poll has found. And while a majority of those questioned worry about setting aside enough money, anxiety on the subject appears to have eased, at least a bit.

headline: Haiti's Opposition Proposes 3-Member Presidency
abstract: Haiti's opposition, in move to end nation's political impasse, reportedly proposes to Pres-elect Jean Bertrand Aristide that he be part of three-member presidency that would lead country to new elections in two years (S)

headline: Calvin Klein-Warnaco License Trial Finally Set to Begin
abstract: Trial is set to begin in Calvin Klein lawsuit to terminate Warnaco's contract to manufacture Calvin Klein jeans; central issue is whether Warnaco abused its license by distributing Klein's brand of jeans in unauthorized manner to low-rent retailers; sales of Calvin Klein jeans supplied Warnaco with $628.6 million in revenue for 1999, about one-third of Warnaco's total revenue and one-third of cash flow; photo of Clein with Linda Wachner, Warnaco chief executive (M)

headline: U.S. Rate Cuts Reverberate in Asian Stock Markets
abstract: Several Asian stock markets rise strongly in response to rate cut by Federal Reserve, but other markets move little or fall as investors worry about how weakening US economy could affect region; graph; chart (M)

headline: Rights Groups Fear Implications in Egypt's Trial of a Sociologist
abstract: Trial of prominent sociologist Saad Eddin Ibrahim on charges of defaming Egypt is bing closed watched for its chilling effect on work of human rights groups and other independent research organizations in Egypt; Ibn Kaldun Center for Development Studies founder is accused, along with 27 others linked to center, with spreading false reports about Egypt abroad on issues ranging from electoral fraud to Muslim-Christian tensions; center has used nearly $160,000 from European Commission to increase public awareness of voting rights (M)

headline: How Missteps and Overreaching Dimmed Lucent´s Promise
abstract: This article was reported by Alex Berenson, Simon Romero and Seth Schiesel, and was written by Mr. Schiesel.

headline: TRW TO REDUCE ITS WORK FORCE BY 1%
abstract: TRW To Reduce Its Work

headline: Article 2001031691140823917 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Article 2001022493117724817 -- No Title
abstract: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

headline: Mad Cow Disease Is Claiming Some Political Victims, Too
abstract: PARIS, Jan. 20 — Angry over the handling of the mad cow disease crisis, French farmers threw stones at their prime minister this week. Spanish cattle ranchers blockaded slaughterhouses to cut off the supply of meat. Other farmers refused to let health workers onto their property.

headline: SAP'S PROFIT RISES
abstract: SAP AG says fourth-quarter profit rose 16 percent; net income rose to 366 million euros ($345 million) from 316 million euros in year-earlier period (S)

headline: SingTel and Optus Shares Slump on News of Deal
abstract: News that Singapore Telecommunications has won bidding for Cable and Wireless Optus sends shares of both companies reeling as investors and analysts conclude that price is too high and not high enough; Singapore Telecommunications' offer values Optus at between 14.9 billion and 17.2 billion Australian dollars ($7.4 billion to $8.5 billion); photo (M)

headline: Colonel's Trial Puts Russian Justice to Test
abstract: ROSTOV-ON-DON, Russia — It was late last March 26 that a Russian Army colonel, Yuri D. Budanov, and three soldiers left an encampment outside Chechnya's capital, Grozny, and pointed their armored personnel carrier south into the village of Tangi, then east on to a lane.

headline: QWEST TO SEEK RIGHT TO EXPAND LONG-DISTANCE SERVICE
abstract: Qwest Communications International will ask Federal Communications Commission for permission to sell long-distance service in Colorado or Arizona this summer; after getting permission from FCC to sell in one state, Qwest will seek permission later this year and early 2002 to sell long-distance in other 13 Western states, where it sells local phone services (S)

headline: Japan Says It Will Take Steps to Halt Falling Stock Prices
abstract: Japanese stock market rises after Prime Min Yoshiro Mori says government is considering liberalization of regulations on corporate share buybacks that would allow companies to hold on to shares they purchase in open market; benchmark Nikkei stock index of 225 issues rises 158.49 points, or 1.19 percent, to close at 13,506.23 (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gold falls almost 2 percent after investors show little interest in bullion auction by Bank of England (S)

headline: Article 2001032394114140877 -- No Title
abstract: STATE OF THE ART

headline: LOAN SUBSIDIES FOR JET BUILDER
abstract: Canada, ratcheting up trade dispute with Brazil, offers to guarantee low-interest bank loans to help Bombardier compete against Embraer of Brazil for order from Air Wisconsin that could be worth up to $3 billion (S)

headline: QUALCOMM BUYS EATON TRUCKING UNIT
abstract: Qualcomm, in move to strengthen its fleet management business, acquires Eaton Corp's trucking information services unit, FleetAdvisor, for undisclosed amount of cash and payments based on future sales; Qualcomm plans to use unit to improve services like automated trucker logs and fuel tax calculation (S)

headline: American Cardinals Handle Reporters and Flying Birettas
abstract: Archbishops Edward M Egan and Thomas Edgar McCarrick and Rev Avery Dulles comment on their elevation to cardinal (M)

headline: Rebel Ambush Traps Macedonian Police and 2 Officials
abstract: Dozens of Macedonian police officers and two senior government officials are trapped for hours in Brest, village near Kosovo border, after ethnic Albanian rebels ambush their convoy, and heavy fighting rages throughout night; attack is blow to Macedonian government, which sent convoy to establish police presence to try to prevent Albanian insurgency from taking hold in area; map; photo (M)

headline: Fighting Crime Online: Who Is in Harm's Way?
abstract: Documents obtained by Electronic Privacy Information Center reveal that requests from law enforcement officials for 'data interception operations'--surveillance taps of information communicated over Internet--increased more than 18-fold between 1997 and 1999; Carnivore, new device developed by FBI, raises many questions regarding extent of wiretapping of suspected criminals; photo; drawings (M)

headline: Private Sector: From the Grave Dancer, Rhyme and Contrary Reason
abstract: Friends of the Chicago investor Sam Zell know not to expect the ordinary season's-greetings card at the end of the year. For six years now, a favored few have received an unusual gift from him — an elaborate, sculptured music box meant to illustrate some theme in the markets that reflects the contrarian bent of Mr. Zell, whose taste for troubled or bankrupt companies earned him the nickname "Grave Dancer."

headline: At 40, They're Finished, Television Writers Say
abstract: Age is particularly sensitive in world of television, affecting not only those in front of camera but those behind it, like writers; television writers say that once they hit 40, they are finished; class-action lawsuit has been filed in Los Angeles by 50 over-40 writers, maintaining that over last two decades, television industry has pursued systematic and pervasive pattern of age discrimination against writers who have passed 40th birthday; 51 defendants include 39 studios and networks and 12 talent agencies; photos (M)

headline: ROLLS-ROYCE HAS RECORD ORDERS
abstract: Rolls-Royce reports having orders for aircraft engines totaling record $13.1 billion at end of 2000 (S)

headline: El Salvador Says Earthquake Aid From Foreign Nations Is Lagging
abstract: Salvadoran officials struggling to cope with major earthquakes of Jan 13 and Feb 13 complain of lagging assistance from abroad, especially United States, which lavished money on country during 12-year civil war; note that 1.2 million people, a sixth of all Salvadorans, are homeless; fear mudslides, floods and disease once rainy season begins in May; US has so far provided $10 million in aid, less than half of what Spain has provided; Pres Francisco Fores will go to Washington to seek more direct aid and grant of temporary protected immigration status to Salvadorans who are working in US and sending home more than $1.5 billion each year; photo; map (M)

headline: A Revival for Brazilian Shipyards
abstract: Fels Setal, joint venture between Keppel Fels Ltd and Pem Setal Group, is gradually reviving Brazil's once-dominant shipbuilding industry; has won $75 million pact to convert aging tanker into offshore production center; government, which finances most shipbuilding, has won promises from state-owned oil company Petrobras and its transportation unit, Transpetro, to use local industry for some contracts; photo (M)

headline: Bozell Closes Offices in Texas
abstract: Bozell Group unit of True North Communications will close Irving, Tex, offices of two agencies, Bozell Kamstra and SixtyFootSpider (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Michael A. Prober; CRM Mid Cap Value Fund
abstract: Carole Gould column profiles Michael A Prober, who runs $40 million CRM Mid Cap Value fund and is co-manager of roughly $2.5 billion in institutional money at Cramer Rosenthal McGlynn, New york money manager that is fund's sponsor; photo; graph (M)

headline: SHARES OF WILLIAMS-SONOMA CLIMB ON PROFIT FORECAST
abstract: Shares of Williams-Sonoma Inc rise after company says that it will report quarterly profits that exceed forecasts and and that annual profit may beat estimates (S)

headline: Zapatista Rebels Rally in Mexico City
abstract: Mexico's Zapatista rebels and leader Subcommander Marcos end two-week trek from jungle hideout in Chiapas with massive demonstration in capital of Mexico City; Marcos addresses throng, estimated at 100,000; demands democracy, liberty and justice for nation's minority Indian population of about 10 million; disproportionately poor, illiterate, malnourished and disenfranchised, they have been traditionally treated as second-class citizens; photos (M)

headline: People
abstract: Steven Thibodeau is named to new post of president of ad agency Dotglu (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: AMERICAN TELLS OF CAPTIVITY  An American relief worker freed from captivity in Chechnya on Saturday said his captors treated him well, even giving him a freshly ironed shirt on his release. But Kenneth Gluck of Doctors Without Borders said he still had no idea who had taken him or why. The Kremlin has said Mr. Gluck was seized by guerrillas. But some say he was abducted by pro-Moscow forces seeking to turn opinion further against the rebels.    Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: JERSEY'S LARGEST UTILITY AGREES TO CHILE DEAL
abstract: Public Service Enterprise Group agrees to pay $460 million for stakes in two Chilean power distributors, Sociedad Austral de Electricidad SA and Empresa Electrica de la Frontera; these two companies serve 3.6 million customers (S)

headline: REALNETWORKS PLANS TO LET WORKERS SWAP OPTIONS
abstract: Software maker RealNetworks, whose shares have fallen 89 percent in last year, will allow employees to exchange existing stock options for new ones with realistic strike price (S)

headline: LUCENT TO SEEK BUYERS FOR TWO FACTORIES
abstract: Lucent Technologies will seek buyers for two of its four remaining US manufacturing facilities, which make telephone switches and wireless equipment (S)

headline: As Japan's Premier Falters, No Successor Is in Sight
abstract: Japan finds itself without obvious successor to Prime Min Yoshiro Mori, whose approval rating is at 6.5 percent; calls for Mori's resignation grow, and representatives of Japan's leading opposition parties are meeting to discuss no-confidence motion; Mori has shown startling talent for verbal and political faux pas throughout his brief tenure (M)

headline: California Couple Sentenced for Helping Clients Evade Taxes
abstract: Judge Garland E Burrell Jr sentences Dorothy and George Henderson of Roseville, Calif, to long prison terms for helping their clients evade at least $13.8 million in federal income taxes; couple sold trusts through which, customers were told, they could put their money beyond reach of Internal Revenue Service; couple kept 5 percent of deposits (M)

headline: GALLAHER'S PROFIT IS FLAT
abstract: Gallaher Group says overseas earnings rose by quarter while cigarette sales in Britain remained flat as British smokers turn to bootleg cigarettes to avoid ever higher government taxes; Gallaher says it is expanding in Russia and Austria to offset shrinking British market; pretax profit in year 2000 remained virtually unchanged at $491 million, in line with expectations (S)

headline: XFL's Audience Tumbles 25% From Earlier Ratings on NBC
abstract: Preliminary ratings for most recent NBC broadcast of XFL fall 25 percent from previous week (M)

headline: Article 2001032893036842145 -- No Title
abstract: March 28, 2001

headline: ONLINE SALES FALL SHORT OF HOPES
abstract: Jupiter Research says online sales last holiday season fell 7 percent short of expectations; pegs sales in November and December at $10.8 billion, up 54 percent from $7 billion year earlier, but short of its forecast of $12.1 billion (S)

headline: Liberia´s Foreign Minister Defends His Country to Security Council
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 25 — A skeptical Security Council today heard Liberia's foreign minister defend his country against charges that its president, Charles Taylor, was trafficking in diamonds and arms with rebels in Sierra Leone.

headline: CONSTELLATION ACQUIRING WINE BRANDS FROM CORUS
abstract: Constellation Brands Inc says its Canandaigua Wine unit purchased some brands from Corus Brands for about $52 million (S)

headline: Article 2001022090666005935 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Food Worker Is Accused Of Corporate Espionage
abstract: FBI arrests Fausto Estrada, catering company employee working in MasterCard International's headquarters, on charge of stealing confidential document in which MasterCard outlined previously undisclosed plan for $1 billion alliance with Disney Corp; he allegedly tried to sell to Visa International, which reported overture to FBI (M)

headline: Serbs Offer Peace Plan in Attempt to End Albanian Rebellion
abstract: Serbia's new government, seeking to end ethnic Albanian insurgency gaining momentum along border with Kosovo, puts together peace plan that rules out annexation or autonomy but would demilitarize area and grant Albanians civil rights stripped away under Slobodan Milosevic; plan is supported by Western diplomats; maps; photo (M)

headline: Dow Gains 260, Bolstered by Consumer Confidence Data
abstract: Stock prices climbed again today after investors were heartened by an unexpectedly strong report on consumer confidence, raising some hopes that personal spending would revive the weakened economy.

headline: On the Internet, Love Really Is Blind
abstract: Few people find true love over the Internet, and psychologists believe that chat rooms, message boards and especially online dating services may have built-in mechanisms that make any offscreen romance very likely to fail; they say that online correspondence makes people feel they have a strong connection, but that nonverbal communication, with its motion and activity, is essential to discovering a real bond with another person; photo; drawing (M)

headline: A Nokia Report Rattles Telecommunications Shares
abstract: Shares of telecommunication equipment makers plummet after Nokia releases figures that point to slowdown in global demand for mobile handsets, raising possibility that ultimate size of market could be smaller than analysts had originally predicted; Nokia estimates that 405 million handsets were sold worldwide last year, 45 percent increase from previous year but short of analysts' expectations for sales of 420 million; Nokia, in unusual move, reports figures weeks before its earnings announcements, scheduled for Jan 30; graph (M)

headline: How the General Put a Pedal to the Metal
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell drives King Abdullah's Mercedes S 500 from king's palace in Amman, Jordan, to airport (S)

headline: DEL MONTE FOODS IS LOOKING FOR A BUYER OR A MERGER
abstract: Del Monte Foods Co says it is seeking buyer or merger partner (S)

headline: A Message in Eroding Glacial Ice: Humans Are Turning Up the Heat
abstract: New studies show ancient Mount Kilimanjaro, Tanzania, icecap, is retreating rapidly and will disappear in under 15 years; scientists say glacial retreat and thinning and similar changes on ice-capped peaks around world signal global warming trend in last 50 years may have exceeded typical climate shifts and is at least partly caused by gases released by human activity; Dr Lonnie G Thompson presents findings at American Association for Advancement of Science meeting, San Francisco; photos (M)

headline: Visit by High Indian Minister Warms Ties With Burmese Junta
abstract: Myanmar, ruled by one of world's most repressive military governments, welcomes high-level Indian cabinet minister, first to visit since Burmese generals set aside 1990 elections and crushed democracy movement; Jaswant Singh, India's minister of external affairs, or foreign minister, speaks during his visit of growing partnership between two nations; Singh tells Indian reporters traveling with him that he hopes India could encourage return to democracy through its engagement with Myanmar (M)

headline: MICROSOFT, COMPAQ AND OTHERS TO WORK ON TABLET PC
abstract: Microsoft Corp will collaborate with Compaq Computer Corp, Intel Corp and Transmeta Corp to create tablet-sized, wireless personal computer; computers will employ next version of Microsoft's Windows operating system (S)

headline: Shell Makes $2.2 Billion Offer for Natural Gas Producer
abstract: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that it had made an unsolicited $1.8 billion takeover bid for the Barrett Resources Corporation, a natural gas producer based in Denver.

headline: INTERNET MERGER TALKS CONFIRMED
abstract: LibertySurf SA, French Internet service provider, is in talks with telecommunications companies, including Belgacom SA of Belgium, that might lead to merger; 70 percent of company's stock is controlled by Europatweb, investment run by Bernard Arnault, and by Kingfisher PLC of Britain; graph (S)

headline: Prague Trying To Sort Out TV Politics
abstract: Lower chamber of Czech Parliament dismisses council that oversees Czech Television and provoked crisis in December by appointing Jiri Hodac as its director; moves are not sufficient to please journalists occupying the station (M)

headline: English Craze, a Dilemma for Japan
abstract: TOKYO—  Yuko Matsubara has what many mothers in Japan these days wish for — a child who is fluent in both English and Japanese, although the family has never lived outside Japan.

headline: As Sharon Moves Ahead, Peace Effort Retreats
abstract: JERUSALEM, Jan. 10 — As Ariel Sharon, the Likud Party leader and clear frontrunner for the premiership, formally kicked off his campaign tonight, an American envoy indefinitely postponed a trip to the region for last-minute peacemaking efforts.

headline: McCann-Erickson's consumer poll points out some image problems for the Olympics.
abstract: Global consumer poll by McCann-Erickson World Group shows that Olympic Games remain strong international brand for potential advertisers, but that recent developments ranging from over-commercialization to publicized use of performance-enhancing drugs by athletes have tarnished Games' once-gold image (M)

headline: YAHOO EXPANDING WIRELESS SERVICE
abstract: Yahoo starts to let users of Internet-enabled wireless telecommunications devices search for localized information (S)

headline: Assets of Pseudo.com Are Sold to New York Internet Company
abstract: The remnants of Pseudo.com, the online television network that filed for bankruptcy protection after investors refused to give it more cash, were acquired today by INTV, a New York Internet company, for $2 million.

abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Ford 4th-Quarter Earnings Fell 40% as Sales Slowed
abstract: Ford Motor Co says earnings dropped 40.4 percent in fourth quarter; net income dropped to $1.98 billion compared with $1.81 billion in year-earlier quarter; sales fell to $42.6 billion from $43.9 billion (M)

headline: MORE NTT SHARES TO BE SOLD
abstract: World B

headline: Crossing Bridges In Workplace Ethics
abstract: George J Zahka letter responds to Feb 18 article concerning ethics in workplaces

headline: Benefits of Deregulated Energy Elude Business
abstract: Booz-Allen & Hamilton study finds that many American businesses are wholly unprepared to deal with electricity deregulation and that few have switched electricity providers to take advantage of deregulation; shows that only 20 percent of those surveyed turned to provider of electricity other than their local utility and that most of those saved 10 percent to 20 percent on their electricity bills (M)

headline: Albanian Rebels Declare a Cease-Fire in Macedonia and Ask for Talks
abstract: SKOPJE, Macedonia, March 21 — Faced with a midnight deadline for an offensive by Macedonian troops and special police, armed Albanian rebels declared a unilateral cease- fire tonight and reportedly began drawing back from villages they are holding northwest of Tetovo.

headline: Korn/Ferry Chief to Retire
abstract: Korn/Ferry International forms committee to find replacement for chief executive Windle B Priem; once successor is found, Priem will serve as chairman before retiring (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: Multiplying Albanian Insurgents in Yugoslavia Threaten Belgrade's New Democracy
abstract: Growing strength of ethnic Albanian insurgents in Serbia, who want to annex parts of Serbia they would like to attach to an independent Kosovo, is becoming serious embarrassment to NATO-led peacekeeping force in Kosovo, and source of political instability to new democratic government in Belgrade; photo; map (M)

headline: Computing Pioneer Challenges the Clock
abstract: Ivan Sutherland and colleages at Sun Microsystems pursue new computer chip design in which the switching on and off of digital circuits is controlled by specific pieces of data rather than by microelectronic crystal, or clock, as in today's microprocessors; he and other advocates of so-called asynchronous logic say it would offer greater computational speed and lower power consumption and make it possible to design new chips more quickly; most of mainstream computer world is not convinced that a wholesale change of the way industry designs and manufactuers chips is practical; photo (M)

headline: Ego Bashing And Scandals As Paris Picks A New Mayor
abstract: Battle over Paris mayoralty continues to provide twists, turns, name-calling, bruised egos and distinct possibility that conservatives will lose control of capital for first time in more than century; Parisians are disgusted with corruption charges that plague right, and bewildered by spectacle of conservative candidates insulting each other; many pollsters believe voters may give Socialists' candidate, Bertrand Delanoe, a narrow victory; current mayor, Jean Tiberi, who had been handpicked for job by Pres Jacques Chirac, has become subject of growing number of investigations; Tiberi has refused to step aside for Philippe Seguin, chosen by his party to run for mayor; photo (M)

headline: AOL to Name Executive of Cinema Division to Run Its TV Unit
abstract: AOL Time Warner is expected to announce appointment of Robert Friedman, top executive at company's New Line Cinema division, to newly created position of president of AOL TV; AOL TV had been overseen by Barry Schuler, as president of AOL Interactive; Friedman will responsible for service's daily operations and strategic direction, and will report directly to Schuler (M)

headline: Robin Hoods of Cyberspace: A Philosopher Examines the Difference Between Good and Bad Hackers
abstract: It can sometimes seem as if the number of people who have speculated on the social implications of Linux, the free computer operating system collectively engineered by thousands of programmers worldwide, exceeds the number of people who have actually used Linux itself. Ever since the open-source software movement entered into the public consciousness in the late 90's, we've been awash in prophesies about the end of the Windows era and the birth of a less proprietary digital age. Together, the emergence of open-source software and the related Napster music file sharing system constitute the most significant technological development since the arrival of the World Wide Web.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: MEETING WITH POWELL -- Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov and Secretary of State Colin M. Powell plan to hold their first face-to-face meeting during Mr. Powell's visit to the Mideast and Belgium late this month, the Kremlin confirmed. No agenda has been released, but the talks may center on the Bush administration's planned national missile defense system, which Russia opposes. General Powell's Feb. 23-27 trip includes stops in Kuwait, to mark the 10th anniversary of the end of the Persian Gulf war, and in Brussels for meetings with European Union officials.   Michael Wines (NYT)

headline: Colombia Massacre's Strange Fallout
abstract: Lt Col Henan Orozco protests three-year sentence he received for not having done enough to prevent Colombian paramilitary gunmen from killing at least 30 people in village of Mapiripan in July 1997; says he spoke about abuses as few other Colombian military officers have, providing hard evidence and risking his life and his family's welfare to tell the truth; human rights groups agree, saying Orozco's conviction will only discourage other officers from coming forward; Orozco informed Gen Jaime Humberto Uscategui that gunmen had entered village, but warning was ignored; Uscategui was sentenced to 40 months; photo (M)

headline: Big Board Will Study Effects of Decimal Trading
abstract: New York Stock Exchange will set up group to study institutional investors' complaints about new decimal stock trading system; quotes now change more frequently, and market offers less liquidity at any given price; it can be easier for individual investor, who may want to buy only 100 or 200 shares, to get good price for trade, but institutional trader who wants to buy 10,000 shares ends up paying higher price (M)

headline: A New Trick Gives Snoops Easy Access To E-Mail
abstract: Watchdog group uncovers new trick that enables person to essentially bug e-mail message so that spy would be privy to any comments that recipient might add as message is forwarded to others or sent back and forth; maneuver is feature of fancier and increasingly common form of e-mail known as HTML mail, which enables users to send and receive e-mail messages that look and act like Web page using programming language called JavaScript; Privacy Foundation plans to provide public demonstrations of process; group is calling for major vendors of e-mail programs to provide their software with JavaScript automatically turned off (M)

headline: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Dodge Stratus and Chrysler Sebring; When Lightning Doesn't Strike Twice
abstract: Behind the Wheel report on Dodge Stratus and Chrysler Sebring; photos; table (M)

headline: Banks Get Plea for Loans From Lucent
abstract: Henry B Schacht, Lucent Technologies president, reportedly made personal pleas to bankers during negotiations to secure $6.5 billion in financing, threatening to seek money elsewhere if bankers did not agree to participate in financing Lucent; company's debt is currently rated just above 'junk' status; Lucent will reportedly pay twice the interest that companies with similar credit ratings normally pay (M)

headline: Shifts in Europe Pose Prickly Challenge to U.S.
abstract: 15-member European Union, long a mere trade bloc ultimately protected by American power, begins to develop into a group with its own serious military and strategic ambitions; specter of Europe--and particularly its central power, Germany--adopting a more independent stance from NATO and paying close heed to Russia is chilling for United States, and hard to reconcile with Atlantic alliance that has preserved Europe's stability and advanced American interests for more than half-century; photo (L)

headline: CORN DOGS SAID TO CONTAIN BANNED CORN
abstract: Greenpeace says vegetarian corn dogs made by Kellogg Co contain StarLink corn, bio-engineered corn that is banned for human consumption; group asks Food and Drug Administration to recall product; Kellogg has notified FDA and sent samples of corn dogs to independent laboratory (S)

headline: LOSS AT INTERNET AUCTIONEER
abstract: QXL Ricardo, British Internet auctioneer, reports wider third-quarter loss related to acquisition costs; for three months ended Dec 31, QXL Ricardo lost 41.3 million pounds ($60 million) compared with 38 million pounds ($55.2 million at current exchange rates) year ago (S)

headline: ADVANCED MICRO OUTLINES SUCCESSION
abstract: W J Sanders 3d, who founded Advanced Micro Devices, will relinquish control of daily operations next year (S)

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: DEALS ARIBA TO BUY AGILE SOFTWARE Ariba Inc., a busi- ness-to-business network service provider, is acquiring Agile Software , a leading provider of Internet-based business-to- business communication technology. Ariba, of Mountain View, Calif., was one of the first network service providers to help companies move their business service relationships to the Internet. The acquisition will allow the company to add collaboration capability to its services, allowing its customers to communicate and coordinate product supply, design and other electronic-commerce functions. Each share of Agile common stock will be converted into 1.35 shares of Ariba common stock, resulting in an aggregate purchase price of roughly $2.55 billion, the companies said.

headline: Cisco Plans Steep Job Cuts And a Charge
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc intends to eliminate as many as 5,000 jobs, 11 percent of its workforce; slowdown in information technology spending impacts sturdiest of computer-networking companies; will take one-time charge of $300 million to $400 million and make cost-cutting changes in its business practices; company's shares tumble nearly ten percent following its midday announcement (M)

headline: BUSH GIVES MEXICO BACKING  ON  DRIVE AGAINST NARCOTICS
abstract: Pres Bush, in visit to Mexico in first trip outside US as president, signals he will support Mexico in its efforts to end annual ritual in which Congress requires government to prove its commitment to war against narcotics or face economic sanctions; bluntly acknowledges that demand by Americans feeds drug traffic; meets with Pres Vicente Fox Quesada in San Cristobal de los Ranchos; uses occasion to open formal talks on range of other issues; visit described; photos (M)

headline: S.E.C. Staff Suggests More Fee Disclosure
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission staff recommends that commission consider requiring mutual fund managers to tell shareholders more precisely and more often how much they pay in fees (S)

headline: American Studying in Russia May Be Swept Up in Spy Case
abstract: 24-year-old John Edward Toobin, American student investigated on suspicion of espionage and charged with possession of marijuana in southwestern Russia, may face more serious drug charges; case may have taken more serious turn because of decision by Bush administration to expel 50 Russian diplomats as spies (M)

headline: Unhappy E-Shoppers May Punish a Store
abstract: Jupiter Media Metrix poll finds that 70 percent of American shoppers who have bad experience at retailer's online site are inclined to take it out on its brick-and-mortar stores (M)

headline: U.S. and Japan Make Pledge to Collaborate on Economy
abstract: WASHINGTON, March 19 — President Bush and Japan's weakened prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, met today to discuss joint strategies for restoring growth to the world's largest and second-largest economies, but ended the session with a vague commitment by Japan to confront its huge banking problem and not to seek a short-term solution by boosting exports to the United States.

headline: U.P.S. Posts 9.5% Increase In Fourth-Quarter Earnings
abstract: United Parcel Service says net income climbed to $724 million in fourth quarter compared with $661 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 6.1 percent, to $7.9 billion from $7.45 billion (S)

headline: The Deeper Dangers of Corporate Bankruptcy
abstract: Ominous increases in corporate debts, defaults and delinquencies signal new wave of bankruptcies, and many vulnerable companies may be less prepared to withstand the pain than those at risk during last wave, a decade ago, because they have weak, often unprofitable businesses; among companies in this bind are Iridium Communications, Loews Cineplex, Carmike and United Artists; photos; graph (M)

headline: CELESTICA BUYING AVAYA PLANTS
abstract: Canadian electronics subcontractor Celestica agrees to buy two manufacturing plants from Avaya and to supply $4 billion of components over five years to company (S)

abstract: NetZero, one of last remaining providers of free Internet service, is granted temporary restraining order against Juno Online Services, its chief competitor; order temporarily prevents Juno from displaying third-party ads on floating advertising window called Juno Guide because NetZero contends Guide infringes on NetZero patent (S)

abstract: Listing of Web sites that examine economic, legal and social dimensions of gambling (M)

headline: Guidelines Set For Media Buying
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies and Internet Advertising Bureau agree on first guidelines to help standardize Internet media buying (S)

headline: Russian TV Network Is Said to Be Talking to Turner
abstract: The American media entrepreneur Ted Turner is in talks to buy part of Russia's biggest independent television network, according to people close to the negotiations. Russia, however, sent signals today that it was not so eager for a deal to take place.    Maura Donlan, a spokeswoman for Turner Enterprises, Mr. Turner's private company, declined to confirm the talks, but said any such discussions were ''a personal initiative and not connected to Time Warner or AOL.'' Mr. Turner is a vice chairman of Time Warner.

headline: Barak Goes for Broke in Israeli Election
abstract: TEL AVIV, Friday, Feb. 2 — The deadline for political parties to change candidates expired quietly at midnight on Thursday, and Prime Minister Ehud Barak finally put to rest the speculation that he would step aside and let former Prime Minister Shimon Peres run in his place in Tuesday's election.

headline: PITNEY BOWES ISSUES EARNINGS WARNING AND WILL CUT JOBS
abstract: Pitney Bowes, which makes postage meters, will eliminate 700 to 800 jobs and reduce its first-quarter and 2001 profit projections because country's economic expansion is slowing and company's technology is changing; company reports earnings of $148 million in fourth quarter, down from $178 million year earlier (S)

headline: FASHIONMALL QUITS MERGER TALKS
abstract: Fashionmall.com and GenesisIntermedia break off merger talks after Fashionmall's board rejects $7-a-share acquisition offer of Genesis (S)

headline: NBC, Facing a Drop in Ads, Will Cut Up to 600 Positions
abstract: NBC, accelerating continuing cost-cutting program in face of advertising drop, to cut 5 to 10 percent of its work force, or 300 to 600 jobs, by end of Mar (M)

headline: A Quest for Irish Business Glory
abstract: Sir Anthony O'Reilly, who retireed last autumn from H J Heinz after 20 years as chief executive and later chairman and who was recently knighted for promoting peace in Northern Ireland, now pours his intellectual and capital resources into effort to push his native Ireland to front of world business stage; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAYNone

headline: I Live Out My Life in Modest Steps
abstract: My job is sitting at home, doing nothing much and pretending I'm busy. It has been four years since I was gainfully employed. But I do work at a variety of pleasurably mundane activities that gain momentum as I roll out of bed -- very gingerly, for ''dem bones'' are aching and aging at 84. I perform the usual ablutions and when tidied up, I get on the pulleys. The physical therapist suggested them for my rotator cuff problem, and mirable dictu, they work.    Then to breakfast. My favorite cereal is Honey Bunches of Oats (honest) with Raspberry Ice Kool Aid (I'm allergic to milk), which I have been dining on for the last several months. Previously, I was on a Grape Nuts kick. Sated, I check my plants, which line the window sills and have eastern and southern exposures, giving them the light they need. The cacti are fabulous.

headline: Congo Buries Elder Kabila
abstract: KINSHASA, Congo, Jan. 23 — President Laurent Kabila, who was gunned down in his office here a week ago, was buried here in the capital today in a state funeral rich with symbolism evoking the country's troubled past and present.

headline: Haitian Opposition Says It Will Form Alternative Government
abstract: Coalition of political opponents of Pres-elect Jean-Bertand Aristide announces formation of alternative government in Haiti, following collapse of talks; group names Gerard Gourgue president (S)

headline: Greenspan Hints Tax Cuts Might Help Weak Economy
abstract: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 — Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave his blessing today to a substantial tax cut, but warned that it should not be so big that it would plunge the government back into deficit if the federal budget surplus does not materialize as projected.

headline: Weak Reception; U.S. Lagging Behind in Wireless, And That May Be Just as Well
abstract: United States has fallen behind Europe and parts of Asia in wireless technology amid questions about whether companies offering wide range of Internet services via cellular telephone can actually make money; American companies have avoided costly investments in network capabilities that customers do not want and American consumers have sidestepped buying unneeded devices or signing contracts for possibly short-lived services, while European companies in particular face likely industry shakeout; photos (M)

headline: Turning the Super Bowl Into a Game of Pixels
abstract: Instant-replay technology being introduced by CBS for Super Bowl uses more than 30 pivoting robotic cameras, spaced apart at 80 feet above the field, to capture what amounts to a 270-degree view of the action; drawing (S)

abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WHIRLPOOL, Benton Harbor, Mich., the appliance maker, said it had acquired a stake in the closely held ZBox Co., San Francisco, a maker of secure home-delivery boxes. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Britain Stops Animal Exports Because of Foot-and-Mouth Disease
abstract: LONDON, Feb. 21 — Faced with its first outbreak in 20 years of foot-and-mouth disease, a virulent illness that spreads with relentless speed, Britain said today that it was suspending all exports of live animals, milk, meat and other animal products.

headline: On Campus, Free Fast Internet Access Is No Longer a Given
abstract: When today's high-school graduates arrive on college campuses, they expect that their new dorm rooms will come with ultra-fast Internet connections. And they expect to be able to use that access as they please, even if that means clogging the campus network with pirated music files.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of natural gas falls as forecasts call for milder weather in northern and central US; in New York, natural gas for March delivery falls $1.037, or 15.4 percent, to $5.706 per million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills Himself and Three Israelis
abstract: NETANYA, Israel, March 4 - In an attack that heightened anxieties that conflict with the Palestinians is moving inside Israel and out of control, a suicide bomber killed himself and three Israelis today, scattering bodies over a pedestrian crosswalk in this incongruously sunny town north of Tel Aviv.

headline: SWISSCOM SELLS PROPERTY
abstract: Swisscom, witzerland's largest telecommunications operator, sells another big property package (S)

headline: Australia Balks at New Online Casinos
abstract: Australia temporarily bans new Internet gambling; Australia's Senate, alarmed by country's pervasive interest in games of chance, passed yearlong ban in December on new online casinos retroactive to May 2000; violation of ban is criminal offense carrying fine as much as $600,000 as day; restrictions threaten operations of some companies that had received Internet gambling licenses from states and territories; graph (M)

headline: That's Bowdoin, Not Bowlin'
abstract: Barry Mills announces that he will abandon law to become 14th president of Bowdoin College (M)

headline: European Markets Post Losses in Tumultuous Trading
abstract: European stock markets fall sharply but then recover slightly after American markets do not perform as poorly as expected; graphs of broad market indexes for British, German, French and Scandinavian exchanges (M)

headline: U.N. Report Proposes Steps to Fight Global Poverty
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 30 — Declaring that no task was more urgent than rescuing 1 billion people in the world from "abject and dehumanizing poverty," the United Nations today proposed dozens of ways to finance the economic development of poorer countries.

headline: Online Music Surveys Look for Future Hits
abstract: Record companies use online surveys to gauge how well new CD's will sell; online surveys lack statistical rigor of traditional testing methods, which they are not expected to supplant, but they may be more accurate in forecasting tastes of the most devoted and adventurous listeners (M)

headline: Taking the Offensive Against Cell Phones
abstract: Technological fixes are being developed to deal with intrusiveness of cellular telphones, whose use is being banned or discouraged in more and more places; among them are a cell phone jammer from NetLine, which faces legal obstacles, a cell phone detector from Zetron and Q-Zone from BlueLinx, which can, with the cell phone user's permission, automatically shift a cell phone ringer to 'vibrate' or turn it down a few notches whenever the phone enters a quiet zone; architectural solutions are also being explored; photos (L)

headline: Amid Pockets of Growth, December Retail Sales Rose a Sliver
abstract: Commerce Depart reports retail sales rose 0.1 percent in Dec from Nov; revises downward its retail numbers for Oct and Nov, making fourth quarter weakest since 1990; Bureau of Labor Statistics reports Producer Price Index was flat in Dec and finished year up 3.5 percent; reports core index rose 0.3 percent in Dec and only 1.2 percent for all of 2000; graph of retail sales (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNET NAPSTER COURT DATE The date has been set for the next legal proceeding in the matter of the record companies versus Napster . On March 2, at 10 a.m., all sides are scheduled to appear at a hearing that may determine when Napster, which permits users to exchange music free over the Internet, will cease to exist in its current incarnation. The hearing is before Chief Judge Marilyn Patel of the United States District Court in San Francisco. Judge Patel issued a preliminary injunction in July ordering Napster to stop permitting the exchange of works whose copyrights are held by the major record labels. Last week, a federal appeals court affirmed much of Judge Patel's ruling but ordered her to narrow its scope. Napster has said that depending on the scope of the injunction it may be forced to close. Matt Richtel (NYT)

headline: Business Travel; Passengers Face Delays, As Well As Labor Woes
abstract: Serious labor disputes involving pilots, mechanics, and flight attendants are threatening to hamper flight schedules, and perhaps raise costs and fares at American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and United Airlines; several smaller carriers are also involved in tense talks with their unions (Business Travel column)

headline: MediaTalk; Report From a New York Most Never See
abstract: Darryl Pinckney, novelist, librettist and occasional writer for The New Yorker, writes in great personal detail about his recent squalid excursion into New York City prison system after arrest on street for smoking marijuana; Pinckney, who is black, says he was surprised by how much racism still exists in prison system; his article appears in The New Yorker; photo (S)

headline: CREDIT SUISSE SELLS UNIT
abstract: Credit Suisse Group will sell property and casualty insurance unit to XL Capital Ltd (S)

headline: Another Use for a VCR
abstract: Larry Hirsch letter, replying to a Jan 4 letter, says a VCR can be used to program the recording of radio programs

headline: When Good Ethics Aren't Good Business
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin The Right Thing column says the beating Smith & Wesson took after its former chief executive, Ed Shultz, entered into agreement with government making gun safety paramount shows that good ethics do not necessarily mean good business; says that in deciding between doing right thing and doing what is best for business, management must do right thing regardless of the consequences; cartoon (M)

headline: Speedy Start On Emergency Economic Plan In Argentina
abstract: Argentine Congress moves quickly to enact emergency economic measures proposed by new economy minister, Domingo Cavallo; refuses to grant him immediate unilateral power he requests; rival political parties begin to cooperate to try to revive country's economy, embattled for two years; photo (M)

headline: MATSUSHITA TO REDUCE ASSETS
abstract: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co will cut group assets by $8.2 billion within three years in order to make its shares more attractive to investors (S)

abstract: Taking the Offensive Against Cell Phones

headline: Bush Tells Blair He Doesn't Oppose New Europe Force
abstract: THURMONT, Md., Feb. 23 — President Bush today endorsed a European rapid-reaction force for the first time, telling Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain that the United States had no objections to a separate military arm to help keep peace in Europe as long as that force was clearly secondary to NATO.

headline: Indian Rights Bill Falters in Mexico; Rebel Going Home
abstract: Subcommander Marcos, leader of Mexico's Zapatista rebels who traveled to capital in hopes of achieving political settlement with government, says he will return to jungle in Chiapas; decision follows failure of efforts to pass measure that would give some autonomy to indigenous Indian communities (S)

headline: Aetna Fourth-Quarter Earnings Fell 65%
abstract: Aetna Inc, nation's largest health insurer, posts 65 decline in fourth-quarter earnings and says it will shed 1.9 million more customers this year as it struggles to catch up with more profitable competitors; earnings plunged to $28.7 million compared with $81 million year ago; revenue for quarter declined $100 million (M)

headline: Waiting at the Gate For Trade With Cuba
abstract: Diplomatic and commercial tug of war between US and Cuba will determine how deeply American comnpanies can penetrate Cuban economy after new law takes effect easing US embargo against Cuba; Bush administration, which wil draft final regulations to carry out law has much tougher view of Cuba than Clinton administration did; in addition, Cuba officially views American products as symbols of oppression; photo; graph (M)

headline: THE BOSS; Fears of Getting Mushy at 50
abstract: Dean Becker The Boss column on being founder and chief executive of ewireless, which links wireless telephone customers with advertisers; photo (M)

headline: Better From Blue

headline: China's Latest Opening Of Market Hits a Snag
abstract: Thousands of Chinese investors jam brokerage houses in hopes of buying shares on newly liberalized hard currency stock market; but most people come away disappointed because there are not enough shares to go around; after government announced last week that citizens would be allowed to buy Class B shares--stocks denominated in Hong Kong and US dollars and previously reserved for foreign investors--money poured into country through wire transfers to residents from friends and relatives abroad; photo (M)

headline: FLETCHER SHAREHOLDERS ACCEPT SHELL'S BID
abstract: Shareholders of Fletcher Challenge Ltd agree to $1.67 billion takeover of its energy unit by Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Apache Corp, spurning rival offer for unit, New Zealand's largest oil and gas company (S)

headline: SUEZ POSTS STRONG RESULTS
abstract: Shares of Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux SA soar after company reports stronger-than-expected growth of revenue and earnings last year (S)

headline: Legal Sparring Turns Testy In a Baby Formula Dispute
abstract: PBM Products, distributor of generic infant formula, asks federal court to force Mead Johnson & Co, maker of Enfamil, to stop distributing what it calls misleading marketing materials claiming Enfamil's superiority (M)

abstract: E-Commerce Report: Comparison Sites Struggling as Well

headline: GAME THEORY; Trinkets and Surprises in a Fighting Game

headline: Business Travel; Foreign currency, and the best way to get it, is a vital issue for those on the road abroad.
abstract: Some readers are puzzled by recent Business Travel column on companies that deliver foreign currency to home or office before trip; they suggest that travelers use automated teller machines that accept American bank debit cards and issue local currency at airports all over world (M)

headline: When It Came to Privacy On EBay, No Became Yes
abstract: EBay outrages many of its members by resetting their e-mail and telemarketing preferences, automatically flipping them from No to Yes, in an attempt to cope with a glitch in its registration system that was making No the default option on members' preferences pages (S)

headline: INTEL UNVEILS LOW-POWER CHIPS
abstract: Intel Corp demonstrates low-power processor for server computers that power Web sites, as it seeks to tap growing market for energy-saving products; showcases low-power, 500-megahertz Pentium III devices (S)

headline: Nike's Role in the Third World
abstract: Press for Change founder and director Jeff Ballinger comments on March 4 On the Contrary article concerning Nike shoe manufacturing in Third World nations

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Murdoch's satellite TV goals raise doubts about the timing.
abstract: Market Place column on impending satellite television deal between Rupert Murdoch's News Corp and Hughes Electronics, part of General Motors Corp; stock analysts are questioning timing of deal because satellite TV business appears to be slowing and economic slowdown could compound problem (M)

headline: After a Difficult 2000, Investment Abroad Gains in Favor
abstract: Stock markets outside US in 2000 posted their worst performance as group in decade, led by sharpest drop in Japan since 1990; many fund managers and analysts have positive outlook on these markets for 2001; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Cisco's Weak Earnings Report Nudges Equities Lower
abstract: Nasdaq composite index finishes at 2,607.82, down 56.67 points, or 2.1 percent; Dow Jones industrial average falls 10.70 points, or 0.1 percent, to 10,946.72, and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slips 11.37 points, or 0.8 percent, to 1,340.89; graph; chart (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: A Day of Record-Breaking Gains and Trading Volume
abstract: Nasdaq composite index scores its biggest one-day percentage gain in its history and New York Stock Exchange produces record trading volume on news that Federal Reserve has cut interest rates; Nasdaq composite index gains 324.83 points, or 14.2 percent, to 2,616.69; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 5 percent, to close up 64.29 points, to 1,347.56; Dow Jones industrial average gains 2.8 percent, or 299.6 points, to 10,945.75; graphs; charts (M)

headline: Murmurs in Baghdad Of a Weakened Boss
abstract: Even if little has changed in the way Saddam Hussein maintains control, growing numbers of Iraqis now risk whispering their hatred of him. And in two interviews in the past 15 days, senior officials have even spoken of his eventual death.

headline: Barak Speaks Stoically Of Tomorrow's Showdown
abstract: Prime Min Ehud Barak of Israel gives last interview in which he presents himself as brave leader who, having taken outsized political and diplomatic risks, is about to fall on his sword for sake of his country; describes himself as having pushed Israeli-Palestinian peace effort to moment of truth and in so doing, shattering illusions of Israeli left and right and unmasking Palestinians' reluctance to compromise (M)

abstract: Royal Ahold NV acquires Parkway Food Service (S)

headline: Changes Made in Liberty Media Cable Deal
abstract: Liberty Media Corp and UnitedGlobalCom Inc make changes to their intended merger plan at insistence of bondholders (M)

headline: Times Vice President For Labor Relations
abstract: New York Times promotes Jay I Sabin, executive director for labor relations, to vice president for labor relations (S)

headline: Edwin D. Etherington, Wesleyan Chief, Dies at 76
abstract: Edwin D. Etherington, who left the the top post at the American Stock Exchange to become president of Wesleyan University, died on Monday at his home in Jupiter Island, Fla. He was 76.

headline: Schröder Joins Debate, Taking Side of Pride In Germany
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder joins heated debate over whether Germans have right to feel national pride; declares himself 'German patriot' who is proud of his country; Germans, for decades after World War II and Holocaust, largely shied away from public expressions of national pride; broad discussion has started in recent months over whether success of country's postwar democracy has legitimized declarations of national pride that would be considered normal in most other countries (M)

headline: Trying to End Haiti's Impasse, Aristide Meets His Opponents
abstract: Opposition leaders who have steadfastly refused to recognize Jean-Bertrand Aristide as Haiti's president-elect say they are willing to compromise after meeting with him and his Lavalas party; Aristide repeats earlier promises to reach out to domestic critics and ease concerns of US and other countries; photo (M)

headline: President's Trial Suspended in Manila
abstract: Senate suspends Pres Joseph Estrada's impeachment trial less than 24 hours after potentially decisive ruling prompts Estrada's prosecutors to resign; Philippines reverts to chaos, conspiracy theories and coup rumors that have marked so many politically fraught moments in country; about 40,000 people rally in Manila to demand Estrada's ouster, and House leaders try to persuade prosecutors to return; photo (M)

headline: A Buyer's Market: The Dot-Com Liquidation Sale
abstract: Bargains can be hald at five online clearance sites: Overstock.com, SmartBargains.com, ReturnBuy.com, outlet section at Amazon.com and Half.com; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of crude oil falls on expectations that weakening demand will leave refiners well supplied, even after OPEC cut production; in New York, crude oil for April delivery falls 59 cents, or 2.2 percent, to $26.15 per barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Religious Sect Gains Victory In Moscow Trial
abstract: Jehovah's Witnesses win potentially far-reaching victory in Moscow court over prosecutors who sought to ban group under 1997 law that prohibits religious sects that incite hatred or intolerance; city court judge throws out charges that Witnesses broke up families, tried to convert minors without parents' consent and even pushed members toward suicide; ruling means group's 10,000 Moscow adherents can continue to practice their religion freely; it also sets political precedent, though not legal one, for many other religious groups outside Russian mainstream; Orthodox Church has been critical of Witnesses, who have been aggressive in recruiting members (M)

headline: VAN DER MOOLEN AGREES TO BUY SCAVONE, McKENNA
abstract: Van der Moolen Holding NV of Netherlands agrees to buy Scavone, McKenna, Cloud & Co for $60 million, strengthening its position as exchange's No. 5 market specialist (S)

headline: First Trip by a Japanese Leader to South Africa
abstract: Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori of Japan arrives, Johannesburg, for six-day visit to South Africa, hoping to strengthen economic ties that date from apartheid era when they were object of considerable criticism and embarrassment; photo (M)

headline: Pope Installs 44 New Cardinals
abstract: ROME, Feb. 21 — Pope John Paul II today installed 44 new cardinals, the largest number at one time in history, in a ceremony that mingled rich pageantry with the solemn purpose of molding the institution that will someday pick his successor.

headline: Verizon's Earnings Rise 1.3%; Sprint's Profit Is Down 11%
abstract: Verizon Communications says fourth-quarter earnings rose 1.3 percent, while Sprint reports 11 percent decline in profit; Verizon says profit climbed to $2.11 billion compared with $2.08 billion year earlier; sales rose 6.7 percent, to $16.9 billion from $15.8 billion; Sprint says profit fell to $358 million compared with $402 million year ago; sales fell to $4.39 billion from $4.42 billion; losses at Sprint PCS narrowed to $512 million from $706 million; sales rose to $1.94 billion from $1.06 billion (M)

headline: In Hong Kong, Mixed Signals On Falun Gong
abstract: Sudden resignation of top Hong Kong official Anson Chan, forceful advocate of city's independence, and politically sensitive meeting of some 1,200 members of Falun Gong sect in government-owned concert hall to protest China's crackdown on sect send deeply contradictory messages about Hong Kong's autonomy within China; sect leaders, citing detention of 11 members at airport, question whether city continues to safeguard rule of law (M)

headline: Interactive Agencies Involved in 2 Mergers
abstract: Leo Burnett Group UK, London office of Leo Burnett Worldwide, increased its ownership in Hard Reality in London to 100 percent from unspecified minority stake, then merged Hard Reality with Leonardo, direct-marketing agency that is part of Burnett Group UK; Expression Engines and Bigfoot Interactive are merging under Bigfoot Interactive name (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRIES,  Jerusalem, a generic drug maker, said it received American approval for a generic version of the Procardia XL hypertension and angina drug made by Pfizer Inc., New York.    ROGERS CORP.,  Rogers, Conn., a maker of components for computers and wireless communications devices, said it had agreed to buy the printed circuit board business of a closely held rival, Taconic, Petersburgh, N.Y., to get new products. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

headline: Japanese Official Steps Down Because of a Bribery Scandal
abstract: Fukushiro Nakaga resigns as member of Japanese cabinet responsible for economic and fiscal policy, unable to escape accusations that he was involved in bribery scandal; is replaced by Taro Aso, former head of Economic Planning agency; denies any wrongdoing (M)

headline: Estrada's Fate Is Entwined With Loyalties and Connections : Manila Trial Isn't Only About Justice
abstract: MANILA—  Sometime in the next few weeks, after prosecution and defense lawyers have finished arguing their cases, the secretary of the Philippine Senate will call out, in alphabetical order, the names of the country's 22 senators and ask them individually for their verdicts in the impeachment trial of President Joseph Estrada.

headline: Bush Backs Turkish Efforts To Resolve Economic Crisis
abstract: Pres Bush telephones Prime Min Bulent Ecevit to offer his support for Turkey's efforts to cope with its second economic crisis in three months; Turkish currency extends its slide, falling additional 10 percent against dollar, and is down 35 percent in two days; graph; list of currencies relative to US dollar (M)

headline: Israeli Campaign Advertising Shifts Into High Gear on TV
abstract: Israel's election campaign shifts into high gear with barrage of television commercials from incumbent, Prime Min Ehud Barak, and challenger, Ariel Sharon; Sharon, who leads Barak by commanding majority in polls, preaches healing of rifts and calls for unity government after election; Barak focuses on Sharon's performance as defense minister in 1982, when he led invasion that embroiled Israel in Lebanon for 18 years; photo (M)

headline: Migrants Flee Borneo as Death Toll Rises
abstract: Death toll from week of ethnic clashes in Indonesian city of Sampit increases to at least 210; there are no new reports of fighting between indigenous Dayak tribesmen and Madurese settlers who had been relocated there by government to reduce overpopulation elsewhere; thousands of Madurese refugees scramble to board navy ship in Indonesian section of Borneo; current crisis is seen as another problem for government of Pres Abdurrahman Wahid, which has so far proved unable to dampen growing separatist and ethnic conflicts in several regions of country; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SARA LEE CORP.,  Chicago, which manufactures and markets brand-name products for consumers across the world, says it is in talks to sell its French bakery business, Brossard, to Saveurs de France.    ALLEGHENY TECHNOLOGIES,  Pittsburgh, which makes specialty metals like stainless steel, said it would eliminate an unspecified number of jobs and close a plant in Albany, Ore., that makes a raw material for titanium products, to help reduce costs by $110 million this year. The job cuts and plant closing will reduce annual costs by $16 million.

headline: CLOROX EXPANDING IN BRAZIL
abstract: Clorox Co will pay $200 million to acquire 50 percent of new joint venture with cleaning products manufacturer Bombril; new venture, to be called Detergentes Bombril, will assume control of three of Bombril's plants to manufacture detergents and other household products under Bom Bril brand; Bombril is controlled by Italian company Cirio (S)

headline: Quake Rescue Operation in India Becomes Search for the Dead
abstract: ANJAR, India, Jan. 29 — Three days after an earthquake devastated swaths of western Gujarat, the search for survivors has largely given way to the grim task of excavating the dead from the rubble.

headline: Man in the News: Ariel Sharon: Hawk, Commander and Finally, Prime Minister
abstract: JERUSALEM, Feb. 6 - Throughout his long military and political career, Ariel Sharon has been nothing if not tenacious.

headline: SONY TO DOUBLE PLAYSTATION 2 PRODUCTION
abstract: Sony Corp will double production of its PlayStation 2 in next three months (S)

headline: Greenspan Says Slowdown Could Be Brief but Acknowledges Risks
abstract: WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 — While warning that the economy still faces substantial risks, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the United States was not in a recession and that the slowdown it was experiencing could prove to be as short as it is sharp.

headline: Scalpel! Clamp! . . . Hemopure?; A New Urgency in the Race for Blood Substitutes
abstract: Companies developing substitutes for transfusable blood respond to current shortage in blood supply with stepped-up research efforts; include Biopure Inc, Hemosol Inc, Alliance Pharmaceutical and Northfield Laboratories; shortage results mainly from fears of HIV and other contaminants and recent concern about mad cow disease; New York City, which gets 25 percent of its blood supply from Europe, could experience severe shortfall; photos; graph (L)

headline: Putting Palm and Phone in One Hand
abstract: David Pogue column on Kyocera's new Smartphone QCP 6035, which combines all features of sophisticated cellular telephone with full-blown Palm computer functioning on latest operating system, photo (M)

abstract: Sidney Guralnick, civil engineering professor at Illinois Institute of Technology, has invented device to detect road abnormalities which, left unrepaired, lead to development of potholes; photo (M)

headline: Explosion Kills 41 in School in Central China
abstract: Explosion in school in Wanzai, China, kills 41 people, mostly children, who reportedly have been assembling fireworks in a business set up by head teacher and local officials; officials deny reports that blast went off during assembly of fireworks, dominant industry in impoverished region; map (M)

abstract: Beef packer IBP Inc sues Tyson Foods Inc for abandoning plans to acquire it for $3.2 billion; Tyson shares jump $1.97, as IBP's stock drops $6.39; photo; graph (M)

abstract: Stephen L Brown announces retirement as chairman of John Hancock Financial Services; will be replaced by David D'Alessandro (S)
