headline: 2 GROCERY DISTRIBUTORS WILL COMPETE TO SUPPLY KMART
abstract: Fleming Companies and Supervalu Inc, grocery distributors, says Kmart will cancel their supply agreements on June 30 because it plans to consolidate to single supplier; Supervalu's contract is worth $2.3 billion annually; Fleming's says it had $1.3 billion in sales attributable to Kmart in 2000; both will bid to become sole supplier; group, including Yucaipa Investment and billionaire investor Ronald Burkle, acquires 6 percent stake in Kmart (S)

headline: TELENOR BUYING LOCKHEED UNIT
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp will sell its Comsat Mobile Communications unit to Telenor of Norway for $116.5 million (S)

headline: Economic Scene: California Must Control Demand for Power
abstract: THE reason for the California electricity crisis can be summed up in four words: demand grew, supply didn't.

headline: FRIEDE GOLDMAN AND NORWEGIAN DRILLER SETTLE DISPUTE
abstract: Shares of Friede Goldman Halter rise 34 percent after company, which builds offshore drilling equipment, says it resolved two-year dispute with Norwegian driller Ocean Rig; Ocean Rig will pay Friede Goldman to finish building two offshore rigs (S)

headline: U.S. and NATO Back Serbian Access to Kosovo Buffer Zone
abstract: BRUSSELS, Feb. 27 — Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said today that the United States was prepared to allow Serbian soldiers back into a three-mile-wide buffer zone along the Kosovo border, where Albanian militants have been increasingly active.

headline: High Fatality Rate Found in Cars That Crash With Explorers
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration study of how vehicles interact in crashes finds that Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles seem to be especially deadly to occupants of cars they hit, even compared with other midsize sport utility vehicles (M)

headline: George Magazine to Cease Publication
abstract: Hachette Filipacchi Magazines chief executive Jack W Kliger says George, magazine founded by John F Kennedy Jr, will cease publication with March issue; says even though magazine's circulation had grown in last year, there was no longer enough advertising support to sustain George (M)

headline: Napster Offers Deal to Record Companies
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 - Outlining plans to transform into a fee-based service, Napster said today that it intends to start charging users this summer to exchange music files online. And the company said it has proposed giving $1 billion over 5 years to record companies, including the major record labels that sued Napster after accusing it of abetting copyright infringement.

headline: China Says Protest Papers Are Distorted
abstract: Chinese Government defends crushing of pro-democracy demonstrations at Tiananmen Square in 1989 as highly necessary to stability and development of country in its first official response to 'Tiananmen papers'--reportedly internal documents newly published in US that show divisions within leadership at time; government spokesman also suggests papers are fake (S)

headline: Making Sense of the Moves in the Markets
abstract: Direction of stock market in 2001 is discussed by Merrill Lynch analyst Chris Callies, Wells Capital Management chief investment officer James W Paulsen and Douglas Cliggott, US equity strategist at J P Morgan; chart; photos (M)

headline: A Questionable Crutch for a Limping Economy
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on views of James Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management, who worries that dreary earnings reports from corporations may persist longer than others expect; his concern is that further cuts in interest rates may not rouse spending on technology products (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MERCURY AIR GROUP INC.,  Los Angeles, an aviation services company, said it planned to spin off and list separately its fuel sales and services unit by August 2001.    LANDSTAR SYSTEM INC.,  Jacksonville, Fla., a freight carrier, said it had opened a truck equipment repair and inspection center in Laredo, Tex., to handle an expected increase in shipments between the United States and Mexico. The cost of the operation was not disclosed.

headline: 2 Banks Follow Fed's Lead And Hope Economy Reacts
abstract: J P Morgan Chase and Wells Fargo Bank announce reduction in benchmark lending rates only hours after Federal Reserve makes its surprise cut in short-term interest rates; every other major bank is expected to follow with similar announcements in coming days; banks hope cuts will spur economic growth (M)

headline: Pyongyang Memo; North Koreans, Belts Tight, Cobble Up a Future
abstract: Belt-tightening is way of life in North Korea, even in capital of Pyongyang; most people get around by walking; slow-moving streams of humans are seen along every highway and street; country has lots of manpower and few machines, so public works projects, including superhighway, are completed with shovels and picks; about 5 percent of North Koreans are thought to be in armed forces, and soldiers are ubiquitous features of North Korean landscape; photos (M)

headline: Article 2001021090514600406 -- No Title

headline: QUANTUM UNIT BUYING BRITISH DATA STORAGE COMPANY
abstract: Quantum Corp, maker of computer disk drives, says unit, DLT and Storage Systems, will acquire M4 Data Holdings for about $56 million in debt, cash and stock (S)

headline: Letters: The Quirks of Behavior, as Part of Economics
abstract: In "Following the Money, but Also the Mind" (Feb. 11), Louis Uchitelle discussed the increasing influence of behavioral economists — those who say economics should do more than assume that people act with rational, unemotional self-interest. The article drew varied responses from many readers. A sampling follows.

headline: CMG RISES ON OUTLOOK
abstract: CMG PLC shares rise 12 percent after company says sales of mobile-text-message software more than doubled in second half and will rise more than 50 percent this year; also says second-half net profit fell 48 percent, to 16.5 million pounds ($24 million) from 31.8 million pounds ($46.3 million) year earlier; revenue rose 460.6 million pounds ($670.4 million) from 318.1 million pounds ($462.9 million); graph (S)

headline: AOL TIME WARNER PLANS TO BUY BACK $5 BILLION IN STOCK
abstract: AOL Time Warner says it may repurchase as much as $5 billion, or about 2.3 percent, of its shares in next two years because it stock is undervalued; will also sell as much as $10 billion of securities like debt or commmon stock (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Cuts Interest Rates, Sending Markets Soaring  Confronted with increased evidence of a stalling economy, the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point, stunning investors and sending a powerful signal that the Fed is worried about the prospects for keeping the expansion alive.

headline: CATHAY JET PURCHASE ON HOLD
abstract: Hong Kong's Cathay Pacific Airways is holding back decision to order new jets for delivery starting in 2002 because of concerns that economic slowdown in US will dampen demand for passenger seats and air freight (S)

headline: Workplace: Second Thoughts for Ph.D. Burnouts
abstract: On the trading floor at Goldman, Sachs, Hayley Boesky looks up from her desk to answer a question from a bond trader sitting a few feet away. He is one of dozens surrounding her, all wearing wireless headsets and perching in front of computer monitors. What will be the effect on bond prices, he wants to know, of the latest statement from the Office of Management and Budget?

headline: Reformer Finally Confirmed As Serbia's Prime Minister
abstract: Zoran Djindjic, leader of Democratic Party, is confirmed as Serbia's new prime minister, and his government is sworn in month after his 18-party alliance wins sweeping election campaign (M)

headline: ITALY BLOCKS TAKEOVER OF TELEVISION NETWORK
abstract: Italian authorities block takeover of Telemontecarlo television network by Seat Pagine Gialle, country's largest Internet company; say deal would violate laws blocking telecommunications companies from directly or indirectly controlling commercial broadcasters (S)

headline: PrivateSector; And the Roast Beef Goes to . . .
abstract: Actress Arlene Dahl organizes party for 60 at Le Cirque 2000 to watch Oscar ceremonies on large screens (S)

headline: Of One Author and Two Builders
abstract: Diana B Henriques reviews two books by Axel Madsen: John Jacob Astor: America's First Multimillionaire and The Deal Maker: How William C Durant Made General Motors; photo (M)

headline: Egan Calls Promotion Pope's Gift To Diocese
abstract: Archbishop Edward M Egan of New York says he is deeply humbled by his appointment as cardinal by Pope John Paul II; says honor belongs first and foremost to archdiocese, which became highly influential within church and society under John Cardinal O'Connor, Terence Cardinal Cooke and Francis Cardinal Spellman (M)

headline: Consumers May Soon Be Drawn to Magnetic Memory Chips
abstract: Magnetic random access memory, or M-RAM, emerges as possible replacement for dynamic random access memory, or D-RAM, used in most personal computers; D-RAM can remember only as long as it is refreshed by electricity, but M-RAM maintains data securely without a constant source of power; M-RAM promises not only instant-on starts but also sharply reduced power consumption; drawing (M)

headline: A New Online Spot to Gather To Find a Game or Analyze One
abstract: RealNetworks's new online service RealArcade will demonstrate, distribute and sell video games, provide forum for people to discuss games, match up players and even help game designers develop games; photo (S)

headline: NEW YORK LAW FIRM TO OPEN SILICON VALLEY OFFICE
abstract: Milbank Tweed Hadley & McCloy, large New York law firm, will open branch in Palo Alto, Calif (S)

headline: DAIMLERCHRYSLER COMMERCIAL SALES RISE
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG says its sales of commercial vehicles rose 5 percent in 2000; plans to consolidate into one entity its units that make components like engines and transmissions; weighs new joint venture with Hyundai Motor Co to make trucks for Asian market (S)

headline: TV Ad Irks Japan Party As Election Draws Near
abstract: Miyagi chapter of Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party runs television commercial that seems to question competence of Prime Min Yoshiro Mori; it is unusual for a local party chapter to produce its own commercial, and unheard of for one to air an ad so incendiary; party headquarters tried to ban commercial (M)

headline: The Free Fall of the Australian Dollar Remains a Mystery
abstract: Australian dollar slumps to all-time low of just under 50 US cents, leaving many analysts baffled; has fallen more than 24 percent against US currency since January 2000 and more than 10 percent since start of current year, making it second worst-performing currency internationally, behind Turkish lira; graph (M)

headline: PMC-Sierra And Conexant Will Cut Jobs
abstract: Conexant Systems and PMC-Sierra will dismiss hundreds of workers because sales this quarter will lag behind already reduced forecasts (M)

headline: Lowe Group and Havas Reorganize Top Offices
abstract: Lowe Group in London and New York and Havas Advertising in Paris are reorganizing operations (S)

headline: A Wraparound Screen For Quite a Pretty Penny
abstract: Panoram PV290 DSK computer screen, priced at $22,750, has three flat 18-inch panels and a total display areas of 43.5 by 11.5 inches; photo (S)

headline: Article 2001030294221170150 -- No Title
abstract: Privacy's Guarded Prognosis

headline: Judge Approves Auction House Settlement
abstract: Judge Lewis A Kaplan gives final approval to $512 million settlement of lawsuit against Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses by customers who say they were cheated in price-fixing conspiracy (M)

headline: ATI SELLS BROADCOM STAKE
abstract: ATI Technologies sells its 494,000-share stake in Broadcom, telecommunications chip maker, for gain of about $54 million; ATI received stake in December, when Broadcom bought SiByte Inc; ATI owned 11 percent SiByte stake and exchanged shares in company for Broadcom stock; graph (S)

headline: Technology Wreckage: Yes, More To Come
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin interview with Roger McNamee, general partner at Integral Capital Partners, a technology-investments firm; he assesses damage to and future prospects of technology stocks; photo (M)

headline: General Motors May Be Running Into Problems in Sale of Hughes Electronics
abstract: Stock market uncertainty and growing friction between Hughes Electronics head Michael Smith and General Motors management reportedly are making it harder for GM to sell Hughes; share price of Hughes, owner of satellite television company DirecTV, has fallen 16 percent in last week alone; stock price graph (M)

headline: An Antitrust Hurdle
abstract: Analysis of merger proposals that would give United Airlines and American Airlines control of nearly half of domestic airline market; says pacts may draw increased scrutiny from regulators (M)

headline: PROFIT DOWN AT HUTCHISON
abstract: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd posts 71 percent drop in profit in 2000, to 34.1 billion Hong Kong dollars ($4.4 billion); revenue rose to 57 billion Hong Kong dollars from 55.4 billion (S)

headline: McDONALD'S INTRODUCES MENU FOR OLDER CHILDREN
abstract: McDonald's Corp is introducing new Mighty Kids Meal, bigger version of its Happy Meal intended for older children (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Internet retailers find that the ancient business method of bartering helps them cope with a variety of transactions.
abstract: Growing number of online retailers are bartering to help shed excess inventory; Web merchants are only now mastering subtler side of sales--including how to order goods in right quantities; rather than unload mountain of unwanted wares on liquidators, who pay pennies on the dollars, e-tailers are bartering, engaging in world's oldest way of doing business; photo (M)

headline: As Deadline Nears, Fate of Racial Bias Accord at Coke Is Uncertain
abstract: Groundswell of dissatisfaction among 2,000 African-Americans covered by discrimination lawsuit against Coca-Cola Co threatens to destabilize or even derail the $192 million settlement; they have until March 19 to accept or reject settlement, and if 200 or more of them opt out of agreement, Coke has option of declaring settlement invalid; source of plaintiffs' frustration is that under settlement, those covered in lawsuit must approve accord and sign away their rights to sue Coke in future before they find out how much money they will receive (M)

headline: A Clinton Web Site For Posterity's Sake
abstract: Official Web site of president of United States, www.whitehouse.gov, will be passed to George W Bush at noon on Jan 20; Clinton administration's Web site will still be available as part of Clinton Presidential Materials Project, a precursor to Clinton library; photo (M)

headline: Conoco in a Buyback
abstract: Conoco Inc plans to repurchase $1 billion of its shares over next three years (S)

headline: Deutsche Telekom Will Delay Deal to Buy VoiceStream
abstract: Deutsche Telekom delays completion of acquisition of VoiceStream Wireless to last Day of May or early June and will pay a special stock dividend that effectively raises price it is paying for VoiceStream; Sen Ernest F Hollings says he will object again to deal if it receives FCC aproval (M)

headline: Jellyfish Gene Leaps From the Test Tube to Tickle Entrepreneurs' Imagination : How About Glow-in-the-Dark Birthday Cake?
abstract: PARIS—  Martin Chalfie, a professor of biology at Columbia University, had studied the tiny worm Caenorhabditis elegans for nearly two decades — "far too many years," he muses — when his big breakthrough finally came.

headline: High-Speed Wireless For Users on the Move
abstract: Mitsubishi Materials Corp's forthcoming Swiftcomm network promises high-speed wireless Internet connection; photo (S)

headline: While Seattle Shook, The Airport Scrambled
abstract: Feb 28 earthquake damaged and disabled control tower at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, but air traffic control was regained two hours after the shock; contingency planning and human ingenuity and resourcefulness triumphed; photo (M)

headline: CONTINENTAL DROPS OBJECTIONS TO T.W.A. AUCTION
abstract: Continental Airlines is dropping its objections to auction of Trans World Airlines by bankruptcy court and will withdraw its appeal to US Appeals Court (S)

headline: Learning Channel Sues Over a Web Site
abstract: Learning Channel, unit of Discovery Communications Inc, sues Pearson PLC, world's largest educational publisher, contending infringement of its trademark by Internet site operated by Pearson (S)

headline: Dow Falls, but Microsoft Lifts Tech Shares
abstract: Blue-chip stocks fall, as Dow Jones industrial average slumps 90.69, or 0.85 percent, to 10,587.59; S & P 500 loses 0.4 percent, or 5.43, closing at 1,342.54; Nasdaq composite index rises 1.89, or 0.07 percent, to 2,770.38, led by Microsoft's reported profits; 10-year Treasury note falls 13/32, to 104 14/32, and its yield rises to 5.16 percent; 30-year Treasury bond falls 1 4/32, to 110 4/32, and its yield increases to 5.55 percent; chart; list of key rates (M)

headline: Amazon Offer Links Profit To Share Price
abstract: Amazon.com offers to cut price of existing emplo

headline: Bush Administration Warns Iraq on Weapons Programs
abstract: George W Bush administration responds to report that Iraq has rebuilt series of factories long suspected of producing biological and chemical weapons by warning government to honor its agreements to destroy its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs; says it is too early to say what steps it will take to ensure Baghdad's compliance (M)

headline: Bank of England Cuts Rate
abstract: LONDON, Feb. 8 — Following cautiously in the footsteps of the Federal Reserve, the Bank of England cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point today, to 5.75 percent. The reduction, the first interest-rate change here in a year, reflected concern that the slowdown in the United States economy may retard Britain's already sluggish growth.

headline: 2 Advertisers, Different Outcomes
abstract: Minneapolis office of Fallon Worldwide and OmniSky Corp, which offers wireless Internet services and devices, are parting ways after working together for less than two months; billings estimated at $40 million to $50 million; OmniSky will handle more of its marketing efforts internally, while continuing to work with agencies including Exile on Seventh, which handles direct and online marketing; Cingular Wireless is starting ad review; is seeking its first agency to handle so-called e-business assignments; BBDO Worldwide handles general advertising for Cingular, with billings estimated at $200 million (S)

headline: CANADIAN INFLATION FALLS
abstract: Canada's annual rate of inflation dipped to 3 percent in January from 3.2 percent in December; core inflation, excluding energy, was 2.3 percent (S)

headline: KANA CUTS WORK FORCE
abstract: Kana Communications, maker of customer relations management software, has laid off 220 employees, or 20 percent of its work force, as part of plan to cut expenses by $30 million to $40 million per year (S)

headline: HOMEBUILDER BID RAISED
abstract: British homebuilder Persimmon raises its offer for Beazer Group to 538 million pounds ($791 million) (S)

headline: FRUIT OF THE LOOM FILES A PLAN FOR REORGANIZATION
abstract: Fruit of the Loom Ltd files reorganization plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: The Nickelodeon cable network agrees to run some commercials that are partly in Spanish.
abstract: Nickelodeon, cable television network that appeals to children, agrees to run some commercials that are partly in Spanish (M)

headline: Pentagon Finds Ongoing Lapses In Gulf Security
abstract: Special Pentagon commission investigating terrorist attack against US destroyer Cole in Aden, Yemen, on October 12 finds lapses in security in Persian Gulf, and will recommend steps to tighten security for American forces there; finds American commanders in region are not devoting enough attention to protecting US forces from attack, and that there are cracks in security for ships and aircraft moving through region; separate Navy investigation focusing on actions aboard Cole concludes that destroyer's captain and crew failed to follow strict security procedures on morning of attack; raises possibility of disciplinary action against Cole's captain, Comdr Kirk S Lippold, or other officers and members of crew (M)

headline: California Plans to Buy Utility's Wires
abstract: State of California announces agreement to buy transmission system of Southern California Edison, state's second-largest utility, for $2.76 billion; this may save utility from filing for bankruptcy protection; if state's other two large utilities fail to make similar agreements with government, this deal will likely be scrapped; for accounting purposes, SCE values its transmission system at $1.1 billion; problem of sufficient electricity supply still remains (M)

headline: Too True, Buildings Kill: Will India Pay Heed Now?
abstract: India's Jan 26 earthquake draws new attention to 1998 government report that warned that builders are ignoring construction standards that could reduce number of collapsed buildings and loss of life in earthquakes (M)

headline: Yogurt on the Go: Now for Adults, Too
abstract: General Mills' Yoplait introduces Expresse, an adult version of Go-Gurt, popular grab-and-go yogurt for children; John Haugen, director of marketing, comments; photo (M)

headline: Topps uses Mickey Mantle, old-style cards and bubble gum to help sales and celebrate 50 years.
abstract: Topps Co has put back bubble gum in its baseball trading card packages as it nears its 50th anniversary; cards, featuring pictures of baseball players rendered in 1950's style, are on old-fashioned cardboard stock; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Close Higher Despite More Profit Warnings
abstract: In a modest reversal of its monthlong decline, the stock market rose today despite a fresh round of corporate profit warnings.

headline: US UNWIRED TO SELL 173 COMMUNICATIONS TOWERS TO SBA
abstract: US Unwired will sell as many as 173 communications towers in Southeast to SBA Communications Corp for about $54.1 million; US Unwired, which provides mobile-phone service, will lease space on each of towers for $1,500 per month (S)

headline: CHIP MAKER WILL SPIN OFF UNIT
abstract: NEC Corp of Japan will convert division that makes processors for network equipment into wholly owned subsidiary in preparation for taking unit public (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Better From Blue

headline: Simple Aid to Gorillas Pays Off: Babies in the Bamboo
abstract: Population of endangered mountain gorrillas in Volcano National Park in Rwanda, one of two places in world where they still exist, is inching up mainly because of modest conservation efforts to save them; recent preliminary estimate puts population at 358, up from 324 in 1989; scientists are pleased, given that numbers could easily have declined since park straddles Rwanda, Congo and Uganda--part of world with extraordinary amount of strife; important strategy of International Gorilla Conservation Program has been merely to keep park rangers paid and equipped in times of war so they can follow gorillas regularly and continue anti-poaching projects; maps; photo (M)

headline: Merrill Unit Makes Leadership Change
abstract: Merrill Lynch names Sam Chapin to replace Daniel Bayly as co-head of investment banking; Chapin will co-manage with Kevan Watts (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper falls to lowest price in two weeks on expectations that slowing economy will hurt sales of wires and pipes; in New York, copper for May delivery falls 0.9 cent, or 1.1 percent, to 81.95 cents per pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: 4th-Quarter Results For Ad Spending
abstract: CMR, formerly Competitive Media Reporting, says ad spending rose 13.3 percent, to $101.6 billion, in 2000 from $89.7 billion in 1999; notes ad spending in December 2000 rose just 1 percent from December 1999 (S)

headline: China Holding U.S. Scholar In Isolation
abstract: Chinese authorities report that Gao Zhan, Chinese scholar based in United States, has been held in isolation in China for more than five weeks, under investigation for 'activities damaging state security'; say her husband, Xue Donghua, and 5-year-old son, who is American citizen, were also detained and held separately for 26 days, before they were released on Mar 8 to fly home to Virginia; Gao and her family were on three-week visit with relatives in China when they were detained by authorities at Beijing airport; Xue says he does not know why his wife is being held and asserts her total innocence; Gao and Xue are permanent residents of US; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Economic Mood Brightens In Europe as It Sours in U.S.  Even as the economic mood of Americans has shifted almost overnight from exuberance to anxiety, Europe has emerged as an oasis of tranquillity and prosperity.    Europe now stands a good chance of outpacing its economic rival by a significant margin. Consumer confidence is running at nearly record levels across most of the Continent and European unemployment, stuck for much of the decade above 10 percent, is now at its lowest level since 1991. [Page A1.]

headline: Israeli Official Is Found Guilty On Sex Charges
abstract: Yitzhak Mordechai, former Israeli defense minister and transportation minister, is convicted of committing 'indecent acts' against two women subordinates; court says Mordechai tried to use force to molest women; Mordechai proclaims his innocence and takes leave from Parliament pending outcome of his appeal; other lawmakers are pushing for his outright dismissal (M)

headline: Disney Posts First-Quarter Drop in Net
abstract: Walt Disney Co reports net income of $63 million in its fiscal first quarter ended Dec 31, down from $356 million for quarter year earlier; revenue rose 7 percent, to $7.3 billion (M)

headline: Strong Gains for Dow as Investors Await Fed
abstract: The Dow Jones industrial average posted a strong gain today, but most of the stock market remained stagnant as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's next move to cut in interest rates in an effort to revive the slowing economy.

headline: With Seattle a Vivid Memory, W.T.O. Seeks a New Host City
abstract: World Trade Organization is seeking host city for its meeting in fall; its last meeting in Seattle in December 1999 was marred by violent protests, scores of arrests and property damage; Chile and Persian Gulf state of Qatar are vying for meeting, which will draw global attention because WTO may again try to start round of trade talks that never got off ground in December 1999 (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Carpal Tunnel Concerns

headline: Study Links Malnutrition to Stunted Growth of Tibet's Children
abstract: New study finds half of all children in Tibetan region of China suffer from stunted growth, medical problems and potentially impaired intellectual development as result of malnutrition; study, by American and Tibetan doctors, finds stunting is often accompanied by bone disorders, depigmented hair, skin disorders and other diseases of malnutrition; study, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, calls into question Chinese government's proclamations of great economic and social progress (M)

headline: Colombian Rebels May Release 100 Prisoners
abstract: Largest rebel group in Colombia may release more than 100 captive soldiers and police officers, in what officials see as conciliatory gesture toward stagnant peace efforts (S)

headline: WITH PROFIT DOWN, SEARS MAY REDUCE PRODUCT LINES
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co's chairman-chief executive Alan Lacy says that Sears might reduce or eliminate some product lines to make room for top-selling categories like appliances, but that company will continue to be general merchant; company reports its profit from operations fell 14 percent in fourth quarter from year earlier, but figure, $639 million, is better than analysts had forecast; revenue rose 2.4 percent, to $12.4 billion (S)

headline: BUSH ISSUES ORDER PREVENTING STRIKE BY AIRLINE UNION
abstract: Pres Bush isues executive order barring potential strike by mechanics at Northwest Airlines and says he will take 'necessary steps' to block walkouts at any major carrier this year; Bush's pledge comes as United Airlines, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines are nearing end to contract negotiations, some of which have lasted for years; mechanics at Northwest, who are represented by Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Assn, have been seeking wage increase and new contract for more than four years; executive order requires that mechanics stay on job for 60 days while three-member emergency board is convened to make settlement recommendation (M)

headline: Privacy at Risk
abstract: Dennis Williams letter responds to March 1 article about privacy of medical records

headline: Online, and Off, English's Hegemony Is Challenged Globally
abstract: PARIS—  Has English become THE global language of communication and education? The question might seem obvious, but the answer is not so simple. Yes, English is the international language of commerce and science. And its utility has spread because up to now it has also been the prime moving language of the Internet. But this is beginning to change, and very fast.

headline: What's My Line? 4 Who Found Jobs Nowhere Near the Beaten Path
abstract: Millions of Americans work in unusual jobs; Labor Dept's Dictionary of Occupational Titles contains 13,000 entries, including worm sorters, wrinkle chasers and wort pumpers; four workers describe their unusual jobs; photos (M)

headline: NATO Soldiers Fire on Kosovo Albanians
abstract: NATO soldiers in Kosovo open fire and wound two Albanian gunmen, raising prospect that peacekeeping force could become tangled in violent Albanian insurgency that has suddenly flared in neighboring Macedonia; peacekeepers are in command of multinational force that moved into Kosovo village of Mijak in operation to stem flow of arms and men to Albanian guerrillas in Macedonia, where clashes have erupted between ethnic Albanians and Macedonian military force; photo (M)

headline: Business; Putting 'Hostile' Back Into Takeover
abstract: Gehl Co, small manufacturer of equipment based in West Bend, Wis, is embroiled hostile takeover battle of the sort not seen since 1980's and 90's, complete with attempts to oust company chairman, William D Gehl, and his board of directors, a class-action lawsuit, potential greenmail and ultra-bitter personal attacks; challenge is mounted by Paul DeRobbio and Mark E Schwarz, who quietly accumulated 6 percent of Gehl's outstanding shares and have backing of Harold C Simmons; photos; graph (L)

headline: MCKESSON HBOC SIGNS CONTRACT VALUED AT $33 BILLION
abstract: McKesson HBOC Inc signs contract valued at $33 billion with ServAll Health Alliance to provide drugs and other services (S)

headline: Extending the Life And Lore of Graffiti
abstract: Hundreds of Web sites are devoted to promoting aerosol art, or graffiti, even though most of it is illegal and many graffiti writers say their culture lives on the streets and in the trainyards, not online; photo (M)

headline: Colombian Military Officers Convicted in '97 Village Killings
abstract: Columbian military tribunal convicts retired Gen Jaime Humberto Uscategui and Col Hernan Orozco of letting right-wing paramilitary gunmen kill dozens of villagers in 1997; conviction is first of high-ranking military officers in human rights case; human rights groups score 40-month sentence for general and 30-month sentence for colonel as too light (M)

headline: Drug Shortages Become a Worry At Hospitals Around the Country
abstract: Doctors, pharmacists and federal regulators are increasingly concerned about what they say is growing shortages of drugs, particularly at hospitals; shortages attributed partly to drug industry's rapid consolidation, which has led to fewer companies making each drug or supplying raw materials; have been made worse by tendency of manufacturers, distributors and hospitals to keep lower levels of drugs on hand under new just-in-time inventory management technique, in which supplies are kept to minimum to save on storage costs and to tie up less money on drugs sitting on shelves; some critical drugs in short supply noted; shortages at some hospitals discussed; health officials comment; photo (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for CLARENCE D. RAPPLEYEA; A Different Sort of New York Power Struggle
abstract: New York Power Authority chairman and chief executive Clarence D Rappleyea discusses how New York plans to avoid difficulties with electric power generation, distribution and pricing currently overwhelming California; photo (M)

headline: AUTO PARTS MAKER ACQUIRED
abstract: Germany's ThyssenKrupp agrees to buy suspension-making unit of Fiat SpA's Magneti Marelli auto components subsidiary in transaction worth as much as 500 million euros ($500 million) to expand its car parts business; ThyssenKrupp will buy 51 percent of unit and has option to buy rest by 2004 (S)

headline: Guinness Book Is Up for Sale, Insiders Say
abstract: Diageo, British company that owns Guinness World Records, which has recorded world records for last 50 years, reportedly plans to sell unit (S)

headline: New Owner Struggles At a London Tabloid
abstract: Article discusses problems besetting Britain's tabloid newspaper The Daily Express, which has seen its circulation decline under new owner Richard Desmond; photo (M)

headline: A Decade Beyond the Gulf War
abstract: Analysis of United States military options against Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein; notes new American and British air strikes on radar installations and antiaircraft sites near Baghdad do not decisively change military situation or provide guide for how new Bush administration hopes to oust Hussein (M)a

headline: Chip Maker In Korea Posts Loss for Year
abstract: Hyundai Electronics Industries reports loss of 2.4 trillion won ($1.9 billion) in 2000 despite rapid sales growth; expects to report 8.9 trillion won ($7.1 billion) in revenue for 2000, 48 percent more than in 1999, and operating profit of 1.5 trillion won ($1.2 billion), more than double previous year's 646 billion won ($510 million) (S)

headline: Germany Expands Workers' Councils
abstract: German's ruling center-left coalition, led by Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, agrees on plan to strengthen power of workers' representatives in corporate management decisions; business groups angrily argued that move would lead to higher costs and greater inflexibility; Schroder offers only modest concessions to salve protests lodged by his own economics minister, Werner Muller (M)

headline: New Cell Phones Put Whole Alphabet in Play
abstract: Motorola introduces two new GSM cell phones, V100 and Accompli, which facilitate text messaging by providing user-friendly keyboards; photo (S)

headline: GENETIC CHIPS ARE FLAWED
abstract: Affymetrix, maker of gene chips used in drug research, says it has found flaws in one line of products and offers replacements; found errors in data taken from mouse genes used to design one type of its gene chips, glass wafers with DNA fragments affixed to their surfaces; replacing defective chips may cost up to $4 million (S)

headline: Zimbabwe Says It Stands By Congo in Conflict
abstract: Zimbabwe Pres Robert Mugabe bows solemnly over body of slain Congo Pres Laurent Kabila, and pledges continued support to Congolese government shaken by several years of war; photo; gesture reflects Mugabe's powerful role; Kabila, wounded or already dead, was rushed to Zimbabwe after shooting (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    THE NETHERLANDS: FOOT-AND-MOUTH CASE  The Dutch government confirmed the country's first case of foot-and-mouth disease and quickly banned all exports of livestock, reinstating a nationwide halt on transporting animals that had been lifted just two days earlier and extending it to cover chickens. Tests showed that four cows had contracted the disease on a farm near Olst, in the eastern part of the country. Also, Britain's outbreak of the disease worsened, reaching 435 confirmed cases, an increase of 40 in one day.    Suzanne Daley (NYT)

headline: New Music Player Can Sing, But It's a Rare Bird
abstract: Sonicblue introduces Rio 800 Extreme, MP3 player that can play 12 hours of medium-fidelity Windows Media Player digital music or 7 to 8 hours of high-fidelity music in Apple QuickTime format; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector: Another Bill as President? A Survey Picks Gates
abstract: William H. Gates has spent a lot of time fighting the government over whether his company, Microsoft , is a monopoly. So it may come as a surprise that if Americans had to hand over the government to the private sector, more would choose Microsoft to run it than any other company.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: AVAYA EARNINGS DROP
abstract: Avaya Inc reports its net income in quarter ended Dec 31 fell 77 percent, to $16 million, from $69 million in 1999 period (S)

headline: Venture in 401(k) Plans
abstract: Ameritrade Holding Corp forms partnership with Persumma Financial, unit of Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Co that provides online 401(k) services (S)

headline: GAINS FORECAST FOR ONLINE ADS
abstract: Jupiter Communications senior analyst Melissa Gluck estimates that online advertising will climb to $7.3 billion this year, from $5.3 billion in 2000, and reach $16.5 billion by 2005, speech to conference organized by American Association of Advertising Agencies and Association of National Advertisers; Yahoo chief operating officer, Jeffrey Mallett, says traditional companies are starting to buy ads online; photo (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    CZECH REPUBLIC: TV CHIEF IN HOSPITAL  The new director of the state-owned Czech Television, Jiri Hodac, was taken to the hospital with what doctors suggested was exhaustion and stress. The illness might also serve as a pretext for Mr. Hodac to resign and end the crisis that began nearly two weeks ago when journalists barricaded themselves in the newsroom to protest what they say is his political bias in favor of the opposition politician Vaclav Klaus.    Steven Erlanger (NYT)    BRITAIN: MORE MILLIONS FOR LABOR  Lord Sainsbury, a supermarket heir who is science minister, and Christopher Ondaatje, a publishing executive and philanthropist, followed the example of Lord Hamlyn, another publishing millionaire, in identifying themselves as $3 million donors to the Labor Party. It has been under pressure to name large benefactors in keeping with the spirit of a new law requiring disclosure of all gifts over $7,500.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: LVMH Reports Record Profit for 2000
abstract: World's leading luxury goods group, LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton of France, reports record revenue and profit for 2000, but warns of more difficult conditions in 2001 because of slowing growth prospects in major economies; says that after two-year acquisition spree it will focus more on strengthening its cash flow and easing burden of acquisition-related debt; operating profit for last year rose 27 percent, to 1.95 billion euros ($1.82 billion); photo of Bernard Arnault, chmn, and Myron Ullman III, general director (M)

headline: AOL Time Warner to Revamp CNNfn
abstract: AOL Time Warner plans to rename CNNfn, its struggling f

headline: A Cautious Sibling Waits to See What Works
abstract: Article on Yahoo Japan Corp, which has learned much from its American counterpart's mistakes, and seen its revenue and net income grow; it is, however, dependent on advertising for 94.6 percent of revenues; Yahoo Japan was founded in 1996 by Yahoo Inc and Softbank Corp; graph (M)

headline: MALAYSIA EASES FINANCIAL RESTRICTIONS
abstract: Malaysia's Securities Commission announces 10-year plan to liberalize country's securities markets, easing restrictions to win back foreign investment and give companies alternatives to what economists say is overreliance on bank lending; plan calls for lifting limits on foreign ownership of financial companies by 2003 and for folding two smaller Malaysian exchanges into main exchange by next year; plan also proposes ending restrictions on selling borrowed stocks or bonds or short-selling (S)

headline: Rather Talk Than Type? Digital Dictation
abstract: Digital voice recorders have become viable alternative for getting words onto paper without using keyboards; article assesses current digital dictation devices; photo (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   9.00   9.00   8.50       Discount rate   5.75   5.75   5.00       Federal funds   5.88   5.83   5.74       3-month T-bills   5.05   4.94   5.38       6-month T-bills   4.82   4.79   5.63       10-yr.
