headline: Last Decker Leaves Power Tool Company
abstract: Alonzo G Decker Jr, son of co-founder of Black & Decker and a former chairman and chief executive, retires as a director after 60 years on board; it is first time in 90 years that company is without a Decker; company has nominated M Anthony Burns to take Decker's seat on the board (S)

headline: BOND RELIEF FOR HYUNDAI AND SSANGYONG
abstract: Korea Development Bank will relieve some of pressure on four cash-short companies by buying 507.1 billion won ($395 million) of new bonds issued by them; deal will refinance about four-fifths of bonds maturing next month for Hyundai Electronics, Hyundai Engineering and Construction, Hyundai Merchant Marine and Ssangyong Cement Industrial (S)

headline: Xerox Reports Loss and Plan To Eliminate 4,000 Jobs
abstract: Xerox Corp reports fourth-quarter loss is slightly larger than analysts' estimates and says it will eliminate 4,000 jobs to help cut costs; company had loss before special items of $198 million in quarter compared with profits of $294 million in year-earlier period; net loss was $119 million; total revenue fell to $4.8 billion, from $5.5 billion year ago; equipment sales for period were $2.7 billion, down from $3.3 billion; company lost $384 million for all of 2000, on revenue of $18.63 billion; chairman Paul A Allaire says company expects to lose money in first quarter of 2001 (M)

headline: Bankruptcy Bill May Lead to a Surge of Filings
abstract: Consumers considering bankruptcy are being advised by lawyers to act before legislation to tighten rules is enacted; some lawyers are running advertisements; those actions and continued weakening of economy are likely to contribute to surge in filings this year; US House has passed bill and Senate is sorting through proposed amendments to bill, which, if passed, Pres Bush is expected to sign (M)

headline: BUSH DUE TO MEET CHINESE ON ISSUES CRUCIAL FOR TIES
abstract: Pres Bush prepares for meeting with China's Deputy Prime Min Qian Qichen in Washington, first with senior Chinese official, as administration faces crucial decisions on military issues that could quickly put US on collision course with Beijing; issues are whether to design national missile defense capable of countering China's small nuclear force or whether to sell Aegis destroyers to Taiwan; China's concern that Aegis system could be used as platform for missile shield for Taiwan and usher in new level of American military cooperation with island, regarded as renegade province, noted; importance of issues among conservative Republicans, who are deeply suspicious of Beijing and who represent important Bush constituency, discussed (M)

headline: GE CAPITAL AGREES TO BUY FRANCHISE FINANCE
abstract: GE Capital Corp agrees to buy Franchise Finance Corporation of America for $1.4 billion in cash (S)

headline: Turkey Floats Currency, and It Falls 25%
abstract: Turkey floats its currency, lira, and value drops 25 percent by end of day and sends wave of concern, but so far no panic, through many foreign markets; while investors and political leaders worry about whether Turkey's financial problems will be contagious, Turks wait for prices to skyrocket and wonder whether crisis might bring down government; leaders of two main opposition parties demand that Prime Min Bulent Ecevit resign and call early elections; US Treasury and International Monetary Fund officials issue statements intended to calm markets by expressing support for Turkey's decision to let currency float; same officials are much more critical in private; chart; photos (M)

headline: Inside the Soap Opera of Television's Early Days
abstract: Several Web sites are devoted to the people responsible for the invention of television; photo (M)

headline: AUDIOVOX 4TH-QUARTER NET FELL 56%
abstract: Shares of Audiovox Corp falls as much as 20 percent after it reports fiscal fourth-quarter earnings fell 56 percent and current economic slowdown will hurt growth; net income for quarter ended Nov 30 fell to $5.06 million; graph (S)

headline: W-2's Swallowed by Dot-Com Black Hole
abstract: Some former exployees of defunct Internet companies have yet to receive their W-2 forms, which they need to fill out their income tax forms; some who received W-2's find disparities between figures there on their pay stubs; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: STARBASE CORP., Santa Ana, Calif., a developer of Internet software, said it would acquire Technology Builders Inc., Atlanta, a software provider, for about $36.9 million in stock. Earlier this week, the company also said that it would buy Worldweb.net Inc. for $26 million in stock and cash.

headline: Chunnel's Human Traffic Has a Dream
abstract: SANGATTE, France, March 8 — In four languages, the signs on the walls in the Red Cross shelter warn of the hazards of trying to sneak into England through the Channel Tunnel: electrocution risk, squashing risk, very high- speed train, mortal danger.

headline: Colombia, in Risky Move, Plans To Cede Zone to 2nd Rebel Group
abstract: Pres Andres Pastrana of Colombia will grant small sliver of land in and around San Pablo to National Liberation Army, second largest rebel force, even though ceding land to rebels has failed to bring peace in past; land granted two years ago to Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, largest rebel group, is being used to stage attacks elsewhere, hide kidnapping victims and grow coca; Pastrana continues to believe that pulling police and army units from territory offers best chance to foster peace talks; government says National Liberation Army shows willingness to negotiate and that group, weakened by attacks by paramilitary forces, has more to lose than Revolutionary Armed Forces (FARC), by not taking part in peace effort; many Colombians view plan as risky proposition; those opposed to plan include paramilitary groups, ranchers, businessmen and poor farmers; photos; map (M)

headline: One Merger Falters, But Second Forges On
abstract: HMS Partners and Fahlgren end talks to merge; Just Partners and Work will combine under holding company, Just Partners, and operate agency under name Work (S)

headline: New Economy; Wassail beats lucre: More people went online to talk to loved ones and send holiday greetings than to shop.
abstract: Pew Internet and American Life Project survey finds American adults used Internet during Christmas holiday season far more for social uses than for shopping; finds only 24 percent of Internet users actually bought gifts online, while 45 percent looked for gift ideas online and 32 percent used Web to compare prices; drawing (M)

headline: Support Mixed With Concern Among U.S. Jewish Groups
abstract: American Jewish groups react to Ariel Sharon's victory in Israel (S)

headline: A Story Line? Who Needs a Story Line?
abstract: Charles Herold reviews Dead or Alive 2, computer game from Tecmo; photo (M)

headline: Empty Aisles and Empty Stores; What Happens When Anchor Stores Weigh Anchor?
abstract: US economic problems signal that nation's merchant's and their suppliers, already over-extended, are probably about to experience painful shake-out, where chains are forced to close or scale back their ambitions; Harvey Miller, who is head of restructuring practice at law firm of Wel, Gotshal & Manges, says Bradlees and Montgomery Ward are edge of curve; Moody's Investors Service says likelihood that publicly held retail companies will default sometime this year on bank loan, outstanding bond or other form of debt has doubled from beginning of 2000; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Funds Watch: Dipping Into the Pool of Amateur Analysts
abstract: Ordinary investors cannot buy shares of hedge funds, but they may soon be able to manage one.

headline: Creating a Generation Of Slouchers
abstract: Educators and researchers express alarm that children are not being taught sound ergonomic practices along with basic computer skills; say the kinds of computer-related injuries adults suffer--neck and back strain and repetitive stress injuries like carpal tunnel syndrome--may become widespread, particularly as more children begin using computers at very young ages and use them for more hours each day; computer work stations in classrooms are often ergonomically deficient, principally becsuse they must be used by many children, each of whom should probably have his or her own setup; photos (L)

headline: CAE BUYING U.S. FLIGHT SIMULATOR BUSINESS
abstract: CAE Inc, Canadian manufacturer of flight simulators, will buy American flight training unit of BAE Systems North America for $80 million (S)

headline: Yeltsin Reported to Be Ill but Improving
abstract: Former Russian president Boris N Yeltsin reportedly is improving after bout with flu and pneumonia (S)

headline: Patches of HDTV
abstract: Paul Fiorentino letter concerns availability of high definition television broadcasts (Feb 15 article)

headline: JUNIPER SALES TOP FORECASTS
abstract: Juniper Networks Inc says fourth-quarter net income was $62.2 million, compared with $3.08 million year earlier; revenue rose to $295.4 million from $45.4 million (S)

headline: REVLON REPORTS LOSS IS BIGGER THAN EXPECTED
abstract: Revlon Inc says loss from operations narrowed to $29.6 million in fourth quarter; sales fell 23 percent, to $321.1 million (S)

headline: WEB MEASUREMENT LAWSUITS
abstract: Jupiter Media Metrix settles patent infringement suit against competitor, PC Data, involving Internet metering technology; PC Data and its PC Data Online agree to withdraw from business of tracking computer use; Jupiter sues NetRatings and NetValue USA for patent infringement; NetValue president Jim Hatch denies charge; photo (S)

headline: JAPANESE CHEMICAL COMPANY ADMITS HELPING FIX PRICES
abstract: Japan's Ueno Fine Chemicals Industry agrees to plead guilty and pay $11 million fine for its role in 17-year conspiracy to fix price of food perservatives called sorbates; Ueno executives Yuji Komatsu, Yoshihiko Katsuyama and Wakao Shinoda are indicted by federal grand jury in San Francisco (S)

headline: Anguish at Every Turn In Ruined Chechen City
abstract: Life in ruined city of Grozny carries on in various states of terror for nearly 2,000 Chechens who have come back from tent cities and other temporary shelters; photos; map; parents fear their children will disappear or be beaten at one of hundreds of Russian military checkpoints, or when soldiers sweep into homes and take away young men (M)

headline: Article 2001022391338812130 -- No Title
abstract: February 22, 2001

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls as weaker-than-expected German labor report raises concern that Europe will outpace US by less than thought; in New York, euro settles at 93.03 cents, down from 93.87 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN, FRANCE: ASYLUM ACCORD -- The two countries agreed to impose tighter controls on their cross-Channel rail link to try to stem record numbers of asylum seekers slipping into Britain. President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Tony Blair, after a day of talks, also called for wider European efforts to tackle the trafficking. France said it would try to ratify by June a pact allowing French and British immigration officers to check passengers boarding the Eurostar train in Paris.       (Reuters)    NORTHERN IRELAND: FIRM AGAINST SINN FEIN -- David Trimble, first minister of the Northern Ireland Assembly and leader of the province's largest Protestant party, said he would continue to bar ministers from Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, from attending cross-border meetings with their counterparts in the Irish government because of the I.R.A.'s refusal to begin disarming. A Belfast High Court judge ruled the ban unlawful last month, but Mr. Trimble is appealing the decision.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: 3 Agencies Announce Expansion Moves
abstract: Kupper Parker Communications acquires Christopher Thomas Associates; Wolf Group acquires National Yellow Pages Marketing Programs; Diversified Agency Services unit of Omnicom Group acquires Matthews Media Group (S)

headline: MOVING ON; White Hairs Settle In Among the Ivy
abstract: Ithaca College in Ithaca, NY, and Longview residential complex, a retirement community, form partnership aimed at improving lives of older adults and education of younger ones; students and faculty engage residents in research projects and other activities, and residents receive college ID cards that enable them to spend as much time as they want on campus and audit up to two courses a semester at no cost; photo (M)

headline: Financial Executive Is Named at Viacom
abstract: Viacom names Richard J Bressler as chief financial officer, succeeding Fredric G Reynolds, who will run CBS television station group (S)

headline: In the wake of a sales setback, Sprite's advertising is revised.
abstract: Coca-Cola Co revamps advertising for its lemon-lime soft drink Sprite for first time in almost seven years, after rare drop in brand's sales and market share; Sprite remains 5th on list of national brands, with 6.6 percent market share, drop of 0.2 percentage points; photos (M)

headline: Giving So Little That It Hurts
abstract: Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter are ridiculed for donating 'only' $75,000 and $90,000, respectively, to Save the Children Foundation at London bankers' charity event; Citibank, at $390,000, was top donor (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Corrections of details in Jan 21 article about Evergreen Capital Growth fund

headline: Putin Tells Schroder He'll Pay Soviet Debt
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder ends visit to Moscow; gets pledge from Pres Vladimir V Putin that Russia will pay debts of former Soviet Union; about $20 billion of $48 billion in Soviet-era debt is held by Germany (S)

headline: Vivendi to Create a Channel After Selling Eurosport Stake
abstract: Saudi Arabia and its partners in six-member Gulf Cooperation Council call for oil output cuts at OPEC's next meeting on Jan 17 in order to raise prices (M)

headline: Scanning For Dollars By Middlemen; Medical Brokers Are Cited In Auto Insurance Costs
abstract: Investigators say medical brokers are behind growing number of abusive and often fraudulent charges in treatment of auto accident victims in Florida; across country, fraud and abuse in diagnostic imaging, one of most expensive and common medical procedures for auto accident victims, is major reason injury claims in several states are rising at three times rate of medical costs in general; nationwide fraud and abuse related to medical treatment for auto accident victims cost insurers about $5.4 billion a year and add average of nearly $35 to annual cost of every car insurance policy; lawsuits involving Advanced Imaging Center in Clermont, Fla, and Hartford Financial Services Group discussed; chart; photos (M)

headline: Macedonian Forces Dig In Against Albanian Rebels
abstract: Army and police troops take up positions in Tetovo, second largest city in Macedonia, to fire on ethnic Albanian rebels in surrounding hills for fourth consecutive day; streets are deserted and shops closed; German peacekeeping troops, in Macedonia as backup for peacekeeping mission in neighboring Kosovo, pull out of their base in Tetovo after being fired on; Macedonian soldiers' move to center of town frightens residents, who fear that troop presence will draw fire of rebels; thousands of people have fled city; photo; map (M)

headline: Stalking New Hot Trends Along the Lycos Trail
abstract: Aaron Schatz of Lycos, Internet search portal owned by Terra Lycos, tracks what millions of people search for on Internet, and then writes daily report that spots trends, called Lycos 50; he also compiles regular lists of most-searched-for terms; photo (M)

headline: DECISION IN CZECH MEDIA FIGHT
abstract: International arbitration court rules that Vladimir Zelezny must repay $23 million to his former employer, Central European Media Enterprises; CNTS, a Media Enterprises subsidiary, operated TV Nova in Czech Repulic with Zelezny until it fired him as station's general director in April 1999; Zelezny, who owns broadcast license for station, started broadcasting without CNTS, depriving it of all income; photo (M)

headline: Tax-Law Shift Gives Investors Tricky Choice On Asset Sales
abstract: Investors face tricky choice on whether to take advantage of change in tax law that lowers top capital gains rate on assets held for more than five years to 18 percent; for investors in 28 percent or higher tax bracket, new law allows 18 percent maximum tax rate only for assets acquired in 2001 and after; investor may make 'deemed sale' at value of asset on Jan 1 and then buy asset back at same price; then tax would be owed on 'profit' taken by investor, but later gains in asset, assuming it was held for five more years, would be taxed at lower 18 percent tax rate (M)

headline: Technology-Wary Investors, Once Scorned, Gain Respect
abstract: Effects on investor behavior of technology market turned sour are tangible; advocates of diversification are no longer dismissed as losers who do not get the new economy; champions of technology stocks are taking back seat as high-tech shares collapse; even on Internet message boards, wellspring of so much of fervor for technology investing, debate has been shifting; new focus is on macro issues, not for next hot stock or next hot trend; photo (M)

headline: Another Ingredient In Alphabet Soup: VCD
abstract: Q. What is a VCD?    A. VCD stands for video compact disk, and as the name implies, it is a format for storing movies on the familiar five-inch compact disks. Like an audio CD, a single VCD can hold 74 or 80 minutes' worth of data. A VCD is different from a DVD (digital video disc), both in terms of capacity and the compression technology used.

headline: Saving for College, And Watching the Clock
abstract: Denton Taylor letter comments on Jan 28 article concerning sales of equity assets in order to fund children's college educations

headline: Article 2001020891687809530 -- No Title
abstract: In Tapping the Net, the F.B.I. Insists Privacy Is Not a Victim

headline: France Télécom Trims Price Of Shares in Orange Offering
abstract: France Telecom cuts price range again on pending offering of shares in Orange PLC, its wireless unit; offering may now yield as little as 6.5 billion euros ($6.04 billion), less than half what France Telecom originally expected (M)

headline: Digital Doctoring; The Race Is On to Put a Computer Into Every Physician's Hand
abstract: Thousands of doctors are turning to hand-held computers for professional assistance in first wave of technology innovation many doctors predict will save lives and money; are mainly using devices so far for reference, writing prescriptions and keeping track of billing data; may eventually use them in wireless networks that could yield enormous cost savings for doctors, health plans and insurers by reducing paperwork and expensive delays in approvals and payments; possible drawbacks include further blurring of ethics and privacy boundaries; at least 50 companies, mostly start-ups are responding to trend toward digital doctoring; tables of companies developing applications; photos (M)

headline: Denial for Chiquita Woes
abstract: European Commission spokesman says long-running dispute over Europe's banana import quota system is not responsible for forcing Chiquita Brands International toward bankruptcy; Chiquita says quotas have cost it $1.3 billion in lost sales, and it has criticized Clinton administration for not forcing Europe to open up its banana market (S)

headline: Chips, Plain and Fancy
abstract: Rachel Bernstein letter comments on David Pogue's Dec 28 column about the new Pentium 4 chip

headline: Business Failures Climb in Japan
abstract: Bankruptcies in Japan climbed in December 2000 to second-highest level since economic collapse in 1989 and, given bleak outlook for the economy and financial system, insolvency is likely to continue apace; bankrupt corporations had $205 billion in unpaid debt; this occurred despite intense campaign by banks to waive debt of politically well-connected corporations (M)

headline: From Under a Couch, an Effort to Stop Ukraine Corruption
abstract: Mikola Melnichenko, a Ukrainian security officer, says he placed tape-recorder under couch of Pres Leonid D Kuchma in order to expose corruption and 'nastiness' that have followed Soviet collapse; charges that Kuchma has pocketed $1 billion for personal or political use; says US intelligence services helped to support democracy in Ukraine, which is recipient of $2 billion in US aid, and to investigate corruption, but that evidence was covered up by Kuchma to protect oligarchs who finance his rule; photo (M)

headline: Federal Tax Agents Arrest 4 Tied to Suspected Fake Trust
abstract: Federal tax agents raid offices across country and arrest four leaders of what Justice Department describes as money laundering and tax-evasion operation whose clients range from small-business owners to drug dealers; raids, against Anderson's Ark & Associates, are latest in renewed Internal Revenue Service crackdown on sellers of fake trusts, especially those that operate offshore; Justice Department arrests Keith Anderson, his brother, Wayne, Karolyn Grossnickle and Richard Marks (M)

headline: Long Waits, and Longer
abstract: Michael Miles letter on Dec 28 Online Shopper column on buying food for a party online; says there is no point in online shopping if it requires extensive contact with customer service over the phone or in person; cartoon

headline: Mideast Talks End With Gain But No Accord
abstract: Senior Israeli and Palestinian officials conclude nearly a week of stop-and-start negotiations in Taba, Egypt, by saying jointly that they they have 'never been closer to reaching' a final peace accord but lack sufficient time to conclude one before Israeli elections on Feb 6; Prime Min Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat, Palestinian leader, may meet within days in Stockholm (M)

headline: NEC WILL USE AMD CHIPS IN FOREIGN PC'S
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices says NEC Corp will use its Athlon and Duron processors in PowerMate DT commercial desktop computers (S)

headline: British Insurer Agrees to Buy U.S. Company
abstract: Prudential PLC, Britain's second-largest life insurer, agrees to buy American General for $26.5 billion in stock in largest insurance deal ever; combination will create huge power in US in variable annuities, fixed annuities and life insurance and it will be yet another instance of European insurers moving into lucrative market for retirement investments as more Americans approach retirement age; merged company will continue to do business as American General and Jackson National Life, which Prudential bought earlier; chart; photo (M)

headline: Boeing's Planned Jetliner to Be Almost Supersonic
abstract: Boeing Co plans new airplane that will fly just shy of speed of sound, or about 20 percent faster than current jets; twin-engine jet, called Sonic Cruiser or 20XX, will have double delta-shaped wing somewhat reminiscent of supersonic Concorde; will seat 175 to 250 passengers, fly at higher altitudes than conventional jets and save about one hour for every 3,000 miles it travels; Boeing decides to halt work on stretched version of 747, which was intended to compete with 550-seat superjumbo jet form Airbus Industrie, and focus instead on new-generation Sonic Cruiser; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Rebooted Any Good Books Lately?
abstract: IN 1938, the first modern American paperback was test-marketed by Pocket Books. The paperback, "The Good Earth" by Pearl S. Buck, was printed on poor-quality paper, the type forced readers to squint, and the binding was flimsy. Despite the drawbacks, the test was a success. Within a year paperbacks from several publishers were flooding the market.

headline: Rwanda and Uganda Begin Pulling Troops From Congo
abstract: In major step toward peace in Congo, armies of Rwanda and Uganda pull back soldiers from front-line positions with expectation that other combatants will do same soon; Rwanda and Uganda, which are two of six outside nations fighting in Congo, make clear they are not withdrawing their forces entirely; but their latest moves are most hopeful sign since August 1999, when most combatants signed accord they all promptly ignored; foreign diplomats react cautiously to latest events, warning of many failures in past; photo; map (M)

headline: LETSBUYIT IN BANKRUPTCY
abstract: Dutch Internet retailer LetsBuyIt.com, which asked for temporary court protection from creditors Jan 2, less than six months after it went public, says it has filed for full-scale bankruptcy proceedings (S)

headline: IN POLICY CHANGE, GREENSPAN BACKS A BROAD TAX CUT
abstract: Federal Reserve chmn Alan Greenspan gives his blessing to substantial tax cut, but warns that it should not be so big that it would plunge government back into deficit if federal budget surplus fails to materialize as projected, Senate Budget Committee hearing; contends improvements in economy's long-term potential and swelling surplus projections have 'reshaped the choices and opportunities before us' to permit combination of debt reduction and tax cuts; says that economy has all but stopped growing; photo (L)

headline: PARK PLACE SHARES FALL 16% ON NEWS OF WEAKER PROFIT
abstract: Park Place Entertainment, world's largest casino operator, says that, on operating basis, it will break even in fourth quarter because of lower casino winnings in Las Vegas and poor weather in other markets (S)

headline: Era Waning, Holbrooke Takes Stock
abstract: Richard C Holbrooke reflects on his 17 months as US ambassador to United Nations, including his success in persuading other member countries to restructure assessment of UN dues (M)

headline: Adrift in the Balkans
abstract: NATO is floundering in Balkans, reaping consequences of refusal to deal seriously with problems and aspirations of Albanians it went to war to protect, news analysis; failure to confront armed, organized Albanians fighting to drive non-Albanians out of Kosovo, Serbia, and to enlarge province and make it independent has allowed them to grow into serious regional threat; ouster of Pres Slobodan Milosevic, once blamed for instability in Balkans, has created new difficulties and uncertainties; photos; map (M)

headline: Software Maker Reports Counterfeit Shares
abstract: MindArrow Systems, small Internet software company, says more than one million shares, or 10 percent of shares outstanding, were counterfeited by its former stock transfer agent, RTT Transfer; founders agree to donate $5 million of their own shares to cover counterfeiting (M)

headline: POSTAL SERVICE AND FEDEX SEEN CLOSE TO AN AGREEMENT
abstract: US Postal Service and FedEx Corp are nearing agreement on highly anticipated delivery alliance (S)

headline: AT&T Receives a Reprieve on a Deadline to Shed Some Holdings
abstract: Federal Communications Commissions grants AT&T's bid to suspend May 19 deadlines for either selling 25.5 percent stake in Time Warner Entertainment or spinning off its interest in Liberty Media; bid followed Federal appeals court decision throwing out FCC rules barring any cable television company from serving more than 30 percent of cable and satellite market's subscribers; decision boosts AT&T in talks to sell assets (M)

headline: In Tapping Net, F.B.I. Insists Privacy Is Not a Victim
abstract: QUANTICO, Va. -- AS long as there have been law enforcement agents, they have tried to listen in on what the bad guys are planning.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: AIRCLIC, Blue Bell, Pa., named Phillip J. Riese chief executive. He had been head of OptiMark.    COLT TELECOM GROUP, London, named Peter Manning, chief operating officer, to the post of chief executive. He succeeds Paul Chisholm, who resigned.

headline: MEDIA: New Risks and Venues Emerge in a Multifaceted Business; In an About-Face, CNN Turns to News Talk Shows to Polish Its Ratings
abstract: CNN's switch to talk programs from highly produced network-style programs is seen as step in right direction in view of mounting competition from Fox News Channel and MSNBC; photo (M)

headline: DOUBLECLICK CUTS 2001 PROFIT FORECAST
abstract: Doubleclick, biggest Internet advertising company, says it broke even in fourth quarter, on operating basis, beating analysts' expectations; company lost $104 million in quarter, compared with loss of $42 million year earlier; revenue increased 41 percent, to $132 million; company cuts its estimate for profits in 2001 by 4 cents a share, to 7 to 9 cents a share (S)

headline: Personal Business; 529: Advanced College Savings Plans for Families
abstract: Savings for college education is made easier by 529 plans offered by almost every state, including prepaid tuition plans and investment programs, which have become more flexible and now offer more investment choices; photo (M)

headline: Pilots at Delta Set Vote on Option to Strike
abstract: Pilots at Delta Air Lines say they will vote on whether to give their union leaders option to call strike against air carrier (S)

headline: S.E.C. Action on Mutual Fund Boards
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission adopts rules intended to increase number of independent directors on boards of mutual funds and to make them better able to protect shareholders' interests (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DELPHI AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS CORP., Troy, Mich., the largest automotive parts maker in the world, said it had formed a new markets unit to increase sales outside the auto industry. The new unit would include parts for farm and construction equipment.    ARGOSY EDUCATION GROUP, Chicago, the nation's largest for-profit provider of doctoral level programs, said it had exercised its option to purchase the John Marshall Law School, which it has managed since August 1999, and would restate its financial results for the year ended Aug. 31 and the quarter ended Nov. 30, to reflect that acquisition.

headline: Russia Calls Expulsions by U.S. Hostile Act and Vows to Retaliate
abstract: Russian government denounces expulsion of about 50 of its diplomats from United States as 'hostile' act and vows 'adequate' retaliation; Foreign Min Igor S Ivanov makes clear that equal number of Americans will soon be expelled from Russia; expulsions, exchanges and threats revive cold war tone that has been largely absent between Washington and Moscow since Soviet Union disintegrated in 1991, and signals marked departure by Bush administration from Pres Clinton's policies of engagement with Russia; American officials say four Russians ordered out immediately had been involved in handling Robert Philip Hanssen, FBI agent who has been charged with spying for Moscow for many years; say other 46 are Russian intelligence officers; say Washington station chief of Russian intelligence service has not been expelled because he operates openly and was not directly involved in Hanssen case; photo; chart outlining fallout after previous spy scandals (M)

headline: Yale Pressed to Help Cut Drug Costs in Africa
abstract: Doctors Without Borders adopts new tactics in efforts to drive down price of AIDS medicines, asking Yale University to permit South Africa to import generic version of d4T antiretroviral drug manufactured by Bristol-Myers Squibb, but on which it holds patent; university, which receives $40 million annually in licensing fees, reportedly removes all barriers to Bristol-Myers making drug available in South Africa (M)

headline: Negotiations on Buying Dome in London Falter
abstract: Legacy, Irish real estate group bidding for beleaguered Millennium Dome in London, hits snag in negotiations with British government over profit-sharing proposal; group has bid 125 million pounds ($184 million) to turn site into high-tech business park; photo (M)

headline: BUILDER TO BID FOR RIVAL
abstract: British construction company Persimmon PLC considers bidding $776 million for rival Beazer Group; Beazer has proposed merger with Bryant Group (S)

headline: Vanguard Hires Y.& R. For Research Project
abstract: Vanguard Group, mutual funds marketer, names New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising to handle research project (S)

headline: American's Bid for T.W.A. Gets Help in Federal Court
abstract: Judge Sue L Robinson approves $200 million emergency loan from American Airlines to ailing Trans World Airlines; grants TWA's request for $15 million bonus plan to keep top employees; approves provisions favorable to American that opponents say would make mounting competing bid for TWA difficult; rebuffs objections from Carl C Icahn, Continental Airlines and Northwest Airlines; sends case to bankruptcy court; TWA asks bankruptcy court to nullify contract that gives Icahn right to buy millions of dollars worth of TWA tickets at 45 percent discount (M)

headline: Microsoft's Future, In Court and The Markets
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin interview with Goldman Sachs analyst Richard G Sherlund on prospects of Microsoft Corp in view of ongoing ntitrust litigation; photo (M)

headline: Fund Aimed at Wealthy Will Be Dissolved
abstract: Scudder Weisel Capital, joint venture of Zurich Scudder Investments, mutual fund company, and Thomas Weisel Partners, San Francisco investment bank, is being dissolved; venture was formed in December (S)

headline: G.M. Reports Sharp Drop in Profits
abstract: Balancing a softening in sales with a ratcheting up of productivity, the General Electric Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 16 percent even though revenue gained only 6 percent. But the company also said layoffs were likely.

headline: Why Purchasing Agents Turned Out to Be Hard to Herd
abstract: Curious Internet invention called B-to-B marketplace, or exchange, promised to bring together corporate buyers and sellers in various industries to erase inefficiencies from their transactions; now many marketplaces are dead and others are growing, but very slowly; such marketplaces appear to work better in theory than in practice; transactions and shortcomings of system described; brief histories of three exchanges that did not survive; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001022493647777711 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Insurer Plans A Large Rise In Auto Rates
abstract: American International Group is seeking increases of 10 percent or more in its auto insurance rates, continuing trend begun year ago in industry (M)

headline: Amtrak Chooses A New Agency
abstract: Amtrak selects New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide as agency for its advertising account, which has been handled for more than 25 years by DDB Worldwide; billings estimated at more than $35 million (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: KOUCHNER RESUMES POST  Bernard Kouchner,  the outspoken former United Nations chief adminstrator in Kosovo, has gotten his old job back as France's health minister. Dr. Kouchner -- a physician who was co-founder of Doctors Without Borders -- had been health minister for two years when he left for Kosovo in July 1999, soon after NATO troops entered the Serbian province after the bombing campaign to end the oppression of ethnic Albanians.    Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

headline: Fox Says It Made Pair in 'Temptation Island' Leave for Lying
abstract: Couple participating in Temptation Island, much-debated new reality televison show on Fox network, were forced to leave show while it was being filmed in September because they lied to network and production company about their being parents of child; premise of show is that four unmarried couples in long-term relationships are sent to tropical island where they go on series of dates with group of singles chosen to be especially enticing as a test (M)

headline: SHARE SALE DISCLOSED
abstract: Florian Haffa, former chief financial officer of EM.TV and Merchandising, sold shares twice last year in company, which owns rights to the Muppets and other children's TV program; shares were worth total of 34 million marks ($16.2 million) Haffa is brother of EM.TV's chief executive, Thomas Haffa, who has acknowledged that he sold shares last year; brothers face insider-trading investigation by German securities regulators and at least eight shareholder suits accusing Thomas Haffa of not telling investors early enought about EM.TV's declining profit outlook (S)

headline: Doubts on Whether Kabila's Son Can Lead Congo
abstract: There are rising doubts whether Joseph Kabila, son of slain Congo Pres Laurent D Kabila, can lead Congo; Joseph Kabila is small, soft-spoken man with little military and no political experience; he has grown up and been educated outside Congo, does not speak national language and is expected to face potentially explosive power struggle from moment his father's body is put in ground next week; photos; map (L)

headline: The Dot-Com Jobless, at Play
abstract: Ellin Abby column reports that a lot of workers laid off in technology sector are reveling in their free time, something they did not appreciate working marathon hours in their former jobs; drawing (M)

headline: Marconi Chooses Grey Worldwide
abstract: Marconi Communications in London, worldwide telecommunications equipment maker, names Grey Worldwide to handle its advertising account, which had been with Athorn, Clark & Partners since August 1999; billings estimated at $50 million (S)

headline: Nafta's Powerful Little Secret; Obscure Tribunals Settle Disputes, but Go Too Far, Critics Say
abstract: Environmental, consumer, labor and other groups opposed to North American Free Trade Agreement say their worst fears about anonymous government have been realized in small group of international tribunals that are charged with protecting rights of foreign investors under treaty; assail sweeping powers and broad impact of these panels, along with their very nature--ad hoc panels drawn from lists of academics and international lawyers almost unknown outside their highly specialized fields; panels have become powerful shields for investors against governments of country where they have made their investments; photos (L)

headline: Fears of Mad Cow Disease Reach Bullfighting Rings
abstract: Shadow of mad-cow disease now looms over bullfights in Spain, where some 40,000 animals are slaughtered each year, producing more than $10 million of prized meat; no case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy has ever been detected in bull from the ring, but fears of losing money from mad-cow disease are already stalking matadors and especially breeders and impresarios who organize bullfights; photo (L)

headline: For TV and the Net, a Marriage Made in Vegas
abstract: Mike and Carol Mulanax, owners of Las Vegas-area UHF television station KEEN-TV, expand station's reach by plugging its signal into Internet; they now get worldwide audience; it is not the first station to disseminate its signal over Internet, but it is one of the first to offer picture, sound and interactivity through a streaming technology; photos (M)

headline: China's Prime Minister Pledges to Promote Private Enterprise
abstract: Beijing, March 5 - Prime Minister Zhu Rongji unveiled China's 10th Five-Year Plan today, promising that the country would forge ahead with the introduction of market forces and private enterprise. He said the Government would continue its program of large-scale investment's in the country's infrastructure and other forms of economic stimulus. He also predicted an annual growth rate of 7 percent in the years ahead, somewhat lower than in the previous five years.

headline: U.S. Economic Ills Spell Risk Abroad
abstract: Faltering US economy is not just domestic problem because America has so dominated world economy over last seven years that nations have come to depend on rising demand for products; fear abounds that, as US economic engine sputters, world financial problems will increase, creating diplomatic problems for Bush administration; graph illustrates exports to US from abroad (M)

headline: Italian Concern Is Acquiring French Internet Business
abstract: Tiscali of Italy agrees to buy its French Internet rival Liberty Surf for $615 million in cash and stock; Internet-access business has been fragmented in Europe, in contrast to US where America Online; Tiscali will buy shares in Liberty Surf that are held by British retailer Kingfisher and EuropatWeb; photo (M)

headline: M.I.T. Performs A Hat Trick In Recruiting
abstract: Massachusetts Institute of Technology hires three of most sought-after doctoral students in finance as professors; they are Antoinette Schoar of Germany, Jun Pan of China and Anna Pavlova of Russia; photo (M)

headline: Chief of Internet Company To Head Newell Rubbermaid
abstract: Joseph Galli resigns as VerticalNet chief executive to join Newell Rubbermaid as chief executive; VerticalNet chief operating officer Michael Hagan will succeed Galli (M)

headline: Traces of Plutonium Found in NATO Arms
abstract: GENEVA—  Two laboratories have confirmed finding "very low" traces of plutonium in rounds of depleted uranium weapons fired by NATO warplanes over Kosovo two years ago, the UN environment agency said Friday.

headline: SHELL RAISES FLETCHER BID
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Apache Corp raise their joint bid for Fletcher Energy to $1.67 billion, 4.4 percent increase, to thwart competing bid by Guinness Peat Group (S)

headline: Oracle Meets Lowered Forecast but Sees Worse Times Ahead
abstract: Oracle Corp reports earnings for its fiscal third quarter of 10 cents per share, on revenue of $2.7 billion, compared with earnings of 8 cents per share on revenue of $2.4 billion year ago; forecasts worse times ahead (M)

headline: Hong Kong Will Check on Falun Gong
abstract: Hong Kong's top official, Tung Chee-hwa, says he is shocked by television images of what Beijing says are members of Falun Gong setting themselves on fire in Tiananmen Square, and that Hong Kong will more closely monitor group, which is outlawed in China but remains legal in Hong Kong; his comments are closely scrutinized, because he has not spoken publicly about Falun Gong since it held conference in Hong Kong at which China's treatment of Falun Gong was protested (M)

headline: Article 2001032192951580101 -- No Title
abstract: March 21, 2001

headline: Honors
abstract: Alex Blum is re-elected chairman of Association of Independent Commercial Producers; Alfred Califano is re-elected vice chairman (S)

headline: ADVANCED MICRO IS SEEKING PARTNER FOR $4 BILLION PLANT
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc, Intel Corp's main rival in computer microprocessor market, plans to find partner and build new factory costing as much as $4 billion by 2004 (S)

headline: Action for Fans and the Simply Curious
abstract: Charles Herold reviews two computer games: NHL Faceoff 2001 from Sony and NBA 2K1 from Sega of America; photos (M)

headline: Barnesandnoble.com to Cut 350 Jobs as Its Loss Widens
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com Inc., the No. 2 Web-based bookseller after Amazon.com, announced today that it would eliminate about 350 jobs in an effort to cut costs.

headline: EBAY TO BUY KOREA'S INTERNET AUCTION
abstract: EBay Inc will pay about $120 million in cash to buy control of Internet Auction Co, South Korea's largest online auction company (S)

headline: An Anxious Wait
abstract: For the thousands of Gujarati immigrants in New York, it was a day when telephone calls did not get through and hopes hung on scraps of information about relatives and friends in the devastated area. For one merchant in Jackson Heights, Queens, hours of dialing finally brought good news about his father.     Article, Page A6.

headline: ICEBOX CALLING IT QUITS
abstract: Icebox, Los Angeles-based Internet company that produced some of most popular animated entertainment distributed on Web, is shutting down; drawing (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARE INTEL CUTS CHIP PRICES Intel slashed prices on its fastest microprocessors yesterday, trying to clear out older product lines to speed the transition to its new Pentium 4 chip. Intel, the leading maker of chips for personal computers, cut the price of its one-gigahertz Pentium III by 42 percent, to $268 from $465, when bought in batches of 1,000. Slower Pentium III chips were reduced 20 percent to 31 percent. Computer manufacturers buy the chips to power their machines. An Intel spokesman said the company hoped to be shipping more Pentium 4 chips than Pentium III's by the end of this year. To accelerate the transition, Intel also discounted the Pentium 4 processor, released in November, 18 percent to 21 percent. Chris Gaither (NYT)

headline: Renewed Hope for Peace Talks as Arafat Returns to Mideast
abstract: The Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, flew back to the Middle East today, trailed by reports that he was prepared to accept, but with reservations, the framework for negotiating a peace accord proposed by President Bill Clinton.

headline: MediaTalk; Television Meets Reality In a Drama on Pardons
abstract: NBC promotional spot for this week's episode of The West Wing deals with issue of Presidential pardons (S)

headline: SEND.COM FOLDS ITS TENT
abstract: Send.com, online gift-giving service, will cease operations and close (S)

headline: Bertelsmann to Take Over Broadcaster for $9 Billion
abstract: Bertelsmann AG takes control of Europe's biggest television broadcaster, RTL Group, in stock transaction worth about $9 billion; acquires 30 percent stake from Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, far-flung holding company controlled by Belgian financier Albert Frere; deal solidifies Bertelmann's position as top of European broadcasting, increasing its stake in RTL to 67 percent from 37 percent; RTL owns 22 television stations and 18 radio stations around Europe (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas prices rise on expectations that colder weather in Midwest will increase demand; in New York, natural gas for March delivery rises 67.3 cents, or 11.8 percent, to $6.38 for one million BTU's; graph; chart (S)

headline: Intel Warning and Jobs Report Help Send Stocks Sharply Lower
abstract: Stocks fall sharply, as investors digest Intel earnings warning and February jobs report; Dow Jones Industrial Average falls 213.63, or 2 percent, to 10,644.62; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops to 1,233.42, down 31.32, or 2.5 percent; Nasdaq composite index loses 115.95, or 5.4 percent, to close at 2,052.78; bond prices are pushed down by surprisingly-strong jobs report; yield on 10-year Treasury note rises to 4.94 percent, its price falling 5/32 to 100 16/32; graphs; list of key interest rates (M)

headline: India's Extended Families Help Orphans of the Quake
abstract: Estimated 3,000 children orphaned by massive earthquake in Gujarat State, India, are finding new homes with relatives in keeping with nation's tradition of close family ties and are becoming reminders of those who died and symbols of those who survived (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bristol-Myers Seen in Pact On Gene-Drug Technology  With pharmaceutical companies frustrated that patents on genes are impeding their drug development efforts, Bristol-Myers Squibb has teamed up with a company called Athersys, which says it can circumvent these patents.    The pact, which executives say will be announced by Athersys today, comes amid a rush to patent genes that are being discovered at a breathtaking pace using genomics technology. In many cases, patents have been granted even though the medical relevance of the gene is not yet known. [Page C2.]

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence/Jan.

headline: TURKEY'S MARKET CALMS DOWN
abstract: Turkey's stock market steadies after costly damage from unprecedented clash between Prime Min Bulent Ecevit and Pres Ahmet Necdet Sezer; two officials had row over ways of fighting corruption; nation's news media berated both leaders for causing crisis that cost country billions of dollars as foreign investors pulled out of Turkey and cost of government borrowing soared (S)

headline: Smelling the Coffee
abstract: Will Waller letter comments on Jan 25 Online Shopper column on buying coffee over the Web; photo

headline: Navy Postpones Inquiry in Sinking Until March 5
abstract: Navy delays to Mar 5 public court inquiry into sinking of Japanese fishing trawler Ehime Maru by nuclear submarine Greeneville at request of Cmdr Scott D Waddle's civilian lawyer, who says he needs time to prepare case (M)

headline: Vin and Sprit In Talks Over Vodka Rights
abstract: Vin and Sprit begins final negotiations with Fortune Brands and Maxxium, consortium of liquor companies, for distribution rights to Absolut vodka; Seagram Co has held rights since 1994 but will lose them once purchase of Seagram's beverage assets by Diageo and Pernod Ricard SA is complete later this year (M)

headline: SYBASE BUYING NEW ERA OF NETWORKS
abstract: Sybase Inc., a maker of database software, agreed to buy New Era of Networks Inc. for about $373 million in stock to acquire New Era's programs for linking incompatible computer systems. Each common share of New Era, known as Neon, will be converted into 0.3878 share of Sybase common stock. That is about $9.50 a share, based on Sybase's closing price of $24.50 today. Neon shareholders would get a premium of about 37 percent; Neon stock last traded today at $6.94, up $1.19, before it was halted on Nasdaq. The shares have fallen about 91 percent in the last year. Sybase, based in Emeryville, Calif., said Neon would broaden its products aimed at doing business over the Internet. Sybase said that it expects the acquisition to be completed in the second quarter and to add to its earnings next year.

headline: Tempers Flare and Losses Mount After Canada Bans Brazil Beef
abstract: Anger at Canada is growing in Brazil over Canadian ban on Brazilian beef as export losses mount and doubts abound over Canada's motives; Canada had cited Brazil's failure to prove that its cattle are free from mad cow disease; North American Free Trade Agreement rules required United States and Mexico to follow suit, move analysts say they made reluctantly; Brazilians and some Canadians argue ban was political; note Brazil has never had documented case of disease; Canadian scientific mission is evaluating risk and may soon lift ban; Nafta accounts for only about 10 percent of Brazilian beef exports, but Brazilians fear domino effect (M)

headline: Article 2001022091519664170 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Article 2001032393668137280 -- No Title
abstract: March 23, 2001

headline: Advertising: Addenda
abstract: Kellogg Consolidates Cereal Work at Burnett

headline: NO BUYERS FOR HYUNDAI LIFE
abstract: Debt-ridden Hyundai Life Insurance Co, Hanil Life Insurance and Samshin Allstate Life Insurance fail to attract buyers in government auction, further stalling South Korea's plan to clean up its financial industry (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    YUGOSLAVIA: ROYAL RETURN -- Parliament voted to scrap a Communist-era law that stripped the former royal Karadjordjevic family of its citizenship and property, paving the way for the family to return to live in Yugoslavia. The Crown Prince Alexander, left, who has lived all his life in exile in London, has said he wants to return to Belgrade and will apply to have the royal residence, the White Palace, returned to his family. It was used by Slobodan Milosevic as his working residence.    Carlotta Gall (NYT)

headline: No Crops Spared in Colombia's Coca War
abstract: Colombian Army says its aggressive land and air assault on country's coca-growing heartland has killed quarter of all coca crops there in last six weeks, but farmers say campaign has destroyed their legal crops like yucca and plantain as well; US officials, who are providing training and financing to eradication effort, confirm army's claim; Colombian health official reports complaints about intoxication, diarrhea, vomiting, skin rashes, red eyes, headaches, especially in children, but American officials dispute such claims, saying numerous tests of the chemical being sprayed, glyphosate, have demonstrated that it cannot harm humans or animals; photos; map (M)

headline: COST CONTROL AT MICROCHIP TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Microchip Technology will cut its work force by 12 percent, or about 400 employees, and trim production by 24 percent; photo (S)

headline: Take that! Campbell Soup responds to Progresso attacks ads.
abstract: Advertising column on Campbell Soup Co's effort to stem further erosion of its lead in US canned-soup market, by responding to advertising by its principal rival, Progresso brand soups sold by Pillsbury Company unit of Diageo PLC; response takes form of three television ads prepared by BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group; photo (M)

headline: Technology Stocks Surge to Give Nasdaq Biggest Rise in Six Weeks
abstract: Technology stocks stage strongest rally in six weeks, bringing Nasdaq Composite up 2.9 percent, or 61.51, to close at 2,204.43; Dow Jones industrial average rises 0.3 percent, or 28.92, to 10,591.22; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes at 1,253.65, up 12.24, or one percent; graph (M)

headline: Raytheon Is Sued Over Deal
abstract: Washington Group International, large construction company formerly known as Morrison Knudsen, is suing Raytheon Co over losses and cost overruns at engineering unit that Washington Group acquired in 2000; is asking for $400 million from Raytheon, which has said it does not owe refund; Washington says it may file for bankruptcy court protection from its creditors because of losses and cost overruns (M)

headline: GLOBAL CROSSING ANNOUNCES SOME EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Global Crossing Ltd names David Walsh president and sole chief operating officer and announces that Gary Cohen, who was co-chief operating officer with Walsh, will become president and chief operating officer of new unit, Global Crossing Solutions (S)

headline: Dipping Into the Pool Of Amateur Analysts
abstract: StockJungle.com hopes to open new Hot Hands hedge fund by June; it will be managed by ten people hired from their message board for tipsters (M)

headline: Mayors Make Overtures as China Holds Baton
abstract: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou meets in Hong Kong with Hong Kong leader Tung Chee-hwa; is highest ranking Taiwanese official welcomed by Tung and key rival of Pres Chen Shui-bian; China, by allowing visit, boosts official who favors eventual unification with China; Chen admits China has made overtures to several leaders of his opposition party, but denies that visit will undermine Taiwanese government, interview (M)

headline: Galliano's Joyful and Juicy Nomads Bring Back That Loving Feeling : Dior:Triumph of Gypsy Romance
abstract: PARIS—  A magnificent Dior show — juicy mouthwatering colors, wild Romany romance and jaunty Irish tailoring mixed as only John Galliano knows how — brought a joyous spirit to the autumn/winter collections.

headline: Napster Suffers Setback in Appeals Court Ruling
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12 — A Federal appeals court dealt a major setback today to Napster , the start-up that has shaken the record industry by allowing millions of people to copy music free over the Internet, by largely affirming a lower-court ruling that the company encourages and abets the wholesale infringement of copyrights.

headline: Extras on Dreamcast
abstract: Eric Hunt letter replies to Jan 4 Game Theory column comparing PlayStation 2 and Dreamcast versions of Dead or Alive 2

headline: No Heavy Lifting: Making a Move With the Net's Help
abstract: Jodi Mardesich article on her use of Internet to find a moving service to transport his belongings accross North America; listing of moving sites on Web; drawing (M)

headline: RYANAIR POSTS HIGHER PROFIT
abstract: Irish budget airline Ryanair Holdings reports 42 percent increase in third-quarter profit, to 21.3 million euros ($20 million); graph (S)

headline: Financial Role Reversal
abstract: Nancy Newlin letter responds to Jan 14 article about older persons remaining in workforce

headline: Questions on Firings and Severance at Computer Associates
abstract: Fired workers at Computer Associates say company is disguising mass layoff as individual firings of subpar employees to avoid paying severance; labor lawyers say if it lacks documentation for firings, company might also have opened itself to lawsuits that argue that firings were discriminatory; company says firings were routine and that it did nothing wrong; since November, company has fired hundreds of workers around world; it will not disclose how many people have been let go, or whether its overall work force of about 18,000 has grown or shrunk in that time (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: Reversing Decades-Long Trend, Americans Retiring Later in Life
abstract: For nearly a century, Americans were able to retire at ever-younger ages and in greater prosperity. But over the last few years, they have begun staying on the job later into life.

headline: SINGTEL BID FOR OPTUS
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications offers $8.8 billion for Optus, Australian unit of Cable and Wireless (S)

headline: OIL PIPELINE PROGRESSES
abstract: Governments of Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan and Turkey sign memorandum of understanding that will allow Kazakhstan's growing oil industry to participate in 1,040-mile pipeline to be built from Baku, Azerbaijan, Ceyhan on Mediterranean coast of Turkey over next three years; analysts say agreement makes more viable proposed one-million-barrel-a-day pipeline, favored by US over other proposed routes through Russia or Iran; A Elizabeth Jones, senior US State Department officer, signs agreement as witness (S)

headline: New Economy; Two pioneers in the study of e-business are creating a new cyberlab. And no one is calling them crazy anymore.
abstract: Vanderbilt University will help underwrite new eLab, center proposed by Prof Donna L Hoffman and Prof Thomas P Novak that will give researchers chance to study way people interact with Web sites as they surf; if it works, eLab could be first research tool to really get at what makes people tick--and click--online; photo (M)

headline: Syrian Leader Weds Computer Scientist
abstract: Pres Bashar al-Assad of Syria reportedly marries Asma Akhras, young Syrian woman who grew up in London and holds degree in computer science (S)

headline: As Law Firms Scramble for New Talent, The New Talent Reaps the Rewards
abstract: Shortage of legal talent in United States means that law school students can get jobs as summer associates at law firms and practically be assured of permanent offers later, at starting salaries of up to $125,000 among Manhattan firms; in most recent survey of starting salaries by National Assn for Law Placement, median was $40,000 in firms of 2 to 10 lawyers and $97,000 in firms of more than 500; photo; graph (M)

headline: Seasoning Fans Religious Tension in Indonesia
abstract: Muslim authorities accuse Ajinomoto Co, big food concern based in Tokyo, of using pork products forbidden under Muslim law in popular food seasoning, despite labeling to contrary; accusations have added to country's simmering religious tensions; police detain eight Ajinomoto executives, including Japanese president of its Indonesian subsidiary, for questioning, and factory near Jakarta is closed while store employees across predominantly Islamic archipelago pull bags of monosodium glutamate from shelves; Pres Abdurrahman Wahid tries to ease situation after meeting with Japanese justice minister, Masahiko Komura; photo (M)

headline: C.I.A. Chief Sees Russia Trying to Revive Its Challenge to U.S.
abstract: Director of central intelligence, George J Tenet, gives Senate committee his annual review of global threats facing US, warning that Russia is using international trade in weapons and technology to improve relations with China, India and Iran while trying to revive its status as great power and challenge American influence; says nature and structure of anti-American terrorism has radically changed over last few years and is now dominated by independent and decentralized groops like Osama bin Laden's al-Qaeda; also warns of threats from proliferation of weapons of mass destruction in flashpoints like Korean peninsula and Iran (M)

headline: Lowe Lintas Names U.S. Chief Executive
abstract: Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide names Paul Hammersley, chief executive at its London office, to post of chief executive for US operations, replacing Lee Garfinkel, who relinquished post in January (S)

headline: Article 2001020192440923180 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Taking Care; Another Reason To Sit Up Straight
abstract: Ergonomics researchers say that children need to adhere to the same ergonomic rules as adults when at the computer and that they have certain unique needs (M)

headline: 3 Pension Funds Sue To Halt AT&T Vote
abstract: Three union pension funds file lawsuit to block AT&T proposal that would make it easier for company to win shareholder approval of its plan to break up into four units; funds provide benefits to administrative employees of AFL-CIO and Communications Workers of America, as well as to union members (S)

headline: More Problems and Fewer Clients; Consulting Firms Are Hurting, Along With the Economy
abstract: Consulting firms face slowdown in demand for their services that mirrors slowdown in national economy; have more experts available to work on projects but fewer new projects from clients; affected firms include Accenture, McKinsey & Co, Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, PricewaterhouseCoopers and Cap Gemini Ernst & Young; photos (M)

headline: WORKERS SAID TO LOOT FAILED DOT-COM
abstract: Ebeon, Dublin-based e-commerce consultancy, is looted by its employees following shutdown (S)

headline: Charles Mérieux, 94, Vaccine Producer, Dies
abstract: Dr Charles Merieux, virologist whose visionary understanding of mass vaccine cultivation and disease-fighting logistics turned relatively modest family microbiology laboratory into international engine for public health, dies at age 94; photo (M)

headline: Some Phone Bidders Quit
abstract: Sprint Corp and Alltel Corp are among 36 wireless phone companies to drop out of federal auction of new airwaves as bid in sale exceed $12.7 billion (S)

headline: DIGITAL ISLAND AIMS TO SPEED PROFITABILITY
abstract: Digital Island Inc says it expects to break even by June 2002, two quarters earlier than expected, and is fully funded until then; cuts revenue expectations for current year and will cut captial outlays; reports losing $142.5 million in quarter ended Dec 31 (S)

headline: Saudi Arabian Police Raid Hijacked Russian Jetliner
abstract: Saudi Arabian police officers force their way into hijacked Russian jet, freeing more than 100 passengers and shooting dead one hijacker after he fatally stabs flight attendant; Turkish passenger is also reported killed in raid; plane was seized by three or four armed men as it took off from Istanbul bound for Moscow; it landed in western Saudi city of Medina; Saudi and Russian officials say hijackers are from rebellious Russian republic of Chechnya; Pres Vladimir V Putin reportedly gave his consent to Saudi authorities to storm plane; Russia's Foreign Ministry asks Saudi authorities to return hijackers to Russia, although two countries have no extradition treaty (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro rises on expectations that reports this week will show that economic growth in Europe is outpacing that of US; in New York, euro settles at 93.87 cents, up from 93.48 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: The Baby Boomers And the Collection Plate
abstract: John Gregg letter on James Schembari's Dec 24 article on his family's decision to increase its church contributions

headline: Telmex Completes Spinoff Of 2 Big Parts of Business
abstract: Telefonos de Mexico spins off its cellular and international businesses throughout Western Hemisphere to its shareholders as new company called America Movil; analysts say spinoff draws clear line between two entities whose boundaries had become blurred under same roof; chart; photo (M)

headline: Excerpts From Fed Chairman's Testimony Before Senate Budget Committee
abstract: Excerpts from testimony of Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, before Senate Budget Committee and exchanges between Greenspan and Sen Pete V Domenici, committee chairman, and Sen Paul S Sarbanes, member of committee (M)

headline: Albanian Rebels Declare a Cease-Fire in Macedonia and Ask for Talks
abstract: Armed Albanian rebels declare unilateral ceasefire and reportedly begin drawing back from villages they hold northwest of Tetovo in Macedona; they faced midnight deadline for offensive by Macedonian troops and special police; coalition government refuses rebels' offer to negotiate, calling group terrorist and saying it is dominated by ethnic Albanians from Kosovo; photo; map (M)

headline: POTOMAC ELECTRIC TO BUY DELAWARE UTILITY
abstract: Potomac Electric Power Co acquires Connectiv, utility based in Delaware, for about $5.4 billion in cash, stock and assumed debt (S)

headline: Slain Congo Leader Buried to Pomp and Confusion
abstract: Laurent Kabila, slain president of Congo, receives state funeral in Kinshasa and is buried in front of old Parlament building; military investigation has yet to reveal who was behind assassination; several government officials depart from official line that Kabila died on Jan 18, saying he was killed on Jan 16 and the announcement was held up for two days to prepare for ascension of Kabila's son, Joseph, to presidency; photo (M)

headline: Web Users Left Scrambling as Big D.S.L. Network Shuts Down
abstract: First bankruptcy of major provider of fast Internet access, NorthPoint Communications, sends more than 100,000 computer users scrambling to find new service as nationwide network shuts down; AT&T reaches $135 million deal to acquire most of NorthPoint's assets, but not its customers; AT&T cites high costs of servicing NorthPoint customers and delinquent payments by some Internet providers that were NorthPoint's main clients; NorthPoint served several big-name Internet providers, including Telocity and Microsoft Network; NorthPoint's rivals like Covad Communications and Rhythms NetConnections could pick up customers stranded by NorthPoint's closing, but these companies face problems similar to those of NorthPoint; chart; photo (M)

headline: Ex-Serb Chief Denies Guilt At Bosnia War Crimes Trial
abstract: Biljana Plavsic makes her first appearance before judges of United Nations War Crimes Tribunal in Hague, and pleads not guilty to nine counts of war crimes during Bosnian war; prosecutor and Plavsic's lawyer say she turned herself in freely and deny any suggestion that she has been promised leniency in exchange for cooperation; she is potential prime source of evidence against her former close political ally, Radovan Karadzic, Bosnian Serb wartime leader who has been indicted twice by tribunal but remains at large; Plavsic, known throughout Bosnian war as fierce Serb nationalist, broke with her wartime associates in 1997, after succeeding Karadzic as Bosnian Serb president; she lost re-election bid because she was seen as too moderate and too pro-Western; photo (M)

headline: In Letter to Bush, Putin Urges Wider U.S.-Russian Cooperation
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin proposes broader Russian-American cooperation in number of areas, letter to Pres Bush; sends note to former Pres Bill Clinton lauding his approach to Russian-American ties; Bush administration calls for political settlement of Russia's drive against separatists in Chechnya; cites credible reports of Russian abuses of civilians (M)

headline: SWISS BANK POSTS LOSS
abstract: Vontobel Holding AG, family-owned Swiss bank, fires three top executives after spending about $100 million in unsuccessful attempt to start Internet bank; earnings fall 29 percent, to $142.8 million, and shares fall 18 percent, sharpest one-day decline in more than 10 years; graph (S)

headline: Expert Says Car Weight Was Key in Tire Failures
abstract: University of California engineering associate professor Sanjay Govindjee, retained by Bridgestone/Firestone Inc, concludes that actual weight of Ford Explorer was the most crucial single factor leading to failure of tires mounted on it (M)

headline: The Unexpected Cost Of Paying Bills Late
abstract: Thirty-five percent of 800 adults surveyed by Direct Deposit and Direct Payment Coalition acknowledge having been late with at least one major credit card payment in 2000; Coalition promotes automatic electronic deposits and payments (M)

headline: Playing Musical Chairs With Airlines
abstract: Joseph B Treaster interviews CIBC World Markets analyst Julius Maldutis about current and potential merger activity within airline industry and its effects on stock prices; photo (M)

headline: Directive Says Rice, Bush Aide, Won't Be Upstaged by Cheney
abstract: Directive issued by Pres Bush gives his national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, traditional powers of her post and rejects suggestions that Vice Pres Cheney head important meetings of National Security Council because of his seniority and experience; directive means that Secretary of State Colin L Powell and Secretary of Defense Donald H Rumsfeld will sit 'deferentially' beside Rice at meetings; such directives outline who has power to get access to most important meetings on foreign policy (M)

headline: Kraft Sues Big Pizza Rival Over Loss of Trade Secrets
abstract: Kraft Foods sues Schwan's Sales Enterprises, its biggest rival in grocery pizza business, charging Schwan's improperly obtained trade secrets about its frozen pizza plans; also sues Timothy Cauley, former A C Nielsen market research firm manager who served as Kraft consultant and quit to join Schwan's; charges violation of Cauley's confidentiality accord; suit follows Dec 3 New York Times Magazine article by Marc Barry, freelance corporate intelligence agent, who said Schwan's paid him in 1997 to find out when Kraft planned to introduce new rising-crust pizza (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Medical Concern Growing Over Shortages of Drugs  Doctors, pharmacists and regulators are increasingly concerned about what they say are more frequent drug shortages. Where a few years ago a hospital might have a shortage of one or two critical drugs a year, the number in the last year has been closer to two dozen.    There is no single reason for the shortages. Some stem from the drug industry's rapid consolidation. In some cases, regulators found problems at factories making the drugs and shut down production until processes were improved. And some big drug companies have stopped making the older drugs and have instead reserved factory capacity for newer drugs, which make more money. [Page A1.]

headline: Judge Clears Way for Auditors To Be Queried in Cendant Suits
abstract: A federal judge has denied a request by Ernst & Young, the accounting firm, to delay the questioning of its personnel in civil suits stemming from the financial fraud at the Cendant Corporation.    The judge, William Walls, on Thursday cleared the way for lawyers for Cendant to question the accountants, while at the same time preventing the questioning of top Cendant officials until after the completion of the criminal trial of Walter A. Forbes and E. Kirk Shelton, formerly the chairman and vice chairman of Cendant, who are charged with financial fraud.

headline: Brazilian Company Is Hacking Its Way Up
abstract: Article profiles success of Modulo Security Solutions, Brazilian information security firm that profits by showing how quickly computer security can be breached; photo (M)

headline: Turkish Currency Falls 28% as Government Stops Defending It
abstract: ISTANBUL, Feb. 22 - Sixty-five million Turks found their national currency in a free fall today that stripped away about 28 percent of its value and sent a wave of concern through world financial markets.

headline: ACQUISITIONS INCREASE JDS LOSS
abstract: JDS Uniphase Corp, world's biggest maker of parts used in fiber optic equipment, says its fiscal second-quarter loss widened on acquisition costs; also says sales for its fiscal third quarter, which ends in March, will miss estimates, while sales for fiscal 2001 could be at low end of estimates; expects third-quarter sales to rise 7 percent to 10 percent from second quarter; graph (S)

headline: Economy Aide To the Rescue, As Argentina Fights Default
abstract: Argentina's economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, wins congressional passage of emergency financial package, lending shaky government some political relief and giving worried investors some hope that crippling default can be averted; political analysts do not expect new lease on life for Pres Fernando de la Rua, whose rumored resignation set local and neighboring stock and bond markets on harrowing ride (M)

headline: The Dividend Check Isn't in the Mail
abstract: Investors do not now give much weight to a company's dividend, failing to appreciate how much dividends can help swell a portfolio; dismissive attitude could change if long bull market, with all the attention-getting capital gains, is replaced by something more sedentary; drawing; graph (M)

headline: Agencies Expand Via Two New Units
abstract: Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners is expanding its public relations and promotion division into autonomous unit to be named Lime; Trahan, Burden & Charles in Baltimore is opening interactive division called TBCi (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Protection for Networking Systems
abstract: ITT Industries' new LANSense system can detect when cord or wire is being inserted or removed from networking system of corporation or other big organization, notify managers, issue audio warning to culprit and take his picture; photo (S)

headline: Article 2001031092600885941 -- No Title
abstract: March 10, 2001

headline: Government Joins in Suits Against Hospital Giant
abstract: Justice Department joins in eight whistle-blower lawsuits against HCA - the Healthcare Co, nation's largest hospital company, contending that company has engaged in series of schemes to defraud federal health programs of estimated $400 million; alleged misconduct includes providing improper inducements to doctors for patient referrals and improperly structuring a transaction to make Medicare pick up part of cost (M)

headline: Caterpillar Expects Lower Profit
abstract: Caterpillar Inc, largest maker of construction and earth-moving equipment, says its profit will fall and its sales will be little changed in 2001 because of slowing economy and higher spending; says fourth-quarter net income rose 10 percent, to $264 million compared with $239 million year earlier; sales rose 1.9 percent, to $5.11 billion from $5.02 billion (M)

headline: Richard Li's Company Removes Web Site Reference to Degree From Stanford : Hong Kong Tycoon's 'Diploma' Disappears
abstract: HONG KONG—  The Hong Kong Internet tycoon Richard Li has made headlines as an Asian technology wizard whose career merited comparison with that of Bill Gates.

headline: Pardon in U.S. For Marc Rich Creates Storm In Switzerland
abstract: Prominent Swiss citizens who wrote to Pres Clinton to urge pardon for Marc Rich are focus of outcry in Geneva over whether former fugitive trader bought their support for his pardon through charitible contributions; Swiss newspapers run stories detailing which prominent Swiss citizens took actions on Rich's behalf; biggest furor is over intervention of Zurich mayor, Josef Estermann (M)

headline: Not Enough Power And No Glory; California's Choices All Look Painful
abstract: Growing chorus of economists, business leaders and policy experts contends that California cannot spend its way out of current energy crisis; believes bickering politicians are delaying inevitable, unpopular certainty that retail electricity rates must rise significantly; photos; graph (M)

headline: Factory Index and Spending Show a Bit of a Rebound
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index rose to 41.9 in January, breaking string of 11 consecutive declines; Commerce Department reports personal spending on goods and services rose 0.7 percent; says incomes rose 0.6 percent in January after 0.4 percent rise month earlier; says construction spending rose 1.5 percent; association's employment index fell to 37.2 in February from 43 in January; Labor Department reports initial jobless claims rose by 39,000, to level of 372,000 last week, highest this year; graph on personal income and construction spending (M)

headline: New Blow for Telecoms:French IPO Price Is Cut
abstract: LONDON—  The outlook for Europe's heavily indebted telecommunications companies suffered a major new blow Wednesday when France Telecom was forced to slash the price of an initial public offering of shares in its Orange mobile unit by as much as 30 percent to attract buyers.

headline: BAXTER SAYS IT WILL DOUBLE CAPACITY AT SWISS PLANT
