headline: German Bank Posts Drop In Income
abstract: Deutsche Bank says net income declined slightly in fourth quarter and acknowledges that last year's huge profit from investment banking is unlikely to be repeated in year ahead; chief executive Rolf Breuer tries to reassure shareholders by outlining broad plan to streamline operations, eliminating about 2,600 jobs and increasingn bank's dividend; net income declined to 581 million euros ($544 million) from 591 million euros ($553.6 million) in year-earlier quarter (M)

headline: U.S. Vetoes Pro-Palestinian U.N. Resolution
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, March 28 — The Bush administration cast its first veto in the Security Council late Tuesday night, ending a weeklong marathon debate and decisively scuttling Palestinian hopes for a United Nations observer force in the Israeli-occupied territories in the foreseeable future.

headline: Two large agencies make adjustments in their specialty units to adapt to the needs of clients.
abstract: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and GM Mediaworks are making changes in specialty operations that underscore increasing attention being paid to how best to aim advertising at consumers most likely to respond to particular pitches; at Ogilvy & Mather, planning operations of its advertising, direct marketing and interactive agencies are being merged, under single executive, Tony Wright, who is being promoted to chief strategy and planning officer for North America; GM Mediaworks is combining operations for traditional and interactive media (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: The Quirks of Behavior, as Part of Economics
abstract: Richard Wells letter comments on Feb 11 Louis Uchitelle column on behavioral economics

headline: Brazil Flexes New Muscle In Another Trade Fight
abstract: Brazil flexes its economic muscle in trade dispute with US over patents on AIDS drugs, shedding image as easygoing and cordial; is rebutting US case before World Trade Organization which argues that Brazilian law, by forcing foreign companies to provide anti-AIDS drugs at lower prices or licensing Brazilian companies to do so in event of health emergency, violates international trade rules; says it will win not only by legal arguments and requirements of intellectual property law, but by moral dimensions of its case; runs highly successful program to fight AIDS, in part because of ability to provide drugs at prices below those charged by major pharmaceutical companies (M)

headline: Harnessing a Photon to Bring Quantum Computers Down to Size
abstract: QUANTUM computers rely on the tiniest objects and smallest interactions in the universe. Scientists measure the atomic spin of molecules and manipulate atoms to make these experimental computers, which one day may perform exceptionally complex calculations.

headline: 2 Companies Adopt New Identities
abstract: Advertisers are making changes in their brand identities; US Tobacco Co is being renamed US Smokeless Tobacco Co to clarify its role as maker of chewing tobacco rather than cigarettes; GlaxoSmithKline is introducing corporate image campaign to herald its formation in merger of Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham (S)

headline: J. BAKER MOVES TO CHANGE NAME TO CASUAL MALE

headline: After Earnhardt's Death, A Rebound for Nascar
abstract: Dale Earnhardt's death during Dayton 500 appears to have increased awareness of Nascar racing and been a boon for racing business, contrary to what some expected; photo (M)

headline: AOL USERS ARE WARNED ON VIRUS
abstract: Antivirus company McAfee.com says rogue computer program that affects users of America Online has been making its way around World Wide Web; program, known as Trojan horse, arrives in form of file that is attached to e-mail message with subject line, 'hey you'; message suggests that attachment, 'mine-zip,' is collection of pictures; when user click on icon for file, program infects machine; next time user turns machine on and connects to AOL, program sends user's online name and password to number of foreign e-mail addresses, and it sends copies of itself to every person on victim's 'buddy list' (S)

headline: ELECTRONICS GROUP LISTS PRIORITIES

headline: For Likud Party, Sharon Is the 'King of Israel'
abstract: Thunderous roar erupts at Likud Party rally at Tel Aviv fairgrounds as news is flashed of Ariel Sharon's stunning victory in Israeli election; supporters hope Sharon will be able to bring peace with Palestinians, as well as internal unity to divided country (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

headline: PERRY ELLIS BUYING BUGLE BOY NAME AND SOME OPERATIONS
abstract: Perry Ellis International Inc acquires Bugle Boy Industries (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Democratic Senators Back An Immediate Tax Cut Plan  Senator Tom Daschle, above left, of South Dakota, the Democratic leader, and Senator Kent Conrad, of North Dakota, the top Democrat on the Budget Committee, announced strong support of an immediate $60 billion tax cut, proposed on Thursday by Republican senators. But Mr. Daschle and Mr. Conrad said they could not go along with the intention of Republicans to tie the tax cut to Congressional approval of the across-the-board tax rate reductions proposed by President Bush. [Page A1.]    Ban on Modified Crops Is Considered  North Dakota is weighing a bill that would make it the first state to ban planting of a genetically modified crop, reflecting a surge of concern about such crops in state legislatures. The North Dakota bill, which would impose a two-year moratorium on growing genetically modified wheat, is one of more than 40 state bills introduced this year. [A1.]

headline: Group Says It Beat Music Security but Can't Reveal How
abstract: Prof Edward W Felten led group that successfully disabled a digital music copyright protection system developed by entertainment and technology companies, but he cannot reveal his methods; to do so would likely violate the law (M)

headline: British Company Reports Option to Costly Genzyme Drug
abstract: Oxford GlycoSciences says patients taking its experimental drug Vevesca for Gaucher disease were able to remain off Genzyme Corp's drug Cerezyme, only approved treatment, for six-month duration of clinical trial; drug could reach market in 2002; Cerezyme costs each patient about $200,000 annually; analysts think Oxford will charge $60,000 to $80,000 a year (M)

headline: China Pursues Executions As Way to Cut Tax Swindles
abstract: China sentences seven people to death for tax fraud, Guangdong, and executes two others for embezzlement, Guizhou Province; is in midst of wave of executions intended to curb corruption and economic crimes government blames for weakening economy and fears could threaten Communist Party's legitimacy (M)

headline: Trader With North Koreans Accuses Ex-State Dept. Aide

headline: Chasing Mexico's Dream Takes a Toll

But even with his gray stubble and grease-stained fingers, he is welcomed like a king into the shantytowns at the edge of this teeming city on the border with the United States.

headline: COMMERZBANK POSTS LOSS

headline: White House Is Not Ruling Out Airline Strikes

headline: MYCFO BUCKS TREND WITH NEW FINANCING

headline: PrivateSector; Another Bill as President? A Survey Picks Gates
abstract: Survey of 1,000 persons by Brouillard Communications reveals that Americans would choose Microsoft to run country if government were turned over to private sector; photo (S)

headline: Share Structure Gives Foreigners Better Deal : China Market Boom Is Raising Questions
abstract: HONG KONG—  The development of China's stock markets has been dramatic, but these emerging markets badly need a more rational structure, and more equal valuations. Chinese stocks have outperformed most others in the past year, but that has only exacerbated a situation in which Chinese pay several times more than foreign investors for the same assets.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: F.A.A. May Bypass Bids For Air Traffic Contract  The Federal Aviation Administration is preparing to skip competitive bidding and choose Lockheed Martin to design and build a replacement for the heart of its antiquated long-distance air traffic control system.    One reason, officials say, is that the company has become familiar with the system over the last few years in performing other work, including replacing old computers in the centers just before the end of 1999. [Page A1.]

headline: Utility Deregulation: Square Peg, Round Hole?
abstract: Joseph Kahn Economic View column on debate over whether California's power woes are due to the way state went about deregulation or to deregulation itself; Alfred E Kahn, Cornell University economist who helped create free markets in rail, trucking and airline industries, says he has always had doubts about eliminating vertical integration in electricity markets; photo (M)

headline: New Economy; A device to link old media to the Web struggles to make good on the promise of an Internet revolution.
abstract: Digital Convergance Corp encounters problems with its CueCat that raise questions about whether there a need for a device that links print or broadcast media and Web and, if so, what it will take to create a technology that is accepted by consumers, advertisers and media outlets; photo (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    IRAQ: AMERICAN ATTACK -- American air forces attacked an Iraqi antiaircraft battery near the southern Iraqi town of As Samawah. Pentagon officials said the action came after Iraqi forces fired on American and British jets patrolling the no-flight zone over southern Iraq during the past two days. It was the first clash in the zone since President Bush authorized a larger strike against Iraq on Feb. 16.    Steven Lee Myers (NYT)    THE AMERICAS    MEXICO: UNDERCOVER RAIDS -- The administration of President Vicente Fox said its first anticorruption raids using undercover agents had led to the arrest of 11 officials who were suspected of taking bribes in exchange for granting everything from licenses to health certificates. The officials were suspended pending further investigation after raids in five cities, including Mexico City. In some cases, the undercover agents posed as average citizens or truck drivers seeking health certificates or driver's licenses.    (AP)

headline: SULZER'S PROFIT FALLS
abstract: Swiss medical and industrial technology company Sulzer reports 19 percent fall in net income, to $128 million in 2000, mainly due to restructuring costs (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    SERBIA: BUFFER WITH KOSOVO  NATO told Serbian officials that it was prepared as part of an overall peace plan to consider changes to the buffer zone on Kosovo's eastern boundary, which ethnic Albanian separatists are using as a safe haven. But while welcoming a plan by Belgrade to stabilize the region, NATO's secretary general, Lord Robertson, above, said any ultimatum or use of force by Serbian forces to regain control of the zone would be unacceptable.    Carlotta Gall (NYT)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    SPAIN: E.T.A. SUSPECTS DETAINED -- The police arrested three people supposedly belonging to the Basque separatist group E.T.A., including a woman accused of organizing what police described as a failed attempt to plant two bombs in Madrid in 1999. The woman, Alicia Sáez de la Cuesta, had reportedly been on the run since December 1999, when the police found two vans loaded with more than 3,740 pounds of explosives.   Emma Daly (NYT)

headline: Stranded Fliers Settle Lawsuit
abstract: Northwest Airlines Corp agrees to pay $7.1 million to settle class-action lawsuit with more than 7,000 passengers stranded at Detroit airport during blizzard on New Year's weekend of 1999 (S)

headline: The Chinese Professor Who Started a Ruckus
abstract: Prof He Zuoxiu, theoretical physicist, devout Marxist and crusader against superstition and bogus science in China, says he has no regrets about article he wrote in spring of 1999 that criticized Falun Gong and set in motion Chinese government's crackdown on movement; cites attempt by seven apparent sect members to immmolate themselves in Tiananmen Square; denies existence of qi, supposed cosmic forces in body and universe that are basis of qigong exercises as well as much of traditional Chinese medical theory; does not call for blanket ban on qigong; photo (M)

headline: Europe Union Asks Restraint By Macedonia
abstract: Top European Union officials urge Macedonian government to exercise restraint against ethnic Albanian militants and to step up discussions with elected Albanian politicians about political change; in response, Macedonian government appears to pull back from vow to 'neutralize the armed terrorists' before serious political discussions; photo (M)

headline: 5 Linked to Banned Sect in China Set Themselves on Fire in Protest
abstract: Five people believed to be members of Falun Gong spiritual group douse themselves with gasoline and set themselves on fire in Beijing's Tiananmen Square; one woman dies and four other people are severely burned; Falung Gong spokesman in New York immediately distances the group from the self-immolations; Chinese government has been bracing itself for potential of intensified protests by Falun Gong, both during Chinese New Year this week and again when International Olympic Committee visits Beijing at end of February (M)

headline: EARNINGS AT NIKE PLUMMET 33% IN THE LATEST QUARTER
abstract: Nike Inc says profit fell 33 percent in fiscal third quarter, to $97.4 million; sales were little changed at $2.17 billion (S)

headline: Ozd Journal; Making a Living Recycling the Ash Heap of History
abstract: Scene in Ozd, Hungary, where factories that once served Soviet market have closed, described; European and American help for Hungary's poorer eastern region and government's more forceful regional policy are bring Ozd and towns like it more attention and beginning of real investment; map; photo (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Plans to cut taxes may be clever politics, but they're not wise fiscal policy.
abstract: Jeff Madrick 'Economic Scene' column holds plans to cut Federal taxes may be clever politics, but they are not wise fiscal policy; photo (M)

abstract: Australian central bank reduces overnight cash rate to 5.75 percent from 6.25 percent (S)

headline: Web Sites Begin to Self Organize
abstract: SUZANNE CROSS, a 49-year-old paralegal in New Orleans with a passion for history, is a prolific writer for a Web site called The VinesNetwork, which bills itself as "the Encyclopedia of Everything, Built by Everyone." Articles on the site, covering dozens of different topics, are all written by members.

headline: French Parties Press for Women in Politics
abstract: Law passed in France last year appears to go further than any other in world in attempting to share representation more evenly between men and women; law obliges all political parties to field equal number of male and female candidates in almost all elections, starting with municipal elections scheduled in Mar; right now 7 percent of France's mayors and almost 9 percent of its national legislators are women; photos; chart (M)

headline: Europe and Bush: Early Storm Clouds to Watch
abstract: News analysis; European Union is signaling new boldness amid growing allied concern over direction of Bush administration's foreign policy that Europeans seem determined to resist; is determined to develop its nascent common foreign and strategic policy, even when policy differs from that of US (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: THE DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose as investors turned to Treasury securities as a haven from the global economic slowdown. In New York, the euro settled at 88.75 cents, down from 89.58 cents on Wednesday.

headline: WEB SERVER SHIPMENTS REMAIN STRONG
abstract: Dataquest says worldwide shipments of computer servers rose to 1.1 million in fourth quarter, 21 percent increase over same period last year; says 3.9 million servers were shipped worldwide in all of 2000 (S)

headline: In China, Computer Use Erodes Traditional Handwriting, Stirring a Cultural Debate
abstract: YANGSHUO, China -- WHEN Li You picks up a pen, he finds that with increasing frequency he can't remember how to write the Chinese characters he learned to write as a child. The delicate strokes scramble themselves in the hazy recesses of his memory, eluding his brain's insistent summons to order.

headline: SOME MIGHT CALL IT HEAVEN
abstract: Microsoft and La-Z-Boy Inc are teaming up to sell first 'e-cliner,' Web-television-enabled reclining armchair; La-Z-Boy's Explorer model comes with keyboard and Sony receiver for Microsoft's WebTV, and buyers will get two free months of interactive television service; WebTV chair sells for $1,049 to $1,299, compared with $299 to $1,800 for unwired models; photo (S)

headline: New Palms Will Use Bluetooth To Cast a Much Wider Net
abstract: Palm unveils new device allowing its hand-held computers to send information wirelessly to other devices within 30-foot radius (S)

headline: CABLE AND WIRELESS CUTS JOBS

headline: SLOWDOWN AT UNITED MICROELECTRONICS
abstract: United Microelectronics of Taiwan expects profit to decline in 2001 amid slowdown in semiconductor industry (S)

headline: Putting A New Soul In Your PC
abstract: J D Biersdorfer State of the Art column recounts his experiences while testing Linux, only competitor to Microsoft's Windows and Apple's OS in field of computer operating systems; created ten years ago by Linus Torvalds, Linux' popularity is growing; it is being installed by some yanufacturers in new personal computers, despite challenges it poses to users unfamiliar with its language and processes; author suggests that adventurous individuals install Linux in old computers and explore its possibilities (M)

headline: Two Agencies Fill Top Creative Posts
abstract: FCB Worldwide names Geoff Thompson, creative director, to additional post of chairman and chief executive at San Francisco office; Thompson New York names Michael J Campbell to vacant post of executive vice president and executive creative director (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Nokia Sales Report Rattles Communications Shares  Shares of telecommunication equipment makers plummeted after Nokia released figures that pointed to a slowdown in global demand for mobile handsets, raising the possibility that the ultimate size of the market could be smaller than analysts had originally predicted.    Nokia estimated that 405 million handsets were sold worldwide last year, a 45 percent increase from the previous year but short of analysts' expectations for sales of 420 million. The American depository receipts of Nokia fell $3.81, to $39.31. The A.D.R.'s of Ericsson, another mobile-phone maker, declined 56 cents, to $10.81, while shares of Motorola dropped $1.06, to $20.69. [World Business, Section W.]

headline: Trash Hauler Posts a Profit but Misses Forecasts
abstract: Waste Management Inc says net income was $39 million in fourth quarter, compared with loss of $115 million year earlier; revenue fell 14 percent, to $2.88 billion (S)

headline: Ecuador Is Fearful As Colombia's War Spills Over Border
abstract: Colombian conflict between right-wing paramilitary fighters and leftist guerrillas spills over into Ecuador in dingy Amazon border town of Lago Agrio; refugees fleeing intensifying combat in southern Colombia are also showing up, and affluent Colombians with no ties to area are suddenly buying up land and stocking up on chemicals used to process cocaine; Eucador, of all of Colombia's neighbors, is perhaps most vulnerable, least prepared and worst equipped to deal with such developments; rising violence in Lago Agrio, service center for oil industry, discussed; map; photo (M)

headline: SARA LEE IS SELLING ITS CHAMPION EUROPE BUSINESS
abstract: Sara Lee Corp will sell its Champion Europe business, which markets athletic apparel and footwear, to group of unit's managers; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: Columbia Bancorp names Roger Christensen president and chief executive (S)

headline: Article 2001020290400566932 -- No Title
abstract: February 2, 2001

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION, -- Houston, an oil and natural gas company, agreed to buy Bargo Energy for about $60 million in cash and $80 million in stock. The acquisition would more than double Bellwether's energy reserves.

headline: One Man and a Global Web of Violence
abstract: First of three articles on Osama bin Laden and the creation of Al Qaeda, Muslim terrorist group he founded 13 years ago; group's initial target was Soviet forces occupying Afghanistan, but today its enemy is United States, which it regards as an imperial power propping up corrupt and godless governments; chronology; photos (L)

headline: Media Talk; Mrs. Clinton Seeks Ghostwriter for Memoirs
abstract: Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has sold rights to publish her memoirs for $8 million, seeks ghostwriter; some of her previous collaborations with writers have been rocky; likely candidates noted; photo (M)

headline: Israel's 'Confused Dialectic': Peace, Sure, but Many Conflicting Definitions
abstract: Analysis of mood in Israel, where almost 70 percent of people say they support peace effort, but almost half of them think that Ariel Sharon, whom they favor, is more likely than Ehud Barak to drag country into all-out regional war; political analysts say Israelis are gravitating to Sharon because he represents iron-fist approachto Israel's neighbors; they want Sharon to calm violence by threat of force that he represents; they do not want him to explode region; photo (M)

headline: Will Congressional Web Learning Report Gather Momentum or Only Gather Dust?
abstract: Capitol Hill insiders and educational analysts are hopeful that several of the key recommendations made in a Congressional panel's report on web-based learning will be acted upon this year.

headline: Free-Speech Advocates Fight Filtering Software in Public Schools
abstract: One month after Congress passed a law pressuring public schools and libraries to install blocking or filtering software on computer terminals to screen out Internet smut, three free-speech powerhouses are gearing up to slay the measure in federal court.

headline: Economic Scene; When it comes to cloning, social science has to catch up with genetic science.
abstract: Alan B Krueger 'Economic Scene' column on economic and social ramifications of human cloning as seen by biologists and economists; cites studies by Lee M Silver of Princeton, Gilles Saint-Paul of Toulouse University and Shirley Tilghman, also of Princeton; photo (M)

headline: Mexico Rebel Chief Says the Fight Is Now for Peace
abstract: Interview with Subcommander Marcos, leader of Zapatista National Liberation Army in Chiapas, Mex, who says pursuit of equal rights for all of country's 10 million indigenous people remain primary goal but that rebels now want peace; maps; photo (M)

headline: Stocks End Mixed as Dow Settles Above 10,000
abstract: Anxious investors won a modest reprieve from the week's heavy selling as the Dow Jones industrial average nudged back over 10,000 today, modestly buoyed by sharpening hopes for an interest-rate cut next week to revive the weak economy.

headline: Israeli Military Worries Some Troops May Be Trigger-Happy
abstract: Senior Israeli army officers express concern, with rising toll of killings of Palestinians by Israeli soldiers, that discipline is eroding in certain units after months of confrontation with Palestinian protesters and gunmen; some soldiers seem to be firing more readily as Palestinian uprising shifts from mass street protests to armed attacks; in few cases army investigations found firing to be unjustified; daily deaths have provoked Palestinian accusations that Israeli Army commanders have failed to halt unrestrained fire by troops; uprising, in fourth month, has claimed 350 lives, mostly of Palestinians (M)

headline: Bayer and CuraGen in $1.5 Billion Pact to Develop Drugs
abstract: Bayer AG and CuraGen Corp will spend as much as $1.5 billion to use CuraGen's gene-hunting technology to develop drugs; will spend up to $1.34 billion over 15 years to develop drugs for adult onset diabetes and obesity and then share profits; Bayer will also invest $85 million for 7 percent stake in CuraGen and pay additional $39 million to use CuraGen's technology to help screen drug candidates for toxicity; agreements are another sign of how genomics is transforming drug development; deal is unusual in that CuraGen will not receive royalties and fees from Bayer; CuraGen will contribute about 44 percent of overall research, development and clinical trials costs, and get similar share of profits from drugs (M)

headline: Ex-Contestant On 'Survivor' Files Lawsuit
abstract: Stacey E Stillman, contestant in original version of TV program series Survivor, sues CBS and show's producer, Mark Burnett, saying they manipulated vote that eliminated her from chance to win $1 million prize; CBS calls suit frivolous and groundless (M)

headline: An Expanded 'Most Wanted'
abstract: New York Times Business Day section adds several categories to its Most Wanted chart: weekly listing of the most popular movies, recordings, television shows, software and other products of media and information technology industries; chart's Stocks segments includes new indexes for technology and media stocks; new feature, Drilling Down, will examine underlying industry trend each week

headline: Detroit's Answer to 'Hybrid' Cars; Cheaper Than Japan Models, But Far Less Fuel Efficient
abstract: General Motors and Ford, while planning to offer some 'full hybrids,' are putting stress on development of 'mild hybrids; electrically assisted gasoline engines that cost little more than conventional engines and are far less fuel efficient than full hybrids; expect to offer various levels of electrically assisted engines at least as option on most models, though in some cases development could take decade or more; environmentalists, despite preference for full hybrids, hail trend; diagram comparing hybrids; fuel economy graph; photos (M)

headline: Clinton, on Israeli Television, Sticks Up for the Underdog
abstract: JERUSALEM, Feb. 2 — In the Middle East, former President Clinton has not yet exited stage left. Four days before the Israeli election, he appeared tonight in a long interview on Israeli television and indirectly endorsed the underdog, Prime Minister Ehud Barak, by praising his courage in peacemaking.

headline: German Regional Elections Are Encouraging to Both Sides
abstract: Two German regional elections show Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's popularity remains strong but suggests opposition Christian Democrats have recovered from slush fund scandal that engulfed party year ago; exit polls show Social Democrats taking 44.3 percent of vote in western state of Rhineland-Palatinate, while Christian Democrats won 45.6 percent in southwestern state of Baden-Wurttemberg (S)

headline: Ex-Daewoo Workers Protest as Auto Production Resumes
abstract: INCHON, South Korea, March 7 — Laid-off employees of the Daewoo Motor Company pounded columns of policemen with rocks, bricks and one or two Molotov cocktails today in the streets near the plant where they once worked, while car production resumed with little hindrance inside the gates.

headline: I'll Be Right With You, Boss, as Soon as I Finish My Shopping
abstract: An adage says it is not good to take work home. But how about bringing the home to work?    According to a recent survey by Xylo, a workplace consulting company, three out of four employees take care of personal business at least once a month while at work. Almost half of that group does so at least once a day, spending an average of 1 hour and 20 minutes.

headline: MORE RESTRUCTURING BY ING GROUP
abstract: ING Group will sell its US operations of ING Barings, investment bank it bought in 1995, to ABN Amro for $275 million; ING will fold remaining ING Barings operations outside US into its European commercial banking division; 1,300 employees of ING Barings in US will transfer to ABN Amro; additional 1,000 people around world will be laid off, including 500 employees in London; reorganization of Barings unit will result in 500 million euros ($458.7 million) in annual savings (S)

headline: Nasdaq Plunges on Sour Economic Reports
abstract: Technology stocks fell sharply today, pulling the Nasdaq composite index down more than 4 percent to its lowest close since the end of 1998, after more sour economic reports failed to prompt the immediate cut in interest rates that much of Wall Street had come to expect.

headline: How Long Is the Reach of Your Former Employer?
abstract: Noncompetitive agreements that many employers require employees to sign may bar them from working in same field after they are dismissed; some high-level employees may effectively be barred from competing with former employers, generally because of their knowledge of proprietary information, but many others are not, regardless of what their agreements might say; photo (M)

headline: Palestinians Delicately Begin Debate on Circle of Violence
abstract: AL BIREH, West Bank, March 8 — Muhammad Darraj, a 40-year-old construction worker with weathered hands and dirt-caked boots, moved his family into a new apartment with a commanding view of a Jewish settlement several weeks ago. His reasons were pedestrian but loomed large in his life: he wanted to own, not rent.

headline: Eastman Chemical Announces Plan to Split Itself Into 2 Companies
abstract: Eastman Chemical Co plans will split into two companies to protect fast-growing specialty chemicals from price fluctuations for commodity plastics and fibers; will buy some of resins operations of Hercules Inc (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls on survey that shows declining consumer confidence in US economy; in New York, euro settles at 92.67 cents, up from 91.83 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: EToys to Lay Off Its Remaining Workers
abstract: EToys will lay off its 293 remaining employees and shut its doors on April 6, barring last-minute rescue in form of large investor or strategic partner; is on verge of being delisted from Nasdaq stock market (M)

headline: Technology Shares Lead Market Lower
abstract: Nasdaq composite index falls 107.03 points, or 4.4 percent, to 2,318.35; Dow Jones industrial average loses 68.94 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,730.88; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 22.59 points, or 1.7 percent, to 1,278.94; graph; chart (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises on speculation Federal Reserve will cut interest rates as soon as this week to shore up economic growth; in New York, euro settles at 91.21 cents, down from 91.78 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Creating a Generation of Slouchers
abstract: AS schools around the country push to increase students' use of computers, a small but growing number of educators and researchers say that children are risking injury because they are not being taught sound ergonomic practices along with basic computer skills.

headline: WATCHING LUMBER IMPORTS
abstract: US Commerce Department will watch how much Canadian lumber crosses border to see whether shipments surge after five-year agreement that limits imports expires this weekend; US lumber industry plans to file antidumping complaint on April 2, asserting that Canadian suppliers receive unfair government subsidies; Canadian officials say Americans do not understand how Canada's system works (S)

headline: $2 Million for a Seat
abstract: Seat on New York Stock Exchange sells for $2 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: A Top Coke Official Resigns Amid a Broad Revamping  As part of its continued efforts to revive its beverage business, Coca-Cola announced a series of sweeping management changes, including the resignation Jack L. Stahl, the president and chief operating officer.    The changes create four business units -- Americas, Asia, Europe/Africa and New Business Ventures -- with the head of each reporting directly to Coke's chairman and chief executive, Douglas Daft. The new structure will eliminate the jobs of chief operating officer and president. [Page C2.]

headline: Market Place; Cablevision, prosperous from shrinking, will welcome bids this week for Rainbow, its big programming asset.
abstract: Cablevision Systems Corp president, Charles F Dolan, bucks industry strategy by deliberately shrinking his company; will begin receiving bids tomorrow for Cablevision's 74 percent stake in Rainbow Media; Cablevision's share price has risen 249 percent, to its current $90; graph; chart (M)

headline: BARRETT RESOURCES REJECTS SHELL OFFER
abstract: Barrett Resources Corp, Denver-based natural gas producer, rejects $1.8 billion unsolicited takeover bid from Royal Dutch/Shell Group (S)

headline: British Aide Is Ousted From Office Once Again
abstract: Peter Mandelson, British Prime Min Tony Blair's closest confidant, again resigns from government in disgrace, this time after admitting he intervened in 1998 to win citizenship for Srichand Hinduja, Indian businessman who contributed $1.4 million to Millennium Dome project, which he once supervised; had earlier denied role; resigns as Northern Ireland secretary and as chief strategist of Labor Party's re-election drive; had resigned under similar circumstances in 1998; Blair tells Parliament Mandelson mislead him; Conservative leader William Hague attacks Blair for giving Mandelson second chance; British, Irish and Northern Ireland representatives say resignation should not halt peace talks; John Reid will replace him (M)

headline: Oaxaca Journal; Mexican Rebels' Hopes Meet Hard Indian Reality
abstract: oaxaca journal: mexican rebels' hopes

headline: Hershey Breaks Tradition in Naming New Chief Executive
abstract: Richard H Lenny, head of cookie business at Nabisco Corp, is named chief executive of Hershey Foods Corp; succeeds Kenneth L Woolfe, who is retiring; photo (M)

headline: Judge Deals Setback to Independent Bookstores
abstract: Judge William Orrick dismisses claim to damages in antitrust lawsuit brought by group of independent bookstores in California and American Booksellers Assn against Barnes & Noble and Borders Group (M)

headline: Starbucks and Microsoft Plan Coffeehouse Web Access
abstract: Starbucks Coffee Co and Microsoft Corp say they will join forces to offer wireless access to Internet from Starbucks coffeehouses; will work with MobileStar Network Corp; Starbucks says service will be available in about 70 percent of its 4,000 stores in one to two years (M)

headline: Article 2001033093664810424 -- No Title
abstract: Bettors Find Online Gambling Hard to Resist

headline: Rich Is Selling Trading Firm to Alfa Unit
abstract: Marc Rich & Co Investment, international commodities trading firm run by Marc Rich, billionaire pardoned by Pres Clinton, will be merged with Crown Resources, Swiss-based energy trading concern owned by Alfa Group of Russia (M)

headline: Bush Team Getting Initiation On Turkey's Ailing Economy
abstract: Turkey's profile has risen sharply with Bush administration since Turkish lira went into free fall last month; fear is that unless collapse is reversed, progressive faction there pushing for integration with West and accompanying reforms will face far harder task; Clinton administration helped Turkey through period of weak governments, and Bush administration has offered support since economy started sagging last month; financial analysts say Turkey needs Bush administration to pressure International Monetary Fund to provide billions more in loans to Turkey (M)

headline: Czech Television Leader Quits; Parliamentary Debate Goes On
abstract: Jiri Hodac resigns as director of Czech Television after weeks of protest about his appointment; despite his departure, crisis at Czech Television, and political struggles that feed it, are far from over; tens of thousands of people converge on Wenceslas Square, determined that more heads should roll and law be changed to ensure independence of state television (M)

headline: China Struggles to Ride Herd on Ever More Errant Media
abstract: China is struggling to control its shadow media, growing number of smaller newspapers and semi-independent reporters that operates mostly outside official state media and is becoming far more vexing foe than foreign press; new media has ability to respond far more quickly to lure of good story than to pressure from country's propaganda department, and has grown exponentially along with China's Internet; is viewed with ambivalence by officials in Beijing, who praise it for uncovering local corruption that would otherwise go unpunished, while finding its unruly existence deeply troubling; imprisonment of career journalist Gao Qinrong for exposing fraudulent multimillion-dollar irrigation scheme discussed; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Shaking the Venture Capital Tree
abstract: SITTING in her office in Midtown Manhattan, Kay Koplovitz took a break from talking about venture capital and women in the workplace and described her recent vacation in Patagonia. The highlight of the trip, Ms. Koplovitz said, was having herself hooked up to a spidery arrangement of straps and pulleys and cables and then dangling for a few suspended moments between the walls of a gorge that rose high above the rapids of the Futeleufu River.    ''I enjoy high-risk adventure,'' Ms. Koplovitz said. It was a statement that could be applied to many aspects of her life.

headline: Talks Are Under Way For SF Interactive
abstract: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos is in negotiations to acquire SF Interactive (S)

headline: Privacy's Guarded Prognosis
abstract: Patient records are increasingly being stored on computer networks, heightening concern over confidentiality; medical records, such as laboratory test results and prescription histories, are available to various interested commercial parties, and some high-profile security lapses have emerged; medical information could also be used to deny insurance coverage and even employment; another concern is identity theft because Social Security numbers and birth dates are commonly used to identify patients; federal government moves to curb these invasions of individuals' privacy; photos; drawing (M)

headline: Grab the W-2, a 1040 and Aspirin, Then the Software
abstract: Steven E Brier assesses tax return preparation computer software; photo (M)

headline: Investing Diary: Suit Challenges Buyout That Won Fed Approval
abstract: Has the Federal Reserve, which administers consumer protection rules in addition to conducting the nation's monetary policy, approved a plan that victimizes minority shareholders in a buyout? At least one lawsuit contends just that.

headline: CYPRESS COMMUNICATIONS WILL TRIM ITS WORK FORCE
abstract: Cypress Communications Inc, seller of telephone services and Internet access, will lay off 200 workers, or half of its work force, as part of its plan to become profitable in second half of 2003 (S)

headline: Putin Invites West to Work On a Defense For Missiles
abstract: Russian Pres Putin calls on Europe and NATO alliance to work with Russia on developing common defense against missile attacks; presents proposals to NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson, who is visiting Moscow (M)

headline: A New Face (And Heart) For the Mac
abstract: David Pogue column appraises Mac OS X operating system that Apple Computer has introduced for Macintosh computers; photo; drawing (M)

headline: Stanford Researcher Convicted And Sentenced Again in China
abstract: Chinese-born researcher at Stanford University who was arrested in Beijing three years ago on charges of revealing state secrets is convicted for second time and given 10-year sentence; researcher, Hua Di, is nuclear weapons expert who fled China in 1989 after criticizing Tiananmen Square crackdown; he returned to China in 1998 after receiving assurances of his safety from Chinese security officials, but he was detained within days (M)

headline: Ralph B. Ryder, 90, a Founder Of the Truck Leasing Company
abstract: Ralph Bennett Ryder, one of three siblings who created what would become worldwide billion-dollar powerhouse Ryder System, died Dec 28 at age of 90 (M)

headline: BUSH TELLS BLAIR HE DOESN'T OPPOSE NEW EUROPE FORCE
abstract: Pres Bush tells Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain that United States has no objections to separate rapid-reaction military force to help keep peace in Europe as long as it is clearly secondary to NATO; announcement, coming during Blair's visit to Camp David, is notable because both Secretary of State Colin L Powell and Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld have indicated reservations about European force, which would make use of NATO equipment and could be dispatched on missions that United States does not endorse, or choses not to join; Blair describes purpose of rapid-reaction force quite narrowly; says it would be limited to peacekeeping and humanitarin tasks and is not a standing army; says it would strengthen NATO by offering alternative when NATO does not want to be involved; photo (M)

headline: Political Wrangling Over Nuclear Plant Intensifies in Taiwan
abstract: HONG KONG, Jan. 31 — Taiwan's political stalemate hardened today, as the country's legislature voted to reverse a decision by President Chen Shui-bian to scrap a partially-built nuclear power plant.

headline: The World Stage, Act I
abstract: News analysis of decision by Pres Bush approving air strikes against Iraq beyond 'no fly' zone; action, less than month into his Presidency, suggests that he is sending message not only for Iraq but for rest of world that he is approaching role of world leader without timidity (M)

headline: Tokyo Journal; The Japanese, It Seems, Are Outgrowing Japan
abstract: Average height of Japanese 11-year-olds has increased by more than 5 1/2 inches in 50 years; increased growth is widely believed to be caused by improvements in diet and elimination of once-commmon infectious diseases; ultimate implication of statistics is that Japanese people are much taller than they once were; photo (M)

headline: TERRA NETWORKS EXECUTIVE QUITS
abstract: Abel Linares resigns as chief operating officer of Terra Networks; photo (S)

headline: Article 2001031991865181117 -- No Title
abstract: EDUCATION

headline: Role of Stock Market In Economy Reflected In Dabate on Rate Cut
abstract: The Federal Reserve is preparing to decide tomorrow how much to lower interest rates in an effort to revive the economy, and that has many on Wall Street lobbying for a cut of three-quarters of a percentage point, or even more, to stop the sell-off in stocks. But other experts argue that a half-point cut is enough for an economy that, apart from the market, still has considerable strengths.    The debate over how far the Fed should go to reduce its benchmark interest rate -- thus influencing what lenders charge for mortgages, home equity loans and other credit -- reflects sharply different views of the stock market's effect on the economy. Many are urging the Fed to recognize that the economy now dances to the stock market, not the other way around. Others view the stock market's movements as a less important influence on the economy than factors like the level of unemployment, the value of homes and the pace of wage gains.

headline: DAEWOO TRIAL STARTS
abstract: Four of 34 Daewoo group executives and accountants on trial for fraud and other charges admit they altered South Korean company's books (S)

headline: Private Sector; Ali and Frazier They Aren't
abstract: Nobody ever said insurance was exciting. But it is unusual to see two big-time players jibing each other, especially when they are gentlemen like Warren E. Buffett of Berkshire Hathaway and Edward Rust, the chief executive of State Farm. Mr. Buffett, in his annual report, complained that Mr. Rust's company had hurt Geico, Berkshire's auto insurance company, by absorbing losses instead of raising prices, as most other insurers did, as expenses increased. Courtly as ever, Mr. Buffett said that State Farm was a great company, but that ''Geico has the much better business model.''     Mr. Rust begged to differ. State Farm more than doubled sales last year, he said, because of superior service.

headline: Jaguar Announces New Global Agency
abstract: Jaguar Cars, part of Ford Motor Co, formally announces selection of Young & Rubicam Advertising to handle its worldwide creative advertising account; billings estimated at $125 million; account had been handled by Global Communications Corp (S)

headline: DIRECTOR ENDS CONFLICT
abstract: Thomas Middelhoff, president and chief executive of Bertelsmann, will resign as supervisory board member of Vivendi Universal; two media companies are competitors in growing number of areas, but are also believed to be negotiating closer ties and joint ventures; photo (S)

headline: Did She Say Primate or Prime Rate?
abstract: Jane Goodall will ring opening bell at New York Stock Exchange while in New York to raise funds for her research into primates; photo (S)

headline: Nasdaq Stages Late-Day Recovery
abstract: Technology stocks rallied late today, leading a recovery across the market.

headline: In Proud Defense of the S.U.V.
abstract: BROOKFIELD, Wis. -- William D. Brouse, the president of the Sport Utility Vehicle Owners Association of America, sits in a cramped office here amid the beautiful, cherry-wood furniture from his 31-year career as the top lobbyist for Wisconsin's savings and loan associations. In his new job, Mr. Brouse sometimes fields phone calls at least as difficult as those he received during the worst of the savings-and-loan crisis of the 1980's.

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: Ricoh Tries to Put Multiple Brands Under One Roof
abstract: Ricoh, best-selling copier brand in Japan, is intent on making name for itself in United States; it has been slowly buying other copier companies whose products it makes; company's various brands command 14 percent of total copier market in United States, and nearly 20 percent for digital machines; Ricoh is now revamping its sales and back-office operations, adding dealerships, fleshing out its product line and mounting its most expensive advertising campaign ever, using tag line 'Dependable Digital'; photos (M)

headline: These Retirees Are Not In Kansas Anymore
abstract: Well over 100,000 Americans 50 and over have chosen to retire in Mexico, leading the good life in places like San Miguel de Allende in state of Guanajuato and Ajijic in state of Guadalajara; map; photos (M)

headline: Shepard Kurnit; Advertising Executive, 76
abstract: Shepard Kurnit, advertising executive, dies at age 76 (S)

headline: Beijing in Battle With Sect: 'A Giant Fighting a Ghost'
abstract: China's battle with Falun Gong, banned spiritual movement, discussed; Chinese government's 18-month campaign has failed to eliminate group, or even reliably identify its millions of quietly devoted followers who make it so resilient; brazen expressions of dissent are mounting; silent majority in Falun Gong do not demonstrate; yet they form an enormous reservoir of believers who may someday be driven to act; they provide one another with emotional and sometimes financial support--as they do those members who have been jailed or lost jobs; photo (L)

headline: French Insurer Seeks German Bank Partner
abstract: French insurer AXA is in talks with Deutsche Bank, Germany's largest bank, on far-reaching alliance under which bank would sell AXA's insurance and mutual fund offerings at its branches throughout Europe (M)

headline: DataBank; Could the Market Slide Be Ending?
abstract: Investors and Wall Street analysts turn optimistic; week's results: Dow Jones Industrial Average closes up 1.7 percent, or 178.31, at 10,644.62; Standard & Poor's 500-stock average loses just 0.76 points, or 0.1 percent, to finish at 1,233.42; Nasdaq composite average ends at 2,052.78, loss of 64.85, or 3.1 percent; job report reverses modest rally in bond market; yield on 10-year Treasury bond closes unchanged from week before, at 4.94 percent; graphs; list of rates and yields (M)

headline: Iraq Rebuilt Weapon Factories, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: Iraq Rebuilt Weapon Factories, US Officials Say** Senior US officials say Iraq has rebuilt series of factories suspected of producing chemical and biological weapons; factories in industrial complex west of Baghdad include two that were bombed and badly damaged by US and British air raids in 1998 to punish Pres Saddam Hussein for refusal to cooperate with UN weapons inspectors; new intelligence indicates that Iraq has rebuilt at least its weapons infrastructure and may have begun covert production of some chemical or biological agents; could confront Pres George W Bush with early test of pledge to take tougher stance against Hussein than Clinton administration; photo (M)

headline: New Front in Calvin Klein vs. Warnaco Fight
abstract: Calvin Klein's company sends letter to terminate Klein jeanswear license held by Warnaco Group, saying Warnaco's debt level now violates terms of their contract; anticipating dispute, company also files complaint in New York State Supreme Court asking for declaratory relief; Warner denies that its debt level violates terms of contract and vows to fight to retain license (M)

headline: Gateway and Hewlett-Packard Hit Hard by Sales Slowdown
abstract: Investors in computer companies took a double blow to their already diminished hopes for 2001 late today. Gateway announced both disappointing fourth-quarter earnings and layoffs, and Hewlett-Packard warned that it would fall short of Wall Street's projections for its current quarter.

headline: PUBLISHER'S PROFITS GROW
abstract: Bloomsbury Publishing reports net income more than doubled in 2000 to $5.35 million; photo (S)

headline: WEIGHING THE OPTIONS/FINANCE; As Savings Go Up, Worries Go Down (A Little)
abstract: New York Times poll finds that the number of Americans saving for retirement has jumped sharply since 1995; majority of respondents still worry abut setting aside enough money, but their anxiety on subject appears to have eased; experts credit baby boom generation's approach to retirement, its entrance into peak earning years, shift from pensions to 401(k)-style plans and strong performance of both economy and stock market until recently; question how much of money described by respondents is actually new savings and how much represents either a shift of money an employers used to put into an old-fashioned pension, or growth of an individual's existing investment; graph (M)

headline: THE BOSS; I Have the I.Q. for Retail
abstract: Petco chief executive Brian K Devine writes The Boss column on running pet supplies company; photo (M)

headline: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS EXPECTS EARNINGS TO SHOW DECLINE
abstract: ICN Pharmaceuticals says that its 2000 earnings will come in below forecasts (S)

headline: Edwin Dodd, 81, Industrialist And Adviser to 4 Presidents
abstract: Edwin D Dodd, chairman emeritus of Owens-Illinois Inc, as well as adviser to four presidents, dies at age of 81; photo (M)

headline: GREENSPAN UPBEAT ON THE ECONOMY
abstract: Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan, while warning that economy still faces substantial risks, says United States is not in recession and that current slowdown may prove to be as short as it is sharp, Senate committee; his analysis suggests further interest rate cuts are likely, if perhaps not so certain and large as investors assumed; stock prices fall as investors apparently conclude stock prices will get less support than hoped from declining interest rates; his cautiously upbeat tone contrasts with Pres Bush's continuing concerns about economy; photo (M)

headline: Faster Modem Makes Gamers Quicker on the Trigger
abstract: Sega introduces DreamcastBroadband Adapter that replaces modem on its video game console and allows players to take advantage of increasingly popular cable and DSL modems (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of March 11 article on Yahoo, which had incorrect picture caption and misstated percentage of advertising space on its Web pages that represents unpaid ads for Yahoo itself

headline: Southern Energy has a new name, a new logo and a plan to let everyone know about the changes.
abstract: Southern Energy, one of nation's largest power companies, changes its name to Mirant Corp as part of planned spinoff from parent Southern Co; will begin drive to advertise change (M)

headline: Digital Book Turf Battle Escalates Over Royalties
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com is expanding its role as digital publisher, setting new royalty rate intended to attract authors and publishing original book by best-selling writer Dean Koontz; move steps up battle between publishers and booksellers over ground rules of electronic book business; while publishers are seeking to sell electronic books directly to readers, Barnesandnoble.com is trying to cut out publisher by acquiring rights directly from authors and releasing their electronic books; Barnesandnoble.com will pay authors and agents royalty rate of 35 percent of book's list price on electronic books sold through its Web site (M)

abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Xerox Debt Is Worrisome To Traders
abstract: Xerox Corp's stock has recently been popular with investors, but traders of its bank debt are lot more skeptical about company's prospects; Xerox has $7 billion bank loan that comes due in October 2002, which trades at close to 70 cents on dollar; price is still worrisome, considering that among loan traders when debt trades below 80 cents on dollar it is often sign that company will have trouble paying its debts; origins of company's financial problems discussed (M)

headline: AMAZON TO OFFER DOWNLOADS
abstract: Amazon.com begins offering software downloading service that allows customers to buy some software online and then to start using products almost immediately; new service is called Software Downloads Store (S)

headline: Chrysler Cuts 1st-Quarter Production 26%
abstract: Chrysler division of DaimlerChrysler AG will build 26 percent fewer cars and light trucks in first quarter of 2001 than year earlier because of slowdown in sales (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: President Bush Intervenes To Stop Northwest Strike  President Bush issued an executive order preventing a potential strike next week by mechanics at Northwest Airlines and said that he would take ''the necessary steps'' to block walkouts at other major carriers this year.    By intervening in the Northwest dispute, which he pledged to do last month, Mr. Bush becomes only the second president to order workers at a major airline to stay on the job since 1966. [Page A1.]    A federal bankruptcy judge criticized a bid by Carl C. Icahn for the assets of Trans World Airlines, and suggested a proposal by American Airlines was the only valid offer. [C3.]    Utility Merger Talks End Abruptly  Merger talks broke down between the Public Service Enterprise Group, which operates New Jersey's largest energy concern, and Cinergy, a Midwest energy utility, executives close to the negotiations said. While the talks could still be revived, they said it was unlikely. Shares of PSEG fell 84 cents, to $41.61, while Cinergy dropped 67 cents, to $34.48. [C14.]    Copyrighted Song List to Napster  In compliance with a court order intended to curb the exchange of copyrighted music on Napster, the major record labels said they planned to deliver a list of 135,000 songs -- music that Napster will have three business days to prevent users from trading. The delivery starts the clock ticking on a process that could gut the amount and types of music Napster users have been able to exchange online. [C14.]    Possible Changes to Tax-Cut Plan  As the tax fight shifts to the Senate, Republicans who have consulted with the White House said the administration had identified two areas of possible compromise in the overall $1.6 trillion tax-cut plan: reducing the amount by which the top income tax rate would drop, and scaling back rather than repealing the estate tax. Those changes could whittle down the dollar figure by several hundred billion dollars. The savings could be used to make the plan smaller, or to add provisions that might attract support from moderates. [A1.]    Ernst & Young Loses Court Ruling  Ernst & Young, the accounting firm whose auditors the government contends failed to uncover a fraud at Cendant, lost an early court battle. A federal judge granted a motion filed by prosecutors to bar depositions by more than 40 potential witnesses in the trial of Walter A. Forbes, above, and E. Kirk Shelton, formerly the chairman and vice chairman of Cendant, who are charged with financial fraud. Ernst & Young asked the judge to either allow depositions by those witnesses or to delay all depositions. The judge refused. [C3.]    The Africa Problem for Drug Makers  This week, the unthinkable happened in Africa: the world's biggest pharmaceutical companies were forced into a painful negotiation over patent rights and the price of AIDS medicines. Suddenly, the question is no longer whether Africans will get life-saving drug cocktails, but how. That question lacks a simple answer; merely cutting prices will not automatically get drugs to patients. [A1.]    BP Faces Hard Choices in Alaska  Over the last few years, BP Amoco broke with most of the oil industry and positioned itself as a leader on environmental issues. Now, a group of American and British investors, hopes to introduce a shareholder resolution at the company's annual meeting on April 19 that asks BP to reconsider drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. They are likely to run into resistance. [C3.]    Contractor Is Ordered to Liquidate  A court ordered the liquidation of Dong Ah Construction, a major international contractor and South Korea's second largest behind Hyundai Engineering and Construction. The court rejected a proposal by the company that it be put into receivership instead. [C2.]

headline: The Young And the Fundless, Ignored by Marketers
abstract: Article by Ken Kurson, co-founder of Green, personal finance magazine for young adults, on reluctance of mutual funds companies to market funds to that audience; holds fund companies, while talking about young people, are actually more interested in reaching larger investors nearer to retirement; drawing (M)

abstract: March 30, 2001

headline: WEST IS ALARMED AS WARFARE GROWS IN BALKANS AGAIN
abstract: Fierce fighting erupts in former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia, which had escaped ethnic carnage of neighboring Kosovo; government forces fire for third day at Albanian insurgents in hills surrounding Tetovo who are seeking to claim part of Macedonia that is overwhelmingly Albanian; population is quickly quickly dividing between Slavs and Albanians; German contingent in NATO peacekeeping force comes under attack, perhaps inadvertently, at base guarded by Macedonians; outbreak alarms West, but allies show no sign of intervening; NATO Sec Gen Lord Robertson says alliance will not allow 'small number of extremists' to destabilize Macedonia, but that it has no military mandate to intervene and does not believe government wants it to; State Department and UN express concern; maps; photo (M)

headline: Chief of Bridgestone Says He Will Resign
abstract: Yoichiro Kaizaki will resign as president and chief executive of Bridgestone Corp, a move widely viewed as way to assume responsibility for problems in US and to renew company's image, which has been tarnished by recall of 6.5 million tires and assertion that its tires led to 148 deaths; Kaizaki denies he is taking blame for episode; senior vice president Shigeo Watanabe will succceed Kaizaki as president; photo (M)

headline: AMR Vows to Apply Pay Scale to T.W.A.
abstract: AMR Corp's American Airlines, bowing to pressure, says that all TWA workers will be compensated under American contracts as of Jan 1, 2002, even if carriers have not fully integrated by that time (M)

headline: Suit Over Goldberg Estate
abstract: Stefania Santacroce, former companion of Arthur M Goldberg, late chief executive of Park Place Entertainment, sues estate seeking to recover property (M)

headline: Tamil Rebels Extend Cease-fire Offer for Another Month
abstract: NEW DELHI, Jan. 23 — Ethnic Tamil rebels who have been fighting for a separate homeland in Sri Lanka since 1983 extended their one-sided cease-fire for another month today. They also called on other nations to try to persuade Sri Lanka to halt its military offensive and restart peace talks that broke off more than 5 years ago.

headline: Lawsuit Says I.B.M. Aided The Nazis In Technology
abstract: Lawsuit filed on behalf of survivors of Nazi concentration camps accuses IBM of providing Third Reich with data-processing technology that it knew would be used to facilitate persecution and genocide (M)

headline: Welcome to the Web. Passport, Please?
abstract: French court ruling in fall of 2000 to restrict Nazi memorabilia offered for sale on Yahoo may be harbinger of World Wide Web where some information is not accessible globally; software may make it possible to deny access to some sites based on viewer's location; current French law prohibits any displays of Nazi insignia; photos (M)

headline: Real Estate Charges to Lower 2000 Deutsche Telekom Profit
abstract: Deutsche Telekom says it will take special charge for cost of writing off real estate assets, which will reduce its profit for all of 2000 by one-fifth; prepares to sell some of its real estate; confirms it will sell its 10 percent stake in Sprint, worth around $2 billion; France Telecom confirms that it will also sell its stake (M)

headline: AMR Unions Oppose Merger With TWA
abstract: Three largest unions at AMR Corp's American Airlines oppose planned $4.2 billion purchase of Trans World Airlines, citing potential conflicts as work forces merge, letter to chief executive Donald J Carty and American directors (S)

headline: CANADIAN RAILWAY TO BUY WISCONSIN CENTRAL
abstract: Canadian National Railway Co agrees to buy Wisconsin Central Transportation Corp for $800 million; purchase will connect Wisconsin Central's 2,850 miles of track in Midwest with Canadian National's 15,000 miles, which run across Canada and south to New Orleans (S)

headline: PSION CANCELS SMARTPHONE PLAN
abstract: Psion PLC cancels plans to build smartphone combination of personal organizer and wireless telephone and says it will cut 100 jobs in $16 million reorganization to offset losses and probable fall in computer sales this year; graph (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    INDIA: KASHMIR WARNING -- Home Minister L. K. Advani warned militant groups in Kashmir that continued terrorist acts would jeopardize the government's cease-fire in the disputed Himalayan region. This admonition comes after a failed assassination attempt against Kashmir's chief minister, Farooq Abdullah. The cease-fire, due to expire on Jan. 26, may be renewed if guerrilla groups diminish their attacks.   Barry Bearak (NYT)    EUROPE

headline: New N.A.S.D. Internet Rules
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers says online brokerage firms may have to get to know their customers better before offering them ideas on what stocks to buy or sell; publishes guidelines for deciding when firms must decide whether purchase is suitable for particular customer; before making recommendations, brokerage firms must assess suitability based on several factors, including customer's age, net worth and appetite for risk; most online firms say they do not recommend stocks or other securities and therefore have no obligation to determine suitability (S)

headline: Business Travel; With new investors, Legend Airlines might defy conventional wisdom and thrive after all.
abstract: Legend Airlines, which shut down in December, only eight months after beginning operations, finds new investors, calls back more than half of its 400 employees and plans to resume service from Dallas to LaGuardia Airport in New York and Dulles International Airport near Washington (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: LEARNING TREE WARNS ON PROFITS
abstract: Shares of Learning Tree International Inc fall as much as 40 percent after company, which provides computer-skills training, says it will miss second-quarter profit and revenue estimates because enrollment growth has slowed; graph (S)

headline: YORK HOLDERS WOOED AFTER COMPANY REBUFFS MERGER
abstract: Shareholders of York Group, maker of coffins and bronze memorial plaques, receive unsolicited offer from Wilbert to buy their shares for about $50 million to bolster Wilbert's funeral business; Wilbert owns about 14 percent of York's shares outstanding; Wilbert says it wants to buy shares directly from holders because York is unwilling to discuss merger (S)

abstract: Outlook for investing in Ciena, which updates and overhauls telecommunications networks to support Internet, discussed; Ciena stock has fallen along with other technology stocks despite company's soaring profits and sales; graphs of stock price and sales (M)

headline: Founder of Janus Selling Half of His Stake
abstract: The founder of Janus Capital , the nation's fifth-largest mutual fund company, said yesterday that he was selling half of his stake back to the Janus parent company, Stilwell Financial .

headline: PITTSTON POSTS $220 MILLION LOSS AND CUTS 350 JOBS
abstract: Pittston Co cuts about 350 jobs from its BAX freight business; says job cuts are part of revamping to reduce capacity and costs at its air transportation business; reports loss of $220.4 million in fourth quarter compared with loss of $17.9 million year earlier (S)

headline: IHT to Start Publishing With Asahi
abstract: The International Herald Tribune and the Asahi Shimbun have formed a publishing partnership in Japan, it was announced Thursday by Shinichi Hakoshima, president and chief executive officer of the Asahi Shimbun, and Peter C. Goldmark Jr., the IHT's chairman and CEO.

headline: Instant Messenger Icons With a Personal Touch
abstract: Q. How can I use a picture of my own choosing (instead of one of the standard options) as a Buddy icon in America Online's Instant Messenger program?    A. The America Online Instant Messenger program comes with many colorful graphic images that you can use for your Buddy icon. When you are having an Instant Messenger session with someone on your Buddy list (the collection of Instant Messenger or AOL screen names of people you chat with using I.M.) your Buddy can see the icon you have selected at the bottom of the message window as you chat.

headline: North Korean Leader and Entourage Make Furtive Trip to Shanghai
abstract: North Korean leader Kim Jong Il, arrives, Shanghai, on furtive impromptu tour of China's economic capital; apparently catches Chinese bureaucracy by surprise (S)

headline: Outlook for Changes at Sega Pushes Shares 19% Higher
abstract: Sega intends to disclose overhaul plan calling for Sega to start supplying games for PlayStation 2, made by Sony Corp, major competitor; is considering similar relationship with Microsoft Corp, which plans to introduce X-Box game console this fall; game developers say Sega is already far along in its plans to develop software for Advanced Game Boy from Nintendo; Sega's stock price rises nearly 19 percent, closing at $10.92 (M)

headline: Critical Path Says Problems Were Limited to One Quarter
abstract: New management of Critical Path, Internet software company, says questionable accounting practices that left its reputation in tatters were largely confined to its fourth-quarter sales in US; company's stock closed at $2.66 on March 2, down from peak of $119.50 in March 2000; investors have initiated dozens of class-action lawsuits against company, accusing executives of manipulating its books to inflate stock price (M)
